Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Chinese Horoscope For the New Year



Kurt Cobain is born in the year of the Ram.

u cin look it up

I know this, because Tyler knows this.

yu may follow the suggestios for the coming yr give

regards,

*****************

Today is the Chinese New Year.  

The Year of the Ram in a Flock of Ewes.

The notion of a ram in the middle of a flock of ewes,
(male in the middle 
of many females) may appear to some to be a position
of good fortune. 
However, much as this may have some benefit, it also
means that this year 
is a year in which it is easy to be seen, and
therefore behaviour must be 
appropriate if you are not to be noticed for the wrong
reasons. It will 
certainly be a year when inappropriate behaviour will
be far more 
noticeable, and open to challenge.

The Ram is the most mild mannered of all of the
Chinese zodiac animals, and 
can be prone to a little nervousness. The ram is an
animal that avoids 
confrontation whenever possible, and a quiet life is
always preferred to 
any other kind.

The direction with which the Ram is associated is not
north, south, east or 
west, but the Chinese fifth direction, (not used in
the West) - central. 
This centrality is perhaps indicative of the Ram's
desire for peace and 
tranquillity, and the avoidance of taking sides.
Though not taking sides 
may be advantageous at times, it may also be perceived
as a lack of support 
for the position held by others, and as such may make
for criticism or 
unsettling times.

This trait may be exacerbated by the Ram's
paradoxically sharp tongue. 
Rarely used in malice, it is often a result of
thoughtlessness. It is wise, 
therefore, in this year to think carefully about what
one says, but 
equally, to try to see beyond the words people
actually use, and to 
understand the motivation behind what is said. Without
taking that extra 
care, confusion may arise, and this may lead to
conflict.

ON THE FIRST day of Lunar New Year, after 1.30am to be
exact, find a yellow
bag, walk north-west and buy something - anything - to
put in it. Once the
mission has been accomplished, head home and go to
bed, placing the
knotted bag on your pillow above your head. This will
bring good luck in the
Year of the Goat, advises Chinese astrologer Edwin Ma
Lai-wah.

With good luck assured, try not to overindulge or
splash out unnecessarily.

What your sign says:
RAT (born in 1936, 1948, 1960, 1972, 1984, 1996):
Watch out for
obstacles in your love life. A third party may creep
in if you neglect your
loved one. Although money won't be a problem, try not
to over-indulge.

OX (1937, 1949, 1961, 1973, 1985, 1997): Don't just
work all the time -
lift your head and look at the world outside. Accept
and welcome any changes,
but most importantly, have fun. Creative activities
such as karaoke, acting
and ballroom dancing would help to soothe your worried
mind.

TIGER (1938, 1950, 1962, 1974, 1986, 1998): A great
year for love:
marriageis on the cards for singles and children for
couples. When not
working, try some adventurous activities and
competitive sports to fulfill
your need to be challenged. Be careful with money.

RABBIT (1939, 1951, 1963, 1975, 1987, 1999): Expect a
tumultuous love
life- try to enjoy the lows as well as the highs.
Speak up and be frank with
your partner. To relax, stick with quieter forms of
entertainment, such as
going to the movies and reading books, to prevent any
further aggravation to
your already troubled mind.

DRAGON (1940, 1952, 1964, 1976, 1988, 2000): Try not
to think too much
and stop banging your head against a brick wall. This
is a wonderful year
for love - don't run away from it. Go to lots of
parties, meet new people
and travel. It's a year for fun, so don't just sit at
home.

SNAKE (1941, 1953, 1965, 1977, 1989, 2001): Although
patience is a
virtue, wait no longer - this year is a good one for
setting plans in action.
You will do well financially and share the fruits of
your hard work with a
loved one - so be romantic and happy together.

HORSE (1930, 1942, 1954, 1966, 1978, 1990, 2002): Even
though you may
not feel like going out, try to get away once in a
while. Go for a hike, get
some fresh air. Expect a year of obstacles and
opposition. Know thy
enemy a useful activity would be people-watching in
shopping centres and
cafes.

GOAT (1931, 1943, 1955, 1967, 1979, 1991, 2003): Your
partner will be in
the mood to go out, splash out and have fun. Join in.
Don't expect too much
to happen this year. Just go with the flow, and don't
put too much pressure
on yourself to do well.

MONKEY (1932, 1944, 1956, 1968, 1980, 1992): With the
help of a lucky
star illuminating your path, you should do well
financially. Although you may
yearn to be alone, try to be sociable. Expect
arguments in
relationships, though they should not be too damaging.

ROOSTER (1933, 1945, 1957, 1969, 1981, 1993): There
will be endless
social obligations - try to avoid unnecessary ones.
Stay clear of places of
sexual temptation, such as girlie bars and hostess
clubs. If you invest wisely
and patiently and are not over-confident, this should
be a prosperous year.

DOG (1934, 1946, 1958, 1970, 1982, 1994): This is a
good year for going
to art galleries and theatres, but stay clear of noisy
functions and
unnecessary challenges. In relationships, an old
partner may leave and a
new one could appear. Try not to swim against the tide
and accept that this
is not your year. Wear something light yellow to ward
off bad luck.

PIG (1935, 1947, 1959, 1971, 1983, 1995): Leave plenty
of room for
manoeuvre in every aspect of your life. You are bound
to overspend so try to
cut back: don't always eat out, and rent movies
instead of going to the
cinema. You will be the source of arguments in
relationships, so try to
control your temper.

Moksha Tribe

House Music 101: 
http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes
true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through
fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by
doing things that one 
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in
the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

SAN FRANCISCO - SATURDAY 01 FEBRUARY 2003

                 E S C
http://www.echolocation.fm/esc


With our highest electromendation...

                 V O L S O C
                 http://www.volsoc.com
                 [check out the live set]

This amazing duo is joining us from Los Angeles and will be
performing a live electro set that we're SURE is going to knock
us all on our asses. This ain't just a laptop show people...they
will be utilizing ze phat analog gear, just the way we like it!

They have just been scooped up by SI BEGG himself, and have
an upcoming release on his NOODLES label....whaaaa!??

Wikked!


We have 4 visual artists headlining as well
SWIPE, MICKEY T, C-TRL and resident + host GIRLIE8.TV.

The event includes an interactive gaming lounge by C-TRL,
who creates a large network of classic macs that have old skool games,
tweaked out hacks and live chat so you can talk to that electrolady
you met at last month's ESC WITH TIPPER.


Musical guests include MS. E who I doubt needs any introduction
(as she is one of the best known/best breaks Deejays from SF),
TUNG who will play at one of our events for the first time and from
the sounds of it should rip the shit out of the dancefloor sufficiently,
and your residents and hosts ANON, DOV + ADAM OHANA.

                 E S C   W I T H   V O L S O C
                 @ CLUB 6IX  - 60 Sixth Street, SF.
                 Opens at 10. Goes till 4AM!
                 $12 at the door.
                 (Yes there are giveaways).

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: DEF-SF site launched re:west coast techno alliance

to the techno faithful,

       i've very recently started up a free website devoted to promoting techno, techno djs, artists and techno producers on the west coast. it is also a site for people interested in furthering the knowledge of techno's presence within the underground and rave community. the site was also made to add a sense of infrastructure which i feel is lacking within the techno community.
if interested, please see the link below to inquire more about the site's purpose and goals.
www.DEFSF.com/info 

also, you are welcomed to visit DEFSF.com itself  to get a better understanding of what DEF represents and why it exists to benefit you. at present it looks like an internet ghost town, that's why we need support from fellow techno enthusiasts to make this site a positive way to support and promote techno within the west coast.

at present the site remains incomplete with future development still in the works. here's a few things that are planned:
internet radio
dj/artist profile pages with booking info, online dj sets, producer spotlights
artists/digital artists pages+profiles
a record label focusing on dj tools called Tactical
DEF-SF techno events
lend/lease it's own soundsystem, DEF-Sound, to other techno events
choice of site skins designed by different digital artists.
online gallery space for techno minded visual artists

thanks for your time and if you have any ideas to contribute see our discussion page or reply to disconnect4@aol.com (subject to change) and i look forward to seeing you at www.defsf.com. -respects, sean. 


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

this year.

techno, around my friends, with a hit of e up my ass.

This sucks.  I'm still gonna party like it was NYE 1999/2k ('sup Harmony,
thanks for that one).  It just won't be the same without techno.

Hope you guys have a good night.

In a message dated 02/01/2003 11:59:51 PM Eastern Standard Time,

<< nobody listens to techno.

 didn't have dave clarke on your side i'd swear you were fucking a corpse.

    What an ignorant thing say... just because this kid can't find a place to 
listen to tonight is not any indication that techno is dead. Techno is 
actually on a rise, and it hasn't even really hit the "pop" scene yet, but 
it's starting to, and it definately will. Techno is as big of a phenomena and 
will soon be as big as rock & roll ever was. People like you who say techno 
is a phase or that it will die or that it is already dead are just like the 
people back in the 50's & 60's who said the same things about rock & roll or 
people in the 80's & 90's who said the same thing about hip hop. In my 
opinion, you probably personally just want techno to die because you're not 
comfertable with it yet, or you don't understand what techno is about about. 
Techno is not ever going to die, and it if it ever did die it would be 
because of people like you who mock and put down the community of it all. 
Happy Chinese New Year SFR :) - johnny Bzzz

Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_891901==_.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:    Thought for Today

--=====================_891901==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I think continually of those who were truly great.
Who, from the womb, remembered the soul's history
Through corridors of light where the hours are suns,
Endless and singing. Whose lovely ambition
Was that their lips, still touched with fire,
Should tell of the spirit clothed from head to foot in song.
And who hoarded from the spring branches
The desires falling across their bodies like blossoms.

What is precious is never to forget
The delight of the blood drawn from ancient springs
Breaking through rocks in worlds before our earth;
Never to deny its pleasure in the simple morning light,
Nor its grave evening demand for love;
Never to allow gradually the traffic to smother
With noise and fog the flowering of the spirit.

Near the snow, near the sun, in the highest fields
See how these names are f=EAted by the waving grass,
And by the streamers of white cloud,
And whispers of wind in the listening sky;
The names of those who in their lives fought for life,
Who wore at their hearts the fire's center.
Born of the sun, they travelled a short while
              towards the sun,
And left the vivid air signed with their honor.


                                  Stephen Spender



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one=20
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But=20
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken
--=====================_891901==_.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] trainwrecking...real? who's fault? dj or producer? nrr

--0-1967269964-1044229880=:16478
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

i  was just thinking about the whole trainwrecking issue....if a dj is playing a good mix, and then all of a sudden you lose your urge to move, do you think it is the fault of the dj or the producer? like, think about those times when suddenly the groove just falls out (like right when your just feeling all smooth and juicy), and then a long spell of simulated kickdrum comes in for what seems like endless seconds....it is not really a fault or mistake actually. art just is so i probably shouldn't use that word, but it is pretty well understood however verbally indescribable the frusteration it can leave one with. :)

Agreed. A trainwreck is when the dj is trying to mix two records and the beats aren't matching, they're just all over the place. This would not be from the producer, but from the dj.  
*~heidi~*

Subject: Re: Fwd: Re: [sfraves] trainwrecking...real? who's fault? dj or producer? nrr

Even if the rythym drops out on a record and the crowd loses it that is the 
djs fault. As a dj you should pick beats that will move the floor and not 
lag at inappropriate times. If you let a rythym line drop and it just leaves 
a kick that is not good. Just my two cents. Peace
  Jason

Subject: [sfraves] Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

as you read this important disclosure, i cant help but think to myself.....=


"is it time to move to the mac or what?"  if you own a pc this is of =
extreme importance to you, especially if you have connections to the net.

i know some people will consider this a little off topic, but think =
seriously, you are reading this email right now using your computer, so it =
AFFECTS EVERYONE who will use this restrictive technology, even without =
knowing it, unfortunately.

I dont know about you, but it is about time we stop with restricting what =
we can do more and more and more year after year.....especially with =
products we buy.

we might wake up and want to produce some music on the pc platform and =
find out that we cant, bc of the govt's war against what they call the =
"Rave Culture" and bc we wont be the one's controlling the background =
processes on our computers.  I urge you to read on and make your voice =
heard, as it seems that the internet is the last open zone for true free =
speech, that is as long as we fight palladium and tpm.

the laws, acts and grip gets larger and tighter every year and it will not =
end unless it is forced to end....

http://www.rationalreview.com/archive/rleewrights/rleewrights011602.html=20=


 From: Seth Johnson <seth.johnson@RealMeasures.dyndns.org>
Subject: Stop Palladium and TCPA Now!


New Yorkers for Fair Use Action Alert:
--------------------------------------

Tell American Megatrends and Transmeta not to make chips
that let others control your computer!

Stop Palladium and TCPA Now!


Okay, you folks understand this issue -- AMI and Transmeta
recently announced their intention to build TCPA technology
into their chips.  It's time to tell them that building
chips that let others control your computer, is
unacceptable.


1) Please send your comments using the form provided below.=20
Tell them not to produce their AMIBIOS8 and TM5800 chips,
and that you will boycott any technology that enables TCPA
and Palladium technology on your computer.  Read the alert
below for details.

3) Take up a role helping with this and other efforts
related to information freedom in the future.  Two roles you
can take up are to become a Press Outreach Campaigner or a
Commentator.  Simply reply to this email to show your
interest.

2) Please forward this alert to any other interested parties
that you know of, who would understand and see the
importance of this issue.


New Yorkers for Fair Use Action Alert:
--------------------------------------
Stop Palladium and TCPA now!=20

Tell American Megatrends and Transmeta not to make chips
that let others control your computer!=20

Please use the following form to tell American Megatrends
and Transmeta not to produce their AMIBIOS8 and TM5800
chips, and that you will boycott any technology that enables
TCPA and Palladium technology on your computer:=20

http://www.nyfairuse.org/cgi-bin/nyfu/palladium=20

What's Going On:=20

Last week, Intel, Microsoft, the RIAA and the MPAA announced
their intention to force Palladium and TCPA into every
personal computer on the planet. Palladium and TCPA are a
different kind of DRM, worse than even the most invasive of
previously proposed "content control" systems.=20

Palladium and TCPA would hardwire your home computer so that
these four entities and their partners would be able to run
processes on your computer, entirely outside your control,
indeed, without your knowledge.=20

Below we answer some questions about DRM, Palladium, TCPA,
and the boycott.=20

New Yorkers for Fair Use=20

What is DRM?=20

DRM is the political, legal, contractual, economic,
hardware, and software infrastructure designed and intended
by a loose alliance of cartels and monopolies to take away
your right to own and privately use a computer. No full DRM
exists in the world today, though pieces of DRM have been
successfully enacted into law and tiny bits of DRM hardware
and software have been placed in some home movie playing and
recording devices. Every single piece of DRM is meant to
help attain the objective of the anti-ownership alliance: to
get control of every personal computer in the world.=20

Intel and Microsoft and RIAA and MPAA, by their own
admission, have, to date, spent billions of dollars to force
universal DRM on the entire world. Last week these four
reiterated their intention to force DRM into every personal
computer on the planet:=20

http://www.nytimes.com/2003/01/15/business/15PIRA.html=20
http://news.com.com/2100-1023-980671.html=20

For more on DRM see:=20

http://newsforge.com/newsforge/02/10/21/1449250.shtml?tid=3D19=20
http://www.panix.com/~jays/what.is.drm.3=20

What is Palladium?=20

"Palladium" is Microsoft's name for its proposed DRM system.
No implementation of Palladium exists today, indeed no
complete specification of Palladium exists today, but
certain hardware which a Palladiated operating system
requires is about to be placed in all personal computers,
unless we stop Microsoft and its hardware and vendor
partners, such as Intel, American Megatrends, Transmeta,
Dell, and CompUSA.=20

What will Palladium do?=20

Palladium will enable a few large corporations and
governments to run source secret, indeed, well-encrypted,
code on home users' machines in such a way that the home
user cannot see, modify, or control the running code. A
Palladiated system is under the complete control of
Microsoft at all times. Microsoft might allow some of its
partners to run code on your machine, but no code will run
on a Palladiated system without Microsoft's consent. The
mechanics are as follows: only code that has been signed
with a special Microsoft provided key will run. Microsoft
will retain at all times the power to revoke any other
entity's keys. In particular, no operating system will be
able to boot without a key from Microsoft. So if Palladium
is forced into every home computer, there will be no more
free software.=20

Microsoft will be able to spy on each and every keystroke,
and mouse movement, and send encrypted messages from your
machine to Microsoft headquarters. Microsoft will also be
able to examine every file on your system. Your encryption
programs will not work against Microsoft, or any other
entities which have full power keys from Microsoft.=20

But surely wily crackers and freedom-loving hackers around
the world will be able to defeat Palladium by breaking it?=20

No. Whether or not a few hackers are able to get around some
versions of Palladium, most people will not be able to.
There are two reasons most people will not be able to escape
the All Seeing Eye and Invisible Hand of Palladium. First,
Palladium is not like the absurdly weak systems called "DRM"
today. Palladium is both hardware and software, and the
software is locked to the hardware in a manner completely
different from today's weak DRM systems. The design of
Palladium allows for defense in depth, and even one layer of
Palladium is harder to crack than any DRM ever seen before.
Second, under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act of the
United States of America, it is illegal to try to see what
Palladium is doing. It is also illegal to modify the
hardware of a Palladiated system. And it is a felony to sell
advice on how to disable Palladium or its supporting
hardware. It is hard enough today to get vendors to sell
computers with a free operating system already installed.
Once Microsoft and Intel have forced Palladiated hardware
into every personal computer, it will be impossible to run a
free OS. The very act of booting a free OS will be outlawed
by application of the DMCA to a Palladiated computer.=20

But there are no Palladium systems available today. So how
can you boycott Palladium?=20

We are boycotting the hardware that Palladium needs. Before
Palladium is rolled out, Palladium-enabling hardware must be
placed in most of the world's personal computers. Right now
such hardware is being placed in computers meant for home
and business use without the buyer being told. Our boycott
is aimed at stopping Palladium-enabling hardware from being
secretly forced into every personal computer in world. We
intend to stop Palladium before we cease to own the
computers in our own houses and offices.=20

The main Palladium-enabling hardware is called a "TPM" for
Trusted Platform Module. The TPM hardware will support, in
addition to Palladium, many different systems which take
control of the computer away from the user and give control
to large corporations and government entities. The TCPA, the
Trusted Computing Platform Alliance, is the standards
organization for the TPM. The founding Alliance members are
Compaq, HP, IBM, Intel and Microsoft. Since 1999, the year
TCPA was founded, about one hundred more companies have
joined the TCPA. The Alliance has published a formal
specification of the TPM. The TCPA's FAQ=20

http://www.trustedcomputing.org/docs/Website_TCPA%20FAQ_0703021.pdf=20

seeks to allay the natural suspicions of computer buyers
about what the TPM does. Unfortunately the FAQ is inaccurate
on the most important issues. For example, the claim is made
that a computer with a working TPM will remain under the
final, ultimate, and complete control of the user. But, as
explained above, this is simply untrue.=20

So what exactly are you doing?=20

We refuse to buy any computer with a TPM inside and we ask
you to refuse to buy any computer with a TPM inside. We use
the term "TPM" to include TPM-like devices, whether in a
separate chip, in the BIOS chip, or even in the cpu. This
means that we ask buyers of personal computers to find out
whether the computer has a TPM or a TPM-like device inside.
We will shortly provide buyers of home computers with
methods for telling whether or not a computer has a TPM
inside.=20

Is it possible to be more specific today?=20

Yes. We call for a boycott of the just announced American
Megatrends AMIBIOS8:=20

http://www.ami.com/ami/showpress.cfm?PrID=3D118=20

http://www.ami.com/products/product.cfm?ProdID=3D127&CatID=3D6&SubID=3D14=
=20

http://interviews.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=3D03/01/09/166251&tid=3D99=20=


http://interviews.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=3D03/01/17/1430214&mode=3Dthr=
ead&tid=3D137=20

and the just announced Transmeta TM5800 cpu:=20

http://siliconvalley.internet.com/news/article.php/1569201=20

http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=3D03/01/14/1719220&mode=3Dthread&tid=3D1=
61=20

Where can I find out more about Palladium, TCPA, and DMCA?=20

For Palladium see:=20

http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/%7Erja14/tcpa-faq.html l

http://wintermute.homelinux.org/miscelanea/TCPA%20Security.txt=20

http://discuss.microsoft.com/SCRIPTS/WA-MSD.EXE?A2=3Dind0301b&L=3Dwmtalk&T=
=3D0&O=3DA&P=3D12347=20
http://www.theregus.com/content/4/25378.html=20
http://www.counterpane.com/crypto-gram-0208.html#1=20

http://www.ofb.biz/modules.php?name=3DNews&file=3Darticle&sid=3D152=20

For TCPA and the TPM see:=20

http://www.trustedcomputing.org=20

For the DMCA see:=20

http://www.nyfairuse.org/analysis/dmca.must.be.repealed.xhtml=20
http://anti-dmca.org=20
http://www.nyfairuse.org/dmca.xhtml=20

How do I tell these folks I don't want DRM?=20

Just click on the URL below:=20

http://www.nyfairuse.org/cgi-bin/nyfu/palladium

From: Nathan Seven <scosol@yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 03 Feb 2003 14:26:50 -0800
In-Reply-To: <se3e9312.087@relay.firstcharter.com>
User-Agent: Opera7.0/Win32 M2 build 2637

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

Howdy alarmist propaganda...

(and I added NRR) :)

On Mon, 03 Feb 2003 16:04:11 -0500, Chris Dooley <dooleyc@firstcharter.com> 
wrote:

> as you read this important disclosure, i cant help but think to 
> myself.....
>
> "is it time to move to the mac or what?"  if you own a pc this is of 
> extreme importance to you, especially if you have connections to the net.

First of all-that has no bearing on anything.
If the day ever comes where all the content on the Internet can only be 
played on "TCPA Enabled" hardware, then you will witness Apple quickly 
become TCPA Enabled...

Other points addressed below:

> Okay, you folks understand this issue -- AMI and Transmeta
> recently announced their intention to build TCPA technology
> into their chips.  It's time to tell them that building
> chips that let others control your computer, is
> unacceptable.

Ok-first of all-TCPA is really nothing more than a hardware encryption 
coprocessor on the motherboard.
Yes, all of this *could* be done today through software.

> Palladium and TCPA would hardwire your home computer so that
> these four entities and their partners would be able to run
> processes on your computer, entirely outside your control,
> indeed, without your knowledge.

That's entirely untrue.

> What is DRM?
>
> DRM is the political, legal, contractual, economic,
> hardware, and software infrastructure designed and intended
> by a loose alliance of cartels and monopolies to take away
> your right to own and privately use a computer. No full DRM
> exists in the world today, though pieces of DRM have been
> successfully enacted into law and tiny bits of DRM hardware
> and software have been placed in some home movie playing and
> recording devices. Every single piece of DRM is meant to
> help attain the objective of the anti-ownership alliance: to
> get control of every personal computer in the world.
>
> Intel and Microsoft and RIAA and MPAA, by their own
> admission, have, to date, spent billions of dollars to force
> universal DRM on the entire world. Last week these four
> reiterated their intention to force DRM into every personal
> computer on the planet:

The fact that the MPAA and the RIAA have the most to lose without DRM does 
not mean it's a bad thing.
DRM is Digital Rights Management.
It's aim is to simply maintain control over a piece of content.
You remember DIVX?
(The limited-play DVDs, not the video codec)
Circuit city sold them-they were DVDs that would only play 3 times or so, 
and you could buy them for cheaper than the normal DVDs.
Guess what-they flopped-but that's besides the point.
That was the essence of DRM-control over the content-
And it's not a bad thing.
You don't want to pay for an mp3 that you can't share with your friends?
Fine-don't buy it.
You don't want to pay for a movie clip that will only play from 8PM-9PM on 
Tuesdays?
Fine-don't buy it.
Just like DIVX-people didn't want to buy a DVD that they could only watch 3 
times.
So they didn't...

> Palladium will enable a few large corporations and
> governments to run source secret, indeed, well-encrypted,
> code on home users' machines in such a way that the home
> user cannot see, modify, or control the running code. A
> Palladiated system is under the complete control of
> Microsoft at all times. Microsoft might allow some of its
> partners to run code on your machine, but no code will run
> on a Palladiated system without Microsoft's consent. The
> mechanics are as follows: only code that has been signed
> with a special Microsoft provided key will run. Microsoft
> will retain at all times the power to revoke any other
> entity's keys.

This is for the most part true, but is *totally* phrased in an alarmist 
way.
The "well encrypted code" is meant to secure the machine.
And it will not be "controlled by Microsoft" in any way.

> In particular, no operating system will be
> able to boot without a key from Microsoft.
> So if Palladium
> is forced into every home computer, there will be no more
> free software.

Those 2 things are straight untrue...

> Microsoft will be able to spy on each and every keystroke,
> and mouse movement, and send encrypted messages from your
> machine to Microsoft headquarters. Microsoft will also be
> able to examine every file on your system. Your encryption
> programs will not work against Microsoft, or any other
> entities which have full power keys from Microsoft.

This can happen today, right now...

> But surely wily crackers and freedom-loving hackers around
> the world will be able to defeat Palladium by breaking it?
>
> No. Whether or not a few hackers are able to get around some
> versions of Palladium, most people will not be able to.
> There are two reasons most people will not be able to escape
> the All Seeing Eye and Invisible Hand of Palladium. First,
> Palladium is not like the absurdly weak systems called "DRM"
> today. Palladium is both hardware and software, and the
> software is locked to the hardware in a manner completely
> different from today's weak DRM systems. The design of
> Palladium allows for defense in depth, and even one layer of
> Palladium is harder to crack than any DRM ever seen before.

Incorrect-Hardware will *always* be tied to software.
You want to see Palladium in action?
Look at the XBox.
There it is, right in front of you.
Palladium HW encryption-used to secure the console.
And what?
You don't like that idea?
Fine-it has of course been cracked, as any sort of HW/SW combo will 
*always* be able to be...

> Second, under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act of the
> United States of America, it is illegal to try to see what
> Palladium is doing. It is also illegal to modify the
> hardware of a Palladiated system. And it is a felony to sell
> advice on how to disable Palladium or its supporting
> hardware. It is hard enough today to get vendors to sell
> computers with a free operating system already installed.
> Once Microsoft and Intel have forced Palladiated hardware
> into every personal computer, it will be impossible to run a
> free OS. The very act of booting a free OS will be outlawed
> by application of the DMCA to a Palladiated computer.

Yes.
The DMCA is IMO the most dangerous thing to personal freedom in existance 
today.
Yes-the DMCA makes what I described above-the cracking of the XBox, the 
bypassing of any Palladium PC-ILLEGAL.The DMCA is the problem, not 
Palladium.
MS could release an OS tomorrow that had the Palladium features in software 
and could then invoke the DMCA upon anything that tried to bypass them.
My point being-the DMCA is the real problem here.

> We refuse to buy any computer with a TPM inside and we ask
> you to refuse to buy any computer with a TPM inside. We use
> the term "TPM" to include TPM-like devices, whether in a
> separate chip, in the BIOS chip, or even in the cpu. This
> means that we ask buyers of personal computers to find out
> whether the computer has a TPM or a TPM-like device inside.
> We will shortly provide buyers of home computers with
> methods for telling whether or not a computer has a TPM
> inside.

I'm all for taking action, but I would recommend demanding repeal of the 
DMCA, because Palladium isn't going to do anything at all...

From: Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

>DRM is Digital Rights Management.
>It's aim is to simply maintain control over a piece of content.

Control that is, arguably, illegal according to the DMCA, but just fine
according to fair-use standards and copyright. I'm not thrilled that the
short-sighted corporate-bought legal fuckover (DMCA) is trumping the Right
(copyright).


>You don't want to pay for an mp3 that you can't share with your friends?
>Fine-don't buy it.
>You don't want to pay for a movie clip that will only play from 8PM-9PM on
>Tuesdays?
>Fine-don't buy it.

If it were that simple, you wouldn't have organizations like the EFF up in
arms over this crap. It's /not/ just a matter of choosing not to pay for
content you feel is too restricted, it's an issue of the *AA's attempting
to circumvent basic economics in order to LEGISLATE free content out of
existence.[1] So, if the *AA's had their way, your dialogue would go
something like:

>You don't want to pay for an mp3 that you can't share with your friends?

Fine. No music for you, because there's no longer any such thing as a
legal mp3 which you can share with your friends.

>You don't want to pay for a movie clip that will only play from 8PM-9PM
>on Tuesdays?

Fine. No movie for you, because there's no longer any such thing as a
legal movie file without time-shifting or space-shifting restrictions
built into it.


Of course it will still be possible to develop and procure *illegal* file
formats and players for movie and music files, but that's dangerous. When
something as normal as copying a movie or song, that you paid for, for
your personal use, is illegal, then it's a sign that there is something
horribly wrong with the law.

There have been two excellent articles written on the topic during the
past week, one on Salon[1] and one on Kuro5hin[2]. Do yourself a favor and
give them a read, if you care about this stuff.


>I'm all for taking action, but I would recommend demanding repeal of the
>DMCA, because Palladium isn't going to do anything at all...

A-men.

1) http://salon.com/tech/feature/2003/02/01/file_trading_manifesto/index.html
2) fuck, k5 seems to be innaccessible to me at the moment. The URL is one
   of the front=page articles.

>>> Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com> 02/03/03 17:51 PM >>>
>DRM is Digital Rights Management.
>It's aim is to simply maintain control over a piece of content.

Control that is, arguably, illegal according to the DMCA, but just fine
according to fair-use standards and copyright. I'm not thrilled that the
short-sighted corporate-bought legal fuckover (DMCA) is trumping the Right
(copyright).


>You don't want to pay for an mp3 that you can't share with your friends?
>Fine-don't buy it.
>You don't want to pay for a movie clip that will only play from 8PM-9PM =
on
>Tuesdays?
>Fine-don't buy it.

If it were that simple, you wouldn't have organizations like the EFF up in
arms over this crap. It's /not/ just a matter of choosing not to pay for
content you feel is too restricted, it's an issue of the *AA's attempting
to circumvent basic economics in order to LEGISLATE free content out of
existence.[1] So, if the *AA's had their way, your dialogue would go
something like:

>You don't want to pay for an mp3 that you can't share with your friends?

Fine. No music for you, because there's no longer any such thing as a
legal mp3 which you can share with your friends.

>You don't want to pay for a movie clip that will only play from 8PM-9PM
>on Tuesdays?

Fine. No moviefor you, because there's no longer any such thing as a
legal movie file without time-shifting or space-shifting restrictions
built into it.


Of course it will still be possible to develop and procure *illegal* file
formats and players for movie and music files, but that's dangerous. When
something as normal as copying a movie or song, that you paid for, for
your personal use, is illegal, then it's a sign that there is something
horribly wrong with the law.

There have been two excellent articles written on the topic during the
past week, one on Salon[1] and one on Kuro5hin[2]. Do yourself a favor and
give them a read, if you care about this stuff.


>I'm all for taking action, but I would recommend demanding repeal of the
>DMCA, because Palladium isn't going to do anything at all...

A-men.

1) http://salon.com/tech/feature/2003/02/01/file_trading_manifesto/index.ht=
ml
2) fuck, k5 seems to be innaccessible to me at the moment. The URL is one
   of the front=3Dpage articles.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
michal migurski- contact info and pgp key:
                 http://www.saturn5.com/mike/contact.html

                "Freedom! Horrible, horrible freedom!"

>>> Nathan Seven <scosol@yahoo.com> 02/03/03 17:24 PM >>>
Howdy alarmist propaganda...

(and I added NRR) :)

On Mon, 03 Feb 2003 16:04:11 -0500, Chris Dooley <dooleyc@firstcharter.com>=
=20
wrote:

> as you read this important disclosure, i cant help but think to=20
> myself.....
>
> "is it time to move to the mac or what?"  if you own a pc this is of=20
> extreme importance to you, especially if you have connections to the =
net.

First of all-that has no bearing on anything.
If the day ever comes where all the content on the Internet can only be=20
played on "TCPA Enabled" hardware, then you will witness Apple quickly=20
become TCPA Enabled...

Other points addressed below:

> Okay, you folks understand this issue -- AMI and Transmeta
> recently announced their intention to build TCPA technology
> into their chips.  It's time to tell them that building
> chips that let others control your computer, is
> unacceptable.

Ok-first of all-TCPA is really nothing more than a hardware enryption=20
coprocessor on the motherboard.
Yes, all of this *could* be done today through software.

> Palladium and TCPA would hardwire your home computer so that
> these four entities and their partners would be able to run
> processes on your computer, entirely outside your control,
> indeed, without your knowledge.

That's entirely untrue.

> What is DRM?
>
> DRM is the political, legal, contractual, economic,
> hardware, and software infrastructure designed and intended
> by a loose alliance of cartels and monopolies to take away
> your right to own and privately use a computer. No full DRM
> exists in the world today, though pieces of DRM have been
> successfully enacted into law and tiny bits of DRM hardware
> and software have been placed in some home movie playing and
> recording devices. Every single piece of DRM is meant to
> help attain the objective of the anti-ownership alliance: to
> get control of every personal computer in the world.
>
> Intel and Microsoft and RIAA and MPAA, by their own
> admission, have, to date, spent billions of dollars to force
> universal DRM on the entire world. Last week these four
> reiterated their intention to force DRM into every personal
> computer on the planet:

The fact that the MPAA and the RIAA have the most to lose without DRM =
does=20
not mean it's a bad thing.
DRM is Digital Rights Management.
It's aim is to simply maintain control over a piece of content.
You remember DIVX?
(The limited-play DVDs, not the video codec)
Circuit city sold them-they were DVDs that would only play 3 times or =
so,=20
and you could buy them for cheaper than the normal DVDs.
Guess what-they flopped-but that's besides the point.
That was the essence of DRM-control over the content-
And it's not a bad thing.
You don't want to pay for an mp3 that you can't share with your friends?
Fine-don't buy it.
You don't want to pay for a movie clip that will only play from 8PM-9PM =
on=20
Tuesdays?
Fine-don't buy it.
Just like DIVX-people didn't want to buy  DVD that they could only watch =
3=20
times.
So they didn't...

> Palladium will enable a few large corporations and
> governments to run source secret, indeed, well-encrypted,
> code on home users' machines in such a way that the home
> user cannot see, modify, or control the running code. A
> Palladiated system is under the complete control of
> Microsoft at all times. Microsoft might allow some of its
> partners to run code on your machine, but no code will run
> on a Palladiated system without Microsoft's consent. The
> mechanics are as follows: only code that has been signed
> with a special Microsoft provided key will run. Microsoft
> will retain at all times the power to revoke any other
> entity's keys.

This is for the most part true, but is *totally* phrased in an alarmist=20
way.
The "well encrypted code" is meant to secure the machine.
And it will not be "controlled by Microsoft" in any way.

> In particular, no operating system will be
> able to boot without a key from Microsoft.
> So if Palladium
> is forced into every home computer, there will be no more
> free software.

Those 2 things are straight untrue...

> Microsoft will be able to spy on each and every keystroke,
> and mouse movement, and send encrypted messages from your
> machine to Microsoft headquarters. Microsoft will also be
> able to examine every file on your system. Your encryption
> programs will not work against Microsoft, or any other
> entities which have full power keys from Microsoft.

This can happen today, right now...

> But surely wily crackers and freedom-loving hackers around
> the world will be able to defeat Palladium by breaking it?
>
> No. Whether or not a few hackers are able to get around some
> versions of Palladium, most people will not be able to.
> There are two reasons most people will not be able to escape
> the All Seeing Eye and Invisible Hand of Palladium. First,
> Palladium is not like the absurdly weak systems called "DRM"
> today. Palladium is both harware and software, and the
> software is locked to the hardware in a manner completely
> different from today's weak DRM systems. The design of
> Palladium allows for defense in depth, and even one layer of
> Palladium is harder to crack than any DRM ever seen before.

Incorrect-Hardware will *always* be tied to software.
You want to see Palladium in action?
Look at the XBox.
There it is, right in front of you.
Palladium HW encryption-used to secure the console.
And what?
You don't like that idea?
Fine-it has of course been cracked, as any sort of HW/SW combo will=20
*always* be able to be...

> Second, under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act of the
> United States of America, it is illegal to try to see what
> Palladium is doing. It is also illegal to modify the
> hardware of a Palladiated system. And it is a felony to sell
> advice on how to disable Palladium or its supporting
> hardware. It is hard enough today to get vendors to sell
> computers with a free operating system already installed.
> Once Microsoft and Intel have forced Palladiated hardware
> into every personal computer, it will be impossible to run a
> free OS. The very act of booting a free OS will be outlawed
> by application of the DMCA to a Palladiated computer.

Yes.
The DMCA is IMO the most dangerous thing to personal freedom in =
existance=20
today.
Yes-the DMCA makes what I described above-the cracking of the XBox, the=20
bypassing of any Palladium PC-ILLEGAL.The DMCA is the problem, not=20
Palladium.
MS could release an OS tomorrow that had the Palladium features in =
software=20
and could then invoke the DMCA upon anything that tried to bypass them.
My point being-the DMCA is the real problem here.

> We refuse to buy any computer with a TPM inside and we ask
> you to refuse to buy any computer with a TPM inside. We use
> the term "TPM" to include TPM-like devices, whether in a
> separate chip, in the BIOS chip, or even in the cpu. This
> means that we ask buyers of personal computers to find out
> wether the computer has a TPM or a TPM-like device inside.
> We will shortly provide buyers of home computers with
> methods for telling whether or not a computer has a TPM
> inside.

I'm all for taking action, but I would recommend demanding repeal of =
the=20
DMCA, because Palladium isn't going to do anything at all...

Received: (qmail 24204 invoked from network); 4 Feb 2003 01:14:56 -0000
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>
cc: Chris Dooley <dooleyc@firstcharter.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <se3e9312.087@relay.firstcharter.com> <oprj1hy0ohr3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com> <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031438030.3060@atari>
Message-ID: <oprj1prd1cr3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-15; format=flowed
From: Nathan Seven <scosol@yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 03 Feb 2003 17:15:03 -0800
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031438030.3060@atari>
User-Agent: Opera7.0/Win32 M2 build 2637
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

On Mon, 3 Feb 2003 14:53:52 -0800 (PST), Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com> 
wrote:

>> DRM is Digital Rights Management.
>> It's aim is to simply maintain control over a piece of content.
>
> Control that is, arguably, illegal according to the DMCA, but just fine
> according to fair-use standards and copyright. I'm not thrilled that the
> short-sighted corporate-bought legal fuckover (DMCA) is trumping the 
> Right
> (copyright).

That's trivial and irrelavent-all of the existing fair-use wording 
(copying, reverse-engineering etc) applies to things that are "sold".
All "they" need to do is suddenly "license" the music to you instead of 
"selling" it to you and fair use goes out the window.
All of it-gone.Then you're left with a EULA, and you either agree to it or 
you dont.

> If it were that simple, you wouldn't have organizations like the EFF up 
> in
> arms over this crap. It's /not/ just a matter of choosing not to pay for
> content you feel is too restricted, it's an issue of the *AA's attempting
> to circumvent basic economics in order to LEGISLATE free content out of
> existence.

I agree-but the DMCA is the problem, not Palladium.

[1] So, if the *AA's had their way, your dialogue would go
> something like:
>
>> You don't want to pay for an mp3 that you can't share with your friends?
>
> Fine. No music for you, because there's no longer any such thing as a
> legal mp3 which you can share with your friends.

Exactly-which is why I used DIVX as an example.
If the restrictions placed on content are reasonable, then it's not a big 
deal and nobody cares.
If the restrictions are *unreasonable*, then nobody will want it and it 
will fade away into nothingness.

>> You don't want to pay for a movie clip that will only play from 8PM-9PM
>> on Tuesdays?
>
> Fine. No movie for you, because there's no longer any such thing as a
> legal movie file without time-shifting or space-shifting restrictions
> built into it.

Great-and are time-shifting and space-shifting restrictions going to be an 
issue for 99.9% of consumers?

> Of course it will still be possible to develop and procure *illegal* file
> formats and players for movie and music files, but that's dangerous. When
> something as normal as copying a movie or song, that you paid for, for
> your personal use, is illegal, then it's a sign that there is something
> horribly wrong with the law.

Again-that will *all* be wiped out once content is "licensed" and not 
"sold".
IE: "Fuck you and your personal use, you agreed to the terms of what you 
can and can not do with this content when you opened the package."
It's not the nicest message, but hey-
You were told *exactly* what you could and could not do with it, you were 
told how much it costs, and then you were given a choice to buy or not to 
buy.

> There have been two excellent articles written on the topic during the
> past week, one on Salon[1] and one on Kuro5hin[2]. Do yourself a favor 
> and
> give them a read, if you care about this stuff.

I've most likely read them-but I'll check and make sure.



---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Date: Mon, 3 Feb 2003 17:43:18 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: mike@atari
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031742370.3060@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Thursday S.F. IndieFest Benefit, and the return of the RAVE Act
 (fwd)

Courtesy of the SFLNC General Mailing List:

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: SFLNC Information <info@sflnc.com>
To: SFLNC General List <announce@sflnc.com>

This Thursday, Feb 6th at 1015 Folsom: the creative energy from two
sub-cultures will come together in a powerful synergy! The San Francisco
Independent Film scene and the San Francisco Late Night scene have put
together a great night of art, film and music with an incredible line-up
of entertainment featuring short films and DJ's Ethan Miller, Dragn'fly,
Forest Green, Monty Luke, Jeff Richmond, 8-Ball, Tyler Reed, Jim Cyr,
Chris McGarry, and Mr. Lazy.

Ticket holders for the Opening Night Screenings at the Castro Theater
admitted free, all others $10. All proceeds benefit the San Francisco
Independent Film Festival.

Don't miss this one.  And keep on dancing!

Read more about this event at:
http://sflnc.com/index/events/special/28.html


Also, last week saw the reintroduction of last year's failed R.A.V.E. Act
under a new name, The Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act (S.226). Despite
being rolled into an unrelated bill, it has the same sponsor and contains
many of the same chilling provisions intended to hold club owners and
promoters criminally responsible for the drug of use of their patrons.

Read more about the ressurected RAVE Act at:
http://sflnc.com/rave_act/

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Want to get involved in the SFLNC?

would like to be added to the SFLNC general mailing list, please send mail
to announce-subscribe@sflnc.com.

Date: Mon, 3 Feb 2003 18:12:07 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: mike@atari
To: Nathan Seven <scosol@yahoo.com>
cc: Chris Dooley <dooleyc@firstcharter.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <oprj1prd1cr3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031756540.3060@atari>
References: <se3e9312.087@relay.firstcharter.com> <oprj1hy0ohr3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com>
 <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031438030.3060@atari> <oprj1prd1cr3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

>> Control that is, arguably, illegal according to the DMCA, but just fine
>> according to fair-use standards and copyright. I'm not thrilled that the
>> short-sighted corporate-bought legal fuckover (DMCA) is trumping the
>> Right
>> (copyright).
>
>That's trivial and irrelavent-all of the existing fair-use wording
>(copying, reverse-engineering etc) applies to things that are "sold".
>All "they" need to do is suddenly "license" the music to you instead of
>"selling" it to you and fair use goes out the window.

I think we agree with each other for the most part, but I don't think
think the above is trivial. The problem is that the content industries are
trapped between "licensed" and "sold" content - they are trying to reap
the rewards of both models, but ultimately the contradictions may cost
them both.

If music is "licensed", then their push for DRM becomes mostly fruitless,
since my purchase of an aluminized polycarbonate music ownership token
implies that I have the right to time- and space-shift that content as I
see fit - it can't be dependent upon the medium, only on my license terms.
It essentially limits them to going after real 'pirates' - the ones who
sell counterfeit DVDs and profit from them without paying the *AA. It also
means that they will have to drastically change their methods of selling
music, including shutting down used CD stores and prosecuting DJ's. Do you
think any of that would fly in a court of law? The already collect on
every purchase of a blank CD, you know, so the argument that personal
piracy and CD duping is killing them will not go far.

If music is "sold", then their attack on the P2P networks becomes
irrelevant, because all that music came from someone who purchased a CD at
one time or another, an owner.

I think all the current hoo-haw is the result of them realizing that their
business model is being slowly flushed down the economic toilet, and that
the music company execs who still have their e-mail printed for them by
their secretaries don't have the faintest clue what to do about it.

"Let's sue the fuckers!"
"Which ones?"
"uh ... tricksterman@hushmail.com!"

They're thrashing. Picture the end of T-2. :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

On Mon, 3 Feb 2003 18:12:07 -0800 (PST), Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com> 
wrote:

> If music is "licensed", then their push for DRM becomes mostly fruitless,
> since my purchase of an aluminized polycarbonate music ownership token
> implies that I have the right to time-and space-shift that content as I
> see fit - it can't be dependent upon the medium, only on my license 
> terms.

I think the absolute opposite-if music is licensed, then the DRM that 
enforces that license is *key*.
Without it, everyone just ignores the license.

> It essentially limits them to going after real 'pirates' - the ones who
> sell counterfeit DVDs and profit from them without paying the *AA. It 
> also
> means that they will have to drastically change their methods of selling
> music, including shutting down used CD stores and prosecuting DJ's. Do 
> you
> think any of that would fly in a court of law? The already collect on
> every purchase of a blank CD, you know, so the argument that personal
> piracy and CD duping is killing them will not go far.

It *won't have* to fly in a court of law, because "strong" DRM will enforce 
the licenses; with only the hardcore pirates investing the time/resources 
to break it.
Isn't that what you want-the RIAA going after only the huge money-making 
pirates?

> If music is "sold", then their attack on the P2P networks becomes
> irrelevant, because all that music came from someone who purchased a CD 
> at
> one time or another, an owner.

Not really-"free redistribution" is not listed under "fair use".

> I think all the current hoo-haw is the result of them realizing that 
> their
> business model is being slowly flushed down the economic toilet, and that
> the music company execs who still have their e-mail printed for them by
> their secretaries don't have the faintest clue what to do about it.

Well it *will* have to change-and bad as you say they are, what does the 
aftermath look like?
How is an artist in the digital realm ever to make a living when his works 
can be freely copied and redistributed by *anyone*?

>>> Nathan Seven <scosol@yahoo.com> 02/03/03 20:12 PM >>>
On Mon, 3 Feb 2003 14:53:52 -0800 (PST), Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>=
=20
wrote:

>> DRM is Digital Rights Management.
>> It's aim is to simply maintain control over a piece of content.
>
> Control that is, arguably, illegal according to the DMCA, but just fine
> according to fair-use standards and copyright. I'm not thrilled that the
> short-sighted corporate-bought legal fuckover (DMCA) is trumping the=20
> Right
> (copyright).

That's trivial and irrelavent-all of the existing fair-use wording=20
(copying, reverse-engineering etc) applies to things that are "sold".
All "they" need to do is suddenly "license" the music to you instead of=20
"selling" it to you and fair use goes out the window.
All of it-gone.Then you're left with a EULA, and you either agree to it =
or=20
you dont.

> If it were that simple, you wouldn't have organizations like the EFF =
up=20
> in
> arms over this crap. It's /not/ just a matter of choosing not to pay for
> content you feel is too restricted, it's an issue of the *AA's attempting=

> to circumvent basic economics in order to LEGISLATE free content out of
> existence.

I agree-but the DMCA is the problem, not Palladium.

[1] So, if the *AA's had their way, your dialogue would go
> something like:
>
>> You don't wnt to pay for an mp3 that you can't share with your friends?
>
> Fine. No music for you, because there's no longer any such thing as a
> legal mp3 which you can share with your friends.

Exactly-which is why I used DIVX as an example.
If the restrictions placed on content are reasonable, then it's not a =
big=20
deal and nobody cares.
If the restrictions are *unreasonable*, then nobody will want it and it=20
will fade away into nothingness.

>> You don't want to pay for a movie clip that will only play from 8PM-9PM
>> on Tuesdays?
>
> Fine. No movie for you, because there's no longer any such thing as a
> legal movie file without time-shifting or space-shifting restrictions
> built into it.

Great-and are time-shifting and space-shifting restrictions going to be =
an=20
issue for 99.9% of consumers?

> Of course it will still be possible to develop and procure *illegal* =
file
> formats and players for movie and music files, but that's dangerous. =
When
> something as normal as copying a movie or song, that you paid for, for
> your personal use, is illegal, then it's a sign that there is something
> horribly wrong with the law.

Again-that will *all* be wiped out once content is "licensed" and not=20
"sold".
IE: "Fuck you and your personal use, you agreed to the terms of what =
you=20
can and can not do with this content when you opened the package."
It's not the nicest message, but hey-
You were told *exactly* what you could and could not do with it, you =
were=20
told how much it costs, and then you were given a choice to buy or not =
to=20
buy.

> There have been two excellent articles written on the topic during the
> past week, one on Salon[1] and one on Kuro5hin[2]. Do yourself a =
favor=20
> and
> give them a read, if you care about this stuff.

I've most likely read them-but I'll check and make sure.

Date: Mon, 3 Feb 2003 19:40:34 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>

To: Nathan Seven <scosol@yahoo.com>
cc: Chris Dooley <dooleyc@firstcharter.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org

Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031927490.3060@atari>
References: <se3e9312.087@relay.firstcharter.com> <oprj1hy0ohr3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com>
 <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031438030.3060@atari> <oprj1prd1cr3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com>
 <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031756540.3060@atari> <oprj1s56i6r3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

>Well it *will* have to change-and bad as you say they are, what does the
>aftermath look like?

Hopefully, the aftermath will be that the combined effect of lower music
sales and pressure from the music companies' corporate overlords (such as
Sony electronics - the vastly more profitable divisions that make money
from media duplication rather than content creation) will leave the RIAA
member companies unable to pay their legal fees, and the problem will sort
of take care of itself. These bungholes only have power to influence
congress so long as they have money to toss around.


>How is an artist in the digital realm ever to make a living when his
>works can be freely copied and redistributed by *anyone*?

That's a completely orthogonal issue.

Personally, I don't think that anyone has an inherent right to make a
living from the duplication of content they have created. They have the
right to prevent others from doing so, thanks to the concept of copyright
(something I'm totally in support of, just not in its local bastardized
form). I know that's harsh--sorry, musicians--but I fail to see how
someone's desire to make money trumps my right to control the objects and
media in my possession in a reasonable way.

I'm perfectly comfortable with the fact that my position will make it
nearly impossible for David Geffen and Britney to vacation in the
Caribbean every year, but I don't fucking care. And I trust that in a free
market with a *massive* demand for music such as ours, someone will think
of a way to address that demand, and make money from it without trying to
legislate us into sticking with a lame distribution model.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
michal migurski- contact info and pgp key:
                 http://www.saturn5.com/mike/contact.html

                "Freedom! Horrible, horrible freedom!"

Date: Mon, 3 Feb 2003 23:13:16 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>

References: <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031756540.3060@atari> <se3e9312.087@relay.firstcharter.com>
 <oprj1hy0ohr3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com> <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031438030.3060@atari>
 <oprj1prd1cr3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com> <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031756540.3060@atari>
 <5.2.0.9.2.20030203201405.00af4ab0@mail.sarilion.org> <001a01c2cc05$bd759e20$ac58ae40@damn>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

>> shouldn't art be about the quality of the product, and not making money? I
>> don't think Michelangelo had dollar signs in his eyes when he covertly
>> performed autopsies.
>
>We do not live in the age of patron saints anymore.  If an artist cannot
>be funded through direct payment by the public for their art, they cannot
>live.  It's that simple, assuming all they do is art and they don't have
>a day job ;)

I'm not sure I agree - in a recent discussion of potential ways to fund
music in a post-RIAA world, I heard that most broadway plays are funded in
an arts-patron model, with small groups of rich investors putting up money
and taking a personal financial risk for a play based on its probability
of success (think Bullets Over Broadway). I think this is a completely
viable model for covering studio costs, etc. Seems to me that the biggest
complaint I usually hear about the relationship between artists and labels
is the way that labels tend to really rape the artist on their initial
recording contract - having third party funding involved may help lessen
that, I think?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

On Mon, 3 Feb 2003 23:13:16 -0800 (PST), Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com> 
wrote:

> I'm not sure I agree - in a recent discussion of potential ways to fund
> music in a post-RIAA world, I heard that most broadway plays are funded 
> in
> an arts-patron model, with small groups of rich investors putting up 
> money
> and taking a personal financial risk for a play based on its probability
> of success (think Bullets Over Broadway). I think this is a completely
> viable model for covering studio costs, etc. Seems to me that the biggest
> complaint I usually hear about the relationship between artists and

What do you think the Record Company Execs are... Rich Investors perhaps?

That's exactly how record companies work today-
They front the money for studio time etc, betting that they'll receive more 
than that back through record sales etc.
No difference, except maybe the greed of the investors.

 <oprj1prd1cr3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com> <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031756540.3060@atari>
 <5.2.0.9.2.20030203201405.00af4ab0@mail.sarilion.org> <001a01c2cc05$bd759e20$ac58ae40@damn>
 <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302032309090.3060@atari> <oprj21v3gir3vllf@smtp.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

>Well-what you describe is *exactly* the model of today. What do you think
>the Record Company Execs are... Rich Investors perhaps?

Yes, but thanks to organizations like the RIAA, there is pretty much no
way for a new investor to make it into that field. It's been clogged and
monopolized, from the A+R guys to the distribution channels.

My issue with the music business is not that it's rich, or that it chooses
to finance its music in a particular way, it's that it is an artificially-
maintained monopoly, which is losing its ability to compete in a
free-market, and is attempting to remove market freedoms to hold onto its
profits.


>That's exactly how record companies work today-
>They front the money for studio time etc, betting that they'll receive more
>than that back through record sales etc.
>No difference, except maybe the greed of the investors.

...And the fact that a grand total of five corporations own the vast
majority of labels, and that those five corporations collude to keep
prices artificially high.

From sfraves-return-98440-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Feb 04 19:38:10 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-98440-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 97469 invoked by uid 1103); 4 Feb 2003 19:38:10 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 97455 invoked from network); 4 Feb 2003 19:38:10 -0000
Message-ID: <20030204193815.95528.qmail@web80312.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 4 Feb 2003 11:38:15 -0800 (PST)
From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302031927490.3060@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

--- Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com> wrote:
> >How is an artist in the digital realm ever to make a living when his
> >works can be freely copied and redistributed by *anyone*?
> 
> That's a completely orthogonal issue.
> 
> Personally, I don't think that anyone has an inherent right to make a
> living from the duplication of content they have created. 

Hmmm..

Say Honda is developing the '05 Civic.  They dream it up, they get the
CAD down, they design the dies, they get the molds together.  So, now
they've got all the tooling in place, and now they're manufacturing the
Civics like mad.  Now, imagine if a lobbyist from the consumer sector
started loudly proclaiming that car companies had no inherent right to
charge any more for these cars than the cost of the raw materials,
worker wages, machine upkeep, and power.  

Now, of course, the vast gulf between those costs and what a car sells
for represents the income of said car manufacturers and their vendors. 
However, if one breaks it down, the manufacture of a car represents
little more than a "duplication of content", only in this case metal,
plastic, and rubber substitute for the tray card, jewel case, liner
notes, and disc.  So why not give them away for cost, under the
paradigm you seem to suggest?  The design, functionality, and "je ne
sais quoi" that send you hurtling towards a certain car dealership come
from ideas, concepts, and work- nothing but synapses flashing.  

Of course, this sentiment would never fly.  In America, the general
idea is to make something people want, manufacture it, and sell it at a
profit.  Chairs, ovens, washing machines- these are tangible things,
and nobody's ever going to criticize anybody for profiting from them in
a capitalist society.  

Oh, but art, music, software, poetry- in their basic form, they are
ephemeral.  They exist only as ink on paper, data on a disc, a tune in
your head.  Creating the best of these things takes no less skill,
time, or work than making inanimate objects- yet listen to 'em crow
when the creators want to make a living!  

Because these things *are* ephemeral, and it's a given in this day and
age that people won't pay for something that isn't a physical object,
(no matter how much they want or need it) it becomes neccesary to put
music out on CDs, and to sell software in retail boxes.  

How many times have you heard, "Oh, this song is my favorite..  It
always makes me happy.  I got it off Kazaa, I figure musicians make
enough money."  Or, maybe, "I was going to go out and buy Photoshop,
but then I got it off of Limewire.  F*ck paying for software!"?  When
somebody's music or a dev team's app is fileshared it's no longer tied
to an inanimate object, so it's not worth anything, right? 

Now, why is that?  It still serves its function.  The creators still
did their work, and did the work it took to get to where they were when
they created it.  Whether you buy Windows XP in a store or install a
janky copy, your computer will still boot (maybe).  Whether you buy
music or fileshare it, it'll effect you in the same way.

So why do these people deserve to eat any less than the people who
design your cars?  The "mechanisms" surrounding car manufacture and
music sales alike are already in place.  On a grand scale, it's as
effortless (proportionate to cost/profit) to pop out a car from a
factory as it is to manufacture a CD.  It's the *thoughts* you're
buying when you spend your money.

I mean, if we can think of a better way to make money from art than
selling duplicates of it, more power to us- but that's the model on
which the world works for nearly everything that's bought and sold. 
It's unfortunate that those whose work is inherantly intangible get the
short end of the current stick.

Anyhow, cheers,
GeorgeC - biased-ass muso

http://sbc.yahoo.com

From sfraves-return-98444-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Feb 04 20:26:54 2003

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 28612 invoked by uid 1103); 4 Feb 2003 20:26:54 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 28597 invoked from network); 4 Feb 2003 20:26:54 -0000
Date: Tue, 4 Feb 2003 12:26:59 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: mike@atari
To: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20030204193815.95528.qmail@web80312.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302041154480.3060@atari>
References: <20030204193815.95528.qmail@web80312.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

>> Personally, I don't think that anyone has an inherent right to make a
>> living from the duplication of content they have created.
>
>Hmmm..

Don't take me out of context, I said: "Personally, I don't think that
anyone has an inherent right to make a living from the duplication of
content they have created. They have the right to prevent others from
doing so, thanks to the concept of copyright (something I'm totally in
support of, just not in its local bastardized form)."


>Say Honda is developing the '05 Civic.  They dream it up, they get the
>CAD down, they design the dies, they get the molds together.  So, now
>they've got all the tooling in place, and now they're manufacturing the
>Civics like mad.  Now, imagine if a lobbyist from the consumer sector
>started loudly proclaiming that car companies had no inherent right to
>charge any more for these cars than the cost of the raw materials,
>worker wages, machine upkeep, and power.

That's not what I said. I don't think Honda has an inherent right to make
money from cars, either. Creators of goods or services or products or
ideas risk their time, resources and energy for an expected return on
their investment. If Honda invests 5 years (the typical design ->
production cycle for a car) into their '05 Civic and it completely tanks,
then they lose money on it. They charge what they feel the market will
bear for a new product, and people either buy it or they don't - there's
no inherent right to profit at play, just an educated guess on what
consumers will want in 2005 and how much they might be willing to pay for
it.

Coming back to copyright, it exists in order to give a creator a limited
period of time during which they can choose how their ideas are put into
practice. You produce a track, and you own the copyright on that track
just by virtue of having created it.

Read more: http://www.nationalreview.com/comment/comment-bloom112202.asp

You can decide whether you want to bear production costs and sell it in CD
form yourself, transfer that copyright protection to a record label in
return for help with production costs and distribution, set up a
pay-per-download system on a website, or use it in a strictly live context
and recoup your productions costs from ticket sales. It's YOURS.

What copyright protection affords you is the guarantee that for a
reasonable period of time, no one can take away your right to decide how
you want to disseminate your creation to the world without your explicit
permission. There is no part of that bargain that guarantees that you
should be able to make a living from doing it - only that you have the
option to do so if you so choose and people are willing to pay.

The mistake of the DMCA is that it confuses legal and moral limitations
with technical ones (by treating copyright as a property of a piece of
content, rather than an agreement between its creator and its social
context), and that it rejects the value of a public domain in the creation
of new content, by favoring current owners of existing content over future
creators of new content.


>Oh, but art, music, software, poetry- in their basic form, they are
>ephemeral.  They exist only as ink on paper, data on a disc, a tune in
>your head.  Creating the best of these things takes no less skill, time,
>or work than making inanimate objects- yet listen to 'em crow when the
>creators want to make a living!

Listen to ME crow when publishers inflate the costs of these things, and
fail to address the realities of a demand curve in order to spend time and
money trampling on the public domain in the service of a distorted reality
where Mariah Carey CD's are worth $16.00.


>I mean, if we can think of a better way to make money from art than
>selling duplicates of it, more power to us- but that's the model on which
>the world works for nearly everything that's bought and sold.

It's a newer model than one might think. Few hundred years old, tops, and
that's only in the domain of the printed word. Marketable ways to
reproduce audio have only existed for ~100 years, less for video. Our
beloved record companies only really started to capitalize on this around
the 1940's or so.

                 http://www.saturn5.com/mike/contact.html

                "Freedom! Horrible, horrible freedom!"

urgently need to make alert phone calls to as many people as possible and 
get the word out on the street about Feb. 16. A.N.S.W.E.R. office near 24th 
street BART cross street is 21st. Two inexpensive parking lots nearby on 
21st between Mission St. and Valencia St. and on Mission St. between 20th 
and 19th. For info call 415-821-6545.

***

3.)SATURDAY FEB.8 MASS OUTREACH DAY FOR FEB. 16 MARCH. MAC CARTHUR BART 
PARKING LOT IN EAST BAY MEET AT 11 AM. IN SF MEET AT 2489 MISSION #24 AT 
11AM. YOU ARE URGENTLY NEEDED!!!There will be just one week left to 
mobilize. Together we can stop the war! For info call 415-821-6545.

***

4.)Come by the A.N.S.W.E.R. office anytime from 9am - 9pm to pick up 
leaflets and posters for the Feb. 16th marches. For info call 415-821-6545. 
Download flyers at http://www.internationalanswer.org/pdf/Feb16FlyerSF.pdf

***

5.)Volunteers are needed on the day of the big march February 16th. Help 
make it happen! Email 16vol@actionsf.org with your contact info. Thank you.

no one on this list needs to vote to impeach bush unless you happen to be a
member of the house of congress.

1. Article I, which creates the legislative branch of government, in Section
2, para. 4 provides:
that the House of Representatives... "shall have the sole power of
impeachment"

we can scream and yell all we want, but only the house can do anything about
it.

Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: vote to impeach bush [Pretty NRR]

on 2/4/03 3:32 PM, Brian - THUMP Radio at thump_radio_bmcd@hotmail.com
wrote:

> no one on this list needs to vote to impeach bush unless you happen to be a
> member of the house of congress.
> 
> 1. Article I, which creates the legislative branch of government, in Section
> 2, para. 4 provides:
> that the House of Representatives... "shall have the sole power of
> impeachment"
> 
> we can scream and yell all we want, but only the house can do anything about
> it.

Correct. That is why the web site (http://www.votetoimpeach.org) has users
fill out a form to encourage their representative to vote on impeachment.

I first saw the site earlier today and thought it was perhaps a scam since I
couldn't get reliable Whois information on it, nor had I heard about former
Attorney General Ramsey Clark's push for impeachment in the mainstream press
- you'd think someone of his stature would garner a mention in the network
news... 

So I researched it some more.  The domain belongs to International ANSWER,
so it's not a scam (though some on this list might find that debatable).
Content from both the Washington Post and NPR's web sites have coverage of
Ramsey's issues.  It's interesting, but from what I can find, it seems he's
been shooting for impeachment since Bush the Elder's ascension to the throne
in 1988. 

I think every President since Nixon has had calls for impeachment by some
group or party or whatever, so it's nothing all that novel. In fact, Nixon
resigned before the impeachment ever happened. Clinton was probably the
closest to it actually happening than anyone.  (To be technical, the term
only applies to the indictment of a president by the legislature - not the
ejection from office.)

  - omid :)


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
