>From: Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com>
>To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: vote to impeach bush [Pretty NRR]
>Date: Tue, 04 Feb 2003 15:28:30 -0800
>
>on 2/4/03 3:32 PM, Brian - THUMP Radio at thump_radio_bmcd@hotmail.com
>wrote:
>
> > no one on this list needs to vote to impeach bush unless you happen to 
>be a
> > member of the house of congress.
> >
> > 1. Article I, which creates the legislative branch of government, in 
>Section
> > 2, para. 4 provides:
> > that the House of Representatives... "shall have the sole power of
> > impeachment"
> >
> > we can scream and yell all we want, but only the house can do anything 
>about
> > it.
>
>Correct. That is why the web site (http://www.votetoimpeach.org) has users
>fill out a form to encourage their representative to vote on impeachment.
>
>I first saw the site earlier today and thought it was perhaps a scam since 
>I
>couldn't get reliable Whois information on it, nor had I heard about former
>Attorney General Ramsey Clark's push for impeachment in the mainstream 
>press
>- you'd think someone of his stature would garner a mention in the network
>news...
>
>So I researched it some more.  The domain belongs to International ANSWER,
>so it's not a scam (though some on this list might find that debatable).
>Content from both the Washington Post and NPR's web sites have coverage of
>Ramsey's issues.  It's interesting, but from what I can find, it seems he's
>been shooting for impeachment since Bush the Elder's ascension to the 
>throne
>in 1988.
>
>I think every President since Nixon has had calls for impeachment by some
>group or party or whatever, so it's nothing all that novel. In fact, Nixon
>resigned before the impeachment ever happened. Clinton was probably the
>closest to it actually happening than anyone.  (To be technical, the term
>only applies to the indictment of a president by the legislature - not the
>ejection from office.)
>
>   - omid :)
>
>

not

> >> shouldn't art be about the quality of the product, and not making
money? I
> >> don't think Michelangelo had dollar signs in his eyes when he covertly
> >> performed autopsies.
> >
> >We do not live in the age of patron saints anymore.  If an artist cannot
> >be funded through direct payment by the public for their art, they cannot
> >live.  It's that simple, assuming all they do is art and they don't have
> >a day job ;)
>
> I'm not sure I agree - in a recent discussion of potential ways to fund
> music in a post-RIAA world, I heard that most broadway plays are funded in
> an arts-patron model, with small groups of rich investors putting up money
> and taking a personal financial risk for a play based on its probability
> of success (think Bullets Over Broadway). I think this is a completely
> viable model for covering studio costs, etc. Seems to me that the biggest
> complaint I usually hear about the relationship between artists and labels
> is the way that labels tend to really rape the artist on their initial
> recording contract - having third party funding involved may help lessen
> that, I think?
>

here is something to attach multiple meanings to:

there are a lot of cool events coming up to celebrate valentine's day...how will you be playing it out this year? here is something NOT to do:

i am quite odd in appearance...someone who is also quite odd in appearance approached me yesterday (the canvasing is starting EARLY this year, EARLY)...he came up to approximately my waist in height, had one stable eye and one perpetually wandering one and a very slow drawling voice.. he says, "i like your hair...it is such a nice day...you look nice with your nice hair...why don't you tell me about yourself?" i told him that i am tired and that it was very nice that he would say such a thing to me, but that i did not feel like talking, and that i was on my way somewhere, and then he says, "i am looking for a valentine's date, and i thought since i like your hair...etc...etc....etc...." i DID NOT laugh my ass off until several hours later...i was good. i was very good. :)

At 11:13 PM 2/3/2003 -0800, Mike Migurski wrote:
> >> shouldn't art be about the quality of the product, and not making money? I
> >> don't think Michelangelo had dollar signs in his eyes when he covertly
> >> performed autopsies.
> >
> >We do not live in the age of patron saints anymore.  If an artist cannot
> >be funded through direct payment by the public for their art, they cannot
> >live.  It's that simple, assuming all they do is art and they don't have
> >a day job ;)
>
>I'm not sure I agree - in a recent discussion of potential ways to fund
>music in a post-RIAA world, I heard that most broadway plays are funded in
>an arts-patron model, with small groups of rich investors putting up money
>and taking a personal financial risk for a play based on its probability
>of success (think Bullets Over Broadway). I think this is a completely
>viable model for covering studio costs, etc. Seems to me that the biggest
>complaint I usually hear about the relationship between artists and labels
>is the way that labels tend to really rape the artist on their initial
>recording contract - having third party funding involved may help lessen
>that, I think?
>

This is the basic model for funding all new ideas/ventures, both business 
and artistic.  Investors risk capital in the hope of a return on that 
investment.

Once one has investors, however, one loses compete creative and other 
control.  Michelangelo had to modify his vision to accommodate  the needs 
of his patrons.

Very few artists, then and now, make a living out of artistic 
creation.  Most artists I know are driven above all things to share a 
vision;  monetary return is secondary.  If one launches into music or art 
with the focus on creation of personal wealth one will create nothing of 
value IMO.

One of the most important developments in the past twenty years has been 
the "democratization" of artistic creation through the use of new 
technologies.  Take film, for example.  In order to do any serious work in 
this medium in the sixties one required hundreds of thousands of dollars in 
investment to begin.  Now, using digital recording equipment and a computer 
hardware/software editing rig those desiring to make film need invest a few 
thousand for a low budget IF.  This might be funded from a full-time job or 
non-intrusive relatives and friends.

Certainly musical have much benefited from new technologies.  When the big 
corporate recording companies decided "disco" dance music was no longer 
viable, and new dance product was no longer readily available, those 
passionate about dance music turned to drum machines, synthesizers and the 
like -- new technologies -- to create what was to become house music, the 
first EDM genre, at a cost that was dramatically lower than previously 
required for producing vinyl recordings.

Now most high school kids have the hardware and software available to do 
basic remixing and new music creation.  These creations can be circulated 
via MP3 files, CDs, and other inexpensive media.  Soon, vinyl cutting 
machines will be available to those with higher end home studios.

Publishing, visual arts -- for all creative work, technology has changed 
the field of play forever.

It is here, with these newly democratized art forms, that true innovation 
now arises and will continue to flourish in future.  Just as street fashion 
is the origin of corporate clothing and other design, new and exciting art 
forms will increasingly arise from people who are not 
"professionals."  What is a professional these days anyhow?  A marketing 
manager?:)

Large corporations, to my mind, are the enemies of true innovation.  This 
is particularly true of the music and film industries.  The corporate, 
market-data driven mind sets have created nothing of great value here in 
many years.  Why anyone would bother to download most of that corporate 
shit is beyond me.

Most of my downloads these days consist of freely-shared EDM cuts offered 
from people all over the world,   I so believe, however, that I should pay 
for the vinyl I spin.  I'm not one of those people who go to the record 
store, create a list of new releases, and download them for use with Final 
Scratch for free.  I understand how little most of these small labels and 
artists make and I feel I should pay when I use their work.

But the record companies aren't concerned with me or EDM.  They wish to 
blame their failure to innovate on downloads.  We are all to pay for their 
lack of vision and corporate constipation.  Won't work.  Art has been set 
free -- democratized -- by technology.  The new "socialism."  People are 
getting together, forming collectives and other entities to share costs and 
resources.  Raving, that is, the art of throwing liberating parties, often 
by collectives, bypasses the money-making model of the club for the not for 
profit motive of artistic creation for the love of sharing a vision with 
others.  Although corporations want a piece of all this action, they just 
can't seem to take off their mind-constricting ties long enough to 
understand what's going down here.

Love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one 
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken
--=====================_7554350==_.ALT--

From sfraves-return-98481-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Feb 05 10:04:27 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-98481-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 32789 invoked by uid 1103); 5 Feb 2003 10:04:24 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 32775 invoked from network); 5 Feb 2003 10:04:24 -0000
Date: Wed, 5 Feb 2003 02:04:25 -0800 (PST)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
cc: Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20030204193815.95528.qmail@web80312.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0302050032120.7808-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....


That's nice.  I still don't want a mandatory signature algorhythm built
into my computer.  I don't want another piece of copy protection on there.
It's bad enough when I get artists from France visiting and I can't play
thier fucking DVDs on my notebook.  They authored the thing, they want me
to see it, I want to see it... oh, sorry... you are region trying to play
this on a region what-the-shit-out-luck-fuck-off player.  Imagine that
times ten and you've got a taste of what it's like to run a system that
only allows signed apps running signed content.

The DMCA is scary and Palladium is scarier.  File players that mandate
signatories are shit.  Would you buy a set of plates that only allowed you
to eat KFC on them?  It might be a nice idea if it wasn't Microsoft at the
helm, but they are.  Few the product that MS has unveiled that didn't end
up serving MS at the expense of others.  I was in the business when MS
released MS-word (amipro/word perfect knockoff including keystroke
compatibility modes), Excel (Lotus 123/framework), MS-Money (almost
verbatim knockoff of Quicken), Windows Media Player (Quicktime anyone?),
DirectX (apple's direct draw + SGI's OpenGL), IE (wow, netscape with
operating system level optimization), inclusion of then popular 3rd party
utilities in DOS5/6/Windows 95 (doubledisk, defrag, memory managers),
MS-Java (took a licensed Sun technology that could only be freely used if
it complied to Sun's open spec... and of course started deviating from it
from day one), Windows NT (and all it's descendants, are actually based on
a POSIX kernel... aka unix style multitasking / security / input-output
engine) etc and don't even get me started on C#, .NET, attempts at
subscription based O/S pricing with XP and all the other recent extensions
of their policy of copy, undersell and conquer (kids, for those of you who
slept through turn of the 19-20th century american history, this is
monopoly 101).

If actions speak louder than words, Microsoft doesn't give a FUCK about
intellectual property, their consumers or ethics unless it's spelled
ETHIC$.

The Palladium PC is as close as I ever want to get to having George
Orwell's vision of telescreens brought to life.  The only part he got
wrong is that it wasn't the government that was in control, but rather
large corporations with enough money to bend government and consensus
public opinion into a pretzel.  Where you want to go today doesn't
matter... it's all about where MS wants to take you and what they can get
for it.

Within years of that product's release and established viablity... expect
to see cost down versions of Windows that *only* allow playback of signed
documents of certain types (and oh how happy you'll be when you upgrade to
the 'media developer' version of windoze for *only* a $100 more)... expect
to see unsigned artists completely and utterly fucked... expect
subscription pricing model operating systems... expect to see renegade
file players creating a shitload of new formats to circumvent the issue...
expect the DMCA expanded to include 'suspect' configuration of
routers/networks/etc...

The solution?

DEMAND SUPPORT FOR LINUX & FREEBSD by software and hardware vendors (even
Darwin/Apple's osx is a good go between if you want ease of use and has
great support from the hardware/software communities).  If you know it,
tell you're friends about it and take the time to take a stand for freedom
of information.  Explain why there are many more advantages to "free"
operating systems than just no up front cost.  Add to that a free office
compatible suite, superior networking, games, performance, etc...  and
it's hard to believe that people don't at least consider it.  Shit, I've
made tracks on a linux box.  There's GIMP if you want to do graphics.
It's a direct lineage to the operating systems that gave us tcp/ip, ipsec,
file security, scripting, individual user environments, etc.  Most of them
come configured with perl, gcc (which allows you to create applications in
fortran, c, c++ and a host of other stuff), apache, ftp, ssh, kerberos,
locale support, and all that other stuff microsoft keeps bringing to the
market years after it works elsewhere.  And you can hack the piss out of
it to make it suit your needs without violating some stupid licensing
agreement you didn't even read (did you know that technically, modifying
your registry is against the default MS-EULA?).  Sound like too much?
Fine then, just get the RedHat disks and install it.  In less than an hour
you'll have all that stuff and you don't need to worry about any of it...
just point and click like you would on anything else.

Even if you are not mechanically inclined, you would not buy a car without
a hood that actually opened.  Let alone one that didn't speed, only would
change lanes after you had used the blinker first, or made you take a
breathalyzer before starting the engine.

Refuse to let anybody assume you are guilty until proven innocent.

I know both sides of this well.  I am a computer technician of multiple
disciplines, a DJ who plays other people's music and collects money for
it, a recording artist (new release coming out on Refined real soon
through Prime distribution!), a novice software developer, and legal owner
of a few hundred cds and licensed user of the software I use for making
music.

When you put everything else aside, the crisis we have is an ethical one,
theft sucks.

I have a serious issue with anonymous/mass file sharing, but I don't see a
problem with sending a friend of mine a copy of a song that made my day
when I hear they aren't having a good time.  In a time before the
internet, I might have sent it to them via mail.  When my neighbor asks to
use my lawn mower, I don't have a problem with that either.  Imagine if
you lent them your mower and it didn't work in anybody's yard but yours?

-&e->--- Mike Migurski <mike@saturn5.com> wrote:
-&e->> >How is an artist in the digital realm ever to make a living when his
-&e->> >works can be freely copied and redistributed by *anyone*?
-&e->>
-&e->> That's a completely orthogonal issue.
-&e->>
-&e->> Personally, I don't think that anyone has an inherent right to make a
-&e->> living from the duplication of content they have created.

really?  as a developer/artist/designer specializing in digital media
formats, you are *SO* in a glass house on that one.  before you get mad,
let me add badass to the beginning of the above career description.  :)

I *should* be able to make the call whether a track I wrote is a numbered
original or a public domain gift and charge accordingly.  Taking something
that I made and saying it's yours to do with as you please is theft.

This issue is not new.  It's been covered.  By patent law, by copyright,
by licensing, by publisher's rights and organizations like
ascap/bmi/copyright control.  Hell, in music, I can't play a cover tune at
a coffee shop without forking up a few pennies to the publishing house
representing the original work, even if it's for free... why?  Cause if
it's at a place of business, my performance of their piece might have
lured people in.

What needs to be revised is the law pertaining to it.  Not operating
systems.  Get caught sharing a file to one friend, you're liable for
treble damages (the cost of the track or whatever) and a non-criminal
conviction for each download (aka no big deal).  Host a site with 1000
possible simultaneous connects with a criZzaX of Adobe Photoshop on it,
and you'll see that go away with even a modicum of proper enforcement
(especially if anonymous sharing is treated criminally).

Simply divert all the funds going to combat drug crime (remember it's ok
to take drugs if you feel bad to feel better, but if you feel ok and you
take drugs to feel better you're a felon), and put them into a more real
issue... that many people today feel somehow entitled to the work of
others at no cost regardless of the author's intentions for the work.

Steps *should* be taken, piracy is commonplace to the point that many
people laugh at me for paying for software or ask me why I bought it when
they could have flowed me a copy (and then they ask my RTFM questions..
*sigh*)... but the measures being taken by wintelamdwhatever are not in
the best interests of anybody but market momentum and those who benefit
from it and that *can* be swayed given a better alternative (and it
exists).

was that a rant...?
andyw


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

To: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR Palladium, M$, MPAA, RIAA and Intel....

>-&e->> Personally, I don't think that anyone has an inherent right to make a
>-&e->> living from the duplication of content they have created.
>
>really?  as a developer/artist/designer specializing in digital media
>formats, you are *SO* in a glass house on that one.  before you get mad,
>let me add badass to the beginning of the above career description.  :)
>
>I *should* be able to make the call whether a track I wrote is a numbered
>original or a public domain gift and charge accordingly.  Taking something
>that I made and saying it's yours to do with as you please is theft.

Agh, people keep skipping over the word "inherent" and thinking that I'm
advocating a public domain free-for-all. All I'm saying is that no one has
the right to make a profit on their idea, they just have the right to
DECIDE how the idea is going to be used - for sale, for freebies, for
whatever, for a limited time. The RIAA is confusing the two to its
advantage, and as a result so is everyone else.

Otherwise, great rant. :D

---------------------------------------------------------------------
michal migurski- contact info and pgp key:
                 http://www.saturn5.com/mike/contact.html

                "Freedom! Horrible, horrible freedom!"




---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From: "SE/30" <grindingbassline@hotmail.com>

X-MIMEOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1106
Message-ID: <OE65bThA9QRmzeyNtqM000027ab@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 05 Feb 2003 19:42:33.0558 (UTC) FILETIME=[BA3E3F60:01C2CD4E]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Looking for RAM - stealing

open question to all the girls (and guys i guess) who worked in retail when they were in highschool
:

how many of you got arrested for stealing merchandise ?

was it pleasent ?

i didn't think so.

retail stores have strict policies that enforce prosecution for stealing.  but just because private
organizations don't, it doesn't mean that it is okay.  i once had a touchy situation where an
employee had stolen a laptop and another time when someone else had stolen an LCD projector... both
times i handled it by bringing it to the attention of upper management and handling it on a personal
level inside the organization.  both times the individual's reputation was tarnished to the point
that each left the company within 3 mos.  so i guess you people theiving from work have that going
for you... they will probably not prosecute *if* you get caught but it still doesn't justify it.

stealing is stealing.  i would no more steal stuff from work as i would steal a dj's needles at a
party (which seems to be happening all to often lately.)  or how about Terry's laptop that got
stollen last year at a small intimate bar that had maybe 30 people in it ?  i'll bet that if you
just ASKED your IT guys, they would GIVE you that old ram that was laying around.  why do you people
beleive that it is okay to take something that IS NOT YOURS ?

this all goes back to that post a week or so back about why there are no venues willing to open up
to the raver community... because many so-called "ravers" are disrespectful.  i keep waiting for the
"respectful ravers" to make that next evolutionary move in american dialect and start calling
themselves something else in order to disassociate themselves with the current publicly-percieved
"raver" community.

if you think  you deserve a raise, and they won't give you one, go find another job !  after you
re-examine the situation, maybe you *are* being paid accordingly and that you should just buck up
and foot the whopping 20 bux for the frivolous item you want (or ask a friendly group of friends for
help :)

-=dave

>organizations don't, it doesn't mean that it is okay.  i once had a touchy 
>situation where an
>employee had stolen a laptop and another time when someone else had stolen 
>an LCD projector... both
>times i handled it by bringing it to the attention of upper management and 
>handling it on a personal
>level inside the organization.  both times the individual's reputation was 
>tarnished to the point
>that each left the company within 3 mos.  so i guess you people theiving 
>from work have that going

I know that casting your vote to impeach Bush is not going to make it happen. 
however, expressing your disapproval is a voluntary action that expresses 
your feelings on that particular matter. For many, people want to help make a 
difference, but they do not know how. That is why I send those forwards from 
internationalanswer. Many people have emailed me and told me that they went 
to the march because I told them about it. Very rewarding. I mean, some of 
you may not agree with it, some may want nothing to do with it, and I respect 
those opinions. For the rest of the people who do not want to see a possible 
Gulf War II, I send these for them. You can clown on me for sending them, but 
all I am trying to do is make a difference in this world...if that's a 
crime...indict me
Don't forget PLUR people,
Britty

--part2_12f.2256d2ec.2b738413_boundary

sleep deprived psychosis is my favorite time of day,
shawn

Subject: [sfraves] Re: vote to impeach bush [Now very RR]

on 2/6/03 10:18 AM, Kevin James at djkevinjames@yahoo.com wrote:

> Listen up you fucking jack ass, this is a RAVE related list.

If there's anything I've learned, raves and politics are inherently related.
For many people, raving goes beyond music and partying - it is a culture and
community that is affected by the policies that shape society at large.  As
such, many ravers are rightfully concerned with political decisions beyond
the little scope of the "party" scene, as they will ultimately affect how we
carry ourselves, what we are permitted to do, etc.

While the Bush administration's policies may seem to have little to do with
the hard house 12" you pick up in the record bin at your local store, its
philosophies and attitudes may very well end up affecting whether or not you
will have the right to play that vinyl for a crowd in the foreseeable
future.

> Grow the fuck up and learn to support your country, or you can
> always move the fuck out.

Grow up? Who's the one virtually sticking his finger in his ears and going
"la la la la la - i can't hear you - la la la la la."

The practice of the First Amendment right to free speech is in itself a form
of support for this country. Much more so than the blind acceptance of the
words of one man without the "mandate of the people." The wish to censor
others, however, is something more fit for the likes of Baghdad or
Pyongyang. (Or the Ashcroft residence, if Iraq or North Korea's captials are
too exotic or too hard for you to identify.)

   - omid

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

support your country???

This country was built from revolution against some of the same policies
that bush has implamented... Our country is set up so that we can get people
who we dont like out of office. But this is hard now that the balence of
power has disapeared.. Not even the Supreme court can have a say becasue the
100's of people who have been imprisoned under the patriot act cant apeal
becasue they dont get a trial...
The rave began as an underground form of social expression and DONT FORGET
IT. Music and politics are one, and never before rock in the 60's has this
been as true as in the rave scene. Besides, the political options of people
who are going to raves or promoting/producing raves is important, especially
now that alot of groups have been invouled in supporting no-profs and the
like. I say KEEP IT UP.. even if you dont agree with me at all I want to
hear what you have to say, because maybe *gasp* I'm wrong..

Subject: Re: Fwd: [sfraves] Fwd: vote to impeach bush [Pretty NRR]

And now..


Just because I can


RAVE ACT RE-INTRODUCED IN TWO FORMS!

As we announced earlier this month, portions of the RAVE ACT appeared hidden
in another bill..

Full Text http://www.dancesafe.org/new/articles/s22.pdf

TAKE ACTION http://www.emdef.org/s22/action.html

Now, the RAVE Act, has become S226, the "Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation
Act"

More Devious, and now with backing from the Coalition or Liscensed Beverage
Association, this bill hopes to end any sort of event which could even
concievably be associated with drugs. Same Story, New Packaging. This is
getting ridiculous, its time to tell our government that you cannot hope to
stop drug use by attacking a culture.

Full Text and Analysis http://www.emdef.org/s226/

TAKE ACTION http://www.emdef.org/s226/action.html

Subject: Re: [sfraves] a case for NRR (was: Fwd: vote to impeach bush [Pretty NRR])

Everyone just chill out. The purpose of the "NRR" subject tag is to
allow people that aren't interested in non-rave-related discussions to
delete messages without having to read them. If you don't like it, set
up a mail filter.

We all identify as "ravers", and many of us see the list simply as a
general discussion forum within that context. If we were to start
prohibiting "off-topic" posts, I really don't think many people would
stick around... The list offers very little *actual* rave-related
subject matter besides BSP's, anyway.

else's rules, while quietly playing by your own."

Yes, but you know what the beauty of half of those people not knowing what is 
going on? They want to know. They have a desire to learn about the flip side 
of government and expressing their discontent in forms of mass (yet peaceful) 
protests. These people may not know a whole lot about what is going on, but 
they came out their for a reason...a desire of knowledge. I think it is 
absolutely beautiful. I didn't mean for all of you to get pissed and scream 
at each other over a government issue. I mean, ravers are supposed to be 
friends...I love all my raver friends. And you want to know where i was 
during the whole Clinton scandal thing? *sigh* I'm gonna hear about this 
one...I was still a kid. I didn't really know too much about it, and at the 
time I  was a minor. I have conservative republican parents (might I add i 
RESPECT their decisions in supporting Bush), and they wouldn't let me doing 
anything political. now i have moved away and am an adult. I can make my own 
choices...and slowly, my parents are learning to accept that. I guess what 
I'm trying to say is tolerance is key here. Jack, I respect your opinions and 
in return, i ask you respect mine. Its not that hard. If you don't want hear 
about the war or anything, just delete my messages :)
Thanks
Britty
True, but, I see your actions as inciting a negative reaction. Half the 
people that are marching don't know what the f**k is going on. I don't know 
myself 100% of what is going on. That is why we rely on a centralized 
government, whom we voted in, to take the responsibility of; (a) finding the 
correct information & (b) making proper decisions on that information. And I 
have to say, even with the internet, there are still some things that the 
common public, you and I, are not as they say "privy to".

I was there on that Saturday march down market street to "reverse protest". 
I just happened to be there having lunch. See how much you guys affected my 
life, lol? True, I was probably the only one, however seeing all these 
confused americans with their kids I think was the most sickening.

People are so blinded by this 2 party system and these negative lies 
concerning George W, that they will do anything they don't find 
liberal/"open minded". You see any protests in Indiana? I believe in PLUR as 
much as anybody. But, that has a flip side; I have no respect for others who 
choose to threaten my way of life, or have openly expressed ideas of 
destruction towards my home land. How do these people who wish us harm so us 
their peace, love, unity, and respect? By building bombs? Flying planes into 
buildings? Kidnapping American tourists in foreign lands? Burning our flag?

You know what the funniest observation I have had about this whole thing? 
The way nobody said anything when billy nilly clinton went to way in the 
Anglo-Saxon Former Yugoslavian region, which was really only an attempt to 
cover up his then infamous sex scandal.

Where was your international group then when clinton was helping murder 
people and using your money to drop bombs?

GOTTA LOVE PLUR.

--
DJ Jack 7RIUMPH

--part1_191.14e183b4.2b74123b_boundary--

Armageddon started. Out of all of the countries in the world we seemed to be
the only one concerned with Iraq. It's very reassuring to know that Bush has
stake in the oil their country produces. I think in the future they should
only allow people in office who have no ties to major companies that would
benefit from starting a war and taking over that counties business. You can
keep believing every word out of that mans mouth, but as far as I'm
concerned he is a bold face liar.

Nick
http://www.core-nrg.net
http://www.hardcoreforthepeople.com
AIM: oburikhan

At 10:18 AM 2/6/2003 -0800, Kevin James wrote:

>Listen up you fucking jack ass, this is a RAVE related list. If you want 
>to talk politics then join a political mailing list. I shouldn't have to 
>delete your bullshit. Grow the fuck up and learn to support your country, 
>or you can always move the fuck out.
>Kj

Wow...peace, love, unity and respect in action.  Thanks for your refreshing 
and moving response, Kevin.  I'm sure we all learned something here.

Further, discussion of the moral implications of war is certainly, to my 
mind, "rave-related."  Time we all looked at our beliefs.  Many of us 
sincerely believe a war of aggression -- pre-emptive warfare -- is immoral 
under any circumstances.  Most of the Christian churches seem to hold this 
belief, although this position seems to have been overwhelmed in recent 
discussion of this issue.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: [sfraves] bsp> ANCESTOR this Sat Feb 8th in SantaCruz (all ages) :.

hey southbayers, this should be a pretty good party...  tom has been
involved in the scene down there for many years and is a real creative
fellow.  he's been working real hard on the decor and themes to create
a tribal, oldschool feelin event... here's the rest of the info:

------ - - - --- - - -  -   -      -       -   - -    -- - 

    .:~ANCESTOR~:.

a Tom L-G production

Saturday, February 8th 2003
9pm to 4am
418 Front St. Santa Cruz

-in memory of Gabriel Caesar-

An aural and visual experience featuring DJ's, and an art exhibit
displaying photography, sculpture, and  paintings by local artists.

DJ's:

Cricket (aka Tektrix, Sister, SF)
Clairity (Scatter/Impulse SF) vs. J-Bot (Cloudfactory/Impulse, SF)
Tom L-G (Ancestor/ Rain Dance, SC)
Rob Monroy (Back to Basics/ Rain Dance, SC)
DJ Toonz (Ancestor, SC)
Broccoli (SF)

WHAT'S  ANCESTOR?

DJ'ing is more than the selecting of music or the mixing of records, it
is a philosophy, a way of life, a craft to be mastered, and ultimately
it is an art form. This is an event created specifically for the
purpose of combined creative _expression in the form of multi-media. A
way to connect the past with the present through the act of creating
forms of music, dance, and visual arts. Come dance and create with us
on this important night, invoke the strength and endurance of your
ancestors whoever they were and wherever they came from. 


ADVANCE TICKETS WILL BE SOLD @ STREETLIGHT RECORDS 
$8.00 IN ADVANCE (plus service charge)
$10.00 AT THE DOOR

COME HANG OUT WITH US
BEGIN TO HEAL

the ancestors are calling,
listen to the drums...........

---- --------- -    --    - --    - --      -     ----- -- - -

thanks,

james

   I am sorry but just like my language has offended some of you, the existence of this thread on this list has offended me. I 'm sorry but this thread has no relevance on this list and while I may be able to delete it, I SHOULDN'T HAVE TOO! 
There is nothing rave related about it. Is this the sfraves list or the sfsaywhateverthefuckyouwant list? I didn't sign on to this list to hear peoples oppinions about Bush, Iraq or politics that do not DIRECTLY affect the rave scene. I should not have to unsub from the list and miss out on info that I might actually want to know because I don't want anti BUSH propaganda littering my inbox. I dont spam people with info about my beliefs and I sure the hell don't want people from this list spamming my inbox with CRAP like this thread.
Kj
   
 Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:At 10:18 AM 2/6/2003 -0800, Kevin James wrote:

>Listen up you fucking jack ass, this is a RAVE related list. If you want 
>to talk politics then join a political mailing list. I shouldn't have to 
>delete your bullshit. Grow the fuck up and learn to support your country, 
>or you can always move the fuck out.
>Kj

Wow...peace, love, unity and respect in action. Thanks for your refreshing 
and moving response, Kevin. I'm sure we all learned something here.

Further, discussion of the moral implications of war is certainly, to my 
mind, "rave-related." Time we all looked at our beliefs. Many of us 
sincerely believe a war of aggression -- pre-emptive warfare -- is immoral 
under any circumstances. Most of the Christian churches seem to hold this 
belief, although this position seems to have been overwhelmed in recent 
discussion of this issue.

Love,

Apollo

look Kevin, it sounds like all you want are the BSP's... so this is what you
do...

1) setup a mail filter within yahoo to move all emails with "BSP" in the
subject line into a folder named "BSP"... set this rule as the highest
priority within yahoo... you will still need to create a folder named "BSP"

2) setup a mail filter to move all emails with SFRAVES (or even just "NRR")
into the Trash... set this rule as the second priority within yahoo...

and wah lah! no more anti-bush propaganda!

Timothy

some things have happened in the cat world lately...bear with me, i PROMISE, the hot sex is coming up really soon...:)....a few weeks ago, a small cat wandered into where i live...it wandered in, and i didn't see it leave, but i haven't seen it since, so i have been presuming that it is gone, however, every time i enter, i always call out in a little voice that i use to talk to animals: "any extra kitties here? are there any extra kitties hiding out? any extra kitties?"..i don't want to be the preverbial cat woman...the one who collects the cats and secludes herself...that is why i go out without cats and have affairs with people. :)....on my way out the door today, a small, gray kitten came up to me though....i stopped, and it walked right up to me, and stood extra close to my leg like they do sometimes...it just stood there all pressed up against my leg looking around at the world before it wandered off again. i will try not to worry about the little thing. we are all surogates, whether we want to be or not at times...i love the kitties....i love the boys too....when they are nice and not covered with fleas. :)

wasn't allowed to proceed with the routing of the Iraqi government.   Not to
mention it was Bush and Regan that helped train and arm Bin Laden in the
first place... its all a never ending cycle of violence.  In the Clinton
era, yes we helped out in Yugoslavia, maybe we should've focused on the
issues in Afghanistan, both were bad at that time and neither had anything
to do with the US.  Sure, looking back its easy to say we should've disarmed
bin Laden but how do you route a terrorist network that we were still
somewhat allies with as well as going into a country with a very bad human
rights policy without starting the holy war then.  Back even further when we
were alllies with Iraq against Iran, Saddam wasn't that bad a guy to us.
Starting to see a pattern here?  We need to stop sticking our hands where
they don't belong unless maybe asked for because all we've been getting from
the middle east is dog bites back attacks.

At 07:29 PM 2/6/2003 -0800, Rayn wrote:
>No, we backed out in 91 because of the fact we got our oil back..  Bush
>wasn't allowed to proceed with the routing of the Iraqi government.   Not to
>mention it was Bush and Regan that helped train and arm Bin Laden in the
>first place... its all a never ending cycle of violence.  In the Clinton
>era, yes we helped out in Yugoslavia, maybe we should've focused on the
>issues in Afghanistan, both were bad at that time and neither had anything
>to do with the US.  Sure, looking back its easy to say we should've disarmed
>bin Laden but how do you route a terrorist network that we were still
>somewhat allies with as well as going into a country with a very bad human
>rights policy without starting the holy war then.  Back even further when we
>were alllies with Iraq against Iran, Saddam wasn't that bad a guy to us.
>Starting to see a pattern here?  We need to stop sticking our hands where
>they don't belong unless maybe asked for because all we've been getting from
>the middle east is dog bites back attacks.
>
>-Rayn

What we are really missing in this country is an understanding of other 
cultures and basic history.  There has been an ongoing conflict between the 
West and Arab nations for thousands of years.  The Persians (modern Iran, 
Iraq and other Mid-Eastern states) had a war with the Greeks that lasted 
hundreds of years.  Athens was burned to the ground.  Alexander the Great 
unified the Greek states and conquered Persia.  In Iran Alexander is still 
remembered as the "horned one" who ended the Persian Empire.

When Mohammed died the former Persian nations united and sacked the Eastern 
Roman Empire, taking Constantinople and bringing to an end Christian-Roman 
rule in what is now Turkey.

Then we had the religious wars.  Crusades.  Arabs invading 
Europe.  Christians invading Arab lands.  Most recently, the Ottoman Empire.

Much of the drama in the Middle East is really the result of the decisions 
made by the Western colonial powers in the nineteenth and twentieth 
centuries.  Many "nation states," including Iraq, were created with 
boundaries that did not represent any tribal or cultural needs.  The 
horrors in Palestine began when the English decided to create a Jewish 
state there during WW II.  Had there been no anti-semitisim in Europe and 
the United States at the time the Palestinians would still have there 
homeland intact.

One could go on.  Nothing...nothing is simple here.  Arab culture is 
ancient and very sophisticated, and I believe the roots of terrorism and 
conflict here lie in the desire of this culture to be received with respect 
and equality in the community of nations.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: [sfraves] Hangover Rating System

--0-1278464716-1044589638=:41870
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


This is hella funny. Not that I associate anything with it.....Well there was all those Thursday Mornings for two years!! right all you old skool Stereophonik/ Killa Subz Guys..

Enjoy

Keith Edwards

PS the Buzz on the street -----Stereophonik---- Will return soon!!!!!!!!!

 

 

 

One Star Hangover (*) 
No pain. No real feeling of illness. You're able to function relatively 
well. However, you are still parched. You can drink 5 sodas and still feel  this way. For some reason, you are craving a steak & fries. 


 Two Star Hangover (**) 

 
 No pain, but something is definitely amiss. You may look okay, but you 
have 
the mental capacity of a staple gun. The coffee you are chugging is only 
 increasing your rumbling gut, which is still tossing around the fruity 
 pancake from the 3:00 AM, Waffle House excursion. There is some definite 
 havoc being wreaked upon your bowels. 
 
Three Star Hangover (***) 
Slight headache. Stomach feels crappy. You are definitely not productive. 
 Anytime a girl walks by you gag because her perfume reminds you of the 
flavored schnapps shots your alcoholic friends dared you to drink. Life 
would be better right now if you were home in your bed watching Lucy 
reruns. 
 You've had 4 cups of coffee, a gallon of water, 3 iced teas and a diet 
Coke 
 --- yet you haven't peed once. 


 

 

Four Star Hangover (****) 



 Life sucks. Your head is throbbing. You can't speak too quickly or else 
you 
 might puke. Your boss has already lambasted you for being late and has 
given 
 you a lecture for reeking of booze. You wore nice clothes, but that can't 
 hide the fact that you only shaved one side of your face. (For the ladies, 
 it looks like you put your make-up on while riding the bumper cars.) Your 
 eyes look like one big red vein, and even your hair hurts. Your sphincter 
is 
 in perpetual spasm, and the first of about five shits you take during the 
day brings water to the eyes of everyone who enters the bathroom. 


 Five Star Hangover, (*****) 
 You have a second heartbeat in your head, which is actually annoying the employee who sits in the next cube. Vodka vapor is seeping out of every pore  and making you dizzy. You still have toothpaste crust in the corners of your  mouth from brushing your teeth in an attempt to get the remnants of the poop fairy out. Your body has lost the ability to generate saliva so your tongue is suffocating you. You don't have the foggiest idea who the hell the stranger was passed out in your bed this morning. Any attempt to defecate results in a fire hose like discharge of alcohol-scented fluid with a rare  'floater' thrown in. The sole purpose of this 'floater' seems to be to  splash the toilet water all over your ass. Death sounds pretty good about 
 right now.... 

> THINGS THAT ARE DIFFICULT TO SAY WHEN YOU'RE DRUNK: 
> Indubitably 
> Innovative 
> Preliminary 
> Proliferation 
> Cinnamon 
> 
> 
>

> Oh, I just couldn't. No one wants to hear me sing 
> Sorry I'm being such a jackass

control

fields in
the North which are under Kurdish control).   Yes, we definately should have
focused on Afghanistan and let Europe deal with Yugoslavia, where were the
liberals then shouting "no war in Yogoslavia"?  There were not any.  It's ok
when a democrat decides to use armed force lol.  We were allies with Bin
Laden during Clintons tenure?  Really....b.s.  In other words, Clinton
wussed
out because it was hard, typical Clinton.  We were never allies with Iraq
btw,
that's just not true at all.   We aided Iraq to the point that the Iran Iraq
war
was a stalemate, which if i'm also not mistaken was achieved.  We easily
could have aided to the point that Iraq won, we did not.  If we did not aid
then Iran would have won, we kept the balance of power between them,
that was our goal.

  ---This isn't 1965.  We have a very good understanding of other =
cultrures and basic history.  If it was 1965 i'd agree with your =
statement, but it isn't.

  There has been an ongoing conflict between the West and Arab nations =
for thousands of years. =20

  ---This is also incorrect.  There has been conflict between the West =
and Arab world since the dawn of the Renaissance, but not much before =
that.  One word describes why the Muslim world (let's hit the nail on =
the head here, it's really a Christian / Muslim thing, not a Western / =
Arab thing) dislikes the "West" and that word begins with J. =20

  The Persians (modern Iran, Iraq and other Mid-Eastern states) had a =
war with the Greeks that lasted hundreds of years.  Athens was burned to =
the ground.  Alexander the Great unified the Greek states and conquered =
Persia.  In Iran Alexander is still remembered as the "horned one" who =
ended the Persian Empire.

  ---The Persians are Iranians only, any Iraqi's or other middle-eastern =
arabs hear you call them Persian they're likely to chop your hands off =
lol!  Also, Alexander may be remembered as the "horned one" and the =
Persian empire may have shrunk in that time period, but those =
responsible for ending (and I mean really ending to the point it never =
recovered, ever) the Persian Empire are actually the Mongols, and that =
was some 1,500 years later around 1253 A.D.  That was the end of the =
great Persian Empire and don't let anyone tell you otherwise.

  Then we had the religious wars.  Crusades.  Arabs invading Europe.  =
Christians invading Arab lands.  Most recently, the Ottoman Empire.
  ---This is where the problems between Muslims and Christians (the =
crusades) really began, but it's not the reason they still continue.

  Much of the drama in the Middle East is really the result of the =
decisions made by the Western colonial powers in the nineteenth and =
twentieth centuries.  Many "nation states," including Iraq, were created =
with boundaries that did not represent any tribal or cultural needs.  =
The horrors in Palestine began when the English decided to create a =
Jewish state there during WW II.  Had there been no anti-semitisim in =
Europe and the United States at the time the Palestinians would still =
have there homeland intact.

  ----These are some important points regarding the creation of =
"artificial" nations, but it's much less true in the middle-east than in =
Africa.  The middle-east may be a hotbed of activity, but the bulk of =
that activity this century has been between Iran / Iraq (which was a =
persia / arab thing, nothing to do with artifical national borders =
mostly) and arab vs. Israel.  In general the national borders drawn up =
in the middle-east by colonial powers worked fairly well, as those being =
called "Jordan" or "Syria" were all arabs and muslims.   So the short =
answer is that no the colonial powers this century and last aren't all =
that responsible for the bulk of the middle-easts turmoil.  I think if =
the colonial powers didn't give back the oil many decades ago we might =
be able to be held accountable, otherwise it's just so much an excuse =
for them being nasty to each other.  Palestine...let's no go there shall =
we :) =20

  One could go on.  Nothing...nothing is simple here.  Arab culture is =
ancient and very sophisticated, and I believe the roots of terrorism and =
conflict here lie in the desire of this culture to be received with =
respect and equality in the community of nations.

  ----I would really like to believe that, but I do not.  There is a =
fundamental flaw in Islam, and it's shared by Christianity as well =
(though the mechanism to "make the locals / naitives / infidels" come =
around is different and therein lies the problem).  The flaw is that =
each religion is "the" religion and any othe is "false" and so on.  In =
times past Muslims employed peacefull means to bring the word of the =
prophet to non-believers.  In times more recent this has been continued =
by most Muslims, but twisted by a few (in this case a few being =
thousands upon thousands) into a need to irradicate any who isn't =
Muslim.  And the reason, as originally hinted at, is more about a word =
starting with "J" (mixed with a little bit of human desire and greed, of =
course) then about converting or killing the infidel.
  Piers

At 08:25 PM 2/6/2003 -0800, P. Sutton wrote:

>   ----- Original Message -----
>   From: Apollo
>   To: Rayn ; P. Sutton
>   Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>   Sent: Thursday, February 06, 2003 7:48 PM
>   Subject: Re: Fwd: [sfraves] Fwd: vote to impeach bush [Pretty NRR]

First, I suggest you clarify your attributions.

Second, review the history of the Persian Empire more carefully.  I'm not 
sure what you mean by "1965" vs today's historical perspective, but I'll 
bet you more people could identify the geography of the Middle East  in '65 
than in '03 -- let alone historical background:)

Third, you want to make this into a religious conflict.  My suggestion is 
that historically this goes way beyond religion and, again, back to very 
ancient conflicts.  The Persian Empire did include Iraq, and Baghdad was 
one of the Imperial Persian courts.

For your edification, here is a brief chronology of the Persian 
Empire.  You can find it in any history book.

630-553 BC: Zarathustra
559-530 BC: Reign of Cyrus the Great
559 BC: Cyrus the Great overthrows Astyages of Media
546 BC: Persians conquer Lydia
538 BC: Persians conquer Babylonia
530-522 BC: Reign of Cambyses
525 BC: Persians conquer Egypt
522-521 BC: Civil War
521-485 BC: Reign of Darius
Reorganizes the government into satrapies.
Builds an extensive system of roads.
521-519 BC: The Empire is extended beyond the Indus River
490 BC: Attempts to conquer the Greek mainland.Persian War Chronology
485-465 BC:Reign of Xerxes
480 BC: Makes a second attempt to conquer the mainland Greeks.Persian War 
Chronology
465-338 BC: A Period of Imperial Decline
465-424 BC: Reign of Artaxerxes I Longimanus
424-404 BC: Reign of Xerxes II
404-358 BC: Reign of Artaxerxes II Mnemon
358-338 BC: Reign of Artaxerxes III Ochus
336-330 BC: Reign of Darius Codomannus
330 BC: Alexander the Great conquers the Persian Empire Rise of Macedonia 
Chronology

Mohammad  was born, according to Muslim historians, on April 20, 571.  By 
the time of the Mongols Islam was already on the rise.  The Persians were 
pagans.

As for a discussion of the Middle East, one really must examine the impact 
of the British rule of Palestine and much of the strife that now exists in 
the region.

Love,

Apollo






>   At 07:29 PM 2/6/2003 -0800, Rayn (no, Apollo) wrote:
>
>   What we are really missing in this country is an understanding of other 
> cultures and basic history.
>
>   ---This isn't 1965.  We have a very good understanding of other 
> cultrures and basic history.  If it was 1965 i'd agree with your 
> statement, but it isn't.
>
>   There has been an ongoing conflict between the West and Arab nations 
> for thousands of years.
>
>   ---This is also incorrect.  There has been conflict between the West 
> and Arab world since the dawn of the Renaissance, but not much before 
> that.  One word describes why the Muslim world (let's hit the nail on the 
> head here, it's really a Christian / Muslim thing, not a Western / Arab 
> thing) dislikes the "West" and that word begins with J.
>
>   The Persians (modern Iran, Iraq and other Mid-Eastern states) had a war 
> with the Greeks that lasted hundreds of years.  Athens was burned to the 
> ground.  Alexander the Great unified the Greek states and conquered 
> Persia.  In Iran Alexander is still remembered as the "horned one" who 
> ended the Persian Empire.
>
>   ---The Persians are Iranians only, any Iraqi's or other middle-eastern 
> arabs hear you call them Persian they're likely to chop your hands off 
> lol!  Also, Alexander may be remembered as the "horned one" and the 
> Persian empire may have shrunk in that time period, but those responsible 
> for ending (and I mean really ending to the point it never recovered, 
> ever) the Persian Empire are actually the Mongols, and that was some 
> 1,500 years later around 1253 A.D.  That was the end of the great Persian 
> Empire and don't let anyone tell you otherwise.
>
>   Then we had the religious wars.  Crusades.  Arabs invading 
> Europe.  Christians invading Arab lands.  Most recently, the Ottoman Empire.
>   ---This is where the problems between Muslims and Christians (the 
> crusades) really began, but it's not the reason they still continue.
>
>   Much of the drama in the Middle East is really the result of the 
> decisions made by the Western colonial powers in the nineteenth and 
> twentieth centuries.  Many "nation states," including Iraq, were created 
> with boundaries that did not represent any tribal or cultural needs.  The 
> horrors in Palestine began when the English decided to create a Jewish 
> state there during WW II.  Had there been no anti-semitisim in Europe and 
> the United States at the time the Palestinians would still have there 
> homeland intact.
>
>   ----These are some important points regarding the creation of 
> "artificial" nations, but it's much less true in the middle-east than in 
> Africa.  The middle-east may be a hotbed of activity, but the bulk of 
> that activity this century has been between Iran / Iraq (which was a 
> persia / arab thing, nothing to do with artifical national borders 
> mostly) and arab vs. Israel.  In general the national borders drawn up in 
> the middle-east by colonial powers worked fairly well, as those being 
> called "Jordan" or "Syria" were all arabs and muslims.   So the short 
> answer is that no the colonial powers this century and last aren't all 
> that responsible for the bulk of the middle-easts turmoil.  I think if 
> the colonial powers didn't give back the oil many decades ago we might be 
> able to be held accountable, otherwise it's just so much an excuse for 
> them being nasty to each other.  Palestine...let's no go there shall we :)
>
>   One could go on.  Nothing...nothing is simple here.  Arab culture is 
> ancient and very sophisticated, and I believe the roots of terrorism and 
> conflict here lie in the desire of this culture to be received with 
> respect and equality in the community of nations.
>
>   ----I would really like to believe that, but I do not.  There is a 
> fundamental flaw in Islam, and it's shared by Christianity as well 
> (though the mechanism to "make the locals / naitives / infidels" come 
> around is different and therein lies the problem).  The flaw is that each 
> religion is "the" religion and any othe is "false" and so on.  In times 
> past Muslims employed peacefull means to bring the word of the prophet to 
> non-believers.  In times more recent this has been continued by most 
> Muslims, but twisted by a few (in this case a few being thousands upon 
> thousands) into a need to irradicate any who isn't Muslim.  And the 
> reason, as originally hinted at, is more about a word starting with "J" 
> (mixed with a little bit of human desire and greed, of course) then about 
> converting or killing the infidel.
>   Piers

> First, I suggest you clarify your attributions.
>
> Second, review the history of the Persian Empire more carefully.  I'm not
> sure what you mean by "1965" vs today's historical perspective, but I'll
> bet you more people could identify the geography of the Middle East  in
'65
> than in '03 -- let alone historical background:)

What I mean is that the people and more importantly politicians of today are
not
as ignorant as they were 30 or more years ago.  I'm sure you wouldn't be
surprised
to know how many U.S. Congressmen(people?) didn't know where Vietnam was, or
things along those lines.  Certainly we can be more sensative, but I don't
think we lack
understanding in the ways we once did.  Can you imagine a politician or
newsperson in
1955 asking questions about Ramadan?  I can't.  But we do today.  That's all
i'm saying.

> Third, you want to make this into a religious conflict.  My suggestion is
> that historically this goes way beyond religion and, again, back to very
> ancient conflicts.  The Persian Empire did include Iraq, and Baghdad was
> one of the Imperial Persian courts.

Being part of the imperial persian courts and *beiing* persian are two
different things.  And no,
I think current issues do not date back beyond about 1,300 A.D. or so.
History does, sure,
but not the current problems between Muslims and Christians.  As a matter of
fact during the
Dark Ages there were many Christian enclaves in the Islamic middle-east that
were allowed
more or less autonomy both religiously and in their own governing.  Ask
yourself, why was that?
Ask yourself, why could that never happen now or in fact in the past 600
years or so.

> Mohammad  was born, according to Muslim historians, on April 20, 571.  By
> the time of the Mongols Islam was already on the rise.  The Persians were
> pagans.

My point about Persia is that it did not end as a power / empire until the
invasion
by the Mongols.  The Persia of 1,000 was smaller than the Persia of 300
B.C., but it
was every bit as robust and powerfull.  This ended in 1253, and they've
never been a power
since then.  The Mongols saw to that.

> As for a discussion of the Middle East, one really must examine the impact
> of the British rule of Palestine and much of the strife that now exists in
> the region.

It's a subject I choose not to get into.  One could go back to the time when
the jewish people
were the rightfull owners of the land called Palestine later.  It's just not
worth discussion in a more
"broad" discussion of what's wrong now in the middle-east and why.  :)

> Love,
>
> Apollo

>From: Keith Edwards <prohouselist@yahoo.com>
>To: Rave List <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: [sfraves] Hangover Rating System
>Date: Thu, 6 Feb 2003 19:47:18 -0800 (PST)
>
>
>This is hella funny. Not that I associate anything with it.....Well there 
>was all those Thursday Mornings for two years!! right all you old skool 
>Stereophonik/ Killa Subz Guys..
>
>Enjoy
>
>Keith Edwards
>
>PS the Buzz on the street -----Stereophonik---- Will return soon!!!!!!!!!
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>One Star Hangover (*)
>No pain. No real feeling of illness. You're able to function relatively
>well. However, you are still parched. You can drink 5 sodas and still feel  
>this way. For some reason, you are craving a steak & fries.
>
>
>  Two Star Hangover (**)
>
>
>  No pain, but something is definitely amiss. You may look okay, but you
>have
>the mental capacity of a staple gun. The coffee you are chugging is only
>  increasing your rumbling gut, which is still tossing around the fruity
>  pancake from the 3:00 AM, Waffle House excursion. There is some definite
>  havoc being wreaked upon your bowels.
>
>Three Star Hangover (***)
>Slight headache. Stomach feels crappy. You are definitely not productive.
>  Anytime a girl walks by you gag because her perfume reminds you of the
>flavored schnapps shots your alcoholic friends dared you to drink. Life
>would be better right now if you were home in your bed watching Lucy
>reruns.
>  You've had 4 cups of coffee, a gallon of water, 3 iced teas and a diet
>Coke
>  --- yet you haven't peed once.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>Four Star Hangover (****)
>
>
>
>  Life sucks. Your head is throbbing. You can't speak too quickly or else
>you
>  might puke. Your boss has already lambasted you for being late and has
>given
>  you a lecture for reeking of booze. You wore nice clothes, but that can't
>  hide the fact that you only shaved one side of your face. (For the 
>ladies,
>  it looks like you put your make-up on while riding the bumper cars.) Your
>  eyes look like one big red vein, and even your hair hurts. Your sphincter
>is
>  in perpetual spasm, and the first of about five shits you take during the
>day brings water to the eyes of everyone who enters the bathroom.
>
>
>  Five Star Hangover, (*****)
>  You have a second heartbeat in your head, which is actually annoying the 
>employee who sits in the next cube. Vodka vapor is seeping out of every 
>pore  and making you dizzy. You still have toothpaste crust in the corners 
>of your  mouth from brushing your teeth in an attempt to get the remnants 
>of the poop fairy out. Your body has lost the ability to generate saliva so 
>your tongue is suffocating you. You don't have the foggiest idea who the 
>hell the stranger was passed out in your bed this morning. Any attempt to 
>defecate results in a fire hose like discharge of alcohol-scented fluid 
>with a rare  'floater' thrown in. The sole purpose of this 'floater' seems 
>to be to  splash the toilet water all over your ass. Death sounds pretty 
>good about
>  right now....
>
> > THINGS THAT ARE DIFFICULT TO SAY WHEN YOU'RE DRUNK:
> > Indubitably
> > Innovative
> > Preliminary
> > Proliferation
> > Cinnamon
> >
> >
> >
> > THINGS THAT ARE VERY DIFFICULT TO SAY WHEN YOU'RE DRUNK:
> > Specificity
> > British Constitution

> >
> >
> >

Date: Thu, 06 Feb 2003 22:27:42 -0800
From: Stephen Freskos <sjfreskos@lbl.gov>
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.0.2) Gecko/20021120 Netscape/7.01
X-Accept-Language: en-us, en
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] off-topic list content - does the list moderator do any moderadation?!

A little food for thought.  I hear the term PLUR in the scene and I 
think it has something to do with the following:

I joined this list to communicate with the underground and to discuss 
the rave culture in the Bay Area.  I'm really disappointed that the 
content doesn't stay focused.  The whole idea of an email list is to 
provide a forum for the discussion of a selected topic, so that you 
don't have to sort through large quantities of information to find what 
you are interested in.  If I was interested in conversations about US 
politics, war and foreign relations I would look at lists like 
talk.politics.mideast, alt.politics.bush, alt.activism, soc.culture.iraq 
to list just a few.  

So, with that in mind, for lists to operate as they were intended, 
everyone participating has to have some basic list ettiquite and show 
respect for the list members individually and the list community, by 
keeping posts and contributions to the agreed upon topic. When 
individuals don't behave, it effects all of us.  It's our list 
moderator's job to keep discussions on track, which occasionaly requires 
reminding members of expected behavior and taking corrective measures 
like kicking people off for repeated spamming
 
Remember, each message you post to sfraves gets copied to about 2500 
members!! Don't you think it's extremely selfish, disrespectful and 
ignorant to make off-topic posts, especially when people ask for it to 
stop?  

I'm publicly putting out a request for moderation.  Does our list 
moderator care to contribute to this conversation?  If not, maybe we 
need a new moderator...

That's it for now and,
think before you post!

-Stephen

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] off-topic list content - does the list moderator do any

Thank you for sharing your opinion with all 2500 of us and filling our 
mailboxes with non-rave related information/spam instead of directly 
emailing the moderator.  Your Ad Populum scheme might get you somewhere, but 
I'm not sure which direction you're headed.  Believe it or not Stephen, this 
topic arises quite often and generally has the same result.  Ravers, who are 
members of SFRaves.org, post what they find relavent to the rave community.  
A lot of what you might consider spam, directly or indirectly affects raves 
and ravers in ways that you may not have the capacity to comprehend.  Don't 
worry though, most of us have to deal with ignorant people all of the time.  
The serious problem I see on this mailing list is people who don't have the 
patience to understand a topic and how it affects their rave realted world.  
In all sincerity, politics, war, comedy, horror, and nonsense all have a 
role in our culture and I think it would be a shame if objectivity standards 
and restrictions were placed on posting.  Just some "food for thought," that 
I thought I would fill your tiny little box with.  Um, yeah... -Trendy-

PS, if you are so concerned with this list, why don't you make your own and 
enforce any Stalinesque or Maoesque restrictions on who can post and what 
they can post about? Just some food for thought. -T-




>From: Stephen Freskos <sjfreskos@lbl.gov>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: [sfraves] off-topic list content - does the list moderator do any 
>moderadation?!
>Date: Thu, 06 Feb 2003 22:27:42 -0800
>
>A little food for thought.  I hear the term PLUR in the scene and I think 
>it has something to do with the following:
>
>I joined this list to communicate with the underground and to discuss the 
>rave culture in the Bay Area.  I'm really disappointed that the content 
>doesn't stay focused.  The whole idea of an email list is to provide a 
>forum for the discussion of a selected topic, so that you don't have to 
>sort through large quantities of information to find what you are 
>interested in.  If I was interested in conversations about US politics, war 
>and foreign relations I would look at lists like talk.politics.mideast, 
>alt.politics.bush, alt.activism, soc.culture.iraq to list just a few.
>
>So, with that in mind, for lists to operate as they were intended, everyone 
>participating has to have some basic list ettiquite and show respect for 
>the list members individually and the list community, by keeping posts and 
>contributions to the agreed upon topic. When individuals don't behave, it 
>effects all of us.  It's our list moderator's job to keep discussions on 
>track, which occasionaly requires reminding members of expected behavior 
>and taking corrective measures like kicking people off for repeated 
>spamming
>
>Remember, each message you post to sfraves gets copied to about 2500 
>members!! Don't you think it's extremely selfish, disrespectful and 
>ignorant to make off-topic posts, especially when people ask for it to 
>stop?
>
>I'm publicly putting out a request for moderation.  Does our list moderator 
>care to contribute to this conversation?  If not, maybe we need a new 
>moderator...
>
>That's it for now and,
>think before you post!
>
>-Stephen

On Thu, 6 Feb 2003, Stephen Freskos wrote:

terry wrote: first things first:
If you joined this list to meet other ravers in this area but can't
because of the off-topic discussion let me know, because current threads
are important yet there are plenty of ways available to connect with
SFRavers.

> I joined this list to communicate with the underground and to discuss
> the rave culture in the Bay Area.  I'm really disappointed that the
> content doesn't stay focused.

This is true. But keep in mind that the people, (at least from my
point-of-view, the heavy hitting posts) are from real-to-the-core ravers
having a discussion about NRR topics. imho I'm glad to see it.

 > So, with
that in mind, for lists to operate as they were intended,
> everyone participating has to have some basic list ettiquite and show
> respect for the list members individually and the list community, by
> keeping posts and contributions to the agreed upon topic. When
> individuals don't behave, it effects all of us.  It's our list
> moderator's job to keep discussions on track, which occasionaly requires
> reminding members of expected behavior and taking corrective measures
> like kicking people off for repeated spamming
>

Point taken. I would review w/ Brian, Karina + all the other
stake holders, except this list collectively dictates what it decides to
be. It has always been like that.

I see this list as a point of congregation for
sf-ravers in the online community. If impending war is more important that
so-and-so's beats or wherz the party at?, than so be it. This list
sways from topics more than
"Days of our Lives", yet the content is so much more real and relevant. I
don't see any problem with the current influx of threads on war.

 > Remember, each message you post to
sfraves gets copied to about 2500
> members!! Don't you think it's extremely selfish, disrespectful and
> ignorant to make off-topic posts, especially when people ask for it to
> stop?

Actually, the list gets about 600 now, the digest+others brings it up
about 20%. People who join this list should know they're entering an onine
community, not a gaming strategies forum, if not they will quickly find
out. Certainly SFRaves requests general nettiquette, but our topics are
more loose. Do you think all our US soldiers in the mid-east are *only*
talking about war? Just put NRR if the topic is "Non Rave Related".

 > I'm publicly putting out a request for moderation.  Does our list
> moderator care to contribute to this conversation?  If not, maybe we
> need a new moderator...

Ug. again. Dood, I read every single day's posts, for 8 years ago. I know
the list is heavy on NRR. I read all the flames. What would you like me to
moderate?

-terry

wellspring for the bitterness which was to follow between the muslim and
christian
world.  The crusades were the seed, the renaissance was the folliage that
followed
and has been the thorn ever since ;)  There were certainly a couple hundred
years
or so of germination, my dear Apollo.

The "J" folk are the jealous folk.  And these folk are everywhere, and
always will
be.  That's the word, and coupled with the history of the middle-east, the
"our way
is the only way"-ness of Islam, and so forth we are now where we are and
have been
since the 1400's (well before colonial times, as I said).  If the situation
were reversed,
i'm sure it would be a mirror image.  When you're down, devided, and on your
ass,
there's nothing like finding a common "enemy" to unite you.  They did it in
the
crusades (hint hint), Hitler did it, the Japanese have done it, and the
militant Muslims are
doing it, moreso now than ever before.  Add the teaching of their religion
(and ours) into
the mix and you have a very rank stew.

>===== Original Message From Stephen Freskos <sjfreskos@lbl.gov> =====
>A little food for thought.  I hear the term PLUR in the scene and I
>think it has something to do with the following:
>
>I joined this list to communicate with the underground and to discuss
>the rave culture in the Bay Area.  I'm really disappointed that the
>content doesn't stay focused.  The whole idea of an email list is to
>provide a forum for the discussion of a selected topic, so that you
>don't have to sort through large quantities of information to find what
>you are interested in.  If I was interested in conversations about US
>politics, war and foreign relations I would look at lists like
>talk.politics.mideast, alt.politics.bush, alt.activism, soc.culture.iraq
>to list just a few.
>
>So, with that in mind, for lists to operate as they were intended,
>everyone participating has to have some basic list ettiquite and show
>respect for the list members individually and the list community, by
>keeping posts and contributions to the agreed upon topic. When
>individuals don't behave, it effects all of us.  It's our list
>moderator's job to keep discussions on track, which occasionaly requires
>reminding members of expected behavior and taking corrective measures
>like kicking people off for repeated spamming
>
>Remember, each message you post to sfraves gets copied to about 2500
>members!! Don't you think it's extremely selfish, disrespectful and
>ignorant to make off-topic posts, especially when people ask for it to
>stop?
>
>I'm publicly putting out a request for moderation.  Does our list
>moderator care to contribute to this conversation?  If not, maybe we
>need a new moderator...
>
>That's it for now and,
>think before you post!
>
>-Stephen
>

OK... so I'm like hella buggin' 'cause the night was so fun & =
hmmmmm..... everything & every1 tonight...Hello 2Day!!

So my night well, venture rather, started when I went 2 San Lorenzo 2 =
spend a much need, mondo overdue quality hang out, kick it time w/ my =
Bro Aryck! Gosh man.... So Dope chillin' 2gether after well, it's been a =
while!!  So yeah, we got 2 talkin', catchin' up, la la la bonding talk & =
it was Groovy! Psssst.... y'all gonna C this guy again soon enough! =3D) =
 Love Ya Bro!

Then I booked to 1015 4 that SfF Indie Film showing after shindig & I =
did SFLNC booth there 4 like hmmmm... well, like almost 2 hours I =
guess!!  It was Dope!!!  I mean... saw  few Groover Cats I ain't seenin =
months, saw some DJ Homies I ain't seen in months, & oooooooooh my =
gosh... the 1st DJ who spun in the 1st room that U like enter when U =
come in from like outside ya know!  Well anywaze, this DJ was Awesome!!  =
Grrrrr... I wish I knew his name! =20

But yeah, he start out his mix playing like Hard Yummy Trance!!  Then he =
started mixin' in some like Tribal Techno (is there such a thing?) & he =
would go like back & forth with that!!  Then he mixed in some Electro & =
totally went in & out w/ all 3 genres!!  It was Fuckin' Sick!!  I was =
dancin' my ass off behind my booth thingie!

In the big main room, my friend I can't remember right now so let's call =
him Damon 4now, was spinning this Dope Ass I guess it could be =
considered Progressive house!!  It was Dope, but I was in the other room =
where the SFLNC booth was!  But yeah... the 1st few house tracks that =
Damon 4 now spun were Sick!

So I got relieved from booth & it was right on time 2 make it 2 =
Incognita 4 Cantos's set!!  Ok... I gotta tell y'all... Cantos is =
Fuckin' Sick w/ his Breakbeats!!!  I mean seriously... he totally knows =
how to sew his tracks 2gether perfectly so that his set comes out =
Sweet!!!  Seriously... he brings in the next track so perfectly & =
melodically perfect w/ the other record that you can't tell & it kinda =
sneaks up on you, ya know what I'm sayin'? Oh My Goodness, Oh My Gosh... =
his set fuckin' Rocked Sitio!!!  Hella people were totally juiced after =
his set & there was this buzz around the club during & after his set =
that people were hella diggin' Cantos's set!

While he was Cantos was spinning downstairs... I think it was Sound Boy =
spinning Jungle upstairs!!  OK... Hello 2Day... I Loved that set!!!  I =
mean, he played alota classic Jungle tracks which I Loved & man... he =
jus' totally got off on the Hard Jungle tip & I was in Awe!!  I Loved =
It!!!

Andy went on down stairs after CAntos & ooooooooooooooh yeah... he =
wasn't lying when he said he was gonna play "Lots of stuff played at the =
wrong BPM, old school classics, detroit techno and ghetto"... this has =
2b my 2nd favorite Andy W set I ever heard!  The 1st fave set is a Happy =
Hardcore set he spun 4 me @ his house this 1 time @ 6 in the =
morning...LoL... Herllo 2Day!  But man... it was a totally fun set & he =
totally got off on the Ghetto Tek tip!!  I Love it!!  There was also =
this Awesome track he spun & all I could recall of it was like alota =
Orchastra Hits in the track!  Andy... if you're reading this Big Bro... =
can U gimme track ID?

While Andy \/\/ spun downstairs, Romeo spun Jungle upstairs!!  Good Shit =
man... he does it 2 me every time w/ his sets!!  He manages 2 go crazy =
w/ all the different style of Jungle there is & mis all that shit =
2gether!!  But this time around, he start out like totally JAzzy DnB =
then gradually got in2 the Hard Jungle Fuck You Up tracks & man... So =
Dope!  He gave me 1 of his CDs last time he spun @ Incognita... but that =
CD don't do him justice 'cause I think his live sets R so Better!!!  =
Hell Yeah!!

OK... the Vibe was sooooooooo Awesome @ Incognita!!  I mean, there was a =
handful of Family that showed up & I Loved seein' Family there!  OH My =
Goodness man... ACME Dave popped up w/ Fuckwork & it was so Dope seein' =
them!!  Oh Gosh, Radly was there 2 & I ain't seen that dude in Hella =
Daze!!!  HIs hair man... Wow!!!  Steph, Rick again, Summer, Steve, the =
Tracy Girls, man.... But yeah... like every week, the Vibe was soooooooo =
on man!!!  Ask anyone who was there tonight & they'll tell U that the =
Energy was so positively thick & Groovy that hmmmmm..... yeah!!! Good =
people, Good Music, Good Vibe, what can be better on a Thursday night! =
Wow... I'm still buggin'!!!  Thanks every1!!! =3D)  Gosh... howcome I =
can't stop smiling?  LoL =3D) =20
