http://www.sflnc.com

Hey y'all... I figured that since I was still like awake & I'm still on =
the computer (maybe 3 Redbulls in one night is over doing it, huh?) ... =
I'd tell ya'll about the new SFLNC website!!  I don't remember reading =
if there was an official launch 4 it & I'm not sure if it's completely =
like finished... but the site is up, the features work,  & la la la la!  =
LoL

I know I haven't been active like this on the list for SFLNC the past =
few months (maybe year or something), but  I aways been doing my lil' =
job if U been seeing me pass stuff out @ clubs or Raves!

Oh yeah, but hey, if you're not on the SFLNC mailing list yet, get on =
it!!  This is a minimum of like 2 emails a month @ most... may be 3 or =
4! =3D)  But this will keep you informed about what's happening, events =
going on that SFLNC is a part of or throwing, & sometimes a call out to =
you about showing up somewhere to represent our Culture like having a =
Groover Army showing up @ City Hall!

So yeah... the link's on top there if U wanna click it & explore the =
World of SFLNC!! =20

Oh oh oh... if you're like interested in knowing, I've been with SFLNC =
for the past like almost 3 years now!  It was Aryck who persuaded me to =
join 'cause Homeboy kept tellin' me that I have the right personality =
for it or something like that!  Then through meetings, boothing, & =
random Grassroots stuff, Angelica became my mentor, Homegirl, & Sister!  =
But yeah, I've steadily maintained my postion in Grassroots since I 1st =
got involved!  I've done several SFLNC booths @ several clubs & raves!  =
Hmmmmm.... what else...ummmm... well, I Love what I do as part of my =
responsibilities for SFLNC!!  I'm like mondo proud of being part of =
something that helps changes flat tires 4 our Culture, ya know!  I =
mean... there's always something trying to take us down that's like like =
some law or act that's totally unfair or unreasonable & it's a never =
ending cycle it seems!  I'm just glad that I can be there to fight back =
and do my share!

So cruise the site, see whatcha like, look @ pictures, & hey... get =
involved if U like feel totally inspired, OK =3D)

Peace =3D-=3D->O=A7bY {8O)

B.C., but it

never been a power

>>> Stephen Freskos <sjfreskos@lbl.gov> 02/07/03 01:27AM >>>
A little food for thought.  I hear the term PLUR in the scene and I=20
think it has something to do with the following:

I joined this list to communicate with the underground and to discuss=20
the rave culture in the Bay Area.  I'm really disappointed that the=20
content doesn't stay focused.  The whole idea of an email list is to=20
provide a forum for the discussion of a selected topic, so that you=20
don't have to sort through large quantities of information to find what=20
you are interested in.  If I was interested in conversations about US=20
politics, war and foreign relations I would look at lists like=20
talk.politics.mideast, alt.politics.bush, alt.activism, soc.culture.iraq=20=

to list just a few. =20

So, with that in mind, for lists to operate as they were intended,=20
everyone participating has to have some basic list ettiquite and show=20
respect for the list members individually and the list community, by=20
keeping posts and contributions to the agreed upon topic. When=20
individuals don't behave, it effects all of us.  It's our list=20
moderator's job to keep discussions on track, which occasionaly requires=20=

reminding members of expected behavior and taking corrective measures=20
like kicking people off for repeated spamming
=20
Remember, each message you post to sfraves gets copied to about 2500=20
members!! Don't you think it's extremely selfish, disrespectful and=20
ignorant to make off-topic posts, especially when people ask for it to=20
stop? =20

I'm publicly putting out a request for moderation.  Does our list=20
moderator care to contribute to this conversation?  If not, maybe we=20
need a new moderator...

That's it for now and,
think before you post!

-Stephen

were allowed

never been a power

Subject: Re: [sfraves] off-topic list content - does the list moderator do any moderadation?!

Remember when you first got on this list Tim? THAT is what high traffic and
low signal to noise ratio really is. When people start bitching about too
much being posted on SFR in the last year it makes me laugh. Folks, a few
years back when raving hit it's MTV primetime peak this list BLEW UP. There
were times when I would get well over 250 emails a day. Most of them riddled
with petty flamewars and NRR topics such as you see now. If anything SFR has
calmed down.

If the traffic on this list is too much and you can't deal with the topics
being posted - leave. There is no contract to be signed when you join so
you're free to go. If you like to whine and bitch about how things aren't up
to your standards, well, go for it. You will get a backlash from the
community if you choose to do so. That's the power of this list. The coice
and ability to say what you want. Moderation only comes into play when
absolutely necessary. Asking Terry to *moderate more* is akin to censorship.
The list wouldn't survive as it has with such governing.

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
www.sninesix.com
www.innocentchild.com

Thanks for the feedback Terry, Jim and everyone.  This whole topic seems 
controversial within the group, some on one side, some on the other, 
some don't care.  I wanted to feel out where everybody was at on this. 
 It's not the way I'm used to lists operating though, but I'm not going 
to unsubscribe over it.  
A couple of things:  I'm disgusted with politics, government, 
censorship, and mass media;  I haven't watched TV in 6 years, I've been 
roaming the 'net since 1990 and am DOWN for the freedom of information; 
 freedom of speech is powerful but if it's disorganized it's not as 
potent; this country is nice place to live but I'm in no way interested 
in being 'American'.

-Stephen

It's not a double standard.  Everyone needs to understand that topics other 
than the next BSP are permissible on the list.  The politics thread had NRR 
in the subject line from the second email, and conformed to filtering 
objectives.  If Stephen doesn't like that, he should leave, because it's 
not going anywhere.  There's far too much traffic on this list for 
full-time moderation.  We tried it.  I'm sorry Stephen doesn't remember or 
didn't bother to check the archives.

> > >From: Stephen Freskos <sjfreskos@lbl.gov>

> > >Subject: [sfraves] off-topic list content - does the list moderator do
>any

> > >Date: Thu, 06 Feb 2003 22:27:42 -0800
> > >
> > >A little food for thought.  I hear the term PLUR in the scene and I think
> > >it has something to do with the following:
> > >
> > >I joined this list to communicate with the underground and to discuss the
> > >rave culture in the Bay Area.  I'm really disappointed that the content
> > >doesn't stay focused.  The whole idea of an email list is to provide a
> > >forum for the discussion of a selected topic, so that you don't have to
> > >sort through large quantities of information to find what you are
> > >interested in.  If I was interested in conversations about US politics,
>war
> > >and foreign relations I would look at lists like talk.politics.mideast,
> > >alt.politics.bush, alt.activism, soc.culture.iraq to list just a few.
> > >
> > >So, with that in mind, for lists to operate as they were intended,
>everyone
> > >participating has to have some basic list ettiquite and show respect for
> > >the list members individually and the list community, by keeping posts
>and
> > >contributions to the agreed upon topic. When individuals don't behave, it
> > >effects all of us.  It's our list moderator's job to keep discussions on
> > >track, which occasionaly requires reminding members of expected behavior
> > >and taking corrective measures like kicking people off for repeated
> > >spamming
> > >
> > >Remember, each message you post to sfraves gets copied to about 2500
> > >members!! Don't you think it's extremely selfish, disrespectful and
> > >ignorant to make off-topic posts, especially when people ask for it to
> > >stop?
> > >
> > >I'm publicly putting out a request for moderation.  Does our list

>

>If you joined this list to meet other ravers in this area but can't
>because of the off-topic discussion let me know, because current threads
>are important yet there are plenty of ways available to connect with
>SFRavers.
>
> > I joined this list to communicate with the underground and to discuss
> > the rave culture in the Bay Area.  I'm really disappointed that the
> > content doesn't stay focused.
>
>This is true. But keep in mind that the people, (at least from my
>point-of-view, the heavy hitting posts) are from real-to-the-core ravers
>having a discussion about NRR topics. imho I'm glad to see it.
>
>  > So, with
>that in mind, for lists to operate as they were intended,
> > everyone participating has to have some basic list ettiquite and show
> > respect for the list members individually and the list community, by
> > keeping posts and contributions to the agreed upon topic. When
> > individuals don't behave, it effects all of us.  It's our list
> > moderator's job to keep discussions on track, which occasionaly requires
> > reminding members of expected behavior and taking corrective measures
> > like kicking people off for repeated spamming
> >
>
>Point taken. I would review w/ Brian, Karina + all the other
>stake holders, except this list collectively dictates what it decides to
>be. It has always been like that.
>
>I see this list as a point of congregation for
>sf-ravers in the online community. If impending war is more important that
>so-and-so's beats or wherz the party at?, than so be it. This list
>sways from topics more than
>"Days of our Lives", yet the content is so much more real and relevant. I
>don't see any problem with the current influx of threads on war.
>
>  > Remember, each message you post to
>sfraves gets copied to about 2500
> > members!! Don't you think it's extremely selfish, disrespectful and
> > ignorant to make off-topic posts, especially when people ask for it to
> > stop?
>
>Actually, the list gets about 600 now, the digest+others brings it up
>about 20%. People who join this list should know they're entering an onine
>community, not a gaming strategies forum, if not they will quickly find
>out. Certainly SFRaves requests general nettiquette, but our topics are
>more loose. Do you think all our US soldiers in the mid-east are *only*
>talking about war? Just put NRR if the topic is "Non Rave Related".
>
>  > I'm publicly putting out a request for moderation.  Does our list
> > moderator care to contribute to this conversation?  If not, maybe we
> > need a new moderator...
>
>Ug. again. Dood, I read every single day's posts, for 8 years ago. I know

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] For those in the war thread...

Interview with Camille Paglia.
http://www.salon.com/opinion/feature/2003/02/07/paglia/index.html

Already in the first question, she addresses reasons why P. Sutton is
wrong, and a tool:

	If there truly were an authentic international coalition that had
	been carefully built, and if the administration had demonstrated
	sensitivity to the fragility of international relations, I'd be
	100 percent in favor of an allied military expedition to go into
	Iraq and find and dispose of all weapons of mass destruction.

	But most members of the current administration seem to have little
	sense that there's an enormous, complex world beyond our borders.
	The president himself has never traveled much in his life. They
	seem to think the universe consists of America and then everyone
	else -- small-potatoes people who can be steamrolled. And I'm
	absolutely appalled at the lack of acknowledgment of the cost to
	ordinary Iraqi citizens of any incursion by us, especially aerial
	bombardment.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 10:52 AM 2/7/2003 -0800, innocentchild wrote:
>It's like watching a video game being played. Only difference is those
>people are really getting blown apart by people that can't tell a square
>from a rectangle. I swear one of them was getting off on his real life
>gaming... Cool, but scary.

The AC 130 is old technology converted with "video game" technology to more 
modern uses.  The first gunship so equipped was a C-47 (civilian is DC 3) 
in Vietnam.

Problem with most of our generation is that we have no reality-based 
experience with war.  Our relationship to killing has become more abstract 
as person-to-person combat is replaced with joysticks, radar, and other 
weaponry controls.

I'm an amateur military historian, with particular interest in the Greeks 
and WW II.  Here is what one of the best historians of WW II, S.L.A. 
Marshall, discovered in his research about combat during that period.

No more than a quarter of the men in combat actually fired their 
weapons.  Discomfort with killing someone was one of the reasons.  But a 
bigger problem was fear.  In one study of a combat division Marshall found 
that a quarter of the troops admitted they had been so scared they 
vomited.  Nearly a quarter shit their pants.  Ten percent urinated in their 
BDUs.  Officers were so frightened that they experienced dry mouth and 
gagging and could not issue comprehensible orders under fire.

War is not a computer game.

Love,

Apollo

By no means was I trivializing war like that either. It's just scary how
much what we now see of war looks like something I'd play on my computer. In
such a desensitized culture I wonder how those figures would change now.
Seems that the value of life isn't as strong as it used to be. I should
say - I wonder how willing someone would be to pull a trigger with a real
human being in front of them. Not from an infra-red night vision targeting
system... That's a game and removes the personal nature of killing a
person(s).

At 02:40 PM 2/7/2003 -0800, innocentchild wrote:
>War is not a computer game.
>
>Love,
>
>Apollo
>
>
>By no means was I trivializing war like that either. It's just scary how
>much what we now see of war looks like something I'd play on my computer. In
>such a desensitized culture I wonder how those figures would change now.
>Seems that the value of life isn't as strong as it used to be. I should
>say - I wonder how willing someone would be to pull a trigger with a real
>human being in front of them. Not from an infra-red night vision targeting
>system... That's a game and removes the personal nature of killing a
>person(s).

Actually, much of the modern weapons control technology resembles those on 
computer and video games.  My joy stick is the same as those used on F-16 
fighters.  When I get all pissed and aggressive I load the flight sim, 
power up my fighter, and wreck havoc in the virtual skies.  That's fine, 
'cause I can release all that testosterone in a relatively constructive way.

But I think, as you suggest, that we have been removed from the realities 
of death and destruction that accompany war.

Love,

Apollo

  to a club environment where they can be experienced in context by a=20
  broader
  audience.   Ascension is now in it's
  third year and has evolved into a showcase featuring the best of the
  electronic dance and art culture from the
  bay area and beyond.  Elements of Ascension will include music,=20
  performance
  artists, multi-media art, and fashion all originating, evolving, and=20
  drawing
  inspiration from electronic music. Music will concentrate on live=20
  electronic
  acts and DJs who produce a significant part of their own play list in=20
  the
  moment.

  We are stoked to have as special guests Uberzone  - playing a special=20
  live
  set in the main room starting
  at 11:45 A fashion show (10pm) will kick things off in the main room
  featuring some of the most promising
  designers in the Bay Area and beats by Ikarus. Performance troupes =
will
  strive to push the boundaries in a
  variety of dance and movement genres. Art installations will create
  atmosphere and encourage interaction
  and the wicked visuals will simply blow the roof off this place before =

  the
  night is through!

  Coalition
  (SFLNC).

  cast
  too numerous to name... love to all!

"the
  biggest beats ever.  Uberzone is the brainchild of southern California

  early singles, "Botz" and "The Freaks", released on taste-maker indie=20
  dance
  label City of Angels, were critically acclaimed club tracks that=20

i just wanted to add my two cents here, for clarification...most usually,  when i am writing my posts, i am replying to what i have been reading on the list or seeing out in the scene...i reply privately to those i have innitiated some sort of conversation or friendliness with, try to stand up for who and what i believe in,  and just because i poke around once, doesn't mean that there is a continuing presense of me later. this is just common sense.  anyone who tries to push anyone otherwise is really not well, and just trying to cause problems...just pretend like your walking down a busy street..... ..trust is a gift, not a right. i like all the varieties of music and discussion...i like to write too. i don' t think there is too much more that can be done via this medium...there will be no virtual me,  and i won't be getting involved with anyone i don't want to. muah to the kissable.  :) :)
 Terry Estioko <terry@hyperreal.org> wrote:On Thu, 6 Feb 2003, Stephen Freskos wrote:

terry wrote: first things first:
If you joined this list to meet other ravers in this area but can't
because of the off-topic discussion let me know, because current threads
are important yet there are plenty of ways available to connect with
SFRavers.

> I joined this list to communicate with the underground and to discuss
> the rave culture in the Bay Area. I'm really disappointed that the
> content doesn't stay focused.

This is true. But keep in mind that the people, (at least from my
point-of-view, the heavy hitting posts) are from real-to-the-core ravers
having a discussion about NRR topics. imho I'm glad to see it.

> So, with
that in mind, for lists to operate as they were intended,
> everyone participating has to have some basic list ettiquite and show
> respect for the list members individually and the list community, by
> keeping posts and contributions to the agreed upon topic. When
> individuals don't behave, it effects all of us. It's our list
> moderator's job to keep discussions on track, which occasionaly requires
> reminding members of expected behavior and taking corrective measures
> like kicking people off for repeated spamming
>

Point taken. I would review w/ Brian, Karina + all the other
stake holders, except this list collectively dictates what it decides to
be. It has always been like that.

I see this list as a point of congregation for
sf-ravers in the online community. If impending war is more important that
so-and-so's beats or wherz the party at?, than so be it. This list
sways from topics more than
"Days of our Lives", yet the content is so much more real and relevant. I
don't see any problem with the current influx of threads on war.

> Remember, each message you post to
sfraves gets copied to about 2500
> members!! Don't you think it's extremely selfish, disrespectful and
> ignorant to make off-topic posts, especially when people ask for it to
> stop?

Actually, the list gets about 600 now, the digest+others brings it up
about 20%. People who join this list should know they're entering an onine
community, not a gaming strategies forum, if not they will quickly find
out. Certainly SFRaves requests general nettiquette, but our topics are
more loose. Do you think all our US soldiers in the mid-east are *only*
talking about war? Just put NRR if the topic is "Non Rave Related".

> I'm publicly putting out a request for moderation. Does our list
> moderator care to contribute to this conversation? If not, maybe we
> need a new moderator...

Ug. again. Dood, I read every single day's posts, for 8 years ago. I know
the list is heavy on NRR. I read all the flames. What would you like me to
moderate?

-terry

apollo@speakeasy.org wrote:

> Problem with most of our generation is that we have no reality-based 
> experience with war.  Our relationship to killing has become more abstract 
> as person-to-person combat is replaced with joysticks, radar, and other 
> weaponry controls.

Have any of you read "Ender's Game," by Orson Scott Card? On the surface, a 
science fiction book, but it brings up a ton of philosophical and ethical 
issues. I wouldn't want to ruin the story for anyone, but it has a lot to do 
with the ways war can be fought as if it were a video game. 

The more removed we are from the actual killing, the easier it is to do.  
It's easier to shoot somebody with an arrow than to hit him with a club. But 
it's easier to shoot someone from a distance with a gun. Even easier to drop 
a bomb. And now we have unmanned planes, controlled remotely, that can launch 
anti-tank missiles at no physical risk to the person at the controls. Scary! 

Take care, everyone. We're at Orange Alert level as of today.

--part1_d3.18113bb5.2b75b3be_boundary--

-----Original Message-----
From: Mike Migurski [mailto:mike@saturn5.com]
Sent: Friday, February 07, 2003 11:49 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] For those in the war thread...


Interview with Camille Paglia.
http://www.salon.com/opinion/feature/2003/02/07/paglia/index.html

Already in the first question, she addresses reasons why P. Sutton is
wrong, and a tool:

	If there truly were an authentic international coalition that had
	been carefully built, and if the administration had demonstrated
	sensitivity to the fragility of international relations, I'd be
	100 percent in favor of an allied military expedition to go into
	Iraq and find and dispose of all weapons of mass destruction.

	But most members of the current administration seem to have little
	sense that there's an enormous, complex world beyond our borders.
	The president himself has never traveled much in his life. They
	seem to think the universe consists of America and then everyone
	else -- small-potatoes people who can be steamrolled. And I'm
	absolutely appalled at the lack of acknowledgment of the cost to
	ordinary Iraqi citizens of any incursion by us, especially aerial
	bombardment.

Mime-Version: 1.0
X-Sender: blindspot@mail.mac.com
Message-Id: <p04330105ba6a13191772@[172.16.2.25]>
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.2.20030207130627.026afd90@mail.speakeasy.org>
References: <OE130OUIHNkjgJKVApw00003186@hotmail.com>

Date: Fri, 7 Feb 2003 17:59:26 -0800
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: blindspot <blindspot@mac.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] AC130 gunship :: your tax dolla, hard at work  
 <nrr>

As a veteran of the Persian Gulf War, I can tell you that the 
detachment of killing is real. I was a loader in a tank that swept 
across the border of Saudi Arabia and into Iraq. Our entire company 
(14 tanks) fired exactly two main gun rounds total. There was plenty 
of laying it down on the .50 cal into the bunkers as the hapless 
Iraqi soldiers jumped into them. I spent the whole time, about 19 
straight hours, sitting in that seat waiting for fire commands and 
watching into the darkness. The gunner scanned the horizon with the 
night vision equipped site waiting for targets to pop up and to get 
the command to fire. Though I was scared, it was very much like a 
video game in that the enemy was relegated to nothing more than being 
a simple target on a screen in a tightly controlled game of shoot em 
up.

Luckily our engagement was very light and our infantry company was 
there to bring across the exhausted POWs. We never even had to leave 
the tank. In fact we were ordered not to because nobody knew exactly 
where the anti-personnel land mines were, though they were all around.

bs




At 13:16 -0800 2/7/03, Apollo wrote:
>At 10:52 AM 2/7/2003 -0800, innocentchild wrote:
>>It's like watching a video game being played. Only difference is those
>>people are really getting blown apart by people that can't tell a square
>>from a rectangle. I swear one of them was getting off on his real life
>>gaming... Cool, but scary.
>
>The AC 130 is old technology converted with "video game" technology 
>to more modern uses.  The first gunship so equipped was a C-47 
>(civilian is DC 3) in Vietnam.
>
>Problem with most of our generation is that we have no reality-based 
>experience with war.  Our relationship to killing has become more 
>abstract as person-to-person combat is replaced with joysticks, 
>radar, and other weaponry controls.
>
>I'm an amateur military historian, with particular interest in the 
>Greeks and WW II.  Here is what one of the best historians of WW II, 
>S.L.A. Marshall, discovered in his research about combat during that 
>period.
>
>No more than a quarter of the men in combat actually fired their 
>weapons.  Discomfort with killing someone was one of the reasons. 
>But a bigger problem was fear.  In one study of a combat division 
>Marshall found that a quarter of the troops admitted they had been 
>so scared they vomited.  Nearly a quarter shit their pants.  Ten 
>percent urinated in their BDUs.  Officers were so frightened that 
>they experienced dry mouth and gagging and could not issue 
>comprehensible orders under fire.
>
>War is not a computer game.
>
>Love,
>
>Apollo
>
>

Shawn (Houseplant, Marinate / SF) 
Kelly Williams (Tribal Souls), 
Anthony S. (Groove), 
Phil Gauthier (Tribal Souls), 
Jesse (Tribal Souls). 

One of the last true underground monthly parties to be held in the bay 
area, if you have been to any of our parties you know what I'm talking about! 


This month is definitely not one to miss either. Markie is a SF legend and 
will grace us with his hypnotic house beats for all in attendance. 

10pm-6am, 
$10 before 11pm, 
18 and up, 
same bay area location as always
info lines: 
415.220.FUNK / 916.556.FUNK / 209.557.FUNK 

Coming up March 1, 2003 Tribal Souls will be taking over the upstairs room at 
the DNA Lounge @ the Melon party. Go to dnalounge.com for more info.

I know this comes without invitation, but if you are concerned about 
the types of censorship and sponsorship that plague media and the govt 
(and everything else), here are four URL's that are worth looking at. i 
hope you find them worthwhile- particularly if you cherish the web, 
which once was an open, free and common forum that economic interests 
and other old school bullies are swiftly converting into an obnoxiously 
convenient and customizable marketplace just like the TV you have 
abandoned....



http://www.dfn.org/index.htm
http://www.cpsr.org/
http://slashdot.org/
http://www.eff.org/

i just spent the day in my car listening largely to NPR for lack of a 
better alternative and being told by this "objective" public source 
(sponsered by Arthur Daniels Midland and other heavy hitters, ahem) 
that America is solidly convinced of and fully supporting our just 
cause for war after Colin Powell's rather redundant speach at the UN 
the other day. The commentator cited a survey that indicated we 
Americans were pro-war through and through with all doubts relieved by 
a few taped messages in arabic and renderings of hypothetical labs on 
wheels. the world is listening to this garbage while d rumsfeld (a good 
chum of hussein's until the end of the Iran conflict) goes about 
insulting key members of the UN, EU and NATO and then questioning why 
they took offence. with a commander in chief that sets a precedent like 
gwb's infamous and fated "axis of evil" speech, precursor to the 
current nuclear escalation in North Korea etc, i am not surprised by 
the war secretary's ignorant rhetoric. he is. after all, paid good 
money to instigate war. looks like general dynamic and raytheon will 
continue to climb (along with oil futures) while the rest of try to pay 
the rent largely on pathetic non-living wages.

hope the rant was not unsavory.

please check out the links and ignore me if it was so.

peace.

jv

>> Terry is definitely one of the /great/ moderators
>> this list has been blessed with
>>
>> if you don't get pissed off at least once in a while by
>> something somebody posts - you're just not
>> paying attention - and, I think, that is part of
>> the whole point
>>
>> I don't post publically very often anymore -
>> a lot of us don't - but we're still here - and we're
>> still interacting with each other and making
>> new friends - Terry rocks
>>
>> Namaste

>> Jim Cyr

LoL.... Thanks4 bringing that up John... I was waiting 2 hear from U on this
post...LoL...Hello 2Day!

1015 is totally know 4 the usual Friday/Saturday night clubs?  Those nights
bring in out the Random Clubber looking 2 boogie, out of town tourists
clubbers who heard bout the club & wanna C 4 themselves what it's ablout,
friends of the promoters of those nights, & so & so on la la la la!  Oh
yeah... 1015 does attract the "Asian" clubbers as well, whatever, just
thuogh I'd sdd that in...

But that crowd is that crowd John!  That crowd has nothing to do w/ the
crowd that comes to the our Benefit!  Well, I mean, there were many a times
I collected emails from people in line there & they get out emails about our
events & come out, ya know!  So people who regularly go there come out to
SFLNC events as well, whatever...

I mean... I jus' also wanna point out that the 1st year we had
"Ascension"...
we held it @ 550 & that was an Awesome vibe that night!  Last year when we
had "Ascension", we had it @ 1015 & it was very successful as well!  Good
People, Good Vibe, Good Music!!

Now Security is Security.... I'm not sure the last time U went there, but
I"m sure there have been serveral phases of chages in sercurity crew there
since U were last there!  I mean, they do their job John 'cause they have
to!!!  When I was there last Thursday 4 that Film party shindig, they were
CooL!!  They didn't bother any1 inside from what I saw & the people there
didn't cause any problem for them to be unplurie sercurity people!!

What I'm saying is John... U know won't know until U go check it out!!  From
what I experienced, the SFLNC draws in a Groovy crowd that security dos not
have a problem with, ya know!!!

Also... this is a Thursday night!!  I'm pretty sure this night won't draw in
the weekend crowd that the security acts more harsher towards!

Dude... I hope I see U there!!  I remember last year when a whole bunch of
SFR people came out!!  It was a fun time!

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] off-topic list content - does the list moderator do any moderadation?!

I'd like to chime in on this topic. I've been an active participate on this
list for about 13 months now. I have found this list to be a community, a
family. While I enjoy the discussions about parties, promoters, djs, sound,
dancing, glowsticking, etc, I also enjoy the posts when people share their
personality and give their views about a variety of topics. I skip over the
topics I don't want to read and I'm glad there is no one doing the sorting
for me. I am usually very careful to mark my off topic posts with NRR, and I
know that a lot of people filter such posts to a separate folder or the
trash. If you read this list for a while, I think you will find that we
police ourselves, and if anyone goes too far off the deep end, we the
community will rise up and address it. I love the fact that whenever someone
complains about Geri Dahl's posts, people speak up both against her and in
support of her. If the overwhelming majority of people were against letting
her post, I'm sure the moderator would ban her from the list. Isn't this the
ultimate expression of what it means to live in a free and technologically
advanced society? How many people in the world get to participate in
something like this? While we know "the law" monitors this list, we have no
fear of them shutting it down or censoring it. There are countries where you
can be executed just for having an internet connection! So, I'm going to
suggest that you first take some time and read people's posts, and
appreciate what they contribute to this community. Yes we have our ugly
stepchildren, but while I cringe whenever I see their name on a post, I
fully support their right to be jerks. If this is too much for you to
handle, setup some filters. And if that still doesn't sanitize the list
enough for you, I wish you well in your search to find what you are looking
for.

Happy  :-)

"A happy person is not a person in a certain set of circumstances,
but rather a person with a certain set of attitudes." -Hugh Downs


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> free -- democratized -- by technology.  The new "socialism."  People are
> getting together, forming collectives and other entities to share

can't own it (it cannot be owned), they are determined to destroy it.

> understand what's going down here.

They understand all right.  They just can't come out and say that what
they really want is a legally-enforced monopoly on ALL music.

Ride the Music

Subject: [sfraves] Jolly Green Jungle is coming!

--Boundary_(ID_pUaSAmk73J7b7LsmCm5ISw)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

Ok everyone, I'm really excited about this party.  I've been thinking
about doing it for months and it's finally coming together.  It is
perhaps the strangest theme for a drum and bass party ever, but it
should be a really good time.  And all the DJ's aren't just tall, they
are really good too. 

 

Here are links to the flyer.

 

http://www.djfreya.com/flyers/jollygreenjungle_cmyk_front.jpg

http://www.djfreya.com/flyers/jollygreenjungle_back_400w.jpg 

 

Name : Jolly Green Jungle 

Date: Saturday March 1st 

Time: 10pm-4am 

Location: 10 minutes from the bay bridge 

Info line (415) 364-3095 

Price: $7 

-One night only, the tallest DJ's ever to convene under one roof 
-Over 32 Feet of DJ'ing experience behind the decks 
-A true underground party 

DJs: 
Controlled Substance (Illformants/Subtitles/Thermal/Breakbeatscience,
6'3.5") A Bay Area Drum&Bass innovator with mad skills behind the decks
as well as the mixing board-CS's laptop will be boomin with a trunk of
funk, playin a little somethin you've never heard before... 

Freya (Hemisphere, 6'3", with heels-???) Smother, warmer, and more
soulful than ever, founder of the chillinest DnB night SF has ever seen,
Freya creates emotionally impacting mixes that shake your rump and move
your soul... 

Genome (Groundscore, 6'5") Resident at SF's legendary Eklektic,
Groundscore Admin to some of you, Bad Motherfucker to the rest...The
last party we had at this location, Genome's blistering mix killed it,
rinsed it, mashed it up, and twisted it out...beware... 

Fife (InnerspaceResearchGroup, 6'6") If you bought a drum&bass record
from Ameoba in S.F., this man probably turned you on to it. Fife's
record box is always pushing the envelope, stuffed with mind-blowing
atmospheric dancefloor tunes... 

Highside (Hemisphere, 6'7") Highside's mix cds have been making the
rounds among East Bay heads, Hemisphere resident and the evening's
tallest spinna-he always starts slow, but finishes fast, strap yourself
in for a ride...inside...the one like Highside...

 

Call on the day of the event for directions.  Hope to see you all there.

 

-Fife

Subject: Re: [sfraves] off-topic list content - does the list moderator

For those of us tired of a US news media unable or unwilling to look closely
at topics less "entertaining" than Michael Jackson's face, BBC World News is
available here:

http://www.idcn.net/mv/tvbbc.asx

Just paste the URL into Windows Media Player (File/Open URL). It's a 300K
feed so this is probably only for people with broadband, but what a
difference from the spin on CNN.

For instance, funny we don't hear much about this here:

> COLIN POWELL'S much-vaunted case for war against Iraq suffered a setback
> yesterday when it emerged that chunks of British "intelligence" that he
> invoked were copied verbatim from an old article by a young academic.
> http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,3-569257,00.html

In other words, a California student's thesis written around the time of the
last Gulf war...

> UK's Blair under fire for plagiarised Iraq dossier
> Reuters:
>    "Outraged politicians jumped on the revelation to accuse Blair of
> misleading the public and said it cast doubt on the credibility of his
> whole case against Saddam.

 
>> I know this comes without invitation, but if you are concerned about
>> the types of censorship and sponsorship that plague media and the govt
>> (and everything else), here are four URL's that are worth looking at. i
>> hope you find them worthwhile- particularly if you cherish the web,
>> which once was an open, free and common forum that economic interests
>> and other old school bullies are swiftly converting into an obnoxiously
>> convenient and customizable marketplace just like the TV you have
>> abandoned....
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> http://www.dfn.org/index.htm
>> http://www.cpsr.org/
>> http://slashdot.org/
>> http://www.eff.org/

Hey to all,

I just saw a reference made to 'wicca'. As an credentialed Priest of 
the Old Religion (yep, we have numerous 'formal' organizations),
I find much of the creativity of the Craft in contemporary rave/edm 
scene: the dress, physical environment, PLUR values, etc., all have 
strong correspondents in witchcraft.

I see this as all good, all fabulous!

James Lovette-Black (Jim)

    Yes probably true, but then again doesn't the rave scene have strong 
correspondents to just about every religion, old and new? it's kind of a 
metaphoric spiritual typhoon of just about every spiritual or non spiritual 
influence east to west and north to south. It seems to me, that the rave 
scene itself, seems to mock religion and orthodoxy but at the same time it 
somehow manages to keep everyone happy and decent to one another... even 
though there is no rules, it's a chaotic environment, but it's the total 
oppisite of what the government thinks a chaotic environment is.... maybe i'm 
going off on a tangent now... but i think ravers often forget the 
significance of the scene and it's potential. - johnny bzzzz

Subject: [sfraves] Oppose Culture War Against Raves! 

--=====================_4984616==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

February 7, 2003

Oppose Culture War Against Raves!

In the 1960s, hippie culture was seen as threatening, irresponsible and 
primarily about drug use. Even though most of those young people came 
together because of a mutual interest in peace, adults of that era labeled 
them as criminals and troublemakers.

A new kind of social event that mixes an electronic music concert, light 
show and dancing--popularly known as raves--has been similarly stigmatized. 
The media often portray raves as dangerous, sinister drug fests and the 
people who attend them as criminals who only use the events to sell drugs 
to youth. Raves, however, are a legitimate cultural event just like rock 
concerts, art exhibitions and film screenings, and are an important outlet 
for youth culture today.

In a misguided spin-off of the "War on Drugs," the Senate is considering 
legislation that targets raves and would have the effect of classifying 
common rave items like glow sticks and massage oils as drug paraphernalia. 
The Reducing Americans Vulnerability to Ecstasy (RAVE) Act, introduced by 
Senator Joseph Biden (D-DE) in the 107th Congress, is back but is being 
referred to now as the "Crack-house Statute amendments".  S. 226 would also 
impose huge fines and even prison time on the owners of venues into which 
customers bring controlled substances. No matter how much security is put 
in place, they could be held responsible for the actions of just one customer.

Holding club owners and promoters of raves criminally liable for what some 
people may do at these events is no different from arresting the stadium 
owners and promoters of a Rolling Stones concert or a rap show because some 
concertgoers may be smoking or selling marijuana. Unless a loud and 
powerful objection to this legislation is voiced, an already misunderstood 
community and culture could be criminalized.

Urge your Senators to oppose attacks on youth culture!

S. 226 threatens free speech.

If S. 226 becomes law, property owners may be too afraid to rent or lease 
their space for events rightly or wrongly perceived as attracting drug 
users -- essentially any event that attracts a young crowd. Out of fear of 
massive fines and prison sentences, law-abiding business owners may stop 
hosting raves and other musical events, driving them further underground 
and away from public health and safety regulations.

  S. 226 is too broad and puts business owners at risk.

While supporters of the bill claim that innocent business owners do not 
need to worry because it only applies to people who knowingly own property 
for the purpose of manufacturing, distributing, or using a controlled 
substance, the terms are too undefined to provide adequate protection to 
innocent business owners. Despite good security, restaurant, bar, 
nightclub, dance and music venue owners could all be fined hundreds of 
thousands of dollars and forced into bankruptcy if a customer sneaks in drugs.

  The bill will endanger the lives and safety of youth.

Under this law, business owners who host raves would be reluctant to enact 
important measures to protect their customers. By insinuating that selling 
bottled water and offering "cool off" rooms is proof that owners and 
promoters know drug use is occurring at their events--as the Senate bill 
from last year suggests--the bill could make business owners too afraid to 
implement such harm-reduction measures and the safety of young people will 
suffer.

TAKE ACTION!

Follow this link http://tinyurl.com/5k04 that will take you to the ACLU 
Action site.  There you will find a simple, automated process that will 
enable you to identify and fax your legislators in under a minute.

Protect your rights now, brothers and sisters.

Much love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one 
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken
--=====================_4984616==_.ALT--

    I propose that ravers create their own political party, the party of "
Ridofit" 
    Why do you ask? well, because we got rid of it.... 
        what do we want? PLUR!  when do we want it?? Now!




This is kinda like my outline statement that i have been playing with lately, 
as if i were the speaker of ridofit, what i would present as my goal for the 
nation. I must point out that it is written in a very amature fashion and it 
might sound way too idealistic or egotistical on my part for having written 
it...? but i am interested if anyone agrees with this type of vision for the 
US?? I think it's very john lennon-ish.

  "Ridofit"
A legitimate, gradual, political effort to reduce government power over the 
people to 0%. 

U.S. military will be reduced and neutralized, global security will be 
largely in the hands of the United Nations which will be globally responsible 
for battling terrorism. 

Nuclear weapons will be publically disarmed, along with the Nuclear weapons 
of all of the other threatening nations. Who should by all means understand 
the meaning of this peacful gesture and do the same.

There is no Police force per se, no security guards, no guns, no handcuffs, 
no jails. The community is now in itself, it's own justice and peace keeper. 
People are incouraged to find the "black sheep" and help them in their 
transformation into a more peaceful wholesome being, rather than ignore and 
avoid these "types" while they linger in resentment of the community until 
lashing out in violent and destructive crime. People are incouraged not to 
rely on the law to defend their rights but rather to rely on themselves and 
their community. People are incouraged to communicate with eachother and 
built trust, and security within their friends, their family, their school, 
work and every person they encounter. People who do not follow in the 
peaceful productive ways of the community will be frowned upon and confronted 
constantly by wiser elders and more responsible peers. Massive arenas of 
entertainment, arts, sports, technology, science and spirtuality and good 
food and health services will assist in happier more peaceful communities. 

Legalization of drugs, alcahol and all forms of sex will result in a high 
quality of life and spiritual contentment. 

Spirituality is of huge concern and is the main focus of education, after a 
child finds him/herself and choses a direction in life he/she will recieve a 
lifetime of free education in the subject of his/her choice.

Money spent on millitary, weapons, national security, police forces, and 
security devices will be recycled in to the communities for better and free 
education, free food for the hungry, clothing for the cold, and shelter for 
the homeless and will be invested in spirtual, environmental, and scientific 
studies and preservation. 

If United States is attacked for any reason we will remain neutral and rely 
on the protection of and our participation in the United Nations for 
retaliation. Our nation itself will not participate, initiate, or provacate 
war or violence. We will suffer through any unjustified, attack on our 
country, much in the example of all of the worlds spiritual leaders have 
always tried to teach us. Having faith in people, trust in the community, and 
an overwhelming developement in music, arts, entertainment, and spirtiuality 
will transform us from the most feared nation in the world to the most 
respected and peacefully revolutionary one. Therefor reducing terrorism not 
by force but by honerable example.
(i do realize that as of now most people living in the united states are not 
"passivists" and therefor probably will not agree with a word of what i just 
said but it's fun to play with these ideas is it not?)

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Official Soulseek Press Release
February 8, 2003
Thomas Mennecke
OFFICIAL ANNOUNCEMENT - Re: Soulseek Status


This is to provide the official status of the Soulseek network as Friday,
February 7th and onward. I have spoken to Nir and Rosalind Arbel on the
matter over the course of this week and prior to this event taking place,
and this notice is being offered on their behalf.

The artist calling herself Sapphirecut previously made a complaint towards
Soulseek regarding the sharing of her material on the network. When she had
contacted Soulseek regarding the matter, she failed to state which material
was in question. There was no information provided, aside from her being
"Sapphirecut". Therefore, acting on such, a global message was made to users
not to share the artist's material, and a notice was made upon entering chat
rooms of the same.

Unfortunately, this was not satisfactory, and the artist went on to file a
complaint against Verio - Soulseek's server host, stating DMCA Copyright
Infringement. Verio, in return did not conduct a formal inquiry into the
situation. Rather, they acted rather quickly, requiring the server, and site
to be pulled. Thus, there was no warning that such was going to take place.
This not only applied to the users of Soulseek, but to Nir himself. On
sudden notice, he was required to seek out a new host for the server.

To calm the air of panic, this does NOT mean that Soulseek is down forever.
The RIAA did NOT have an injunction against Nir, as rumors have stated.
Soulseek WILL be returning shortly, and this unfortunate delay was not
expected. A new potential host has been found, however they are working
through the paperwork for such, and have not completed such as quickly as we
would have expected. At this level, it is out of Nir's hands as they have to
simply go through the process of completing it. That said, we apologize
again for the delay and hope that it does not last a great deal longer.

It is important to note that Soulseek can not and will not condone any
actions towards the artist that may cause her or her affiliated labels harm.
Such actions would include defaming emails, defacing, or otherwise damaging
her website or the site of her affiliates, and other further actions which
may be damaging. Such actions will simply result in further problems for the
network, as the artist will direct complaints towards Soulseek itself. Those
wishing to show their support for Soulseek will best do so by simply NOT
sharing any files by this artist. The files in question include:

1.Free Your Mind, Megan's epic mix.


2.Free Your Mind, Sapphirecut's Original mix


3.Action-Reaction by Sapphirecut (in any form)


4.Any music that has Sapphirecut on it except the Illustrious track "I'd Say
Yes", which is a remix.

We thank you for your patience and support through this situation, and we
look forward to seeing all users back on Soulseek shortly. Users who wish
further information regarding the DMCA are directed to browse to
www.chillingeffects.org. All information needed regarding the act can be
read or studied there. Cheers.

On behalf of Nir and Rosalind Arbel,
Sean Nelson / Proteus93
Soulseek Administration


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

Apollo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Soulseek Press Release

":: Our musical family grows through the connections that we meet day by
day. We need your support. Twisted is an Independent dance lable that can
only survive through the sales that it receives. We are NOT talking about
big business, we speak of the future of independent music. We can not be
distributed throughout the world unless the Independents survive and they
are dying out as a result of MP3 pirating and CD copying.

:: Please let us continue to survive and draw creative input from this world
connection by purchasing our music."

-- The Sapphirecut Website

Feel free to share your thoughts with this act: megan@sapphirecut.com

The way I see this it is a great way to get your name out quick by getting
some free PR. Shutdown a major P2P server, get your name all over the net,
people suddenly know who you are. The statement above from the artist's
website is a farse. MP3 has changed the music industry forever. The freely
swappable files enable an unknown to become a known. In the case of a dj act
like this the primary sales are going to come from vinyl. If a dj can hear
the full track and enjoy it they will be more likely to buy it.

I still think this is a clever way to get your name out and a shitload of
attention. I wouldn't have heard this person had it not been for this little
kid move against SoulSeek.

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
www.sninesix.com
www.innocentchild.com



----- Original Message -----
From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Sunday, February 09, 2003 11:22 AM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Soulseek Press Release


Official Soulseek Press Release
February 8, 2003
Thomas Mennecke
OFFICIAL ANNOUNCEMENT - Re: Soulseek Status


This is to provide the official status of the Soulseek network as Friday,
February 7th and onward. I have spoken to Nir and Rosalind Arbel on the
matter over the course of this week and prior to this event taking place,
and this notice is being offered on their behalf.

The artist calling herself Sapphirecut previously made a complaint towards
Soulseek regarding the sharing of her material on the network. When she had
contacted Soulseek regarding the matter, she failed to state which material
was in question. There was no information provided, aside from her being
"Sapphirecut". Therefore, acting on such, a global message was made to users
not to share the artist's material, and a notice was made upon entering chat
rooms of the same.

Unfortunately, this was not satisfactory, and the artist went on to file a
complaint against Verio - Soulseek's server host, stating DMCA Copyright
Infringement. Verio, in return did not conduct a formal inquiry into the
situation. Rather, they acted rather quickly, requiring the server, and site
to be pulled. Thus, there was no warning that such was going to take place.
This not only applied to the users of Soulseek, but to Nir himself. On
sudden notice, he was required to seek out a new host for the server.

To calm the air of panic, this does NOT mean that Soulseek is down forever.
The RIAA did NOT have an injunction against Nir, as rumors have stated.
Soulseek WILL be returning shortly, and this unfortunate delay was not
expected. A new potential host has been found, however they are working
through the paperwork for such, and have not completed such as quickly as we
would have expected. At this level, it is out of Nir's hands as they have to
simply go through the process of completing it. That said, we apologize
again for the delay and hope that it does not last a great deal longer.

It is important to note that Soulseek can not and will not condone any
actions towards the artist that may cause her or her affiliated labels harm.
Such actions would include defaming emails, defacing, or otherwise damaging
her website or the site of her affiliates, and other further actions which
may be damaging. Such actions will simply result in further problems for the
network, as the artist will direct complaints towards Soulseek itself. Those
wishing to show their support for Soulseek will best do so by simply NOT
sharing any files by this artist. The files in question include:

1.Free Your Mind, Megan's epic mix.


2.Free Your Mind, Sapphirecut's Original mix


3.Action-Reaction by Sapphirecut (in any form)


4.Any music that has Sapphirecut on it except the Illustrious track "I'd Say
Yes", which is a remix.

We thank you for your patience and support through this situation, and we
look forward to seeing all users back on Soulseek shortly. Users who wish
further information regarding the DMCA are directed to browse to
www.chillingeffects.org. All information needed regarding the act can be
read or studied there. Cheers.

On behalf of Nir and Rosalind Arbel,
Sean Nelson / Proteus93
Soulseek Administration


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Oppose Culture War Against Raves! 


On Saturday, February 8, 2003, at 11:42 PM, JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:
>   "Ridofit"
> A legitimate, gradual, political effort to reduce government power 
> over the
> people to 0%.

> Spirituality is of huge concern and is the main focus of education, 
> after a
> child finds him/herself and choses a direction in life he/she will 
> recieve a
> lifetime of free education in the subject of his/her choice.
>
> Money spent on millitary, weapons, national security, police forces, 
> and
> security devices will be recycled in to the communities for better and 
> free
> education, free food for the hungry, clothing for the cold, and 
> shelter for
> the homeless and will be invested in spirtual, environmental, and 
> scientific
> studies and preservation.

You seem to have positive goals, but I'm confused about the logic here.
You say 0% government is the goal but you seem to be proposing:
- continuing to have the government teach US history
- expanding the welfare state (who pays for this and how is it possible 
to collect taxes without coercion?)
- the merging church and state

Cheers,
Steve

>   "Ridofit"
>A legitimate, gradual, political effort to reduce government power over the
>people to 0%.
>

>largely in the hands of the United Nations which will be globally 
>responsible
>for battling terrorism.

>Nuclear weapons will be publically disarmed, along with the Nuclear weapons
>of all of the other threatening nations. Who should by all means understand
>the meaning of this peacful gesture and do the same.
>
>There is no Police force per se, no security guards, no guns, no handcuffs,
>no jails. The community is now in itself, it's own justice and peace 
>keeper.
>People are incouraged to find the "black sheep" and help them in their
>transformation into a more peaceful wholesome being, rather than ignore and
>avoid these "types" while they linger in resentment of the community until
>lashing out in violent and destructive crime. People are incouraged not to
>rely on the law to defend their rights but rather to rely on themselves and
>their community. People are incouraged to communicate with eachother and
>built trust, and security within their friends, their family, their school,
>work and every person they encounter. People who do not follow in the
>peaceful productive ways of the community will be frowned upon and 
>confronted
>constantly by wiser elders and more responsible peers. Massive arenas of
>entertainment, arts, sports, technology, science and spirtuality and good
>food and health services will assist in happier more peaceful communities.
>
>Legalization of drugs, alcahol and all forms of sex will result in a high
>quality of life and spiritual contentment.
>
>Spirituality is of huge concern and is the main focus of education, after a
>child finds him/herself and choses a direction in life he/she will recieve 
>a
>lifetime of free education in the subject of his/her choice.
>
>Money spent on millitary, weapons, national security, police forces, and
>security devices will be recycled in to the communities for better and free
>education, free food for the hungry, clothing for the cold, and shelter for
>the homeless and will be invested in spirtual, environmental, and 
>scientific
>studies and preservation.
>
>If United States is attacked for any reason we will remain neutral and rely
>on the protection of and our participation in the United Nations for
>retaliation. Our nation itself will not participate, initiate, or provacate
>war or violence. We will suffer through any unjustified, attack on our
>country, much in the example of all of the worlds spiritual leaders have
>always tried to teach us. Having faith in people, trust in the community, 
>and
>an overwhelming developement in music, arts, entertainment, and 
>spirtiuality
>will transform us from the most feared nation in the world to the most
>respected and peacefully revolutionary one. Therefor reducing terrorism not
>by force but by honerable example.

>not

all the Fuck U Up Music 'cause all the DJs, Hello 2Day, spun Amazing =
sets that jus' Fucked Me Up while I was dancing on the floor!

& it was so nice!!  I satrted dancing right away when I got in there!!  =

breakdown that went on 4 a few measures where it like went down to like =
this down tempo beat & oooooooh man... so nice!

Then Konkers went on & spun this Awesome Techno Set that was nice & Hard =
& oh man... So Dope!!!  It's been really nice getting my fill of Techno =
Lateley!!!  But I could sworn he spun like Breakbeats @ the Start of his =
set though... hmmmmmm

tip, w/ I think lots of Acid Techno 2 if I'm not mistaken, right????  =

dancefloor!!!

other room!!  So Nice!

2 people 'cause oh My Goodness... every1 was there!!  It'd be soooooo =
ridiculous 2 try 2 name every1 who I saw there, but man, it was totally =
filled w/ Family every which way I looked & walked!  LoL... Finally hung =
out w/ Nico after a year of online chatting which was Groovy!  LoL... =
Hella Funny Guy!  But yeah man... it was sooooooo Gooooood 2 B around =
Family all 2gether in 1 place!

inside... I dunno... but man... there were all these Acid Breakbeats =
goin' on & I was Lovin' it!  OK... I do totally give it up 2 Indigo 4 =
his set!!!  I can't even begin to describe how his set was!!!  Full of =
yummy Breakbeats & ooooooh my gosh.. there was this 1 track where he =
spun this sweeeet vocal that this Girlie was singing!  Also notable =

anouther vocal track & the words like totally summed up what the whole =
night was about & LoL.... he spun the Bird as his closing closing =
track!!!  Niiiiiiice!

Medicine!!!

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROTESTS AND WALKOUTS

As the Bush Administration threatens to wage a unilateral 
war of aggression we must do all we can to make this 
movement the single biggest obstacle to war. We do not 
believe that war in inevitable. However, if the war starts 
we must be organized to resist and disable the war 
machine.

The DAY a new U.S. war on Iraq starts -- EMERGENCY PROTEST 
at a central location -- in Washington, D.C. at the White 
House, in New York at Times Square, in San Francisco at 
Powell and Market -- to protest the war followed by a 
march through city neighborhoods beginning at 5 p.m. (the 
next day at 5 p.m. of the bombing begins at night). Many 
cities and communities have a tradition of holding these 
emergency actions in response to U.S. military aggression. 
If your community does not have a traditional plan, pick a 
busy location/intersection, a Federal Building, Town Hall, 
etc.

THE MORNING AFTER THE WAR STARTS -- WALK OUT/STAYAWAY! 
ORGANIZE WALK OUTS from school, work, leave your home. 
Spend the morning leafleting for people to join the 
anti-war movement. A.N.S.W.E.R. offices and organizing 
centers around the country will be open in the morning to 
pick up leaflets and from there you can head out with 
others into your community. Converge mid-day at noon at 
city centers -- in Washington, D.C. at the White House, in 
New York City at Union Square, in San Francisco at Civic 
Center Plaza -- to engage in protest actions against the 
war. Download flyers at www.internationalanswer.org and 
locate organizing centers in your area.

THE FIRST SATURDAY AFTER -- CONVERGE AT THE WHITE HOUSE -- 
The Saturday after a new war on Iraq is launched, 
thousands of people will be converging at the White House 
in Washington DC at 12 noon.

To list your city's Emergency Response Mobilization Plan, 
fill out the form at
http://www.internationalanswer.org/campaigns/emerg/index.html#emergevent
(if the link does not take you directly to the form, just 
scroll down)

---------------------------------------

FEBRUARY 15 & 16 MASS ACTIONS
Part of the February 13-21 Week of Resistance

On February 15, there will be demonstrations in thousands 
of cities across the country and around the world in 
response to the call issued from the European anti-war 
movement. The A.N.S.W.E.R. Coalition joins with the 
hundreds of organizations who will be mobilizing for the 
NYC, Chicago, Los Angeles and other regional and local 
actions on that day. On February 16, there will be a mass 
action in San Francisco co-sponsored by the A.N.S.W.E.R. 
Coalition, Bay Area United Against War, Not in Our Name 
Project, and United for Peace and Justice.

In New York City, join A.N.S.W.E.R. on Friday, February 14 
for a teach-in from 9 am to 4 pm on Building an anti-war 
movement that connects the struggle against war on Iraq 
with the fight for social and economic justice and civil 
rights at home, followed by an Indoor Rally from 7 to 10 
pm on Linking the struggle against corporate 
globalization, war, militarism and racism. Both events 
will take place at Community Church, 35th St. between Park 
and Madison Ave.

To find out about FEBRUARY 15 & 16 LOCAL AND REGIONAL 
EVENTS, AND BUSES TO THEM GO TO:
http://www.internationalanswer.org/campaigns/f15/f15transp.html

Fill out this form if you are ORGAINZING A LOCAL OR 
REGIONAL EVENT:
http://www.internationalanswer.org/campaigns/f15/index.html#feb15event
(If the link does not take you directly to the form, 
scroll down to the form entitled "List your local area 
February 15th event")

Fill out this form if you are ORGANIZING TRANSPORTATION TO 
A REGIONAL EVENT:
http://www.internationalanswer.org/campaigns/f15/index.html#f15transp
(If the link does not take you directly to the form, 
scroll down to the form entitled "Fill out this form to 
list details about transportation to February 15 & 16 
regional events")

For more information, go to:
http://www.internationalanswer.org/campaigns/f15/index.html

---------------------------------------

FOR MORE INFORMATION:
http://www.InternationalANSWER.org
http://www.VoteNoWar.org
dc@internationalanswer.org
New York 212-633-6646
Washington 202-544-3389
Los Angeles 213-487-2368
San Francisco 415-821-6545

To make a tax-deductible donation, go to
http://www.internationalanswer.org/donate.html

Sign up to receive updates (low volume):
http://www.internationalanswer.org/subscribelist.html

Subject: [sfraves] valentine's day advice

together, and i finally found a new place and now it looks like i will be
moving on valentines day.  woo hoo, irony lives.  my question is
this:  after moving all my things to my new place this friday, should i

1) stay home and unpack and try to medidate on how i don't need anyone but
me, and how valentine's day is just a hallmark scam desgined to make the
unattatched feel bad, or

2) go out and party like the newly single fool i truly am now?

what do y'all think?  and, if 2), advice on where the hell i should go
would be very, very welcome (oh, i am in san francisco).

help unbreak a lonely heart!  cheers,

jacob

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tons of NEW Hardcore/Happy Hardcore at Solid Grooves! <bsp>

I personally from a DJ standpoint think that grouping resitance recordsin 
the HHC bin is apporiate.. Now keep in mind I don't listen to HHC or any of 
that and I don't know andy personally so it ain't like I got "his back" on 
this issue.. But I personal play prog house and have many tracks on lots of 
labels that are not Traditionally "Prog House" labels and they fit just fine 
in the prog section and vice versa goes for some prog labels that can be 
worked into a Traditonal house set. So it is like splitting hairs.. Cause if 
you ask me what Tronic plays is Hard core, Happy hardcore or whatever.. It 
is fast and annoying to *ME*

Now I know that just pissed alot of you off... But that is a fact to most 
people that listen to slower types of music. Just like people may not like 
"Prog house" or don't consider it house it is trance etc.. to each there own 
opinion :)

Please drive forward!

Macadio

Go out and have fun. Don't make the night into anything more than it is.
Remember that it's a Friday night like any other time of the year, but since
there is some corporate fueled holiday you have parties occuring. Masquerade
Di Valentino is going to be awesome. It's on Valentine's day in Oakland
somewhere. 5 rooms, tons of people, and the perfect way to go out and just
have fun. Sitting around and thinking about why the holiday is stupid and
corporate fueled is a waste of time. =)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tons of NEW Hardcore/Happy Hardcore at Solid Grooves! <bsp>

Exactly. It's symantics and splitting hairs. What's too progressive and more
on the trance side of things might be too housey to someone else. It's all
perspective. Something to also consider is when playing a HHC/hard house set
do you and other dj's in the genre stick solely to just that spectrum?
Consider that in a jungle/dnb set you might here something that's a rather
2-stepish track or rather on the breakbeat side of things. Still works,
still uses similar patches in the sequence, but if you're picky about genres
you could easily say those aren't jungle/dnb! Those tracks are the ambiguous
tracks. One of the prime examples that comes to mind is the AK1200 remix of
Cleveland Lounge's Drowning. That's dnb/breaks/progressive trance all
wrapped into one. Given the speed of the track it falls more under dnb, but
the sounds and structure of the track definately sound like other genres.

Anyway - I'm sure you have better things to get irritated about, like
traffic on 880 and all the shithead drivers out there. ;-)

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
design :: www.sninesix.com
photography :: www.innocentchild.com


----- Original Message -----
From: "Macadio G." <macadio@hotmail.com>
To: <itswidow@hotmail.com>; <datpsychoguy@hotmail.com>;
<bayareahappycore@yahoogroups.com>; <sacramento_happycore@yahoogroups.com>;
<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, February 10, 2003 12:14 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tons of NEW Hardcore/Happy Hardcore at Solid Grooves!
<bsp>


I personally from a DJ standpoint think that grouping resitance recordsin
the HHC bin is apporiate.. Now keep in mind I don't listen to HHC or any of
that and I don't know andy personally so it ain't like I got "his back" on
this issue.. But I personal play prog house and have many tracks on lots of
labels that are not Traditionally "Prog House" labels and they fit just fine
in the prog section and vice versa goes for some prog labels that can be
worked into a Traditonal house set. So it is like splitting hairs.. Cause if
you ask me what Tronic plays is Hard core, Happy hardcore or whatever.. It
is fast and annoying to *ME*

Now I know that just pissed alot of you off... But that is a fact to most
people that listen to slower types of music. Just like people may not like
"Prog house" or don't consider it house it is trance etc.. to each there own
opinion :)

Please drive forward!

Macadio

Subject: [sfraves] found this:

this seemed like such a good idea... it had to be passed along

*****************************************************************

Friends and Fellow Americans:

As the drums of war begin to sound it is the duty of those who 
want peace to remind the President that not all in this great land 
of ours are happy with the blind march towards slaughter. While 
street demonstrations are a good way of raising the people's 
awareness of political unrest, it appears that the recent rallies 
have fallen on deaf ears.

It is time to take a new tack. We need to make an emotional 
connection between the concept of peace and something dear to our 
President's heart.

We propose the humble Pretzel.

Our President's zeal for this simple snack food is well known the 
world over. So we propose a mass mailing of pretzels to the White 
House. Enclosed is a recipie for pretzels, if you wish to make a 
Peace Sign shaped pretzel of your own to send. Otherwise a store 
bought pretzel accompanied by a simple note card with a peace sign 
will do.

Act now. We want a million pretzels to reach the White House by 
March 1st. Send this missive off to friends and relatives. Hold 
pretzels for peace baking parties. Change the way our President 
looks at the idea of Peace, send a pretzel today!

pretzels:
2 1/4 t. yeast (or one packet, red star is good yeast)
1 1/2 c very warm water (about 102 degrees F.)
4 c. flour 
1 T. sugar
1 t. salt
Add yeast to warm water and stir. Add flour, sugar, and salt. Mix 
and knead dough. Roll into a sheet and then cut in strips to make 
worms. Shape in pretzel bows, or peace signs, or roll to make 
sticks, or some such thing. Place on cookie sheet (non-stick 
spray, wax-paper, or greasing it lightly is a good idea). Bake at 
425 degrees F. for 12 to 15 minutes, or until light brown.
Just before baking, you can sprink on top any favorite herbs or 
spices, or coarse salt, or maybe even finely chopped bits of 
broccoli. You know, get creative.

Address:

The White House
1600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW
Washington, DC 20500 

Return Address:

Remember your vote is annonymus, so why not make your pretzel 
annoynmus as well? The postmark is the important part, but mail to 
the WhiteHouse really needs a return address, feel free to use 
ours:

John M. and Linda Poindexter
10 Barrington Fare, Rockville, MD, 20850

-The Pretzels for Peace Coalition

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tons of NEW Hardcore/Happy Hardcore at Solid Grooves! <bsp>

>Resistance Recordings is a HARD HOUSE label, not a HARDCORE label... 
> >whatsup with that?!?!

Because Tim, my large mouthed friend, most people associate what I spin to 
be Hardcore, and Solid Grooves chose to place it in the Hardcore section. 
Since we are now being distributed as a HARDCORE label now by a couple of 
distributors, we feel it's ok by us. Hope that clears up any questions you 
might have. :)

andy

I'll have to agree with the vodka over whiskey.  Whiskey is definitely a 
depressing liquor.  If you don't get violent I'd choose tequila over vodka.  
Both are party liquors but damn does tequila kick a night into rockstar 
gear.  Beer will just make you tired and dwell on whats going on in your 
life at that moment.  And I'd also recommend a place with friends who are 
also single or ones who are going out to party with their SO's instead of 
spending it alone and quiet.

I'm a pro at the whole getting dumped/ending it before V-Day.  I've only not 
been single on one of them since I've been dating.

Subject: [sfraves] Rumblings of Coachella 2003...

Anyone already planning on going? They just announced that it will be
happening on April 26 & 27th this year.  Rumored headliners include Jane's
Addiction and Radiohead...

Naturally, all y'all will probably be interested in the rumored lineup for
the Dance Tent (which absolutely rocked last year), and this is what Virgin
Mega has to say:

"The dance tent possibilities look fantastic with talk of Underworld, Deep
Dish, Groove Armada and Timo Maas - if they add Satoshi Tomiie, Danny
Howells, John Creamer and Stephane K, it would be unflappable"

Yeah, $75+ tix and travelling to what is arguably the ass end of California
are unappealing, but the vibe in the tent last year was BEYOND amazing. I've
already booked a (highly inflated) hotel room. See you there!

At 10:45 PM 2/8/2003 -0800, Steve Dekorte wrote:

>On Saturday, February 8, 2003, at 07:20 PM, Apollo wrote:
>>In a misguided spin-off of the "War on Drugs," the Senate is considering 
>>legislation that targets raves and would have the effect of classifying 
>>common rave items like glow sticks and massage oils as drug 
>>paraphernalia. The Reducing Americans Vulnerability to Ecstasy (RAVE) 
>>Act, introduced by Senator Joseph Biden (D-DE) in the 107th Congress, is 
>>back but is being referred to now as the "Crack-house Statute amendments".
>
>Given that both the Democrats and Republicans are pro-Drug War, who do 
>rave-culture friendly folks here vote for? I know Libertarians want to 
>decriminalize all victimless crimes (drugs, prostitution, etc), is the 
>same true of Greens or any other 3rd parties?
>

The Green Party platform includes:

Criminal and Civil Justice Reforms

Abolish the Death Penalty

Prosecute Police Brutality-The Jonny Gammage Law: Require independent 
federal investigation and prosecution of law enforcement officers charged 
with violating the civil rights or causing the bodily injury or death of a 
human being.

End Political and Racial Persecution by the Criminal Justice System: 
Freedom for all political prisoners and prisoners of racial injustice.

Restorative Justice: Establish a humane criminal sanction system based on 
prevention, restitution, rehabilitation, and reconciliation rather than 
vengeance, forced labor, and profits for the Prison-Industrial Complex. 
Restore full funding for college degree granting programs in state and 
federal prisons. Jobs and justice, not more police and prisons.

Legal Aid: Expand funding of legal aid and public defender programs so all 
people can have competent legal representation.

Fight Corporate Crime: Strengthen laws and enforcement against corporate 
crime with penalties that include incarceration of executives and 
revocation of corporate charters.

Oppose Tort Reform that Limits Class Action Lawsuits and Caps Victims' 
Compensation: The threat of high victim compensation awards by civil juries 
must be maintained as an important deterrent to corporate crime.

Civil Liberties: Support the Bill of Rights. No compromise on civil 
liberties and due process for "national security," "anti-terrorism," or 
"the war on drugs." Repeal the 1994 Crime and 1996 Anti-Terrorism bills. 
End domestic political spying by police, military, and intelligence agencies.

End the "War on Drugs:" Decriminalize possession of drugs. Regulate and tax 
drug distribution. Release nonviolent drug war prisoners. Treat drug abuse 
as a health problem, not a criminal problem. Drug abuse treatment on demand.



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one 
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken
--=====================_18157459==_.ALT--

At 02:42 AM 2/9/2003 -0500, JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:
>In a message dated 02/09/2003 1:46:09 AM Eastern Standard Time,
>steve@dekorte.com writes:
