It's always a good thing to outline, at least to yourself, what kind of 
world you would like to see.  This is a good beginning, J, although many 
would disagree with some of the proposals.

A life without beliefs is not worth living.  Beliefs without action are 
meaningless.  I've always believed that "raving," that is positive 
transformation through communal music and dance, is the first step in 
liberating the mind and soul from much of the garbage of modern 
life.  There should, however, be step 2....

Love,

Apollo



>     I propose that ravers create their own political party, the party of "
>Ridofit"
>     Why do you ask? well, because we got rid of it....
>         what do we want? PLUR!  when do we want it?? Now!
>
>
>
>
>This is kinda like my outline statement that i have been playing with lately,
>as if i were the speaker of ridofit, what i would present as my goal for the
>nation. I must point out that it is written in a very amature fashion and it
>might sound way too idealistic or egotistical on my part for having written
>it...? but i am interested if anyone agrees with this type of vision for the
>US?? I think it's very john lennon-ish.
>
>   "Ridofit"
>A legitimate, gradual, political effort to reduce government power over the
>people to 0%.
>
>U.S. military will be reduced and neutralized, global security will be
>largely in the hands of the United Nations which will be globally responsible
>for battling terrorism.
>
>Nuclear weapons will be publically disarmed, along with the Nuclear weapons
>of all of the other threatening nations. Who should by all means understand
>the meaning of this peacful gesture and do the same.
>
>There is no Police force per se, no security guards, no guns, no handcuffs,
>no jails. The community is now in itself, it's own justice and peace keeper.
>People are incouraged to find the "black sheep" and help them in their
>transformation into a more peaceful wholesome being, rather than ignore and
>avoid these "types" while they linger in resentment of the community until
>lashing out in violent and destructive crime. People are incouraged not to
>rely on the law to defend their rights but rather to rely on themselves and
>their community. People are incouraged to communicate with eachother and
>built trust, and security within their friends, their family, their school,
>work and every person they encounter. People who do not follow in the
>peaceful productive ways of the community will be frowned upon and confronted
>constantly by wiser elders and more responsible peers. Massive arenas of
>entertainment, arts, sports, technology, science and spirtuality and good
>food and health services will assist in happier more peaceful communities.
>
>Legalization of drugs, alcahol and all forms of sex will result in a high
>quality of life and spiritual contentment.
>
>Spirituality is of huge concern and is the main focus of education, after a
>child finds him/herself and choses a direction in life he/she will recieve a
>lifetime of free education in the subject of his/her choice.
>
>Money spent on millitary, weapons, national security, police forces, and
>security devices will be recycled in to the communities for better and free
>education, free food for the hungry, clothing for the cold, and shelter for
>the homeless and will be invested in spirtual, environmental, and scientific
>studies and preservation.
>
>If United States is attacked for any reason we will remain neutral and rely
>on the protection of and our participation in the United Nations for
>retaliation. Our nation itself will not participate, initiate, or provacate
>war or violence. We will suffer through any unjustified, attack on our
>country, much in the example of all of the worlds spiritual leaders have
>always tried to teach us. Having faith in people, trust in the community, and
>an overwhelming developement in music, arts, entertainment, and spirtiuality
>will transform us from the most feared nation in the world to the most
>respected and peacefully revolutionary one. Therefor reducing terrorism not
>by force but by honerable example.
>(i do realize that as of now most people living in the united states are not
>"passivists" and therefor probably will not agree with a word of what i just
>said but it's fun to play with these ideas is it not?)
>
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From sfraves-return-98727-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Feb 10 23:54:17 2003

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 11662 invoked from network); 10 Feb 2003 23:54:14 -0000
Message-ID: <20030210235422.14573.qmail@web40704.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 10 Feb 2003 15:54:22 -0800 (PST)
From: Susan Gwartney <sooziqueue@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] a vday message about plur (NNRR - not necessarily rave-related)

with political terror looming, i keep looking around
and wondering if i'm really a firm believer in fate or
if maybe i'm just so jaded and cynical these days that
it makes me downright apathetic.  probably a little of
both.

i was told years ago to choose my battles or lose my
wars, and the advice really struck home.  so i find
that more in my direct view and perhaps, as a result,
more in my immediate concern, there are little wars
going on all around me, wars that more frequently
demand my focus and attention - wars at home, wars at
work, wars in the hearts and minds of people i love.  

it strikes me sometimes that perhaps we are a warring
nation simply because so many of us are at war with
ourselves.  

it seems like we're incapable of finding and keeping
peace, anyway, unless we constantly have fresh
reminders of the ramifications of war, since we're
such shortsighted forgetful things as a species. 
maybe if the american citizens who got royally fucked
over by the political conflicts of the last few
decades weren't all traumatized homeless
schizophrenics as a result (and thereby had some
credibility when they shouted their doomsday
prophecies from city sidewalks), we'd be a little less
eager as a world power to engage other countries in
power struggles and ego games. 

something i'm a little less apathetic about is
valentine's day, maybe because i have someone to spend
it with this year.  i will sheepishly admit, it's nice
to have a little something other than the usual
narcotics to distract me from the mass cultural
anxiety and hysteria that surrounds me because of this
whole war situation.  i wouldn't go so far as to say
that love is all we need, but damn, it sure helps.  

in closing, here's some random food for thought:
others can see how much self-respect you have by how
much respect you show for others than yourself.  there
can be no unity without diversity.

count your blessings this valentine's day.   

sooz

Subject: [sfraves] RE: Rumblings of Coachella 2003...

> I've already booked a (highly inflated) hotel room. See you there!

Just a quick suggestion for a fun Coachella trip...

(I'll not likely have the money to go this year, but I had a blast when I did.)

When I went, a bunch of us from work all chipped in on renting a big-ass RV for
the weekend.  It was $600 to rent it from friday clear through till monday, and
we paid $12 a night for a full-hookup campsite st the Salton Sea.  (And yeah,
there was RV parking at Coachella itself.)

Divided up among the six of us, it was about the same cost as those
aforementioned inflated hotel rooms (prolly slightly more actually, when you
figure in the cost of gas), and we had a MUCH better time driveing down and up
than we would have if we had crammed ourselves (and our stuff) into our cars.

And lemme tell ya... not much livens up an otherwise tediously long trip to the
ass-end of nowhere more than being able to get up and walk back into the
kitchen and make yourself a vodka and Red Bull!


cya,
john

Subject: [sfraves] Do your part to help push US Breaks. - 2/8/2003

Do your part to help push US Breaks. - 2/8/2003I have forwarded this from a
fellow breaks DJ.  Help US artists make more US music!.!.!

Please send an email to Alex Leon (aleon@urb.com) and let URB magazine know
that US breaks deserve some page time!!!
Chris Fenton
<forward below>

Do your part to help push US Breaks. - 2/8/2003
US Breaks.
There is still time to send your letter!
Thank you to everyone who has sent your letter to URB. For those of you who
did not write there is still time for you tell URB your thoughts and
opinion. For those of you who did write, please tell your friends and anyone
else you think agrees with us.

URB Magazine vs. US Breaks
To 1000 Members Strong,

It's amazing that within the past 5 months Kaleidoscope Music has now added
more than 1000 members to our site. In our forum section we have tried to
clear up many issues plaguing the US Breaks scene and all of the
contributions have been very crucial in what we have been trying to present
to URB magazine. For the past 6 months I, Huda Hudia, have been fighting a
battle with URB magazine and have pointed out numerous times about their
lack of coverage for US Breaks. If you look at their review section on
breaks you will hardly ever see any reviews for US Breaks artists. Also,
their lack of support for US Breaks is quite apparent in their lack of
coverage. Now, I must tell you I have not been wagging this battle in the
name of Kaleidoscope Music alone and would like to tell you what I have
proposed to URB Magazine.

Basically, my proposal has been to write about the top 5 selling and
contributing breaks labels here in the US for over 5 years. This will show
to the public the commitment of our labels here in the US and to show that
breaks is not some new thing developed by UK artists. I feel that people
should know there are labels out there that have worked hard for a very long
time to bring this breaks scene to where it is now, where it will be in the
future, and the survival of something special.

I would hope that "you" the people would spend at least half an hour of your
time to e-mail Alex Leon, Account Manager, of URB and give him your
thoughts. I will be speaking to him on Monday, February 10th, along with the
editor of URB Magazine, and your contributions will help drastically. His
e-mail address is aleon@urb.com. Please write "LACK OF US BREAKBEAT IN URB
MAGAZINE" as your subject.

The leaders in this scene have only been concerned about themselves and I
hope we can make a difference and change that perception. Together, I feel
we can make a difference. We are 1000 strong and if everyone participates we
can make a huge difference. I would ask that you keep in mind that
constructive criticism works. Your letter should not be to boycott URB in
any way, but to show that there is more than one person out there that
believes in US breaks and is willing to fight for the coverage it deserves.

Thank you,
Huda

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] a vday message about plur (NNRR - not necessarily rave-related)

IF WE COULD JUST LIVE OUR LIVES WITH THESE FOUR THOUGHTS

BE IMPECCABLE WITH YOUR WORD
Speak with integrity. Say only what you mean. Avoid using the word to speak against yourself or to gossip about others. Use the power of your word in the direction of truth and love.

DON'T TAKE ANYTHING PERSONALLY
Nothing others do is because of you. What others say and do is a projection of their own reality, their own dream. When you are immune to the opinions and actions of others, you won't be the victim of needless suffering.

DON'T MAKE ASSUMPTIONS
Find the courage to ask questions and to express what you really want. Communicate with others as clearly as you can to avoid misunderstandings, sadness, and drama. With just this one agreement, you can completely transform your life.

ALWAYS DO YOUR BEST
Your best is going to change from moment to moment; it will be different when you are healthy as opposed to sick. Under any circumstance, simply do your best, and you will avoid self-judgment, self-abuse, and regret.

 
   
 
   
 
   


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Gel Instead of Condoms...

--=====================_34471842==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

What a wonderful thing this would be.:


Hunt revives for anti-HIV gel after tests on monkeys

February 10 2003

http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/02/10/1044725733857.html

The quest for a gel that can kill the AIDS virus, offering protection to 
women and homosexuals exposed to HIV-infected sperm, has suddenly revived 
after tests showed it worked with monkeys.

The idea of a barrier cream that can destroy the human immunodeficiency 
virus (HIV) has gripped experts for the last two decades, offering the hope 
of simple, cheap protection for vaginal and anal sex in the absence of an 
AIDS vaccine.

But relatively little money has been invested in this line of research - 
and the only candidate gel, an over-the-counter spermicide called 
nonoxynol-9, proved horrifyingly to be worse than useful.

When this gel was tested on a large group of prostitutes in Africa and 
Thailand, it was found in fact to boost the risk of catching HIV, possibly 
by damaging the delicate mucus membranes and thus exposing them more to 
contact with the virus.

That has led many to draw the grim conclusion that the search for a 
microbicide may lead only to a dead end.

But research published today by a US-British team of microbiologists has 
reignited hopes.

Their experimental treatment incorporates a human antibody, b12, which is 
known to attack the virus by identifying a protein, gp120, located on the 
virus surface.

Twelve macaque monkeys received b12 in the form of a cream or in a saline 
solution, and were then exposed, up to two hours later, with the monkey 
equivalent of HIV.

Only three of the 12 became infected.

Among a control group of 13 monkeys who were not given the b12, 12 became 
infected.

There is a long way to go and many uncertainties to be resolved before this 
early success results in a product for humans, but at least it demonstrates 
that a microbicide works, the authors say.

"Viral inhibitors can help prevent the sexual transmission of HIV-1 to 
humans," they say.

Among the hurdles ahead are broadening the attack base of b12 so that it 
can neutralise the many genetic sub-types of HIV, they say.

The study is published online by Nature Medicine, a specialist journal of 
the London-based Nature group.



Moksha Tribe

Subject: [sfraves] (bsp) Special Valentine's event 02.14.03 /// Secret Garden - Monterey


Hello all,

Just wanted to mention of a special event we are hosting:

S e c r e t  G a r d e n - Valentine's Day - Friday Night Feb 14th -
9:00 pm to 1:00am - Indian Summer Restuarant - Downtown Monterey

DJ: Maneesh the Twister ( Dubmission, Dhamaal, Stir-fry-day SF)
Maneesh the Twister will be spinning a wide array of genres of
electronic (2step,brokenbeat,breakbeat,house,dub,downtempo) as well
as, traditional Indian music.

On Tabla Drums: Ferhan Najeeb Qureshi
Qureshi has been a student of tabla and traditional Pakistani/Indian music 
for the last 7 years. He began studying with Shri Surrinder Mann, and now 
continues his studies as a disciple of Ustad Tari Khan, concentrating on the 
Punjab gharana(school or style) of classical tabla. His focus is primarily 
on classical/traditional music, but he has become involved with various 
other projects recently. Such as fusing his traditional drumming with 
electronic musicans and djs.

Projections: Daniel V (Cloudfactory SC)
rolling down from Santa Cruz to add to the evening with various forms of 
visual stimuli.Definitely bringing a great flavor to this event, both 
visually andpersonally. Bring on the laughs!

Henna artist: Mehndi Mama Rica
heading down from Santa Cruz and will
be providing henna art tattoos for us. Her work/designs are quite
impressive and very beautiful.She will be applying her art on the
premises on a first come first serve basis. Those interested in
receiving a tattoo, please arrive by 10:30 pm.


Secret Garden Residents: Scientists of Sound
DJs Kiyoshi one and Kelau opening and closing things out for this night of 
LOVE, MUSIC , and ART. Bringing forth various ethnic and electronic
sounds to groove and chill to.



Admission FREE
Check the info below or email us with any questions

peace...

Subject: [sfraves] Club Exit and Sound Factory in NYC Closed

--=====================_11391676==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

February 8, 2003 -- Police were party poopers at two popular West Side 
nightclubs last night, shuttering the hot spots after amassing evidence of 
rampant "designer drug" use and sales.

Narcotics cops shut down Club Exit on West 56th Street and the Sound 
Factory on West 46th Street after a 22-month undercover investigation.

During the probe, undercover cops posing as clubgoers purchased a laundry 
list of drugs - mostly "ecstasy" - and witnessed numerous drug transactions 
and patron drug use.

"Thanks to our detectives' hard work, we are sending a clear message to 
nightclub owners: If you allow illegal drugs to saturate your business and 
endanger your patrons, we'll shut you down," said Police Commissioner Ray 
Kelly.

Over the last three years, the clubs have been the scene of more than 200 
drug-related arrests.

So far, 11 people have been arrested for their involvement in selling and 
using drugs - but no club owner has been charged.

State law could keep the clubs closed for up to a year - and cops say they 
could close more clubs soon.

http://www.nypost.com/news/regionalnews/30164.htm


Fear Is The Key

Bruce Dickinson, Janick Gers

          We live our lives in fever
          In a choking sweat of fear
       In the heat of the night you can
                 feel so much
       In the heat of the night I scream
                "Don't touch!"

           I remember a time when we
                used and abused
        And fought all our battles in vain
        I remember a time we thought that
               passion was free
   In the heart of the night... bodies aflame

              We live in fever...

         I hear your secret heartbeat
         I can hear your silent cries
       The kids have lost their freedom
        And nobody cares till somebody
                famous dies...

           I remember a time when we
                used and abused
        And fought all our battles in vain
        I remember a time we thought that
               passion was free
   In the heart of the night... bodies aflame

     Now we live, in a world of uncertainty
    Fear is the key - to what you want to be
       You don't get a say the majority
                gets its way
      You're outnumbered by the bastards
           till the day you die...

anyone interested in a good stack of happy hardcore vinyl (mostly old
stuff ... i.e. the good stuff)
 
if anyone's interested ... please inquire _privately_ for a list ...
i've got about 25 records to get rid of, you can make me an offer & i'll
meet up with you for the transaction ... as long as it's in the
immediate bay area.
 
-Anton

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY1-F141JmGzrLCCtg000063b4@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 11 Feb 2003 18:54:57.0326 (UTC) FILETIME=[124654E0:01C2D1FF]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves]  records Tax Deductiable!!


Hey Guys,

Just wanted to share some tax info with some of you semi pro DJ's if you 
bought alot of records in the 2002 tax year and got a few gigs but like many 
DJ's not enough to cover record expenses.. You can file what is called 
Schedule C.. Small business form and write off some of your record expense 
to minimize your Tax liability. KEEP IN MIND. Im not a tax expert by any 
means but I was doing my taxes last night and my Aunt was helping me and 
explained that I could file a schedule C She on the other hand is a CPA. So 
she knows just a lil bit about tax law ;)

So long story short if you have recipts for records that you have bought for 
the year  and contracts with promoters about fees you were to collect you 
can report that income and the cost of the records and in most "Part-Time" 
DJ's casses like myself my record expense way excedes proceeds that I 
brought in from contract gigs or verbal gigs with payment. So in my case it 
ended up that I get a lil bit more coin back from taxes so all that $$ you 
spend on recs isn't a total loss..

DISCLAIMER: Im not a professional tax accountant please consult your tax 
advisor to see if said info applies to you!

PPS: I doubt "pro" DJ's that get upwards of 500-1000 per gig can do a 
schedule C cause in most cases they are not dishing out that same amount on 
records.. At least none of the Bay area DJ's I know do.. And if they do It 
hardly show's in the sets that I have heard some jocks play, the same exact 
set upwards of a month in rotation..


Happy Trails!

Macadio

Subject: Re: [sfraves]  records Tax Deductiable!!

quoth Macadio G.:
> Just wanted to share some tax info with some of you semi pro DJ's if you 
> bought alot of records in the 2002 tax year and got a few gigs but like 
> many DJ's not enough to cover record expenses.. You can file what is called 
> Schedule C.. Small business form and write off some of your record expense 
> to minimize your Tax liability.

Also note that if you've already been doing this for the last two years,
you might want to skip it for this year's return. The IRS frowns upon
"small businesses" that "lose" thousands of dollars in every year. I was
told by another CPA that after 3 years, you're likely to get audited.

That said, last year I got a nice fat return thanks to my Schedule C --
I would have owed a couple hundred bucks if I hadn't filed it. ;)

> PPS: I doubt "pro" DJ's that get upwards of 500-1000 per gig can do a
> schedule C cause in most cases they are not dishing out that same
> amount on records.. At least none of the Bay area DJ's I know do.. And
> if they do It hardly show's in the sets that I have heard some jocks
> play, the same exact set upwards of a month in rotation..

No doubt. Of course, most big-name DJ's get promos thrown at them all
day, so I wouldn't count on them not actually *having* a lot of records.
I guess it's just "safe" for them to play those charted tunes rather
than busting out something /interesting/. I guess the same could be said
for any facet of pop music, though.

-- 
shawn allen

  aim://shawnpallen

From: "Giles Bowkett" <gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Tue, 11 Feb 2003 12:15:55 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.00.2615.200
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2615.200
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] turntablism (I found something nifty)

rent the dvd for "scratch." skip the movie and go to the bonus CD.

on the bonus cd, there's an awesome qbert how-to thingy...not only does he
give excellent advice on how to scratch, he also turns out to be an expert
plumber.

also excellent is the scratch notation demo. Rob Swift demonstrates a
number of different scratches. the footage is great, especially since you
can put it on half speed and watch him scratch in slow motion. the
scratching is so quick you can't see it any other way.

the only problem is that most of the techniques center on the crossfader,
and for rave DJs, the crossfader tends to not only be much wider, it also
usually operates on a broader curve which is less well-suited to scratching.

luckily Q-Bert provides one possible answer in his how-to video. you can use
the faders instead of the crossfader. he points it out as simply a different
method which produces a different (more textured) effect, in his section on
how to do lazer scratches, but it's worth exploring as a general alternative
to crossfader scratching owing to the generally broader crossfader curves on
rave/club mixers.

there's also a fragment of QBert's movie. combination of turntablism and
Adobe After Effects. it's pretty great.

once upon a time I broke my crossfader beat-juggling jungle. then I forgot
all about turntablism for years.

now, of course, I get interested in it again - having sold over 100 hip-hop
records on eBay, completely cleaning out my hip-hop collection, and leaving
me only Muppet records to scratch with.

*sigh*


Giles

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Club Exit and Sound Factory in NYC Closed

You know, this may sound hypocritical, but while I occasionally like to
indulge in illegal substances, I hate being approached by drug dealers when
I'm out partying. If I want to do something, I always bring it with me,
after getting something from a friend that I know is clean and safe. I don't
trust anything from someone I'll never see again. When I used to go to
massives, I would always go "candy", and thus was a target for every sketchy
guy with a bag of pills in his pocket. My hypocrisy also extends to pot.
While I like to smoke it sometimes, and think it should be legal, I could
never sell it, no matter how desperate for money I became. Perhaps growing
up in East Oakland has given me a bad taste for drug dealers. Which is why I
like going to undergrounds, where no one ever tries to sell me anything.

Happy  :-)

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Iraq Grants Anti-War 'Human Shields' Entry Visas



  Several members from the local Spaz and 5Flowershop collectives are on 
their way to Iraq.  They have been sending emails describing their 
experiences.  Last messages were from  Amann, Jordan.


Reuters
Tuesday, February 11, 2003; 8:50 AM

http://tinyurl.com/5o67

ANKARA (Reuters) - A group of around 50 Western anti-war activists received 
visas Tuesday to enter Iraq where they plan to form "human shields" in an 
effort to deter a possible U.S.-led attack on the Arab state.

The volunteers said at an impromptu news conference in the Turkish capital 
they hoped their presence and the possibility of Western casualties would 
encourage U.S. political leaders and military planners to re-think any 
plans to bomb Baghdad for its alleged development of weapons of mass 
destruction.

"I am an American human shield on this trip to Baghdad to try and stop this 
war," said volunteer John Rosse.

"I ask American troops headed here...not to come, they have no business 
being here. They do not make good ambassadors. They are here to kill, 
murder, devastate the civilian population of Iraq. That is not an American 
thing to do."

The group is traveling across Turkey in a convoy, including a red 
double-decker bus, that is expected to cross into Syria on Wednesday before 
entering Iraq. The volunteers left London late last month and headed 
overland across Europe.

On arriving in Iraq, they plan to disperse to populated areas of Baghdad 
and other parts of the country. Critics have said they are naively playing 
into Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's hands.

Turkey last week deported Ken Nichols, a former U.S. marine who helped 
organize the "human shields" campaign, after he tried to enter the country 
using documents describing himself as a "citizen of the world."

Edward Cranswick, a seismologist who works for the U.S. government, said he 
wanted to raise awareness among Americans.

"I believe I am doing a small bit to raise attention, particularly (among) 
the American public...I want to be a human being alongside the Iraqis and 
that will get the attention of Americans," he said.



Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one 
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken
--=====================_3491105==_.ALT--

That's pretty freakin' cool, indeed.  Actually, it was a few weeks ago when
I was up at night doing the whole "can't sleep so I'll think" thing and
thought that some serious activists should do that... Particularly
celebrities and various luminaries. Have them go and camp out in civilian
areas and say, "Ok, if you're so confident in how accurate your bombs are
and that there won't be any collateral damage, do your war thang." See how
eager the administration would be to rain bombs.

Then the next morning, I was scanning the news, and read about this. Go
figure. :)

What's sad is how many people actually believed the hype that "This was
being done for their own safety."  My adoptive grandfather, a

interned by it. The couple of times I tried to bring it up and ask him about
it, it was shushed as a "non-issue." At the time, he thought it was a good
idea, too. It's amazing what state of mind war can put people into.

Date: Tue, 11 Feb 2003 15:09:12 -0800
From: DJ Chris Fenton <info@deafignition.com>
To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Reply-to: DJ Chris Fenton <info@deafignition.com>

MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
References: <BAY1-F141JmGzrLCCtg000063b4@hotmail.com>
 <20030211191019.GC526@pion.local>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]  records Tax Deductiable!!

**disclaimer: not giving tax advice, only opinion**

I believe you may only write off against what you earn (as a DJ), and are
you willing to claim that cash in order to take a deduction?  If you are
paid in checks and get a w-2 or 1099, then there you go...
Also, you cannot claim a loss for more than 2-3 years.  Otherwise, IRS
considers it as hobby and not business.
Take the deduction, but enjoy it for only a few years.

Don't forget to write off the needles, cartridges, gas to and from venues,
mileage, promotion expenses, and that small "home office" (audit alert) in
the corner.

There is also a performing artist credit. Check into it.

There isn't a lot of *taxable* income to be made in DJ'ing.  But the love
for the music is priceless!

Peace,
Chris


----- Original Message -----
From: "shawn allen" <shawn@alterior.net>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, February 11, 2003 11:10 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] records Tax Deductiable!!


> quoth Macadio G.:
> > Just wanted to share some tax info with some of you semi pro DJ's if you
> > bought alot of records in the 2002 tax year and got a few gigs but like
> > many DJ's not enough to cover record expenses.. You can file what is
called
> > Schedule C.. Small business form and write off some of your record
expense
> > to minimize your Tax liability.
>
> Also note that if you've already been doing this for the last two years,
> you might want to skip it for this year's return. The IRS frowns upon
> "small businesses" that "lose" thousands of dollars in every year. I was
> told by another CPA that after 3 years, you're likely to get audited.
>
> That said, last year I got a nice fat return thanks to my Schedule C --
> I would have owed a couple hundred bucks if I hadn't filed it. ;)
>
> > PPS: I doubt "pro" DJ's that get upwards of 500-1000 per gig can do a
> > schedule C cause in most cases they are not dishing out that same
> > amount on records.. At least none of the Bay area DJ's I know do.. And
> > if they do It hardly show's in the sets that I have heard some jocks
> > play, the same exact set upwards of a month in rotation..
>
> No doubt. Of course, most big-name DJ's get promos thrown at them all
> day, so I wouldn't count on them not actually *having* a lot of records.
> I guess it's just "safe" for them to play those charted tunes rather
> than busting out something /interesting/. I guess the same could be said
> for any facet of pop music, though.
>
> --
> shawn allen
>   mailto://shawn@alterior.net
>   phone://415.577.3961
>   http://alterior.net
>   aim://shawnpallen

Recoverable: 
 
- smilies 
- avatars 
 
Unrecoverable: 
 
- usernames 
- posts 
 
It happenned around late evening yesterday. The database table the forum
runs off of was dropped somehow. Unfortunately the latest backup was
from this morning w/o the table. The server backs up the next day and
erases the previous backup. 
 
Email me if you have any questions.
 
Thanks,
Deepak

the US? Now remember, pearl harbor had just been attacked in on the most 
cowardous acts ever committed during wartime in the 20th century.

staring back at a fire house and about 50 billy clubs.

From sfraves-return-98775-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Feb 12 01:43:05 2003

From: Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:I CANT BELIEVE THIS SH*T

on 2/11/03 5:03 PM, Jack 7RIUMPH at jacktriumph@hotmail.com wrote:

> No, holding japanese in camps wasn't cool. I fully agree. But, riddle me
> this batman; How many of those japanese would have been raped, murdered,
> stoned, persecuted had they been left to  walk the streets with the rest of
> the US?

I think this is best answered by the anonymous quote, "I'd rather die on my
feet than live on my knees."

The government took advantage of the fact that Japanese-Americans, at large,
were a very "compliant" people and wouldn't complain. Had this been done to
any other ethnic group, there would have been MUCH more of a furor.

There could've been public education, community efforts, etc. but instead,
we took the easy way.  What the government did was take a number of its own
citizens and put them in "protective custody" without making it a choice.
Not to mention that many of them had nothing to come home to when the war
was over, having their property reposessed or ransacked during the
internment. 

None of them had the CHOICE to stay at home and even take the risk of being
beaten for practicing the very freedoms that their parents and grandparents
had come here to enjoy and, mind you, contribute to.

> Now remember, pearl harbor had just been attacked in on the most
> cowardous acts ever committed during wartime in the 20th century.

It was a military attack on a military target. That's not outrageous. What
was outrageous was that it was the first modern attack on US soil - so I'll
give you the shock factor, and concede that yes, there may have been a great
risk to members of the Japanese-American population. But my point is that if
they wanted to continue their own lives, it should've been their choice to
assume that risk.
 
> What would you do? Hold a little anti-us protest? back then that wouldn't
> have been tolerated. Yeah right; You and Brooke would have found yourself
> staring back at a fire house and about 50 billy clubs.

Once again, back to the quote at the beginning. Not everyone is as fiercely
protective of their civil rights as others. And certainly, not having been
there alongside my grandpa, I don't know how it feels to have your family
locked away by the very country you're engaging in armed combat for.  In
fact, from my experience, the descendants of the interned Japanese are more
bitter about what happened than those who were actually there. But just as
we're now more enlightened about race relations and politics than people
were in the 1940's, were also much more aware of what a violation it was of
civil rights.

What I do find ridiculous is that the same people who preach "smaller"
government and less federal interference with our lives condone the forcible
custody of one portion of the population in an attempt to "protect" it from
another. This all stems from the same bottom line that the government
doesn't trust its population. So in turn, why should we trust them?

We're not trusted with our bodies (see agenda on: drug war, reproductive
rights), and it seems when times get tough, we aren't trusted with our own
citizenry. The outrage, though, goes beyond whether or not my great-aunt
needed some sort of protection during WWII. The real outrage in hearing a
current politician support internment is its demonstration of a lack of
trust in the American public.

So what I ask is this - if your government doesn't trust you to do what's
right, should you trust them?

 - omid, getting off the soapbox.. for now  ;)


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:I CANT BELIEVE THIS SH*T

Okay I will not allow my emotions get to me and I can go on and on about
how it really went down...but i wont unless someone is curious but the
main thing is ..if it was for the protection of the Japanese American
people ...Why were the guns pointing at THEM while in camp.  Wouldnt they
be pointing in the other direction?  Remember also the camps were in the
middle of the desert...there was no escape even if you did get over the
barbed wire fences.  Yes...bad things happened to the other races at that
time as well but they do not compair to what happened to the Japanese A M
E R I C A N S.   Understand that I know how things really went down(passed
to me by relatives who lived it)  It is not what has been told or taught
to you in school or most books.

Peace...one love

Sean

they were any more or less vocal about their situation that anyone else
would have
been given the day and age and what America was back then.

grandparents

went on
in the mind of the Japanese (that were in Japan) and how bloodthirsty they
were,
nor how afraid Americans were about spies in California.  A sad part of our
history,
but it wasn't founded on racism exactly, though race had a part in it.

Perhaps you are forgetting one crucial thing....we weren't at WAR.  Ahem.
Bombing
ships of a country NOT at war at 6 a.m. is pretty cowardly and ruthless.

of life is unacceptable.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:I CANT BELIEVE THIS SH*T

>> It was a military attack on a military target. That's not outrageous.
>
>Perhaps you are forgetting one crucial thing....we weren't at WAR.
>Ahem. Bombing ships of a country NOT at war at 6 a.m. is pretty cowardly
>and ruthless.

We were, however, very busy helping supply the British against the Germans
(Japan's allies) during that time. The U.S. was scared shitless of finding
itself mired in another WW1 situation, and Pearl Harbor was the event that
helped tip the balance in favor of direct involvement in WW2. Apparently,
it came as something of a relief to more than a few higher-ups, since it
provided a great excuse to join in all war fun our allies in Europer were
enjoying.

I see it as a very similar situation to the 9/11 attacks, except for the
fact that there's no government to hold responsible this time. I see our
current situation as potential quagmire of counter-escalations and
neverending grudgematches.

A friend sent me this earlier today, a really funny-but-frightening
view of the potential mess our dearly beloved leaders are about slide
into: http://www.idleworm.com/nws/2002/11/iraq2.shtml

From sfraves-return-98787-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Feb 12 04:59:29 2003

From: Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com>
To: Argumentative Fools <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <BA6F14BA.529D%otavallai@mac.com>
In-Reply-To: <008401c2d24f$d479da00$0a01a8c0@damn>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:I CANT BELIEVE THIS SH*T

on 2/11/03 8:33 PM, P. Sutton at micromu@sbcglobal.net wrote:

> That's kinda painting the Japanese as wussies, and I don't think that's
> fair.  

No, I don't either, particularly as a half-Japanese ;)  However, I was
reading an article a few months back (wish I could remember where it was)
that cited that as one of the reasons to go ahead with the internment.
Granted, since I can't remember where this was, I have about as much
credibility as Kent Brockman on the Springfield News.

> I personally don't think any of us on this list can fathom the thinking that
> went on  in the mind of the Japanese (that were in Japan)  and how
> bloodthirsty they were,

I think "bloodthirsty" is a broad characterization. My (real, not adoptive)
grandfather was a young man in Japan at the time, and all his primary
concern were fishing and raising his 3 young daughters.  That'd be like an
Iraqi saying that all Americans are Arab-hating warmongers, or to make it
more  relevant, that all ravers are e-tarded drug fiends. "Fear of the
other" is what they call it in sociological circles.

> nor how afraid Americans were about spies in California.

Very justified fear after what happened. But to round people up and lock
them up in camps in middle of nowhere with Ansel Adams as the only friendly
white face to show up? C'mon, man. If fear justified everything, then we
should be locking up all middle eastern people, anyone who's ever
philosophically agreed with militia-types like Timothy McVeigh, and youths
who listen to Marilyn Manson and KMFDM and wear a lot of black.

> Perhaps you are forgetting one crucial thing....we weren't at WAR.  Ahem.
> Bombing ships of a country NOT at war at 6 a.m. is pretty cowardly and
ruthless.

I'll concede the not-at-war point, certainly! But I will now and forever
object to the term "cowardly" for any act of war/aggression, as it takes
some serious cojones to attack any sovereign state, especially knowing that
there will be swift retaliation. I think it's a cop-out word like
"evil-doer," used as a judgment label to mobilize people emotionally. Japan
had no justification for what it did in WWII, but in terms of the US
response (interment AND two nukes) has hardly anymore moral standing.

Anyway, this'll be my last post on the topic, as if I go on, it'll break
down into the usual left vs. right thing as the topic starts to stray from
the original point.. One which I'll re-iterate one last time:  That it's
outrageous that the US would treat its own citizens with such disregard for
their rights.  Sadly, I see it all happening again.

This time, it's the Iranian half of me worrying!  *grin*

  - omid

P.S. Pre-emptively, I know other countries treat their own citizens worse, I
live here because I love it here, and I rail on our establishment because I
want to love it more.   So there. :)

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Coachella?

In a message dated 2/11/2003 1:40:11 PM Pacific Standard Time, 
sfraves-digest-help@hyperreal.org writes:


> 
> Don't suppose anyone from SF is going to this and would consider giving me 
> a
> ride?  :)
> 
> love always



I'm so afraid to drive there after the last time we went.  My family has a 
time share in Palm Springs (a quick drive to Coachella from the resort) and 
last time we got a phat condo-style room for four people with a full kitchen 
and our own patio.  We spent one day at Coachella and one day lying by the 
pool with waterslides having daquiris with rum floaters and 3 course meals 
delivered to our lawn chairs.  The whole trip was ideal and the room was free 
(since we own the time share and are entitled to our once-a-year vacation).

However my friends and I decided to leave a night early to beat commuter 
trafic back to the bay and were unfortunately caught in a drunk driving 
accident.  A man (drunk) hit a woman and sent her car across three lanes of 
the freeway spinning around until she got confused, hit the gas and drove 
headfirst into my car.  I was fortunately not driving at the time and 
fortunately our driver was experienced and got us to the side of the road 
quickly and unscathed.  My car, however, was totalled and we were stranded in 
SoCal without any transportation.  We ended up having to get a cab to an 
airport to rent a car to drive home.  Thank goodness no one was hurt but I 
will never ever drive my car down there again.

I would go again and volunteer my time share if someone wanted to stay with 
me, in exchange for not having to drive my own car.  It was probably a fluke 
and a one-time deal, but I've had too many run-ins with drunk drivers to risk 
it again.
Coachella was pretty fun, though.

;) Patrice

--part1_12f.22c9bf86.2b7b38b1_boundary--

From: "Omid Tavallai" <otavallai@mac.com>
To: "Argumentative Fools" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, February 11, 2003 8:59 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:I CANT BELIEVE THIS SH*T


> on 2/11/03 8:33 PM, P. Sutton at micromu@sbcglobal.net wrote:
>
> > That's kinda painting the Japanese as wussies, and I don't think that's
> > fair.
>
> No, I don't either, particularly as a half-Japanese ;)  However, I was
> reading an article a few months back (wish I could remember where it was)
> that cited that as one of the reasons to go ahead with the internment.
> Granted, since I can't remember where this was, I have about as much
> credibility as Kent Brockman on the Springfield News.

Glad to hear that :)   There are a few key factors to consider here
(regardless of
a handfull of Germans that encountered the same fate).  Many of the Germans
of
the period weren't 1st generation as much as many of the Japanese of the
same time
were.  Secondly, can you tell the difference between a German and other
European
Americans?  I can't.  The sad fact is that with the Japanese by default of
ethnic features
they were easy to spot.  Rounding up Germans and Italians is a much trickier
business,
and also as I mentioned many weren't "new immigrants".  So the Japanese had
a couple
of things going against them.  The other thing which wasn't on their side
was location.
Iowa, for example, isn't exactly a key spot militarily, economically, or
otherwise.  CA
was.  Lastly this all happened around the height of immigrations from Asia,
and as racism
(or rather fear and ignorance, the root of all racism) kicked in there was
this paranoia about
"being overrun" by asian immigrants and being "taken over from the inside"
as was said.
Doesn't excuse it, of course, but these are some things i've noted when
studying the historical
records of the times.  I'm sure there was a fair amount of biggotry involved
in the decision to go
forward with the camps, but there was also a fair amount of other factors as
well.

> > I personally don't think any of us on this list can fathom the thinking
that
> > went on  in the mind of the Japanese (that were in Japan)  and how
> > bloodthirsty they were,
>
> I think "bloodthirsty" is a broad characterization. My (real, not
adoptive)
> grandfather was a young man in Japan at the time, and all his primary
> concern were fishing and raising his 3 young daughters.  That'd be like an
> Iraqi saying that all Americans are Arab-hating warmongers, or to make it
> more  relevant, that all ravers are e-tarded drug fiends. "Fear of the
> other" is what they call it in sociological circles.

Strike that a replace with imperialistic, determined, unafraid, and
convinced (like all in such
situations) that they are God's people.  It makes for a very tough enemy.  I
didn't mean
bloodthirsty as a basic trait lol.  Obviuosly there were plenty of Japanese
at home
who had better things on their mind (as you point out) but there's also the
ones who
join the military to further the empire.  All aggressors are like this, 1/3
aren't interested, 1/3
are going with the flow (and that can change you after a while) and 1/3
truely believe what
they are doing is right.  So anyway, what I mean is what I said and that's
the only aspect of
the Japanese which Americans were familiar with (as they say, bad news
travels) at the time, i'd
bet.

> > nor how afraid Americans were about spies in California.
>
> Very justified fear after what happened. But to round people up and lock
> them up in camps in middle of nowhere with Ansel Adams as the only
friendly
> white face to show up? C'mon, man. If fear justified everything, then we
> should be locking up all middle eastern people, anyone who's ever
> philosophically agreed with militia-types like Timothy McVeigh, and youths
> who listen to Marilyn Manson and KMFDM and wear a lot of black.

I'm not justifying what happened, just saying that the motivations (while
wrong) were
based mostly in fear (uninformed and baseless fear, but nonetheless).  We're
a wiser
and kinder nation now I'd like to think and that is evidenced in the lack of
anti-Arab
sentiment following 9/11.  Sometimes to see who we are we have to look at
the now
and not the distant past, except in such cases where it's a reminded of how
we do not
want to be.  And I love KMFDM so there :)

> > Perhaps you are forgetting one crucial thing....we weren't at WAR.
Ahem.
> > Bombing ships of a country NOT at war at 6 a.m. is pretty cowardly and
> ruthless.
>
> I'll concede the not-at-war point, certainly! But I will now and forever
> object to the term "cowardly" for any act of war/aggression, as it takes
> some serious cojones to attack any sovereign state, especially knowing
that
> there will be swift retaliation. I think it's a cop-out word like
> "evil-doer," used as a judgment label to mobilize people emotionally.
Japan
> had no justification for what it did in WWII, but in terms of the US
> response (interment AND two nukes) has hardly anymore moral standing.

I'm sorry, that doesn't wash.  By that token any playground bully is not a
coward.
In most cases it's usually a person bigger than everyone else who has some
serious
problems and takes them out on those who aren't able to defend themselves.
That's
the definition, in this case and imo, of cowardly with regard to Pearl
Harbor.  A sneak
attack on someone you're at war with is one thing, a sneak attack on a
non-participant is
another.  The nukes weren't an easy decision i'm sure, but it happened.  At
a mimimum
America was nice enough to help rebuilt Europe and Japan out of its own
pocket and the
kindness of its people who didn't want to be in that war and didn't affect
American soil
(PH aside) for the most part.

> Anyway, this'll be my last post on the topic, as if I go on, it'll break
> down into the usual left vs. right thing as the topic starts to stray from
> the original point.. One which I'll re-iterate one last time:  That it's
> outrageous that the US would treat its own citizens with such disregard
for
> their rights.  Sadly, I see it all happening again.

Fair enough.  It is outrageous, but at least it wasn't motivated by a pure
evil hatred
or something so barbaric.  It isn't excusable, but it's at least
understandable.  I'm glad
we didn't make such a poor decision about american citizens using the logic
of others
like Milosovic, Hussein, the Spanish, etc.  "Lucky" us?  =/

> This time, it's the Iranian half of me worrying!  *grin*
>
>   - omid
>
> P.S. Pre-emptively, I know other countries treat their own citizens worse,
I
> live here because I love it here, and I rail on our establishment because
I
> want to love it more.   So there. :)

I'm not a "love it or leave it" person, no pre-emptivity needed lol.
Without discussion
what's the point?  America may be heading down a bad lane (remains to be
seen, imo)
but at least it's in the open heh.

Subject: Re: [sfraves]  NRR - France, why wont they fight?

Someone sent this to me, very funny stuff.

The following encapsulates the "old Europe" irrelevancy of France as
demonstrated lately:
THE COMPLETE MILITARY HISTORY OF FRANCE

Gallic Wars - Lost.   In a war whose ending foreshadows the next 2000 years
of French history, France is conquered by, of all things, an Italian.

Hundred Years War - Mostly lost.    Saved at last by female schizophrenic,
who inadvertently creates The First Rule of French Warfare: "France's armies
are victorious only when not led by a Frenchman."

Italian Wars - Lost.   France becomes the first and only country to ever
lose two wars when fighting Italians.

Wars of Religion - France goes 0-5-4 against the Huguenots

Thirty Years War - France is technically not a participant, but manages to
get invaded anyway.   Claims a tie on the basis that eventually the other
participants started ignoring her.

War of Devolution - Tied.   Frenchmen take to wearing red flowerpots as
chapeaux.

The Dutch War - Tied

War of the Augsburg League/King William's War/French and Indian War - Lost,
but claimed as a tie.  Three ties in a row induces deluded Frogophiles the
world over to label the period as the height of French military power.

War of the Spanish Succession - Lost.   The War also gave the French their
first taste of a Marlborough, which they have loved ever since.

American Revolution - In a move that will become quite familiar to future
Americans, France claims a win even though the English colonists saw far
more action. This is later known as "de Gaulle Syndrome", and leads to the
Second Rule of French Warfare: "France only wins when America does most of
the fighting."

French Revolution - Won, primarily due the fact that the opponent was also
French.

The Napoleonic Wars - Lost.  Temporary victories (see First Rule above)! Due
to leadership of a Corsican, who ended up being no match for a British
footwear designer.

The Franco-Prussian War - Lost.   Germany first plays the role of drunk Frat
boy to France's ugly girl home alone on a Saturday night.

World War I - Tied and on the way to losing, France is saved by the United
States. Thousands of French women find out what it's like to not only sleep
with a winner, but one who doesn't call her "Fraulein."  Sadly, widespread
use of condoms by American forces forestalls any improvement in the French
bloodline.

World War II - Lost.  Conquered French liberated by the United States and
Britain just as they finish learning the Horst Wessel Song.

War in Indochina - Lost.  French forces plead sickness, take to bed with the
Dien Bien Flu.

Algerian Rebellion - Lost.   Loss marks the first defeat of a western army
by a Non-Turkic Muslim force since the Crusades, and produces the First Rule
of

Muslim Warfare: "We can always beat the French."  This rule is identical to
the First Rules of the Italians, Russians, Germans, English, Dutch, Spanish,
Vietnamese and Esquimaux.

War on Terrorism - France, keeping in mind its recent history, surrenders to
Germans and Muslims just to be safe.  Attempts to surrender to Vietnamese
ambassador, but fails after he takes refuge in a McDonald's. For any country
silly enough to count on the French, the question  should not be, "Can we
count on the French?" but rather, "How long until the French collapse?"

S> I do.  Post 9/11, how many Arabs have been killed in this 
S> country?  5?  Statistically, that's not very many, although I feel any loss 
S> of life is unacceptable.

Right- my point was that it was a different place in the 40s.
And I'm not just talking about killings- racism takes many forms.

>>My dad's got stories about what happened to the only German family in
>>his little Iowa town circa 1940- and they're not pretty.

S> Who lived in this town?  I find it hard to believe the ancestry wasn't 
S> German, since they brought the beer to America.  Where is Coors 
S> located?  How about Budwesier?  You think these are Irish names?

Well of course some ancestry was german- but come on- there's a big
difference between your grandparents coming from germany and having a
FOB german family, accent and all.

>>Imagine the racism of today, and then imagine what it was like in the
>>30s and 40s.

S> More violence today, more ignorance back then.

I don't know about that- I would wager that it only *seems* like that-
With the communication methods of today, you hear about *everything*.
And I think today's violence is more shocking than it was back then.
Like today someone would get killed- back then the kid would get beat
up and their house would be set on fire or something.

> it again.
> Coachella was pretty fun, though.

I'm gonna be wild and crazy and *fly* to LA, then head out to Coachella with
friends from there.  $39 each way isn't bad.  If I do end up getting a new
car and driving, though, I'll let y'all know.

As desolate as that road out there can be, it is statistically dangerous.
Throughout my (yikes) 7 years at college down there, I knew of a good number
of people involved in accidents between LA/Palm Springs and LA/Vegas. I've
always driven the roads anyway (it's an assumed risk) and had no problems,
but it's a valid concern.

So if you need to hitch a ride, when they fire up the message board at
coachella.com again, you can check out all the rideshare info, as well as
buses to/from LA, Phoenix, Vegas, etc.

You know, it's funny how I generally slag on massive events with really
overpriced tickets, but after finally experiencing the real festival vibe
last year, I just want everyone else to go and take part :)

 - omid


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> ----Original Message Follows----
> From: Fraser Clark - The Parallel YOUniversity 
> <fraser@parallel-youniversity.com>
> To: terryosborne@beeb.net
> Subject: THE FREE PRESS OR ELSE! MEDIA BOYCOTT   an EMERGENCY UP!
> Date: Mon, 10 Feb 2003 02:28:56 +0000
> 
> THE FREE PRESS OR ELSE! MEDIA BOYCOTT
> DEMOCRACY CANNOT WORK WITHOUT A FREE PRESS
> 
> Friends, Allies, Sympathisers and Bystanders (except that 'terrorism' places 
> everyone on the Front Line now!),
> 
> As History comes to the boil, desperately inspired last minute appeals to 
> Bring Us All Together are arriving in the UP!'s In-Box on an almost hourly 
> basis :)
> 
> - ALL of them involve MOST OF US doing some act simultaneously.
> - NONE of them will work UNLESS A LARGE MAJORITY DOES IT.
> 
> And that's their fatal weakness.
> 
> 
> WHich is why we feel so sure that the FREE PRESS OR ELSE! MEDIA BOYCOTT is 
> definitely
> 
> THAT ONE ACTION YOU CAN PERSONALLY MAKE
> THAT CAN TRULY HELP TO MAINTAIN THE PEACE!
> 
> PLEASE DO IT NOW!  WE ONLY HAVE TILL FEB 15!!
> 
> 
> 
> 
> THE FREE PRESS OR ELSE! MEDIA BOYCOTT
> DEMOCRACY CANNOT WORK WITHOUT A FREE PRESS
> 
> Dear Person For Peace,
> 
> Although the massive peace movement around the world is gaining huge 
> momentum, news coverage and analysis is overwhelmingly devoted to reporting 
> and echoing the US/UK government line, which runs counter to the views of 
> the majority of the UK population, most countries around the world, and 
> elementary common sense.
> 
> This shows MOST BLATANTLY when the media deliberately play down the crowd 
> numbers (and the "people power" implied by these anti-war events). This is 
> often through pressure from the corporate owner, advertisers, or directly or 
> indirectly from government.
> 
> The time has now come to implement a worldwide, well co-ordinated boycott of 
> the media which are not reporting the peace marches accurately.  Otherwise, 
> the Peace Movement will continue to be reported as a Minority!
> 
> If you agree that it is a matter of life or death that the general 
> population be informed of the strength and size of the Peace Movement this 
> coming Saturday, Feb 15th, and beyond, then here's an EASY WAY to start 
> making sure it happens.  PLEASE, PLEASE DO IT NOW!
> 
> 
> 6 STEPS TO A FREE PRESS OR ELSE! MEDIA BOYCOTT
> 
> 1.      Read the Dear Editor letter below, and fine-tune as you wish.
> 
> 2.      Then Cut & Paste the Dear Editor letter into a new email, type FREE 
> PRESS OR ELSE! MEDIA BOYCOTT in the Subject, Box, and send to as many 
> publications as you can (see list below but please add as the campaign 
> spreads).
> 
> 3.      Next, FORWARD this entire email to EVERYONE so they know about the 
> plan.
> 
> 5.      Circulate the news, on flyers and web sites  everywhere, and on the 
> marches too!
> 
> 6.      In the days after the demos, make your own judgement and stick to 
> it.!
> 
> This can really make a difference.  On-line democracy is useless unless the 
> information reaches the general public.
> 
> ================================
> 
> Dear Editor
> SAMPLE LETTER
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> THE FREE PRESS OR ELSE!  MEDIA BOYCOTT
> DEMOCRACY CANNOT WORK WITHOUT A FREE PRESS!!
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Dear Editor,
> I need to let you know about a provisional media/newspaper boycott being 
> organised by a very concerned public.
> 
> People (a majority!) who are against war on Iraq are committing themselves 
> to change their newspaper-buying habits PERMANENTLY, based on how accurately 
> they report on the next peace demonstrations on February 15th.
> 
> OUR COMPLAINT
> Although the massive peace movement around the world is gaining momentum, 
> news coverage and analysis is overwhelmingly devoted to reporting and 
> echoing the US/UK government line, which runs counter to the views of people 
> in the vast majority of countries around the world, and against elementary 
> common sense.
> 
> This shows MOST BLATANTLY when the media deliberately play down the crowd 
> numbers, and the implied "people power" demonstrated by these anti-war 
> events.  We understand that this is often through pressure from the 
> corporate owner, advertisers, or directly or indirectly from government.
> 
> THE  FREE PRESS OR ELSE!  MEDIA BOYCOTT CAMPAIGN
> In the days after the big Peace march/demo on Saturday Feb 15th, marchers 
> and their friends will look at YOUR COVERAGE OF THE MARCH.
> Each marcher will personally decide whether your headlines, photos and 
> articles do or do not reflect what really happened.
> 
> If they are pleased with the accuracy of your portrayal, they will:
> a) buy a copy immediately
> b) if not already a subscriber, subscribe to your paper within 48 hours OR
> c)  commit to buying your paper on a regular basis
> d) contact their non-marching friends, relatives and cyber lists to explain 
> what has happened and to urge them to subscribe to your newspaper within 48 
> hours.
> 
> If they are displeased with the accuracy of your portrayal, they will:
> a) refrain from buying that day's paper
> b) if a subscriber, call to cancel the subscription within 72 hours OR
> c) COMMIT TO NEVER BUYING YOUR PAPER AGAIN!!
> d) contact their non-marching friends, relatives and cyber lists to explain 
> what has happened and to urge them to cancel their subscriptions to your 
> paper
> e) boycott your advertisers and explain why they are doing so.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> WHY THE  FREE PRESS OR ELSE!  CAMPAIGN?
> We understand that you and your newspaper are not the cause of this war. We 
> believe in your basic human qualities and that when you entered journalism 
> you desired to tell the truth.  We think it has taken extreme pressure from 
> your owners etc to silence you.  We think you need our strong support in 
> order to portray accurately what is going on.
> 
> What is going on is an extremely varied, broad-based, multi-cultural, 
> strong, heartfelt opposition to the US/UK invasion of Iraq.  This opposition 
> is hundreds of times bigger, more informed, and better organised than one 
> would guess from reading most newspapers in the UK.
> 
> We believe that it's the biggest Peace movement since the anti-Vietnam War 
> movement (and bigger) and it is more diverse in terms of the age, political 
> loyalty, race, religion, class background, profession and point of view of 
> those involved.
> 
> We want this truth to be accurately reported.  We are all very serious about 
> stopping this war.  WE DO NOT MAKE THIS THREAT LIGHTLY!
> 
> There has never been such a majority against a war BEFORE it started.  
> Should war go ahead, this majority will become even more massive.  Will they 
> be buying your medium's version of the news?!
> 
> 
> 
> WHAT KIND OF COVERAGE WILL WE BE LOOKING FOR?
> Each marcher will decide independently whether to boycott your paper. (Free 
> Press Or Else! is another of those "leaderless groups.")
> 
> I can tell you what I personally will be looking for:  if the Feb 15th Peace 
> March turns out to be a tiny handful of people walking up the street, I 
> won't expect much coverage of it.  But if it's something really huge, I will 
> be looking for:
> 
> i)      Confirmed (and accurate - don't depend on the police!) comments on 
> the crowd size: e.g. "looking down from a sixth-floor window above the march 
> at 2:00 PM, one could see wall-to-wall people filling all of the park/square 
> etc."  Using practical details makes it much easier to visualise than an 
> argument about numbers of marchers a couple of days later.
> 
> ii)     Large, representative photographs.
> 
> iii)    Acknowledgements of the diversity of the crowd.  For example, while 
> TV reporters may call the assembly 'a rag-tag body of political activists, 
> radicals made up of thousands of Muslims, students and anarchists', we are 
> very likely, in fact, to include every imaginable group, from a possible 
> cross section like "Engineers for Peace" to "Mothers Against War" to 
> "Educators for a Sane Budget" to "War Veterans Against Bloodshed".  Your 
> article should quote several signs that indicate some of the identities 
> claimed by the protestors, and mention that every age group was represented.
> 
> iv)     Details of the reasons why various marchers are against the war.  
> For example, "Protestors voiced a deep distrust in the current political 
> leadership in the US and UK, describing the US government as 'the world's 
> primary source of terror,' and portraying oil and weapons companies as the 
> only potential beneficiaries of this war."
> 
> 
> I encourage you to share this letter with your publisher and advertisers as 
> you make plans to cover the upcoming Peace March.  I suspect that as the 
> real news sinks in, you will find that underneath their reluctance and fear 
> of reprisals, even THEY do not wish to support this war.
> 
> Yours very very seriously,
> 
> 
> 
> Another Person For Peace
> 
> P.S  Could I/we ask you to, please, forward this to all other media people 
> on your list as it also affects them?  Thank you.
> 
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR:  I  BELIEVE THIS SH*T

Its certainly not impossible that such an internment could happen.  My
sister who is an ultra liberal was actually suggesting this right after
9/11.  If people with her values can be convinced to support such things its
certainly not an unimaginable outcome.

Ever watch the television show the Prisoner?  Retired secret agents and
operatives are taken against their will to The Village, a themed
environment, where they are subjected to mind control, torture, and various
manipulations with the goal of extracting information.  Many of the  themes
we face today were pretty thoroughly explored in this show including the
difficulty of telling the keepers from the prisoners, the commoditization of
human values, and more.  Worth renting the DVDs if you haven't seen this
show.

Be seeing you,

Peter

WASHINGTON -- U.S. Rep. Howard Coble of Greensboro drew sharp criticism
Wednesday for saying in an interview that he agreed with the U.S.
government's internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II.



One reason why this politician might have said this

Would be to test the public's response to the internment of a large group of
people.


You could say they are test marketing the idea of internment camps.

Maybe" Interment Theme Camp"  = "The human solution" might be the logical
outcome of such vigorous testing.

"Interment Theme Camp"
 A "Theme-Camp" paradise guarding the safety of its "Guests".

our representative don't make boneheaded mistakes, like squandering the
wgoodwill of the entire world a scant year after the attack. :[

At 08:59 PM 2/11/2003 -0800, Omid Tavallai wrote:
>on 2/11/03 8:33 PM, P. Sutton at micromu@sbcglobal.net wrote:
>
>
>
> > I personally don't think any of us on this list can fathom the thinking 
> that
> > went on  in the mind of the Japanese (that were in Japan)  and how
> > bloodthirsty they were,
>
>I think "bloodthirsty" is a broad characterization. My (real, not adoptive)
>grandfather was a young man in Japan at the time, and all his primary
>concern were fishing and raising his 3 young daughters.  That'd be like an
>Iraqi saying that all Americans are Arab-hating warmongers, or to make it
>more  relevant, that all ravers are e-tarded drug fiends. "Fear of the
>other" is what they call it in sociological circles.
>

I have spent years reading and studying other materials from this period in 
an attempt to understand the extraordinary levels of violence committed by 
the Nazis, Japanese and, yes, the United States in WW II.  The most recent 
bloodbath in the former Yugoslavia is another example of the heart of 
darkness in our times.

When one unleashes the monster of war one must deal with the consequences 
in oneself and others.  War is the giving over of the soul to a number of 
evils, including greed, self-focused fear, and abandonment of 
compassion.  The latter, I think, is probably the most important.

The recent discussions of internment in Washington result from efforts by 
organizations like the American Bar Association to get some clarification 
from our government on the status of "prisoners of war" and "suspects" now 
being held in limbo.  This is part of a larger pattern that seems to emerge 
when countries enter into a warlike focus:  curtailment of civil 
liberties;  propaganda (lies);  persecution of those who disagree with the 
agenda or who are just "different"; and eventually a complete substitution 
of passion for reason.

We are headed down this path.  Our Republic is in danger, not from without 
but from within.  Our country is becoming and international pariah.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: [sfraves] questions: m di v

first question: is it come for the goat, stay for the techno? or come for
the techno, stay for the goat?

not necessarily an important question, but one that's been troubling me
personally.

second question: has anyone noticed the inordinate amount of conversation
generated by the list in general, and myself specifically, for this party?

this endless banter is actually a very good thing for Shane and the other
ppl running the thing. it means increased turnout in all probability. in
fact you've got to wonder if they didn't include the live goat simply to get
some extra attention and thereby more ticket sales.

disclaimer: i have not actually been paid to draw attention to this party.
nor am I accusing Shane of any involvement in some kind of goat-->attention
plot. however, Shane, I do have to reprimand you for spinning at this party.
Shane techno, altho it does have many virtues, is definitely not the humane
thing to force a goat to listen to.

third question: am I the only person who has noticed that this party, a
Valentine's party featuring a live goat, will take place while Venus is in
Capricorn?


Giles


ps: Mercury is also in Capricorn. that can't really mean much tho. astrology
works sometimes, but how seriously can it really be taken? I think it's a
bit much to say that cosmic wheels have been set in motion which we are
governed by and powerless to stop.

I mean, it's a bit Vincent Price, really, isn't it?

pps: I will say no more about goats. it's a sad day when George Bush gets
more attention than a live goat, but it's downright ludicrous when a live
goat gets more attention than DDR.

From sfraves-return-98816-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Feb 12 23:20:43 2003
