X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski

ok, I've been sitting on this for a while, so, more thoughts:

>San Francisco has always been where every precocious 20 year old with the
>slightest bohemian pretense eventually comes to do time, usually for about
>5 years. They often come in bunches from places like Denver, Chicago,
>Brighton etc. Often Artists who have made a name for themselves will come
>to San Francisco and their Artistic output will drop to zero. There is no
>hard edge to culture here; the living is easy, you get spoiled playing
>with the alterno-children dressing fun and looking for smoochies.
>DJs/Artists come here thinking they will own the place and find themselves
>caught in the mire of the 5 year status quo: If they don't show up at the
>cusp of one of these transitions it is hard to make an impact. Often you
>end up on heroin or speed and have to go home. It used to have a lot of
>LSD, it has less now. Often there are several scenes happening at once but
>there is usually an Uber Scene. The last 7 years were dominated by a
>hybrid identity of dot com/Burning Man/ravers. I think we may be on a
>transition now but have no Idea where the Cultural injection will come
>from; we have never in the past put it together ourselves. My favorite
>thing about partying in SF is that you don't frequently get beat up.

this morning I was watching Moulin Rouge and I couldn't help being reminded
of San Francisco. it starts off there's a Bohemian revolution brewing, and
the guy goes to Paris to be part of it. this is kinda what initially brought
me to San Francisco, and the odd thing about that is that it's been what
brought people to San Francisco in the past as well. it's what brought the
Beats to San Francisco in the 50s, and when Kerouac and his crew made the
whole Beat experience a literary phenomenon, that's what brought bucketloads
of hippies to SF in the 60s. there's a great book about smuggling marijuana
during this period, unfortunately the book is out of print, but it describes
the feelings of the Beats when the first waves of hippies crashed on the
shores of North Beach and "kids from Kansas stood standing on street corners
waiting for something to happen."

I came to SF from Chicago. Chicago is a mean, nasty, dangerous city. the
posture and walk I had adopted there, both of which had become habit, made
me stick out like a sore thumb when I first arrived - to the point that in
the Tenderloin I more than once saw people cross the street when they saw me
coming. when I lived in the Mission, I wore red and white - the local gang
colors - almost every day, just to show the gangbangers I wasn't scared of
them. my attitude was, I don't care if you're packing an Uzi, you're not
from Chicago. and a fellow Chicagoan I worked with told me how he had been
the "victim" of an attempted mugging in the Tenderloin. a heroin addict
pushed a gun in his face, demanding his money, so he smacked the gun out of
the addict's hand and beat him to a pulp.

now Chicago, as bad as it is - and it isn't a good place to live - is
nonetheless the birthplace of house. but compare San Francisco house to
Chicago house and you begin to see why I buy into these words quoted far
above (very far above at this point). Chicago house is full of urgency,
danger, and passion. the 303 acid line was invented in Chicago. meanwhile,
San Francisco house is comfortable and relaxing. San Francisco house is very
popular, and indeed some of it is quite good - I'm not dissing it. I like
it, in fact. but it doesn't have that intensity. it doesn't even have
anything remotely resembling that intensity. Chicago house carries within it
distant echoes of Chicago's other great music, the blues. (birthplace of
house, home of the blues.) however, in San Francisco, easy living sometimes
comes dangerously close to easy listening.

I believe this explains a good deal of the polarization which occured in the
rave scene between massives and undergrounds. the music at massives was
simply too nice - devoid of fire and lightning, completely lacking in true
soul. the underground response was necessary, bkz raves have never been
about easy listening or mainstream music, and in San Francisco, certain
varieties of rave music became so mainstream that they ceased to have any
real meaning at all.

however, I'm not totally sure of this element of my analysis. what I am sure
of is that, historically speaking, Chicago exhibits cycles of musical
development which exist to specifically counteract the overall oppression
one experiences in that city. and that oppression is very real, btw.
virtually every movie by Chicago filmmakers, or with a Chicago setting,
features the heroes being chased by the cops at some point. there's a reason
for that.

San Francisco, I believe, also exhibits historical cycles, and I think
whoever wrote these words of truth which Migurski found floating on the
Internet identified those cycles, and even their approximate length, with
uncanny accuracy. those words describe the Beatniks perfectly, and the
Beatniks had their day fifty years ago. those words describe the hippies as
well, and that too was very long ago. only time will tell, but I suspect
these words will one day describe Epiphany, Viberation, Children of the Sun,
and all the other great and once-great underground collectives - as well as
Harmony and other purveyors of massives, and indeed Koinoinea, 1015 Folsom,
and everyone in between.

(random thing: Koinoinea was deliberately preventing their BSPs from
appearing on sfraves as early as 2000. I asked someone why and he told me
they wanted to avoid drama.)

however, the historical anaylsis, useful tho it may be, does not explain
things like this:

>Often Artists who have made a name for themselves will come
>to San Francisco and their Artistic output will drop to zero. There is no
>hard edge to culture here; the living is easy, you get spoiled playing
>with the alterno-children dressing fun and looking for smoochies.
>DJs/Artists come here thinking they will own the place and find themselves
>caught in the mire of the 5 year status quo: If they don't show up at the
>cusp of one of these transitions it is hard to make an impact.

I believe this is simply intrinsic to the city. Just as living in Chicago
requires that you watch out for the cops and realize that they are simply
the biggest gang, so does living in San Francisco require that you sit back,
relax, and realize that you may never achieve any of your ambitions there.

This is why I'll never live in San Francisco again, or even the East Bay.
I'm still on this list because, like so many others before me, I left my
heart in San Francisco, but ultimately living in San Francisco is a matter
of choosing comfort over ambition. Not me. This is why I've decided to move
to Arizona. Phoenix has a street called "Loop 303." I think that's a good
omen. Somebody somewhere is inventing the next equivalent of the 303 acid
line, and the lessons of history would indicate that this is more likely to
happen in a police state than it is in San Francisco. And Arizona is
certainly a police state. From the moment you drive into the state, passing
the enormous billboard with a star in the center of the words "Welcome To
Arizona. Watch Your Language," this fact is inescapable.

Of course, I'm reluctant to face the perils of living in a police state, but
I'm not that worried. I don't care if they're packing Uzis. They're not from
Chicago.


Giles


ps: if you're reading this, you dived to the bottom of an ocean of words. I
hope you found some treasure here, or at least glimpsed something pretty
swimming around.



---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

brook

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:I CANT BELIEVE THIS SH*T

Yes, i agree that Japanese Americans would have
suffered prejudice during that time. But the point is
that they were taken unvoluntarily into camps where
the conditions were poor, and armed guards patrolling
the gates. On top of this, they were forced to give up
their businesses and possessions. The views of the
time werent to protect them, they were percieved as a
threat. No matter what the case, the goverenment has
no right to place people in seclusion against their
will.

my take,

Delia

Subject: [sfraves] Hi-fi and DJ turntable repair and custom modifications

--------------000403010300030407010900
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Hello everyone!
Has anyone noticed that there are very few places in the Bay Area to get 
your Technics fixed?  Not only that, but it's really expensive to have 
fairly simple repairs made.  Well, I have been collecting vinyl for 
about 6 years, have a background in electronics and  have been fixing my 
own tables and my friends tables for a while now, and decided to do 
something about this problem instead of just complaining about it. So, I 
recemtly started offering a quality, low cost alternative to my fellow 
DJs and vinyl enthusiats out there who need work done to their 
turntables.      

So, here's the info:
I provide NON-WARRANY repair services and perform custom modifications 
to turntables, specializing in Technics, although I welcome any brand 
name.  My rates will beat just about anyone out there, and there is a 
short turn around time on most repairs.  I'm a one man operation and 
have no overhead, so the savings get passed on to you.  All work is 
guaranteed and includes a basic check-up and cleaning at no extra charge.  

Standard Repairs and Services
.    Deluxe tune-up & calibration includes: (pitch calibration, general 
clean-up, spindle lubrication,
      tonearm locking ring tightening, headshell terminal cleaning, etc.)
.    Replace RCA phono cable
.    Installation of new pop-up light bulb
.    Tonearm replacement
.    Pitch fader replacement
.    Fix broken power switch - where ON/OFF switch spins but doesn't 
turn the unit ON or OFF
Note: I can fix just about anything that goes wrong even though it's not 
listed here.

Custom Modifications for Technics
.    Internal grounding -- eliminate that annoying ground wire
.    Blue LED Kit -- Customize the color of 33, 45, pitch and strobe 
lights.  Pop-up light not included.  
.    'Vinyl Touch' Reverse Kit installation - for the serious 
turntablist.  Play your records backwards with pitch control!
        By Schutt MixMachines www.mixmachines.com/products/vtr-tuni.html
.    Pitch Fader Modifications
        .  Pitch range adjustment -- Is +/-8 not enough for you?  
Increase your pitch range.
        .  Removal of the annoying center 'click' for the SL1200-MK2 models
        .  Center quartz lock removal for the SL1200-MK2 - for 
continuous pitch control like the M3D
.    Phone cord upgrade -- replace the stock phono cord with a higher 
quality RCA cable
.    Custom shell cover -- change the color of your decks!
.    Brake Adjustment -- stop on a dime, stop hard and rewind, smoothly 
slow to a stop
More custom modifications in the works...


PLEASE BE AWARE:  I do not do any warranty repairs.  You should go to a 
Panasonic Authorized Service Center if your turntable is still under 
warranty.  Some of the custom modifications will VOID your warranty.  I 
use only QUALITY components, specifically Technics® brand parts or, upon 
request, higher quality replacement parts such as Monster Cable RCA 
cords.  I get parts directly from Technics and do not mark up the cost 
at all.  You pay what I pay, including tax and shipping and handling.    

FOR SERVICE:  Call Stephen Freskos at (510)301-9221 or email to 
stephen@freskos.com for quotes on service and repairs.  Please leave a 
message with your contact information and brief description of the 
trouble.  Your call or email will be returned shortly.

EQUIPMENT DELIVERY:  Currently, pick-up and delivery in the East Bay 
including Contra Costa County, S.F., and the North Bay is by appointment 
only.  On-site/same day repairs are available, depending on the problem 
and parts needed.  There is an additional charge for same day service.

Thanks!
-Stephen Freskos


--------------000403010300030407010900--

From: Peter H <don_pedro11@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Club Exit and Sound Factory in NYC Closed

--0-1036988206-1045096801=:27158
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


I saw this on the web.  Its a response to the NYC closures.  In theory, it seems like a good idea:  if someone asks you if they can "score", you assume the worst (that they are an undercover cop) and go get security to throw them out.

 

My question: Can security really throw someone out, just because I accuse them of asking me for drugs?

 

And, is that fair to the person, if they are not a cop and just want to have a good time?  maybe that answer would be don't do drugs, and if you do, get it from someone you know/trust?

 

And the other side of the coin: if you KNOW someone is pushing in a club, should you get security to throw them out, or will that just bring more bad press to the club?

 

Just wondering what others think about this idea.

 

<<<<<<<< 

 

What's going on is the dance music scene is slowly but surely under attack.  It is under attack by those that see no distinction between the people who do illegal drugs (which exist in every music, art, and cultural scene) and the dance music scene itself.  The last couple of years has seen the closure of many great clubs such as Twilo in NYC and Buzz in DC.  Just this past weekend the NY Police shut down two major clubs there, Exit and Sound Factory because of drug use they saw and buys they were involved in.

On the same weekend here in SF, undercover police were at 1015 Folsom, DNA Lounge, and other commercial venues, as well as even underground parties they would have had to go through some trouble to locate.  In every party it's the same.  Normal looking party go-er asks people in the party if they can buy any illegal drugs, usually ecstasy.  In some cases, naive person may try and help this person out, only to be busted later.  It's happening every weekend.  They may not make a bust every time, but they are gathering data and contacts to make bigger arrests later and make a case to shut down our favorite spots to go dancing and hear music.

We all know we can't stop people from making individual decisions about what they choose to do.  But we can spread the word amongst our friends that this is happening, and we need to be aware of it.

If someone in a club or party asks you if you know where to get illegal drugs, do us all a favor.  Tell them YES, wait right here, and then go inform security so they can be thrown out of the party immediately.  You may ruin someone's night just trying to have fun, but obviously that's well worth protecting our scene.

Make no mistake, the police are trying to shut down venues where electronic dance music is played.  They are doing this because of the actions of a minority of the people that come to the parties, and it's jeopardizing all of us.  We in the scene know it is a positive movement, bringing people from many different walks of life together to connect and share.  We must not just assume everything is going to be OK, it will not be unless we make it so.

 

 

----- Original Message   -----

From: "Happy" <happy@happycandykid.com> 

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org 

Date: Tue, 11 Feb 2003 11:57:13 -0800 

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Club Exit and Sound Factory in NYC Closed 

 

 

You know, this may sound hypocritical, but while I occasionally like to

indulge in illegal substances, I hate being approached by drug dealers 

when

I'm out partying. If I want to do something, I always bring it with me,

after getting something from a friend that I know is clean and safe. I 

don't

trust anything from someone I'll never see again. When I used to go to

massives, I would always go "candy", and thus was a target for every 

sketchy

guy with a bag of pills in his pocket. My hypocrisy also extends to 

pot.

While I like to smoke it sometimes, and think it should be legal, I 

could

never sell it, no matter how desperate for money I became. Perhaps 

growing

up in East Oakland has given me a bad taste for drug dealers. Which is 

why I

like going to undergrounds, where no one ever tries to sell me 

anything.

 

Happy  :-)

Forwarded Message  

Date: Mon, 10 Feb 2003 23:27:28 -0800 

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org 

From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org> 

Subject: Club Exit and Sound Factory in NYC Closed 

 

 

 

February 8, 2003 -- Police were party poopers at two popular West Side 

nightclubs last night, shuttering the hot spots after amassing evidence 

of 

rampant "designer drug" use and sales.

 

Narcotics cops shut down Club Exit on West 56th Street and the Sound 

Factory on West 46th Street after a 22-month undercover investigation.

 

During the probe, undercover cops posing as clubgoers purchased a 

laundry 

list of drugs - mostly "ecstasy" - and witnessed numerous drug 

transactions 

and patron drug use.

 

"Thanks to our detectives' hard work, we are sending a clear message to 

nightclub owners: If you allow illegal drugs to saturate your business 

and 

endanger your patrons, we'll shut you down," said Police Commissioner 

Ray 

Kelly.

 

Over the last three years, the clubs have been the scene of more than 

200 

drug-related arrests.

 

So far, 11 people have been arrested for their involvement in selling 

and 

using drugs - but no club owner has been charged.

 

State law could keep the clubs closed for up to a year - and cops say 

they 

could close more clubs soon.

 

http://www.nypost.com/news/regionalnews/30164.htm

 

 

Fear Is The Key

 

Moksha Tribe

 

House Music 101:  

http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

is 

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a 

purpose."

-Helen Keller

 

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that 

one 

becomes transformed."

-Heinrich Zimmer

 

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  

But 

there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."

-H. L. Mencken

At 04:11 PM 2/12/2003 -0700, Giles Bowkett wrote:

>however, the historical anaylsis, useful tho it may be, does not explain
>things like this:
>
> >Often Artists who have made a name for themselves will come
> >to San Francisco and their Artistic output will drop to zero. There is no
> >hard edge to culture here; the living is easy, you get spoiled playing
> >with the alterno-children dressing fun and looking for smoochies.
> >DJs/Artists come here thinking they will own the place and find themselves
> >caught in the mire of the 5 year status quo: If they don't show up at the
> >cusp of one of these transitions it is hard to make an impact.
>
>I believe this is simply intrinsic to the city. Just as living in Chicago
>requires that you watch out for the cops and realize that they are simply
>the biggest gang, so does living in San Francisco require that you sit back,
>relax, and realize that you may never achieve any of your ambitions there.
>

I come from NYC, and what I've experienced in SF is that the city will 
either destroy you completely creatively or otherwise -- and you leave, hit 
the therapists couch, or dip into the hard stuff -- or it transforms and re 
energizes creative output.  There is almost complete freedom here.  Very 
difficult for some to handle.  No old boys' network, so that the sphere of 
privilege that exists on the East Coast is meaningless.  This place is not 
without competitive and other motivational forces.  Seems that way on the 
surface, but there is fire and passion underneath the appearance of comfort.

I've never felt "comfortable" here.  Far from it.  I feel I'm on the edge 
of something new.  Sometimes disorienting.  Never boring.  The coming 
together of the East, West and Hispanic culture.

Chicago vs SF house.  Guess it depends on what one believes typifies SF 
house these days.  One thing we lack here that I miss is a vibrant gay, 
African American music culture.  But house here is evolving in wondrous 
ways lately -- and I'm talking a move back to hard edge, gut burning stuff.

Love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one 
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

Subject: Re: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski

I find this a fascinating geography/creativity thread you have touched on here.

What do you all make of the SF DnB scene as it existed a few years 
back? SF DnB was some of the hardest around. I'm not into that scene 
any more and no doubt it's changed a bit, but I always wondered how 
such a hard and angry sound could have been so popular here in the 
land of love and flowers.

I always thought it had something to do with what seemed at the time 
like a disproportionately, and also refreshingly large, participation 
of the females representin' in that scene. Don't know if that's a 
connection or not or what it could mean, but it's one I ruminated on.

Any thoughts?

bs

---------- Forwarded message ----------
To: SFLNC General List <announce@sflnc.com>

Ascension 03
"A Celebration of Electronic Dance and Art Culture"

Event Information, Line-up, Speakers, Performers:
http://www.sflnc.com/index/events/special/29.html

Date:          Feb. 13, 2003
Location:      1015 Folsom
Time:          9:30pm - 3:30am
21+
$10

Ascension brings new entertainment forms and cultural movements developed
deep in the underground to a club environment where they can be
experienced in context by a broader audience. Ascension is now in it's
third year and has evolved into a showcase featuring the best of the
electronic dance and art culture from the Bay Area and beyond.

Elements of Ascension will include music, performance artists, multi-media
art, and fashion all originating, evolving, and drawing inspiration from
electronic music.

Music will concentrate on live electronic acts and DJs who produce a
significant part of their own play list in the moment.

We are stoked to have as special guests Uberzone - playing a special live
set in the main room starting at 11:45.

A fashion show (10pm) will kick things off in the main room featuring some
of the most promising designers in the Bay Area with beats by Ikarus.

Performance troupes will strive to push the boundaries in a variety of
dance and movement genres.

Art installations will create atmosphere and encourage interaction, & the
wicked visuals will simply blow the roof off this place before the night
is through!

Proceeds from the event will benefit the San Francisco Late Night
Coalition (SFLNC).

Energized by Red Bull Energy Drink, and produced by Infinite Kaos and a
cast too numerous to name... love to all!

http://www.redbullascension.comA

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Want to get involved in the SFLNC?
Check out http://www.sflnc.com

If you have received this message in error, please send mail to
announce-unsubscribe@sflnc.com to be removed from our general list. If you
would like to be added to the SFLNC general mailing list, please send mail
to announce-subscribe@sflnc.com.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

IMPORTANT: If the war starts in the morning stay away from work or school 
and converge at Civic Center at Noon. If it starts in the afternoon take 
the day after off. There will also be an emergency protest at 5pm at Powell 
and Market.

Thanks for contacting the ANSWER (Act Now to Stop War and End Racism) 
Coalition. Right now, thousands of people around the country are working to 
stop the war -- we hope you can join us in a Week of Resitance Against War 
& Racism this February.

Thursday Feb. 13: Youth and student teach-ins on the 12 anniversary of the 
destruction of the Al-Ameriyah Bomb Shelter in Bagdad. If you need help 
organizing a teach-in or need speakers please contact ANSWER at 
<mailto:answer@actionsf.org>answer@actionsf.org or (415) 821-6545.

Sat Feb 15: Mass mobilizations in New York, Sacramento and Los Angeles and 
many other cities across the country around the world to stop the war. 
Visit <http://www.internationalanswer.org/>www.internationalanswer.org and 
click on the CONTACTS link at the bottom of the page to find the organizing 
center near you. For info on the Sacramento demonstration call (916) 
448-7157. For info on the Los Angeles demonstraton call (213) 487-2368 or 
email <mailto:iacenterla@action-mail.org>iacenterla@action-mail.org

Sunday February 16 Mass march to stop the war in San Francisco. Gather at 
11 AM at Embarcadero Plaza at the foot of Market St. to march to 2 PM rally 
at Civic Center Plaza. For logistical information visit 
www.internationalanswer.org Volunteers urgently needed.

Friday February 21: Coordinated Day of Student Resistance, walk outs and 
other acts of non-compliance. Contact Youth and Student ANSWER for flyers 
and support.

Here is what you can do today to help stop the war:

  1.  HELP BUILD THE FEBRUARY 16  ANTI-WAR MARCH IN SAN FRANCISCO.

To PUBLICIZE THE MARCH, download flyers at 
<http://www.actionsf.org/>www.actionsf.org and make copies to distribute in 
your community. Or contact us at 415-821-6545 or answer@actionsf.org to 
have flyers sent to you by mail.

2.    JOIN THE PEOPLE'S ANTI-WAR REFERENDUM AT 
<http://www.votenowar.org/>WWW.VOTENOWAR.ORG

We're encouraging everyone to get involved in building this 
campaign.  Congress did not end the war in Vietnam, but the people's 
movement did, and once again it is up to the people to stop this war.  The 
VoteNoWar People's Anti-War Referendum is an effort to expose the lie that 
the people of the United States support George W. Bush's planned war in 
Iraq and reveal the mass anti-war opinion that exists as a majority 
sentiment. The masses of votes against the war will be presented at a 
Grassroots Peace Congress (as opposed to the U.S. "War' Congress) on Jan. 
19 in Washington, DC.

*  to VOTE NO TO WAR, go to 
<http://www.votenowar.org/referendum.html>http://www.votenowar.org/referendum.html

* to HELP GATHER VOTES AGAINST THE WAR, download the flyer at
   <http://www.votenowar.org/referendum.pdf>http://www.votenowar.org/referendum.pdf, 
make copies, and mail the votes in to the address
   listed on the bottom of the flyer.  You can help build the People's 
Anti-War Referendum in
   your community, campus, high school, and place of worship.



* to HELP ORGANIZE THESE EVENTS, contact your local ANSWER chapter to attend
organizing meetings, pick up outreach materials (posters, flyers, etc.), 
volunteer and plug  yourself and your community into this movement. In San 
Francisco ANSWER meets weekly on Tuesday at 7 PM at the Womens Building at 
3543 18 St.

* NOT NEAR AN ANSWER CHAPTER?  Start your own organizing center for the 
event or just help get out the word.  Generate discussion about the war, 
organize buses to travel from your community to the rallies, or hold your 
own solidarity rally.  You can have outreach materials sent to you as well.


3.    DONATE OR HELP RAISE FUNDS

Anti-war activities and materials can cost thousands of dollars and ANSWER 
is solely funded by its grassroots supporters.  Any contribution you or 
others can make will help pay for flyers, phone calls and 
posters.  Organize a fundraiser with your family & friends to help stop the 
war! Supporters can donate online at 
<http://www.progressunity.org/>www.progressunity.org or send checks to 
ANSWER, 2489 Mission Street #24, San Francisco CA 94110.


On January 18th, 500,000 people marched on Washington DC and 200,000 on San 
Francisco as well as thousands around the world announcing with a massive 
visible and vocal presence the growth of the new anti-war movement to stop 
George W. Bush's plans to wage war against Iraq.  Let's keep up the 
momentum until we stop the war!

CONTACT US TO GET MATERIALS!               (415) 
825-6545           answer@actionsf.org


In struggle,


LeiLani Dowell, Nancy Mitchell, Tina Landis

ANSWER

--=====================_157392756==.ALT

<font size=2><b>IMPORTANT: If the war starts in the morning</b> <b>stay
away from work or school and converge at Civic Center at Noon. If it
starts in the afternoon take the day after off. There will also be an
emergency protest at 5pm at Powell and Market.</b> <br><br>
</font>Thanks for contacting the ANSWER (Act Now to Stop War and End
Racism) Coalition. Right now, thousands of people around the country are
working to stop the war -- we hope you can join us in a Week of Resitance
Against War &amp; Racism this February.<br><br>
Thursday Feb. 13: Youth and student teach-ins on the 12 anniversary of
the destruction of the Al-Ameriyah Bomb Shelter in Bagdad. If you need
help organizing a teach-in or need speakers please contact ANSWER at
<a href="mailto:answer@actionsf.org">answer@actionsf.org</a> or (415)
821-6545.<br><br>
Sat Feb 15: Mass mobilizations in New York, Sacramento and Los Angeles
and many other cities across the country around the world to stop the
war. Visit
<a href="http://www.internationalanswer.org/">www.internationalanswer.org</a>
and click on the CONTACTS link at the bottom of the page to find the organizing center near you. For info on the Sacramento demonstration call (916) 448-7157. For info on the Los Angeles demonstraton call (213) 487-2368 or email <a href="mailto:iacenterla@action-mail.org">iacenterla@action-mail.org</a> <br><br>
<b>Sunday February 16 Mass march to stop the war in San Francisco. Gather at 11 AM at Embarcadero Plaza at the foot of Market St. to march to 2 PM rally at Civic Center Plaza. For logistical information visit <a href="http://www.internationalanswer.org/" eudora="autourl">www.internationalanswer.org</a> Volunteers urgently needed. <br><br>
</b>Friday February 21: Coordinated Day of Student Resistance, walk outs and other acts of non-compliance. Contact Youth and Student ANSWER for flyers and support. <br><br>
<u>Here is what you can do today to help stop the war:</u> <br><br>
<i>&nbsp;1.&nbsp; HELP BUILD THE <b>FEBRUARY 16&nbsp; ANTI-WAR MARCH</b> IN SAN FRANCISCO. <br><br>
</i>To PUBLICIZE THE MARCH, download flyers at <a href="http://www.actionsf.org/">www.actionsf.org</a> and make copies to distribute in your community. Or contact us at 415-821-6545 or answer@actionsf.org to have flyers sent to you by mail.<br><br>
<i>2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; JOIN THE PEOPLE'S ANTI-WAR REFERENDUM AT <a href="http://www.votenowar.org/">WWW.VOTENOWAR.ORG</a><br><br>
</i>We're encouraging everyone to get involved in building this campaign.&nbsp; Congress did not end the war in Vietnam, but the people's movement did, and once again it is up to the people to stop this war.&nbsp; The VoteNoWar People's Anti-War Referendum is an effort to expose the lie that the people of the United States support George W. Bush's planned war in Iraq and reveal the mass anti-war opinion that exists as a majority sentiment. The masses of votes against the war will be presented at a Grassroots Peace Congress (as opposed to the U.S. &quot;War' Congress) on Jan. 19 in Washington, DC. <br>
&nbsp;<br>
*&nbsp; to VOTE NO TO WAR, go to <a href="http://www.votenowar.org/referendum.html">http://www.votenowar.org/referendum.html</a><br><br>
* to HELP GATHER VOTES AGAINST THE WAR, download the flyer at <br>
&nbsp; <a href="http://www.votenowar.org/referendum.pdf">http://www.votenowar.org/referendum.pdf</a>, make copies, and mail the votes in to the address<br>
&nbsp; listed on the bottom of the flyer.&nbsp; You can help build the People's Anti-War Referendum in <br>
&nbsp; your community, campus, high school, and place of worship.<br><br>
<br><br>
* to HELP ORGANIZE THESE EVENTS, contact your local ANSWER chapter to attend<br>
organizing meetings, pick up outreach materials (posters, flyers, etc.), volunteer and plug&nbsp; yourself and your community into this movement. In San Francisco ANSWER meets weekly on Tuesday at 7 PM at the Womens Building at 3543 18 St.<br><br>
* NOT NEAR AN ANSWER CHAPTER?&nbsp; Start your own organizing center for the event or just help get out the word.&nbsp; Generate discussion about the war, organize buses to travel from your community to the rallies, or hold your own solidarity rally.&nbsp; You can have outreach materials sent to you as well.<br>
&nbsp;<br><br>
3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>DONATE OR HELP RAISE FUNDS<br><br>
</i>Anti-war activities and materials can cost thousands of dollars and ANSWER is solely funded by its grassroots supporters.&nbsp; Any contribution you or others can make will help pay for flyers, phone calls and posters.&nbsp; Organize a fundraiser with your family &amp; friends to help stop the war! Supporters can donate online at <a href="http://www.progressunity.org/">www.progressunity.org</a> or send checks to ANSWER, 2489 Mission Street #24, San Francisco CA 94110.<br><br>
<br>
<i>On January 18th, 500,000 people marched on Washington DC and 200,000 on San Francisco as well as thousands around the world announcing with a massive visible and vocal presence the growth of the new anti-war movement to stop George W. Bush's plans to wage war against Iraq.&nbsp; Let's keep up the momentum until we stop the war!<br><br>

'Scratch' is dope shiznitz...

In a message dated 2/11/2003 11:18:15 AM Pacific Standard Time, 
gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com writes:

> 
> rent the dvd for "scratch." skip the movie and go to the bonus CD.
> 
> on the bonus cd, there's an awesome qbert how-to thingy...not only does he
> give excellent advice on how to scratch, he also turns out to be an expert
> plumber.
> 
> also excellent is the scratch notation demo. Rob Swift demonstrates a
> number of different scratches. the footage is great, especially since you
> can put it on half speed and watch him scratch in slow motion. the
> scratching is so quick you can't see it any other way.
> 
> the only problem is that most of the techniques center on the crossfader,
> and for rave DJs, the crossfader tends to not only be much wider, it also
> usually operates on a broader curve which is less well-suited to 
> scratching.
> 
> luckily Q-Bert provides one possible answer in his how-to video. you can 
> use
> the faders instead of the crossfader. he points it out as simply a 
> different
> method which produces a different (more textured) effect, in his section on
> how to do lazer scratches, but it's worth exploring as a general 
> alternative
> to crossfader scratching owing to the generally broader crossfader curves 
> on
> rave/club mixers.
> 
> there's also a fragment of QBert's movie. combination of turntablism and
> Adobe After Effects. it's pretty great.
> 
> once upon a time I broke my crossfader beat-juggling jungle. then I forgot
> all about turntablism for years.
> 
> now, of course, I get interested in it again - having sold over 100 hip-hop
> records on eBay, completely cleaning out my hip-hop collection, and leaving
> me only Muppet records to scratch with.
> 
> *sigh*
> 
> 
> Giles
> 


--part1_d.9e68d48.2b7c7744_boundary--

Ascension 03
"A Celebration of Electronic Dance and Art Culture"

Event Information, Line-up, Speakers, Performers:
http://www.sflnc.com/index/events/special/29.html

Date:          Feb. 13, 2003
Location:      1015 Folsom
Time:          9:30pm - 3:30am
21+
$10

Ascension brings new entertainment forms and cultural movements =
developed
deep in the underground to a club environment where they can be
experienced in context by a broader audience. Ascension is now in it's
third year and has evolved into a showcase featuring the best of the
electronic dance and art culture from the Bay Area and beyond.

Elements of Ascension will include music, performance artists, =
multi-media
art, and fashion all originating, evolving, and drawing inspiration from
electronic music.

Music will concentrate on live electronic acts and DJs who produce a
significant part of their own play list in the moment.

We are stoked to have as special guests Uberzone - playing a special =
live
set in the main room starting at 11:45.

A fashion show (10pm) will kick things off in the main room featuring =
some
of the most promising designers in the Bay Area with beats by Ikarus.

Performance troupes will strive to push the boundaries in a variety of
dance and movement genres.

Art installations will create atmosphere and encourage interaction, & =
the
wicked visuals will simply blow the roof off this place before the night
is through!

Proceeds from the event will benefit the San Francisco Late Night
Coalition (SFLNC).

Energized by Red Bull Energy Drink, and produced by Infinite Kaos and a
cast too numerous to name... love to all!

http://www.redbullascension.com

Event Information, Line-up, Speakers, Performers:
http://www.sflnc.com/index/events/special/29.html

Date:          Feb. 13, 2003
Location:      1015 Folsom
Time:          9:30pm - 3:30am
21+
$10

Ascension brings new entertainment forms and cultural movements developed
deep in the underground to a club environment where they can be
experienced in context by a broader audience. Ascension is now in it's
third year and has evolved into a showcase featuring the best of the
electronic dance and art culture from the Bay Area and beyond.

Elements of Ascension will include music, performance artists, multi-media
art, and fashion all originating, evolving, and drawing inspiration from
electronic music.

Music will concentrate on live electronic acts and DJs who produce a
significant part of their own play list in the moment.

We are stoked to have as special guests Uberzone - playing a special live
set in the main room starting at 11:45.

A fashion show (10pm) will kick things off in the main room featuring some
of the most promising designers in the Bay Area with beats by Ikarus.

Performance troupes will strive to push the boundaries in a variety of
dance and movement genres.

Art installations will create atmosphere and encourage interaction, & the
wicked visuals will simply blow the roof off this place before the night
is through!

Proceeds from the event will benefit the San Francisco Late Night
Coalition (SFLNC).

Energized by Red Bull Energy Drink, and produced by Infinite Kaos and a
cast too numerous to name... love to all!

http://www.redbullascension.com




---------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject: Re: [sfraves] GOAT CONSPIRACY (was: questions)


The goat attention plot is more real than you know.  It has been
contolling Josh praxis for weeks now as far as I can tell.  I am
concerned for the safety of the rave scene, and the entire human race if
the goat succeeds in it's mission this Friday.

Placing the blame on Shane or Josh or any of the crew is exactly what the
goat wants you to do.  We need to drill down to the true cause of this
situation and find a solution, fast.

The astrological signs show that this theory is correct, as you've already
pointed out.  The question is what do we do about it?



On a positive note, It should be a great time.  Lots of live techno, and
other dance goodness, great people, and multi-room space...  Mix in the
transmissions from a telepathic goat, and bam, you've got a raging party!


See you there!

-e-

>---------- Forwarded message ----------
>To: SFLNC General List <announce@sflnc.com>
>
>Ascension 03
>"A Celebration of Electronic Dance and Art Culture"
>
>Event Information, Line-up, Speakers, Performers:
>http://www.sflnc.com/index/events/special/29.html
>
>Date:          Feb. 13, 2003
>Location:      1015 Folsom
>Time:          9:30pm - 3:30am
>21+
>$10
>
>Ascension brings new entertainment forms and cultural movements developed
>deep in the underground to a club environment where they can be
>experienced in context by a broader audience. Ascension is now in it's
>third year and has evolved into a showcase featuring the best of the
>electronic dance and art culture from the Bay Area and beyond.
>
>Elements of Ascension will include music, performance artists, multi-media
>art, and fashion all originating, evolving, and drawing inspiration from
>electronic music.
>
>Music will concentrate on live electronic acts and DJs who produce a
>significant part of their own play list in the moment.
>
>We are stoked to have as special guests Uberzone - playing a special live
>set in the main room starting at 11:45.
>
>A fashion show (10pm) will kick things off in the main room featuring some
>of the most promising designers in the Bay Area with beats by Ikarus.
>
>Performance troupes will strive to push the boundaries in a variety of
>dance and movement genres.
>
>Art installations will create atmosphere and encourage interaction, & the
>wicked visuals will simply blow the roof off this place before the night
>is through!
>
>Proceeds from the event will benefit the San Francisco Late Night
>Coalition (SFLNC).
>
>Energized by Red Bull Energy Drink, and produced by Infinite Kaos and a
>cast too numerous to name... love to all!
>
>http://www.redbullascension.comA
>
>--------------------------------------------------------------------------
>Want to get involved in the SFLNC?
>Check out http://www.sflnc.com
>
>If you have received this message in error, please send mail to
>announce-unsubscribe@sflnc.com to be removed from our general list. If you
>would like to be added to the SFLNC general mailing list, please send mail
>to announce-subscribe@sflnc.com.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski


a quote i've had around seems fitting for an answer to "why dnb was what
it was..."


"True music must repeat the thought and inspirations of the people and
the time."
George Gershwin

when things are secure and oh-so-grand as in the dotcom economy, the
music produced is directly proportional and frenzied to make up the
drama quotient not attained through daily struggle.

just thoughts,
m.

:: -----Original Message-----
:: From: blindspot [mailto:blindspot@mac.com] 
:: Sent: Wednesday, February 12, 2003 5:35 PM
:: To: Apollo; Giles Bowkett; sfraves@hyperreal.org
:: Subject: Re: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski
:: 
:: 
:: I find this a fascinating geography/creativity thread you 
:: have touched on here.
:: 
:: What do you all make of the SF DnB scene as it existed a few years 
:: back? SF DnB was some of the hardest around. I'm not into that scene 
:: any more and no doubt it's changed a bit, but I always wondered how 
:: such a hard and angry sound could have been so popular here in the 
:: land of love and flowers.
:: 
:: I always thought it had something to do with what seemed at the time 
:: like a disproportionately, and also refreshingly large, 
:: participation 
:: of the females representin' in that scene. Don't know if that's a 
:: connection or not or what it could mean, but it's one I ruminated on.
:: 
:: Any thoughts?
:: 
:: bs
:: 
:: 
:: At 17:07 -0800 2/12/03, Apollo wrote:
:: >At 04:11 PM 2/12/2003 -0700, Giles Bowkett wrote:
:: >
:: >>however, the historical anaylsis, useful tho it may be, does not 
:: >>explain things like this:
:: >>
:: >>>Often Artists who have made a name for themselves will 
:: come to San 
:: >>>Francisco and their Artistic output will drop to zero. 
:: There is no 
:: >>>hard edge to culture here; the living is easy, you get spoiled 
:: >>>playing with the alterno-children dressing fun and looking for 
:: >>>smoochies. DJs/Artists come here thinking they will own 
:: the place and 
:: >>>find themselves caught in the mire of the 5 year status 
:: quo: If they 
:: >>>don't show up at the cusp of one of these transitions it 
:: is hard to 
:: >>>make an impact.
:: >>
:: >>I believe this is simply intrinsic to the city. Just as living in 
:: >>Chicago requires that you watch out for the cops and 
:: realize that they 
:: >>are simply the biggest gang, so does living in San 
:: Francisco require 
:: >>that you sit back, relax, and realize that you may never 
:: achieve any 
:: >>of your ambitions there.
:: >>
:: >
:: >I come from NYC, and what I've experienced in SF is that the city
:: >will either destroy you completely creatively or otherwise -- and 
:: >you leave, hit the therapists couch, or dip into the hard stuff -- 
:: >or it transforms and re energizes creative output.  There is almost 
:: >complete freedom here.  Very difficult for some to handle.  No old 
:: >boys' network, so that the sphere of privilege that exists on the 
:: >East Coast is meaningless.  This place is not without competitive 
:: >and other motivational forces.  Seems that way on the surface, but 
:: >there is fire and passion underneath the appearance of comfort.
:: >
:: >I've never felt "comfortable" here.  Far from it.  I feel I'm on the
:: >edge of something new.  Sometimes disorienting.  Never boring.  The 
:: >coming together of the East, West and Hispanic culture.
:: >
:: >Chicago vs SF house.  Guess it depends on what one believes typifies
:: >SF house these days.  One thing we lack here that I miss is a 
:: >vibrant gay, African American music culture.  But house here is 
:: >evolving in wondrous ways lately -- and I'm talking a move back to 
:: >hard edge, gut burning stuff.
:: >
:: >Love,
:: >
:: >Apollo
:: >
:: >
:: >Moksha Tribe
:: >
:: >House Music 101:  
:: >http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
:: >
:: >"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.
:: >It is not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity 
:: >to a purpose."
:: >-Helen Keller
:: >
:: >"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that
:: >one becomes transformed."
:: >-Heinrich Zimmer
:: >
:: >"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.
:: >But there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
:: >-H. L. Mencken

oh, love...valentine's day....valentine's day is for people who don't know how to love...it is the yearly reminder to try....dinner dates are really just interviews where no one is being heard and the food is rarely enjoyed except amongst true friends...oh, the title is my reaction to the daily news, by the way....once a year, and once a year alone, men and women from around the world continue the hideous argument of responsibility, money and time, and if you really loved me, blah, blah, blah and shouldn't you blah, blah, blah, and maybe if i ask a total stranger about my mate, i'll get some insite into my mate....valentine's day, the time when a man who takes lovers secretly behind his girlfriends' back, takes her out and makes her pay half...valentine's day....the day your friends try to get in on your plans probably worse than any other time of year...valentine's day...the day the guy from out of town in the truck makes a u-turn in  your neighborhood and starts yelling at you to stop for him because he likes your hot bod in front of all of your neighbors and friends from church who are silent and staring as you try to ignore the crap that he is saying he likes....valentine's day....the time of year when people get really uptight or  rather, remain so, and think that red is the only appropriate color and buy something really ugly for their girl, and then get mad when they can see without her saying a thing, that yes, this is a tacky piece of shit...where is the receipt, dear?...valentine's day...when men around the world make a point of treating the women they date like unpaid prostitutes and then wish for thanks...valentine's day...kind of like thanksgiving....the day when people who forget about gratitude, remember that it is mostly just an idealism in their lives. :)

Subject: RE: [sfraves] [nrr] Re: [sfraves] Deciblast Forums broken by stupid admin

Broken by stupid admin? No one touched anything on the box between it
working and it being gone. I wasn't aware that db's just disappear in
mysql. I would figure ALL OF IT WOULD DISAPPEAR.

There's several exploits between Phpbb 2.0.3 and 2.0.4 (the latest
version).
The only db that was dropped was the forum...

My best guess was that someone got through the forums.

It's not a shared host.. this is a private server that halogen,
ravepictures, deciblast, hardcoreforthepeople, resistancerecordings, etc
are hosted on.

I'm sorry I upset a bigshot security man. Don't hurt me please.

Thanks,
Deepak

> > >
> > > - smilies
> > > - avatars
> > >
> > > Unrecoverable:
> > >
> > > - usernames
> > > - posts
> > >
> > > It happenned around late evening yesterday. The database table the
>forum
> > > runs off of was dropped somehow. Unfortunately the latest backup was
> > > from this morning w/o the table. The server backs up the next day
>and
> > > erases the previous backup.
> > >
> > > Email me if you have any questions.
> > >
> > > Thanks,
> > > Deepak
> > > Deciblast - http://www.deciblast.org/
> >--
> >Greg Borie al'Brecht <gba@ambreaks.com>
> >         ¡Viva No Molesté!

>> Ascension brings new entertainment forms and cultural movements 
>> developed
>> deep in the underground to a club environment where they can be
>> experienced in context by a broader audience. Ascension is now in it's
>> third year and has evolved into a showcase featuring the best of the
>> electronic dance and art culture from the Bay Area and beyond.
>>
>> Elements of Ascension will include music, performance artists, multi- 
>> media
>> art, and fashion all originating, evolving, and drawing inspiration from
>> electronic music.
>>
>> Music will concentrate on live electronic acts and DJs who produce a
>> significant part of their own play list in the moment.
>>

>> live
>> set in the main room starting at 11:45.
>>
>> A fashion show (10pm) will kick things off in the main room featuring 
>> some
>> of the most promising designers in the Bay Area with beats by Ikarus.
>>
>> Performance troupes will strive to push the boundaries in a variety of
>> dance and movement genres.
>>
>> Art installations will create atmosphere and encourage interaction, & 
>> the
>> wicked visuals will simply blow the roof off this place before the night
>> is through!

>> Coalition (SFLNC).

working and it being gone. I wasn't aware that db's just disappear in

version).

ravepictures, deciblast, hardcoreforthepeople, resistancerecordings, etc
are hosted on.

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20030213222955.GG775@pion.local>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <005b01c2d3a2$3b04acc0$0100a8c0@hondacrx> <OE671nSe3DBV3lLf8Ll00001dd1@hotmail.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <OE671nSe3DBV3lLf8Ll00001dd1@hotmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [nrr] Re: [sfraves] Deciblast Forums broken by stupid admin

> From: "Deepak Jagannath" <deepakj@myrealbox.com>
> 
> Broken by stupid admin? No one touched anything on the box between it
> working and it being gone. I wasn't aware that db's just disappear in
> mysql. I would figure ALL OF IT WOULD DISAPPEAR.

Err...
mysql% DROP DATABASE foo;

> There's several exploits between Phpbb 2.0.3 and 2.0.4 (the latest
> version).  The only db that was dropped was the forum...

Yeah, I imagine it's much more difficult to trigger an exploit that
would loop over all the available databases and drop them than it would
be to issue a single DROP statement.

> My best guess was that someone got through the forums.

What version of PHPBB are/were you guys running? You could pretty easily
find out at least the IP of whoever did it by taking a look at your
access logs -- the popular phpBB SQL injection exploit is usually
carried out with a perl script that uses a pretty distinct user-agent
string (though it'd be easy to change). If you keep a mysql log, you can
grep that for the last DROP statement and compare the timestamps.

The exploit: <http://tinyurl.com/5sw8>

-- 
shawn allen

  phone://415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

From sfraves-return-98869-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Feb 14 00:00:58 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-98869-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 4576 invoked by uid 1103); 14 Feb 2003 00:00:58 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 4561 invoked from network); 14 Feb 2003 00:00:57 -0000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <OF0F6732AF.ECFBAFC4-ON85256CCD.000014D0@washpost.com>
From: "Mary Morris" <morrism@washpost.com>
Date: Thu, 13 Feb 2003 19:01:46 -0500
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] scott henry, jay-j, noel sanger, and other stuff :)

hello from dc, sf-ravers!  :)

fyi, i write a column about the rave scene for a regional paper called
music monthly (dc/maryland/virginia).  in case you're bored, here's wha=
t
ran in february (pre-edited).

your Jay-J is such a cool guy, peeps!  :)

much love and respect,
mary :)


SCOTT HENRY:  BACK TO THE FUTURE

      Once upon a time in a land far away there was an oasis of culture=

called Buzz. It began as a glint in the eyes of Baltimorean Scott Henry=
 who
channeled his love for a new type of music into building a home fit to
attract the finest and brightest creators of this music to perform thei=
r
feats of magic on thousands of people who gathered to dance Friday afte=
r
Friday for nine long years. Dark forces arose time and again to threate=
n
the peaceful revelers, and finally the darkness grew so great that a sh=
adow
fell over Buzz, until with pride but sadness it finally declared the pa=
rty
over. It was the end of an unsurpassed era of continuous world class
excellence. A candlelight vigil was held before the locked doors that h=
ad
once welcomed the faithful.
      Fortunately, Scott had had visions of expanding the dream, so tho=
ugh
the end of Buzz was unforeseen, when it came, Buzzlife Productions was
already working on new projects. Soon a new weekly began in Baltimore o=
n
Saturday nights at Redwood Trust.
      Music Monthly had the good fortune to connect with the itinerant,=

mercurial legend at a Thai restaurant in Georgetown one evening in late=

November.

Music Monthly:  What was it like for the Buzz Crew after announcing the=
 end
of Buzz at Nation?

Scott Henry:  Of course, we were all pretty sad, but we looked at it as=

more of an opportunity to move forward and try different things, and th=
at
maybe this happened for a reason. Those four walls may have been holdin=
g us
back. I felt bad because, not that we were providing a service, but we =
were
providing Washington, DC with some special fun times and now that that'=
s
gone, part of me feels a commitment to get something started again, but=
 the
right opportunity really hasn't arisen yet. It has to be from the right=

space, to working with the right people, right sound system, right ligh=
ts.
It's hard to come back and do something that's not up to what it was. M=
aybe
we're looking to go the route of being involved in owning a club. I'm
looking around. We're developing a community in Baltimore. We might
initially do a monthly party in DC to keep things rolling until we can =
come
up with a new club.
      Spundae (San Francisco) does things in 3 or 4 cities. We've learn=
ed a
lot from watching Spundae and how they went about going into different
markets. We want to do something once a month in different cities, and =
try
to help and develop a community, like we did here, maybe through each c=
ity
having its own Buzz message board, maybe with the sites linked. But to =
us
the community, and the presentation and production right now are what's=

most important. It's not as much any more about the super star DJ.   (
www.buzzlife.com)

MM:  Will you play at the Buzz parties in different cities?

SH:  I'm going to make it my priority to play as many as possible and I=
'm
trying to convince John Tab to as well. We've always tried to give peop=
le a
wide array of talent. I used to play Buzz every two months. The first p=
arty
in Chicago, at Zentra, February 1, will have DJ Rap, DJ Blame, RY-N, PN=
S,
Andre Harris, School 'n' Sheffield, and me. We were going to start with=

Dieselboy but he's in Moscow then. Joey Swanson, who was with XM (Satel=
lite
Radio), is moving back to Chicago to get back on alternative radio, and=
 our
night will actually broadcast on this station. Joey's our partner there=
. He
grew up in Chicago, knows Chicago, loves Chicago, and I think he'll be =
a
great person to work with. Joey's working on a couple of respected
well-liked Chicago house DJ's because Chicago's a house town. Buzz has
always been about encompassing all the different styles of music. We wa=
nt
to give Chicago what they know, but also maybe a little of what they do=
n't
know.

MM:  Do you see a change in the climate in which parties are being thro=
wn
in America?

SH:  I do. I think our interest in a new club situation in DC or wherev=
er
should be concentrated on looking at a mid-size space that accommodates=
 a
thousand people instead of two thousand people, because we are in a per=
iod
now when it's too hard to pack a super club. We were certainly fortunat=
e
that we were able to pull it off for as long as we did. We had to our
advantage that we created a community, in the strongest sense of the wo=
rd,
and we didn't charge ridiculous prices. We think the recession played a=
 big
part all across America [in the slowing down of the scene]. I don't thi=
nk
it hurt DC as much because we're a government town and so many people h=
ere
work for the government and their jobs were protected. But I think if w=
e
were to try to re-create that (Buzz), 2500 people, it would be a seriou=
s
uphill battle. Between the economy and people starting to realize that =
some
of the DJ's were getting paid this crazy amount of money, more than the=
y
make in a year, then they go, oh, so this is why it cost $30 to get in
tonight. I think people just got kind of turned off by that. With promo=
ters
complaining to agents, some DJ's are getting it and realize they have t=
o
bend with it. But there are other DJ's that say, I made this kind of mo=
ney,
if you don't want to pay it, don't book me. Those are the DJ's I think =
this
time next year who are not going to be around.

There's a lot to be said when we may have been targeted because we were=
 in
the media, people looked up to us, and our involvement against the RAVE=

Act. It's pretty sad when all we were doing was promoting this music th=
at
we love, and they want to take that away from us. There are civil liber=
ties
issues here that are astounding, sickening. I think if the average Amer=
ican
really knew what was going on, they might not like this music or what s=
ome
of the kids look like, but if they realized the government is basically=

trying to tell us what kind of music we can listen to, I think most
Americans would have a big problem with that. But the only way we can l=
et
them know what's going on is to have a more mainstream, or popular,
celebrity, like Madonna or Moby, say: This is screwed up. Then people w=
ill
listen. MTV's "Rock the Vote" expressed interest in getting behind this=
.
But the key is education and PR and getting America behind us. Hopefull=
y
we'll have the time to do it.

We had a meeting in New York about a month ago with several major booki=
ng
agents, a couple major promoters, PR people, management people. Really,=
 the
type of people you would never see sitting around the same table becaus=
e
they're all very fierce competitors and that's just the way it is. But =
we
realized that this could affect all our businesses and livelihoods and =
the
trickle down effect could be absolutely devastating to hundreds, thousa=
nds
of businesses. For electronic dance music, if there's no avenue to prom=
ote
this music, the music will disappear, along with the people who work fo=
r
the record labels, the distributors and sales people, the booking agent=
s,
the DJ's.

MM:  What are you most proud of looking back on Buzz in DC?

SH:  I'm proud of the people in the scene in DC, and on our end, I'm pr=
oud
of our longevity, more than anything. It's very hard and very rare for =
a
popular club to last more than a year, and we defied the odds.

METATRACK ON THE AIR

      February 4 marks lift-off for Metatrack Studios' new show "The
Launchpad" on XM Satellite Radio, announces Metatrack founder Juliette
Siegfried (DJ Zelda) and Luis Baro, producer of "The Move" channel.
      Music reviewers will find and present up and coming DJ's from acr=
oss
the U.S. in House (Dimitri Botbol, Adrian Collazo, Sheila Storms, Ivan
Smith aka Ivan G., Courtney Reyers aka Apple), Breaks (Charles Young ak=
a DJ
Smalls), Techno (Jambi Ganbar, Matt Poe aka The Technologist),
Trance/Progressive (Tony Carver aka DJ 621, Zach Fitzjarrell aka Xodus)=
,
Drum 'n' bass (Matt Rogers and Jeff Hancock aka Freefall), and
Downtempo/Experimental (Gil Yaker aka Gee Why, Lindsey Kistler aka Elka=
y,
Mike Reger). Genres will rotate weekly and will feature two one-hour se=
ts.
Congratulations!

NOEL SANGER
      There in his shout-outs for "Noel Sanger: Summerbreeze2" (Nettwer=
k
America) was a clear DC connection: Ben Camp, Brian Transeau (aka BT),
Sharam and Ali (aka Deep Dish). Sanger explains: "My DC ties run pretty=

deep, actually. I am originally from Virginia, about 2 hours from DC, n=
ear
Charlottesville, and my entire family lives there. I have lived in Flor=
ida
since I was 6 years old, but spent a huge amount of time over the years=

between the Blue Ridge and DC. I am signed as a producer to DC's MusicN=
ow
Recordings, the label that brought BT to the world back in the early '9=
0s.
In 2000 I actually tried to move to DC, but the real estate market was =
so
tight that we couldn't find anything in Northern Virginia. Houses were
renting 20 minutes after they came on the market. We were tired of Sout=
h
Florida and at that point settled on Orlando. In fact, the cover art fo=
r my
"Trance II" CD in 2000 was the DC Metro! Someone who deserves mention i=
s
DC's Holmes Ives. To me he is one of the hottest musicmakers in America=

right now and he keeps getting better. On 'Summerbreeze2' he appears un=
der
his Memnon and Oko Tek monikers. Brilliant stuff."

JAY-J!  JAY-J!
      LoveGrove aka LG Concannon, who hosted Grammy nominee Jay-J at So=
nar
on January 25, couldn't have been happier: "Jay-J was excellent. A supe=
r
nice guy. It was the first time he played the Baltimore/DC area, and we=

will be bringing him back for sure. It isn't uncommon for a great produ=
cer
to show up and be a sub-par DJ. Well, Jay-J is one of the best house
producers in the world, as his Grammy nomination (with Chris Lum for be=
st
remixed recording category for Jill Scott's "He Loves Me" (Illegal Remi=
x))
certainly proves, and he is one hell of a DJ. It is nice to see he is
getting the recognition he so rightly deserves."
      Said Jay-J, who is on his local NARAS committee in San Francisco:=

"When we sat down to do a listening I saw this track on there. Usually,=

over the last few years, the songs that are voted and that win are not
soulful songs. They're more of the aggressive remixes, a lot of the New=

York guys, or like Deep Dish who won last year, the harder edge stuff, =
so I
really didn't think anything of it. I voted for it but I mean, you know=
,
it's like, whatever. All of a sudden I got a call from Nikki, my public=
ist,
and she's like, Hey! I've got good news for you! It made that final rou=
nd
so we're really excited. I was on my way to the studio and as I was wal=
king
in she calls and she's giving me the news and I was just like, Wow! Tha=
t's
pretty cool! And Chris was in Australia and I knew with the time change=
 it
was really late or really early over there but I just had to call. I wo=
ke
him up and said, Hey, what's up! Are you up? Are you ready? Guess what?=

We're going to the Grammy's!" (laughs)
      How did his family react? "I went to college and have a degree in=

psychology and they were glad that I did that but all along they've alw=
ays
been supportive of the music. My Dad always said, 'You know, we'll be a=
t
the Grammy's some day.' I used to think, Oh yeah, right, I do House mus=
ic.
So he was the first person I called and the funny thing is that I rarel=
y
meet my Dad for lunch, but I was going to meet him for lunch that day. =
I
called and then realized, I don't want to tell him over the phone, so w=
hen
he called me back I was like, I'm just confirming for lunch. Then I wen=
t
down there (San Jose) and I said, Okay, you ready? He was like, Wow!
(laughs) So they're going to come to New York. I was born in New Jersey=
, my
parents were born and raised in New York, so we're going to back there =
and
have fun."
      Any reaction from Jill Scott? "I haven't spoken to her but I know=

that she really likes the remix. Chris and I saw her live and she does =
a
slow version earlier in the show and then later towards the end the dru=
mmer
starts playing a house beat, and we were like, Whoa! And she's goes int=
o
this little thing and says, 'Girl, I'll house you!' and she breaks into=
 the
'He Loves Me' remix. Chris and I, we LOVE her, and that's why it all ca=
me
about, and we just looked at each other and went, Oh my God! Dude! She'=
s
doing our version LIVE!"
At the end of his rollicking set, Jay-J handed out advance promos of hi=
s
new release "West Coast Sessions" (double-CD set with Miguel Migs at
Moulton Studios, SF, on Defected, UK), and the crowd, including DJ Cort=
ex
of DC Skillz, house diva Lady J and one of her dancers, Esperonto, chan=
ted
"Jay-J! Jay-J!" and "One more! One more!" House lovers in paradise. (Fl=
uid
and Chris Bulla held down the lounge.)

ROCK YER BODY
      )EIB(  aka Bad Company UK's new "Shot Down on Safari" on Dieselbo=
y's
HUMAN label is two CD's, the first with nine radioactive tracks by this=

infamous, formidably creative drum 'n' bass force. The second is a
continuous stream of the "Best of the Bad," rich and decadent like eati=
ng a
box of your favorite Godiva chocolates. Killer track after killer track=

that you already know from DSL, AK1200, Dara, Ransom, Jesse Tittsworth,=

Brian Arsenault, Bryce et al deploying these lethal weapons on the danc=
e
floor. Hardcore, feral d 'n' b to die for. Boh! Boh! Boh!
      Adam F Presents Drum and Bass Warfare (System Recordings) is an
historic hip-hop vs. drum 'n' bass summit featuring Redman, LL Cool J,
Capone n' Noreaga, Lil' Mo, Beenie Man, Guru, Carl Thomas, MOP and Phar=
oahe
Monch on the hip-hop tip, and Adam F, Roni Size, Andy C, J Majik, High
Contrast, Matrix, John B, and Bad Company UK representing for d 'n' b. =
The
double-CD set features 15 d 'n' b remixes of hip-hop tracks on one, and=
 on
the other a dazzling mix of 15 tracks by 3-time DMC World Champion DJ
Craze, a cinematic, operatic, panoramic, high voltage revolution on the=

streets vision that will run you over like a tank.
      On the softer end of the dance spectrum is a new CD of eight tran=
ce
and progressive remixes of Sinead O'Connor's "Troy (The Phoenix From Th=
e
Flame)" (Radikal). It began as a 12" white label record of trance remix=
es
in 2002 which O'Connor came to support. Different envisionings are offe=
red
by Schiller, Rob Searle, Kay Cee, Felipe Inoa, and John Creamer & Steph=
ane
K, with varying ratios of soulfulness to prettiness, but all are design=
ed
to rock you, gently.
      "I could have danced all night, I could have danced all night, an=
d
still have begged for more." Alan Jay Lerner, "My Fair Lady" 1956.  Dan=
ce!
Dance! Dance! - MIM

      mary ishimoto morris
      music monthly
      february 2003

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [nrr] Re: [sfraves] Deciblast Forums broken by  stupid admin

S> huh?

S> Just because the box wasn't touched when it happened doesn't mean a stupid 
S> admin forgot a step somewhere.  Even if the site was hacked, it's still the 
S> admin's fault.

I beg, no- I demand to differ-

Part of sane security in the real world is the understanding that you *will* be
compromised.
End of story.
The entire architecture of an installation must be architected with
that in mind.
Minimization of damage, and a post remedy contingency plan are what you need to focus on.

I don't know the details of what was even in deciblast's forums, but
the "this backup overwrites yesterday's, oh and we don't check if
they're sane either" is not something that would fly with *my*
network-
But was is appropriate for forum content?
I don't know- that's not for me to decide.

Certain systems must be relied upon- I give the example of the latest
OpenSSH remote exploit.
"We" were compromised by this-
But due to all the other measures in place, there was NO interruption
of service and no data loss whatsoever.
That situation was unavoidable- ssh is needed for our operations.
The fact that we were compromised was not the fault of *anyone*.


--
"Insanity is the last line of defense for the master diplomat, but the groundwork must be laid early..."
AIM: IMFDUP
http://www.thedenofsin.org/

Subject: Re: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski

> I find this a fascinating geography/creativity thread you have touched on
> here.

thank you! :-)

> What do you all make of the SF DnB scene as it existed a few years
> back? SF DnB was some of the hardest around. I'm not into that scene
> any more and no doubt it's changed a bit, but I always wondered how
> such a hard and angry sound could have been so popular here in the
> land of love and flowers.

I think the jungle thing has something to do with the popularity of trance.
I don't think very much trance was actually produced in the Bay during the
development of the SF d&b sound, but certainly there were tons of trance
parties. in general trance was hugely popular, and a lot of people
consequently hated it with a passion. (I'm embarassed to admit that I was
one of those people.) probably the SF jungle sound came as a reaction to the
uber-pretty sound of foo-foo trance, as I think, to a lesser extent, the
popularity of hard techno might have done as well.

> I always thought it had something to do with what seemed at the time
> like a disproportionately, and also refreshingly large, participation
> of the females representin' in that scene. Don't know if that's a
> connection or not or what it could mean, but it's one I ruminated on.
>
> Any thoughts?

disproportionate and refreshingly large women are wonderful, but all the
women involved at the creative level in the d&b scene in SF are, if I
recall correctly, both proportionate and reasonably sized.

for example, Sage.

mmm...Sage.








what were we talking about?


Giles

X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.00.2615.200
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2615.200
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski

> I've never felt "comfortable" here.  Far from it.  I feel I'm on the edge
> of something new.  Sometimes disorienting.  Never boring.  The coming
> together of the East, West and Hispanic culture.

hold on - I think you might have misunderstood me. after all, when talking
about a place, you're dealing with something very subjective. I know someone
who has an astrology program that maps your birth chart across the planet.
when I used this, I found that it appeared to work (which is all you can
really ever say of astrology). what you feel in any given place may just be
a reflection of whatever energies are there for you.

I'm not actually saying SF is the land of the lotus-eaters...nor am I saying
I'd rush like a maniac into the middle of Mexico (or whatever random
location) expecting to find the latest and most brilliant new musical
development simply because I'd heard a rumor of police brutality there. I am
certainly prone to eccentric behavior, but even I am not that insane.

> Chicago vs SF house.  Guess it depends on what one believes typifies SF
> house these days.  One thing we lack here that I miss is a vibrant gay,
> African American music culture.  But house here is evolving in wondrous
> ways lately -- and I'm talking a move back to hard edge, gut burning
> stuff.

in Chicago house is the soundtrack to the gay world, the black world, and
the raver world, as well as many other worlds, like the swinging and bondage
scenes. these worlds are not as free in Chicago as they are in San Francisco
(where they simply fade into the background as one more spectacle to be seen
in the carnival).

I think the most disorienting experience I had, when I moved from Chicago's
suburbs to the city proper, was finding out that rap music was much more
popular among white kids in the suburbs than it was among black kids in the
city. in Chicago rap is the daytime music you can listen to at work. house
is the real party music.

however, I am not really qualified to speak on the role of any form of music
in communities of which I am not part...the most I can say on this is that
in San Francisco house plays a different role, and consequently takes a
different shape.

I can't say what the future will bring for SF house, but I wasn't dissing
it...Naked Music is a great label.


Giles

Subject: Re: [sfraves] GOAT CONSPIRACY (was: questions)

> The goat attention plot is more real than you know.  It has been
> contolling Josh praxis for weeks now as far as I can tell.  I am
> concerned for the safety of the rave scene, and the entire human race if
> the goat succeeds in it's mission this Friday.
>
> Placing the blame on Shane or Josh or any of the crew is exactly what the
> goat wants you to do.  We need to drill down to the true cause of this
> situation and find a solution, fast.
>
> The astrological signs show that this theory is correct, as you've already
> pointed out.  The question is what do we do about it?

We trust in the motions of the universe, and watch the skies - or pay close
attention to those who do. The goat may indeed have diabolical plans up its
sleeve (assuming this is a goat who goes about clothed), but when all is
said and done, we are the ones with opposable thumbs.

The goat controls the day - but we control the night.

We may be tempted to flee the goat in a panic, or slaughter it in a vengeful
frenzy, but the wisest course is simply this:

Bring the goat some comfy earplugs and a nice bit of lettuce.

Pat it on the head, wish it good luck, and let it be.

> On a positive note, It should be a great time.  Lots of live techno, and
> other dance goodness, great people, and multi-room space...  Mix in the
> transmissions from a telepathic goat, and bam, you've got a raging party!

Indeed! And enjoy it while you can.

Venus is in Capricorn now, but soon it moves into Aquarius - the sign of all
that is strange and brilliant.


Giles

minimum resources should be the focus :)

>That situation was unavoidable- ssh is needed for our operations.

>> back? SF DnB was some of the hardest around. I'm not into that scene
>> any more and no doubt it's changed a bit, but I always wondered how
>> such a hard and angry sound could have been so popular here in the land
>> of love and flowers.
>
>I think the jungle thing has something to do with the popularity of
>trance. I don't think very much trance was actually produced in the Bay
>during the development of the SF d&b sound, but certainly there were tons
>of trance parties. in general trance was hugely popular, and a lot of
>people consequently hated it with a passion. (I'm embarassed to admit
>that I was one of those people.) probably the SF jungle sound came as a
>reaction to the uber-pretty sound of foo-foo trance, as I think, to a
>lesser extent, the popularity of hard techno might have done as well.

I don't know if trance is really to blame, but I /do/ distinctly remember
seeing my first-ever candy raver at a Harmony Freaky People party
(december, 1996) - I think the DnB thing was ascendent around that time as
well, so maybe that had something to do with it?

It's all just so much conjecture, though. I wouldn't want to perform an
autopsy until I knew for certain the patient was dead, so give the rave
scene another month or two here. :)

I do believe I agree with your original post, though, Giles. At least in
the sense that it seeks to provide an explanation for why SF is such an
oddball place. I suspect that part of the culprit is the *reputation* this
city has, from the Barbary Coast through the Beats and Hippies on down,
this city is known for being a crazy bohemian town. This reputation is
both advantageous (it draws crazy bohemians here) and harmful (it draws
GODDAMN crazy bohemians here), and I think that it contributes to a
general vibe of us being "on display" for the rest of the world. Or maybe
I only think so because I just returned from Ascension at 1015, a crazy
bohemian event put on for the benefit of the legal survival of SF's
nightlife.

(Go, there's still time: http://www.sflnc.com/index/events/special/29.html)

I spent part of the evening knocked sideways by the sheer force of
artistic expression contained in that club, and the other part of the
night frustrated that it was really just a big play-act, a mini-
burningman-clone intended to make an impression on the city supervisors,
mayoral candidates, and other representatives of the SF establishment in
attendance. In a sense, it's something I think about a lot, as a member of
the SFLNC on one hand, and generally disenchanted raver who wonders
whether there's anything left to protect, preserve, or promote anymore on
the other.

Shit was real good here in SF when people throwing parties didn't give a
rat's ass what the government, or the media, or their parents, or the
neighbors thought about what we up to when we inexplicably took off for
entire nights or weekends, returning early sunday morning with a slightly
dazed grin and a hearing problem.

Perhaps the east bay looniez throwing tomorrow's Masquerade Di Valentino
will salvage things - I'm definitely going to give them a chance. :)

---------------------------------------------------------------------
michal migurski- contact info and pgp key:
                 http://www.saturn5.com/mike/contact.html

                "Freedom! Horrible, horrible freedom!"

> Please copy and circulate widely:
