> IF WAR BEGINS
> 7:00 AM
> MORNING OF THE NEXT BUSINESS DAY AFTER WAR BEGINS
> MEET: Market and Main, Embarcadero BART, San Francisco
> 
> EMERGENCY MASS NONVIOLENT DIRECT ACTION & PROTEST
> 
> TRANSFORM OUR CITY
> From Profit And War To Life And Resistance
> Shut Down The Corporate Warmakers!
> 
> 
> o Dont go to work or school
> 
> o HEAD DOWNTOWN: Bring friends, music, art,
> performance, and food to share
> o Join/create an ongoing transformation/occupation  
> o Prepare Now: Form an affinity (action) group
> 
> Direct Action to Stop the War
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/No-War-in-Iraq/
> (415) 820-9649
> 
> OUR GOALS 
> 1)  If the government and corporations won?t stop the
> war, we?ll shut down the warmakers! We will impose
> real economic, social and political costs and stop
> business as usual until the war stops.
> 
> 2)  Assert our power to transform our city from
> profits, oil and war to resistance and life! We will
> create an open, welcoming, inspiring space that gives
> voice to the anti-war majority as an assertion of real
> democracy.
> 
> 3)  Uproot the system behind the war (and behind the
> war at home racism, poverty); help catalyze mass
> movements to challenge corporate and government power
> and create socially just, directly democratic,
> ecological, peaceful alternatives.
> 
> 
> WHAT YOU CAN DO
> 
> If the war starts, dont go to work or school and head
> downtown. Call in sick, walk out, dont go (and get
> your co-workers/ schoolmates to join you).
> 
> Form an affinity or action group to get prepared. Get
> a group of five to 25 of your friends, family,
> neighbors, co-workers, or schoolmates to prepare for
> and participate in the emergency morning-after action.
> Make a plan of how you will get together, get downtown
> and what you will do if war starts. Send one or two
> people from your group to the weekly action
> "spokescouncil" to coordinate with other groups.
> Participate in a nonviolent direct action training to
> get prepared. Several affinity groups can join
> together as a "cluster." 
> 
> Bring friends, music, art, performance, and food to
> share to help transform our city. Help sustain the
> transformation/occupation as long as possiblewe will
> keep it going. 
> 
> 
> ACTION MENU
> 
> We are asking affinity (action) groups choose from the
> menu and take over and transform the following key
> intersections and corporate and government
> offices/buildings. Or join the "Take Out" mobile Bikes
> not Bombs actions. Or plan your own action and menu
> item. Attend the weekly spokescouncil meeting to
> coordinate and help organize. The business day the
> morning after war starts you may wish to just go
> directly to a "menu" location or else to Main and
> Market where people will go out to support the
> actions. 
> There are many ways to reclaim, transform, occupy or
> blockade spaces. Sit-ins, street parties, lockdown,
> objects, performance, street murals, gardening, large
> sculpture, die-insS<caron> PLAN AHEAD. Invite everyone
> you know. We will have fliers and encourage everyone
> to make an effort to talk to, diffuse or get support
> from those who get stuck on their way to work, school
> or other business.
>

> Bicycling: A QUIET STATEMENT AGAINST OIL WARS. 
> Join the mobile Bikes not Bombs. Bring your bike (or
> rollerblades, or skateboard or any human-powered
> wheels) with signs, flags, and decorations to Main and
> Market at 7am (or whenever you can make it) and
> support all the stationary action, fill the streets
> with bicycles, get the word outS<caron>. Your affinity
> group can be its own moving anti-war bike ride. 
> 
> 
> Direct Action to Stop the War
> 
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/No-War-in-Iraq/
> (415) 820-9649
> 
>

> Do you Yahoo!?

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

A Global Antiwar Movement

By Ruth Rosen, AlterNet
February 13, 2003

Many of us will never forget when the people of the world welcomed the dawn=
=20
of the new millennium. As the Earth turned, we watched televised pictures=20
of people celebrating and cheering as the sky lit up with fireworks =AD from=
=20
Asia to Europe, from Africa to North America. And, for the first time in=20
human history, we understood, in a deeply visceral way, that we really do=20
inhabit the same planet and that we are, in fact, members of a global=
 society.

That is what's going to happen again on Saturday and Sunday. In 316 cities=
=20
in 60 countries =AD Cairo, Bangkok, Beirut, Jakarta, Prague, Budapest,=
 Tokyo,=20
Moscow, London, Cape Town, Kigali in Rwanda, Madrid, Warsaw, Kiev, Lisbon,=
=20
Mexico City, San Francisco.

Sao Paulo, New York, Sydney, Barcelona, to name but a few =AD more than a=20
million people are expected to march and rally against an American invasion=
=20
of Iraq. Even McMurdo Station in Antarctica will hold a protest against the=
=20
war. Such a global outpouring against the threat of war is unprecedented.

Without the Internet, of course, such a global protest would be=20
unimaginable. But the Internet is only the messenger. Clearly, there is=20
strong opposition here and abroad to an American invasion of Iraq.

What's truly surprising are the concise slogans posted on the Web sites of=
=20
the coalitions that have helped organize this protest. No America bashing.=
=20
No defense of Saddam Hussein. No solidarity with al Qaeda terrorists. In=20
dozens of languages, the message is simple and direct: "No war in Iraq."=20
"Stop the war in Iraq."

People around the world now feel a right to express their opposition to war.

They clearly believe Hussein is a ruthless dictator. But they also=20
understand that the greatest threat is terrorist attacks from elusive=20
networks that cannot be stopped by American bombs or U.N. weapons=20
inspections. The Bush administration, of course, will try to discredit this=
=20
global uprising against an American war with Iraq. But it won't be so easy.=
=20
The coalitions assembled in these cities include business, labor and=20
religious groups; veterans of former wars, environmentalists, human rights=
=20
activists and mothers against war; and thousands of ordinary people who are=
=20
asking the U.N. Security Council to pursue further weapons inspections in=20
Iraq, not war.

Expect a tiny band of adolescent anarchists, who would rather spray=20
graffiti and smash windows than join others in a peaceful march. We should=
=20
condemn such antics. There is nothing less persuasive than using violence=20
in the name of preventing war.

Why, you may ask, should you participate in this demonstration? Because you=
=20
are a citizen of a great nation that is violating its own democratic=20
ideals, treating the rest of the world with dismissive contempt and=20
refusing to be restrained by international law. Because you are a citizen=20
of a new global society. Globalization is about more than free trade. What=
=20
we are witnessing is the birth of a grassroots global democracy. To=20
emphasize our membership in this new global society, many protesters around=
=20
the world will be carrying the U.N. flag, a fitting symbol for a new era.

When people ask, as they eventually will, who stood up for human rights,=20
let your name be among those who opposed an unjust and unnecessary war.

For information on anti-war protests in San Francisco and around the world,=
=20
see www.unitedforpeace.org.




Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one=20
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But=20
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken
--=====================_2576727==_.ALT--

FYI!!! Next they will be closing down clubs in SF!



>From: Syd Gris <sydg@earthlink.net>
>To: <save@ourdancescene.com>
>Subject: Wake Up Call to the Scene
>Date: Wed, 12 Feb 2003 12:55:18 -0800
>
>I'm sending out this e mail to my friends and concerned people in the dance
>music scene, in the hopes of getting people's help spreading the word about
>what's going on.
>
>What's going on is the dance music scene is slowly but surely under attack.
>It is under attack by those that see no distinction between the people who
>do illegal drugs (which exist in every music, art, and cultural scene) and
>the dance music scene itself.  The last couple of years has seen the 
>closure
>of many great clubs such as Twilo in NYC and Buzz in DC.  Just this past
>weekend the NY Police shut down two major clubs there, Exit and Sound
>Factory because of drug use they saw and buys they were involved in.
>
>On the same weekend here in SF, undercover police were at 1015 Folsom, DNA
>Lounge, and other commercial venues, as well as even underground parties
>they would have had to go through some trouble to locate.  In every party
>it's the same.  Normal looking party go-er asks people in the party if they
>can buy any illegal drugs, usually ecstasy.  In some cases, naive person 
>may
>try and help this person out, only to be busted later.  It's happening 
>every
>weekend.  They may not make a bust every time, but they are gathering data
>and contacts to make bigger arrests later and make a case to shut down our
>favorite spots to go dancing and hear music.
>
>We all know we can't stop people from making individual decisions about 
>what
>they choose to do.  But we can spread the word amongst our friends that 
>this
>is happening, and we need to be aware of it.
>
>If someone in a club or party asks you if you know where to get illegal
>drugs, do us all a favor.  Tell them YES, wait right here, and then go
>inform security so they can be thrown out of the party immediately.  You 
>may
>ruin someone's night just trying to have fun, but obviously that's well
>worth protecting our scene.
>
>Make no mistake, the police are trying to shut down venues where electronic
>dance music is played.  They are doing this because of the actions of a
>minority of the people that come to the parties, and it's jeopardizing all
>of us.  We in the scene know it is a positive movement, bringing people 
>from
>many different walks of life together to connect and share.  We must not
>just assume everything is going to be OK, it will not be unless we make it
>so.
>
>Please spread the word, and help save the scene.
>
>Thanks,
>
>Syd Gris
>
>
>
>P.S. If you're interested, here's what Danny Tenaglia had to say about what
>happened in NYC this weekend, I couldn't agree more,
>
>
>                           Danny Tenaglia on DTOURISIM
>                              DEAR FRIENDS OF THE NIGHTLIFE,
>
>                           I AM WRITING THIS POST HERE ON THIS SUNDAY
>AFTERNOON TO MAKE AN IMPORTANT
>                           STATEMENT ABOUT TWO SEPARATE ISSSUES. FORGIVE ME
>FOR WRITING IN ALL CAPS,
>                           BUT (A) IT'S JUST EASIER AND (B), IT'S WRITTEN 
>IN
>BOLD FOR A REASON.
>
>                           ISSUE # 1.
>                           WHETHER YOU BELIEVE ME OR NOT, I PERSONALLY WAS
>VERY SADDENED TO HEAR
>                           ABOUT THE SHUT DOWNS OF THE SF & EXIT. I TRULY 
>DO
>HOPE THIS SITUATION ONLY
>                           LAST THIS ONE WEEKEND AND THEY WILL WORK IT OUT
>WITH THEIR LAWYERS AS THEY
>                           USUALLY DO, AND BOTH WILL BE RE-OPENED NEXT 
>WEEK.
>I DON'T KNOW ALL THE
>                           FACTS EXCEPT FOR WHAT I RECEIVED IN ONE E-MAIL
>THAT SOMEONE
>                           FORWARDED TO ME FROM THE NEWS.
>
>                           ANYHOW, I FEEL AND MADE THIS ANNOUNCEMENT AT MY
>PARTY THIS PAST FRIDAY AT
>                           VINYL. I SAID SOMETHING ALONG THE LINES OF: 
>"IT'S
>SAD ENOUGH WHAT WE ARE
>                           LIVING THROUGH WITH THE CRISIS THAT OUR PLANET 
>IS
>IN WITH TERRORISM AND THE
>                           THREAT OF WAR, AND THAT THIS WEEK OUR COUNTRY 
>WAS
>WARNED TO BE ON "HIGH
>                           ALERT." I MADE IT VERY CLEAR THAT I WAS NOT 
>HAPPY
>TO HEAR THE NEWS ABOUT SF &
>                           EXIT AND WARNED THE PEOPLE IN ATTENDANCE THAT 
>OUR
>NYC NIGHTLIFE APPEARS TO
>                           BE IN SEVERE "HIGH" ALERT!
>
>                           I BEGGED EVERYONE TO PLEASE STOP MISBEHAVING AND
>POSSIBLY RUINING SUCH A
>                           GREAT THING WE HAVE IN THIS CITY BY SADLY 
>ABUSING
>DRUGS, WHETHER AT HOME OR
>                           ESPECIALLY IN PUBLIC AND PUTTING ALL OF US AT 
>RISK
>OF LOSING WHAT WE LOVE
>                           THE MOST, THE MUSIC & DANCING, AND TO US CLUB
>EMPLOYEES, "OUR LIVELIHOODS!"
>                           NYC NEEDS THESE CLUBS TO BE RE-OPENED BECAUSE OF
>OVER POPULATION.
>                           EVERYONE KNOWS THAT THE SF ALREADY DOES GREAT IN
>THEIR ATTENDANCE,
>                           ESPECIALLY ON SATURDAY'S AND EVEN AS BIG AS EXIT
>IS, I HEAR THEY ALSO DO VERY
>                           WELL EVERY WEEK CONSIDERING HOW MASSIVE THE 
>VENUE
>IS. IT'S SAD ENOUGH THAT
>                           THERE IS NO MORE TWILO OR TUNNEL, AND I HEAR 
>EVEN
>LIMELIGHT AND CENTRO FLY
>                           HAVE BEEN AFFECTED IN NUMBERS OF ATTENDANCE
>LATELY. PS: SO HAVE WE...
>                           AFTER THE HOLIDAY'S, IT APPEARS THAT ALL CLUBS 
>AND
>BUSINESS'S TAKE A DIP AND
>                           PRAY THAT THINGS WILL QUICKLY INCREASE AGAIN.
>(WHICH THEY APPEAR TO BE,
>                           THANK GOD.)
>
>                           MY MAIN POINT HERE IS THAT WE NEED THESE CLUBS
>OPENED OR ELSE EVERYONE
>                           WILL TRY TO JAM INTO ANY NIGHTCLUB THAT IS 
>OPENED
>AND THEN THAT VENUE WILL
>                           OBVIOUSLY BE THE NEXT TARGET, AND THE MORE 
>PEOPLE
>IN ATTENDANCE, THE MORE
>                           LIKELY THERE ARE TO BE THOSE FEW ASSHOLES WHO 
>WILL
>RUIN IT FOR 1000'S OF US.
>                           SO, I "DANNY TENAGLIA" WHO AM NOT SHY AND HAVE 
>NO
>PROBLEM GETTING ON THE
>                           MICROPHONE AND TELLING THE PEOPLE EXACTLY HOW I
>FEEL! I WILL SAY IT AT MY
>                           PARTIES, I WILL WRITE IT ON MESSAGE BOARDS LIKE
>THIS ONE HERE, ETC. ALTHOUGH I
>                           KNOW ALL CLUBS DO SEARCHES, IT'S IMPOSSIBLE TO
>CHECK PEOPLES PRIVATE AREA'S
>                           WHERE THEY HIDE THE NONSENSE. SO, I, AM EVERYONE
>HERE JUST LIKE I DID AT MY
>                           PARTY TO PLEASE HELP US SAVE THE PARTIES BY
>IMMEDIATELY AND ANONYMOUSLY GET
>                           THE ATTENTION OF A SECURITY GUARD OR CLUB 
>MANAGER
>AND POINT OUT THE PERSON
>                           YOU JUST WITNESSED SELLING OR BLATANTLY DOING
>SOMETHING ILLEGAL LIKE
>                           POPPING A PILL OR SNORTING POWDERS, OR DOING THE
>WORST OF ALL "GHB." YOU
>                           ARE NOT BEING A RAT BY DOING THIS, YOU ARE 
>SAVING
>OUR PARTIES AND OUR JOBS!
>
>                           I KNOW THAT SOME OF YOU READING THIS MIGHT EVEN 
>BE
>SOME PEOPLE WHO ENJOY
>                           RECREATIONAL PARTYING EVERY NOW & THEN, SO I 
>GUESS
>I AM BEGGING YOU MORE
>                           THAN ANYONE TO PLEASE REALIZE THE THREAT WE ARE 
>IN
>RIGHT NOW IN 2003 HERE IN
>                           NYC CLUBLAND! PLEASE HELP SAVE OUR NIGHTLIFE.
>
>                           JUST THINK HOW MISERABLE WE WOULD ALL BE IF THIS
>CITY WAS LIKE BOSTON AND
>                           PHILLY WHERE ALL THE NIGHTCLUBS HAD TO BE CLOSED
>BY 2AM!!!?? HOW HORRIFIC
>                           WOULD THIS BE? NO ONE WOULD EVEN BOTHER GOING 
>OUT
>AT ALL. SO ONCE AGAIN, I
>                           BEG YOU ALL TO TAKE PART IN BEING A PART OF THE
>SOLUTION AND CONTINUE TO
>                           POST SUGGESTIONS THAT MIGHT HELP US CLUB 
>EMPLOYEES
>AND MANAGEMENT KEEP
>                           THOSE UNDESIRABLE AND EVIL PEOPLE WHO JUST MIGHT
>RUIN IT FOR "ALL OF US" OUT
>                           OF "OUR" PARTIES.

	"Ryan Tandy" <ryan@liquidmercury.com>
References: <5.1.0.14.2.20030212165514.02578370@mail.speakeasy.org><p04330100ba70a4f7eda2@[172.16.2.25]> <00f001c2d3d2$cab8d960$f665020a@direcway.com> <Pine.GSO.4.52.0302132242320.3060@atari>

	charset="iso-8859-1"

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski

> >> What do you all make of the SF DnB scene as it existed a few years
> >> back? SF DnB was some of the hardest around. I'm not into that scene
> >> any more and no doubt it's changed a bit, but I always wondered how
> >> such a hard and angry sound could have been so popular here in the land
> >> of love and flowers.
> >
> >I think the jungle thing has something to do with the popularity of
> >trance. I don't think very much trance was actually produced in the Bay
> >during the development of the SF d&b sound, but certainly there were tons
> >of trance parties. in general trance was hugely popular, and a lot of
> >people consequently hated it with a passion. (I'm embarassed to admit
> >that I was one of those people.) probably the SF jungle sound came as a
> >reaction to the uber-pretty sound of foo-foo trance, as I think, to a
> >lesser extent, the popularity of hard techno might have done as well.
>
> I don't know if trance is really to blame, but I /do/ distinctly remember
> seeing my first-ever candy raver at a Harmony Freaky People party
> (december, 1996) - I think the DnB thing was ascendent around that time as
> well, so maybe that had something to do with it?
>
> It's all just so much conjecture, though. I wouldn't want to perform an
> autopsy until I knew for certain the patient was dead, so give the rave
> scene another month or two here. :)

ah, migurski, you misunderstand me too!

assume the seasons of "uber-scene"-hood vary on a roughly 7-year schedule
(as the mysterious anonymous wise man said in his post). I believe the
throne of San Francisco landed on the head of the rave scene in 1995, and
fell off in 2002.

but there was a rave scene in 1994 in San Francisco, and there is still one
now in 2003.

to quote an old Koma & Bones record, "underground will live forever baby,
never dying, always moving."

> I do believe I agree with your original post, though, Giles. At least in
> the sense that it seeks to provide an explanation for why SF is such an
> oddball place. I suspect that part of the culprit is the *reputation* this
> city has, from the Barbary Coast through the Beats and Hippies on down,
> this city is known for being a crazy bohemian town. This reputation is
> both advantageous (it draws crazy bohemians here) and harmful (it draws
> GODDAMN crazy bohemians here), and I think that it contributes to a
> general vibe of us being "on display" for the rest of the world. Or maybe
> I only think so because I just returned from Ascension at 1015, a crazy
> bohemian event put on for the benefit of the legal survival of SF's
> nightlife.
>
> (Go, there's still time:
http://www.sflnc.com/index/events/special/29.html)
>
> I spent part of the evening knocked sideways by the sheer force of
> artistic expression contained in that club, and the other part of the
> night frustrated that it was really just a big play-act, a mini-
> burningman-clone intended to make an impression on the city supervisors,
> mayoral candidates, and other representatives of the SF establishment in
> attendance. In a sense, it's something I think about a lot, as a member of
> the SFLNC on one hand, and generally disenchanted raver who wonders
> whether there's anything left to protect, preserve, or promote anymore on
> the other.

jaded.

has anyone else noticed the paradox that futuristic music lends itself so
easily to nostalgia?

> Shit was real good here in SF when people throwing parties didn't give a
> rat's ass what the government, or the media, or their parents, or the
> neighbors thought about what we up to when we inexplicably took off for
> entire nights or weekends, returning early sunday morning with a slightly
> dazed grin and a hearing problem.

yes. it was an urban nomad thing.

but this is another paradox, really. if the throne has passed on to some
other scene, this means that things for the rave scene in general in the bay
area are in fact looking up. media attention and city legal bullshit could
diminish. I personally believe the schism between undergrounds and massives
will become less significant and may even disappear completely.

I'm not saying raving in SF is doomed, therefore there's no point ever
coming back. I hope to come back, I hope to visit real soon. all I'm saying
is that the potential that was once there has diminshed considerably.

I think at one time the rave scene in SF was the single most remarkable and
exciting thing happening in the entire country. I'm just saying that this
may no longer be the case. so for me personally, it seems the only thing
left to do is make some nostalgic future music -- and that will be easier in
a less expensive place with more favorable astrological energies.

> Perhaps the east bay looniez throwing tomorrow's Masquerade Di Valentino
> will salvage things - I'm definitely going to give them a chance. :)

if any hope exists for the rave scene in san francisco, it rests in the
hands of the east bay loonies.

i have great faith in them -- altho I fear for their goat.

dude.

i should write dialogue for "star wars."


Giles

off with your significant others, going to dinner, and etc.,
but everybody else will be out and looking extra careful for
that once-a-year, extra-jiggy, mack-down that is all the
more likely with everybody getting blizted for that very reason!

2) I'm very excited have Domingo Yu as my guest DJ.
Domingo has DJed in Detroit for years and has traveled the world
representing its sounds and musical sensibilties.  Hinting
at a varied mix of "everything from  50 Cent to Shalamar
to Buju Banton to DJ Rolando" Domingo is for sure gonna REPRESENT!!!

3) This is the last Ghett $et to be held on Friday.
Starting next week, we're moving to Thursday, and I will be firing
up the mix right at 6 to get that straight from work energy.

TONIGHT We'll be going full on from 6-10.
Prepare for some extra juicy in ya boogie cuz its gonna be like that.  and by the way, its totally free!
Thats at Skylark, 3089 16th St. in the Mission, SF.

PEACE, Rob AKA DJ Baby Daddy

Subject: Re: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski

>> In a sense, it's something I think about a lot, as a member of the
>> SFLNC on one hand, and generally disenchanted raver who wonders whether
>> there's anything left to protect, preserve, or promote anymore on the
>> other.
>
>jaded.

I have a hat. :) But terry borrowed it so he could dress like Gilligan two
halloween's ago - terry?


>has anyone else noticed the paradox that futuristic music lends itself so
>easily to nostalgia?

Not at all, given that the futuristic music we listen to has always been
created on yesterday's castoff machines: failed bass synthesizers
re-tooled to make squireelly gibbon noises, big clunky drum machines you
can take apart and tune with a screwdriver, and VINYL ferchrissakes. For
all its explicit future talk (which really amounts to UFO soundbites),
techno is some of the most explicitly backwards-looking music out there
right now. Not that I'm not totally in love with it or anything, but the
bulk of futuristic technology put into the service of musicmaking out
there is being used to warble Cher's voice and keep the Backstreet Boys in
tune.

Subject: [sfraves] (bsp) Tonight in Monterey /// Special Valentine's Event at the Secret Garden





Happy Valentine's Day,

Just wanted to let you know that tonight
we have scheduled a Special Valentine's Event.
Starting up at 9:00 pm

////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

Valentine's Day - Secret Garden - Friday Feb 14th - Monterey

DJ: Maneesh the Twister ( Dubmission, Dhamaal, Stir-fry-day SF)
maneesh the twister will be spinning a wide array of genres of
electronic (2step,brokenbeat,breakbeat,house,dub,downtempo) as well
as, traditional Indian music. Accompanying Maneesh on tabla -

On Tabla: Ferhan Najeeb Qureshi ( Dhamaal SF )has been a student of tablaand 
traditional Pakistani/Indian music for the last 7 years. He began studying 
with Shri Surrinder Mann, and now continues his studies as a disciple of 
Ustad Tari Khan, concentrating on the Punjab gharana
(school or style) of classical tabla. His focus is primarily on
classical/traditional music, but he has become involved with various
other projects recently. Such as fusing his traditional
drumming with electronic musicans and djs.

Projections: Daniel V (Cloudfactory SC) rolling down from Santa Cruz
to add to the evening with various forms of visual stimuli.
Definitely bringing a great flavor to this event, both visually and
personally. Bring on the laughs!

Henna artist: Mehndi Mama Rica heading down from Santa Cruz and will
be providing henna art tattoos for us. Her work/designs are quite
impressive and very beautiful.She will be applying her art on the
premises on a first come first serve basis.

Secret Garden Residents: Scientists of Sound DJs Kiyoshi One, Sunshine and 
Kelau will be opening and closing things out for this night of
LOVE, MUSIC ,and ART. Bringing forth various ethnic and electronic sounds to 
groove and chill to.


If you are interested in making this you dinner date destination.
Please come earlier for the Buffet Dinner, which will run til
9:00 pm. If not for the food, still come out from the music and
festivities which starts up at around 9:00ish. Date or no Date
it is all good; come by and enjoy the tunes and the hookahs...

Admission FREE
Check the info below or email us with any questions

peace...

//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

s e c r e t _ g a r d e n

happening at:
Indian Summer Restaurant & Hookah Bar
220 Olivier Street
Monterey, CA 93940
(behind the Double Tree Hotel, Next to Peter B's Pub)

*Note: this is NOT at the India's Clay Oven*

phone: 831-372-4744
time: 9:00pm - 1:00am
admission: F R E E.


* for directions please use link below:
map: http://maps.yahoo.com/

** or contact us at:
email: secret_garden@scientist.com
website: http://www.indiansummerca.com





peace...
scientists of sound

I agree with this basic idea, but I am not sure it would work.  It would be great to get any undercover cops kicked out of clubs, but how do you know if they are cops or not?  I would never personally buy or sell drugs inside a club/party to strangers.  And I don't think anyone else should either (if you really need them, just buy them before hand).  I just have a hard time being a "snitch".   Unless that person was being a real ass-hole...or I KNEW it was a cop - of course if I knew I would then leave the party very discreetly...

Subject: Fwd: Wake Up Call to the Scene 

Date: Wed, 12 Feb 2003 13:06:08 -0800 

 

FYI!!! Next they will be closing down clubs in SF!

 

>From: Syd Gris <sydg@earthlink.net>

>To: <save@ourdancescene.com>

>Subject: Wake Up Call to the Scene

>Date: Wed, 12 Feb 2003 12:55:18 -0800

>

>I'm sending out this e mail to my friends and concerned people in the 

dance

>music scene, in the hopes of getting people's help spreading the word 

about

>what's going on.

>

>What's going on is the dance music scene is slowly but surely under 

attack.

>It is under attack by those that see no distinction between the people 

who

>do illegal drugs (which exist in every music, art, and cultural scene) 

and

>the dance music scene itself.  The last couple of years has seen the 

>closure

>of many great clubs such as Twilo in NYC and Buzz in DC.  Just this 

past

>weekend the NY Police shut down two major clubs there, Exit and Sound

>Factory because of drug use they saw and buys they were involved in.

>

>On the same weekend here in SF, undercover police were at 1015 Folsom, 

DNA

>Lounge, and other commercial venues, as well as even underground 

parties

>they would have had to go through some trouble to locate.  In every 

party

>it's the same.  Normal looking party go-er asks people in the party if 

they

>can buy any illegal drugs, usually ecstasy.  In some cases, naive 

person 

>may

>try and help this person out, only to be busted later.  It's happening 

>every

>weekend.  They may not make a bust every time, but they are gathering 

data

>and contacts to make bigger arrests later and make a case to shut down 

our

>favorite spots to go dancing and hear music.

>

>We all know we can't stop people from making individual decisions 

about 

>what

>they choose to do.  But we can spread the word amongst our friends 

that 

>this

>is happening, and we need to be aware of it.

>

>If someone in a club or party asks you if you know where to get 

illegal

>drugs, do us all a favor.  Tell them YES, wait right here, and then go

>inform security so they can be thrown out of the party immediately.  

You 

>may

>ruin someone's night just trying to have fun, but obviously that's 

well

>worth protecting our scene.

>

>Make no mistake, the police are trying to shut down venues where 

electronic

>dance music is played.  They are doing this because of the actions of 

a

>minority of the people that come to the parties, and it's jeopardizing 

all

>of us.  We in the scene know it is a positive movement, bringing 

people 

>from

>many different walks of life together to connect and share.  We must 

not

>just assume everything is going to be OK, it will not be unless we 

make it

>so.

>

>Please spread the word, and help save the scene.

>

>Thanks,

>

>Syd Gris

>

>

Subject: [sfraves] RAVERS FOR PEACE

--=====================_12935197==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


This may be our last chance to demonstrate to the world and the Bush 
administration our opposition  to this immoral war, so let's make sure we 
get our bodies on the line this Sunday -- rain or shine:)

Sfravers have formed a group to represent in the march and rally:  Ravers 
for Peace.  We have prepared a large banner (DJ Disconnect designed the 
lettering), with your brothers and sisters working on painting this banner 
and signs for many hours.  We have also obtained some art through Jeff 
Storey  for "Drop Beats, Not Bombs" signs and Philip Diaz and some sfravers 
will be screening these tonight.

We hope those of you on this list who share our beliefs will join us on 
Sunday to march in solidarity.

MEETING TIME/PLACE ON SUNDAY

The rally and march begin around 11:00 AM at Justin Herman Plaza at the end 
of Market Street.  We should plan to gather there around 10:30 on at the 
fountain on the left hand side of the Plaza as you enter from Market Street 
(that's where the skateboard kids often do their thing.)  Look for the 
Ravers For Peace banner and signs.   Also, since we cannot have a truck 
with sound, bring drums, musical instruments, hell, boom boxes if you can 
carry them so we can march to some rhythm.

Be sure to leave early.  Last time public transportation was overwhelmed by 
the large number of marchers, and this promises to be an even larger event.

Looking forward to seeing you all Sunday!!!!

Much love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."

becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

Subject: Re: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski

--=====================_14817687==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 11:03 PM 2/13/2003 -0800, Mike Migurski wrote:


>I spent part of the evening knocked sideways by the sheer force of
>artistic expression contained in that club, and the other part of the
>night frustrated that it was really just a big play-act, a mini-
>burningman-clone intended to make an impression on the city supervisors,
>mayoral candidates, and other representatives of the SF establishment in
>attendance. In a sense, it's something I think about a lot, as a member of
>the SFLNC on one hand, and generally disenchanted raver who wonders
>whether there's anything left to protect, preserve, or promote anymore on
>the other.
>
>Shit was real good here in SF when people throwing parties didn't give a
>rat's ass what the government, or the media, or their parents, or the
>neighbors thought about what we up to when we inexplicably took off for
>entire nights or weekends, returning early sunday morning with a slightly
>dazed grin and a hearing problem.

That was when we were a counterculture:)  In the early nineties "raving" 
was defined by uncomfortable "agitator" types who were really interested in 
creating some mind-opening, transformative experiences.  Many of those 
folks thought raving was over before 1995 -- the Wicked FMRs were over by 
then, as were many of the uninhibited parties, both underground and in clubs.

I think, as someone suggested on this topic, that the late nineties were 
just too fuckin' comfortable around here.  People believing they could make 
a million before thirty;  entrepreneurs entering the underground and 
bringing it mainstream -- just not enough energizing discontent, I think.

Now we are back to "balls to the wall" days.  As the Chinese say, we have 
been cursed with need to live in interesting times once again.

I have said before that there are parallels between the gay subculture and 
the rave counterculture.  Both experienced co option in the late 
nineties.  For gays, materialism replaced creativity;  the desire for 
integration overwhelmed the need to build a unique culture;  corporate 
types replaced activists, and the gay pride parade became one big beer 
commercial, IMHO.  Prada shoes, pec implants, commodification of 
desire:  horrible.

Now there is a group called Gay Shame.  They are very similar to the people 
I knew in Queer Nation and Act Up in the early nineties.  At a black tie 
affair recently for the new Community center, attended by the politically 
powerful and Range Rover queens, these queers crashed the party and were 
arrested.  Ah...fresh, sweaty, agitators back.

Fine.  I'm with them.  I'm personally tired of attempting to appear 
"responsible" to people I don't respect, who hate me -- and who would put 
me in jail no matter how conventional I try to appear.

Same with raves.  Perhaps it's time for a "Ravers Shame" group.  A healthy 
society needs a dialectic:  a counterculture.  We were and can be that 
counterpoint.

Love,

Apollo


>Perhaps the east bay looniez throwing tomorrow's Masquerade Di Valentino
>will salvage things - I'm definitely going to give them a chance. :)
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>michal migurski- contact info and pgp key:
>                  http://www.saturn5.com/mike/contact.html
>
>                 "Freedom! Horrible, horrible freedom!"
>
>
>
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Moksha Tribe

> I have a hat. :) But terry borrowed it so he could dress like Gilligan two

Gilligan...Terry how could you?

don't talk to me about Gilligan...

ever since I was in kindergarten I have been plagued with Gilligan
associations...

> >has anyone else noticed the paradox that futuristic music lends itself so
> >easily to nostalgia?
>
> Not at all, given that the futuristic music we listen to has always been
> created on yesterday's castoff machines: failed bass synthesizers
> re-tooled to make squireelly gibbon noises, big clunky drum machines you
> can take apart and tune with a screwdriver, and VINYL ferchrissakes. For
> all its explicit future talk (which really amounts to UFO soundbites),
> techno is some of the most explicitly backwards-looking music out there
> right now. Not that I'm not totally in love with it or anything, but the
> bulk of futuristic technology put into the service of musicmaking out
> there is being used to warble Cher's voice and keep the Backstreet Boys in
> tune.

au contraire mon frere...the most sophisticated technology used in the
service of musicmaking is, of course, a borderline criminal technology which
operates for the betterment of mankind...

it's called Gnutella...

as for the trend to using antiquated machinery...when the 303 acid line was
invented it was a bold repurposing of technology...similar to the techniques
developed in mid-90s jungle, reinventing the sampler as a complete studio in
a box...still, you've definitely got a point...


Giles

Subject: Re: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski

> Now there is a group called Gay Shame.  They are very similar to the
people
> I knew in Queer Nation and Act Up in the early nineties.  At a black tie
> affair recently for the new Community center, attended by the politically
> powerful and Range Rover queens, these queers crashed the party and were
> arrested.  Ah...fresh, sweaty, agitators back.
>
> Fine.  I'm with them.  I'm personally tired of attempting to appear
> "responsible" to people I don't respect, who hate me -- and who would put
> me in jail no matter how conventional I try to appear.
>
> Same with raves.  Perhaps it's time for a "Ravers Shame" group.  A healthy
> society needs a dialectic:  a counterculture.  We were and can be that
> counterpoint.

well...again this is not a community I'm really qualified to speak on at any
great length...but I can certainly see the humor, and maybe even the wisdom,
of a group called Gay Shame...certainly there is something almost wickedly
clever there...

anyway...

raving does have a countercultural component...that is undeniable...some of
the most brilliant moments of rave music are the moments of ostranenie...a
Russian word meaning the process by which a true artist can make you see how
strange some of the things we accept as normal truly are...sampling even the
announcements on the subway...so that you find yourself underground on a
train and thinking, this is good...but I prefer the remix...social fictions
collapse...you glimpse the truth of your life...and in that moment you
realize what you want to do...there is tremendous power there...

and if raving seems mainstream in San Francisco...with all the boredom and
lameness that implies...just remember that everywhere else in the
country...it is so inimical to the powers that be that they have actually
attempted to pass laws against not only the gatherings but the music
itself...


Giles

mindblowing....I haven't danced like that in a loooong time.  I was sad that

Dan-0

From: Stacy Moss <stacymoss78@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-756138160-1045266784=:21182"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] not really your fault, migurski

--0-756138160-1045266784=:21182
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


 I think it's interesting that nobodys ever really touched on some of the fundamental reasons this scene has demised. 

 Apollo touches on it in his response, but i think there is another point that needs to be made and i'm sure i'll probably catch some enemies here, but so be it.

 back in the 80's and 90's it was trendy to be in a band, everybody was in a band and had a brother in a band, etc. then hip hop came to surface and everybody became a rapper.

 if your band sucked or your rapping skills were less then par YOU KNEW BETTER not to even try to entertain people. You most certainly could NOT get a gig and people would probably boo your ass off in a heart beat if they thought you were wack!

 when you go to a hip hop show, if the performer is bootsy, they get boo'ed! very rude and loud sometimes.

 which is the exact opposite of the rave scene. Everybody is now a DJ now. I mean every tom dick and harry, boys and girls are all DJ's.

 however, only %25 of all you DJ's can actually mix records. The rest of you cant. Plain and simple. Yet, you take gigs, sometimes even asking to get paid.

 how the hell do you get paid to spin records when you cant even mix? i can name a slew of local bay area dj's, some who have even owned record stores. Simply cannot connect the beats.

which makes it confusing when someones train wrecking and the crowd is so high they dont care (ok so i'm sharing my experiance at hotel trance when thomas was playing), they just keep screaming and dancing.

 which brings me to my next point. Inflation and Economics. Local DJ's should NOT CHARGE local promoters to play, and if so it be extremly cheap or just for expenses ie; gas, food, party favors, etc.

 how the heck are you supposed to create a low ticket party when everyone wants to get paid hella money. it's ridiculous. 

  why should mars and mystre or tom and jason charge $5,6,7,8,9,1000 plus dollars to play at a local gig? and why would you pay for them that much to play anyways?

   when i starting raving days ago, we had real talent on a day to day bassis visiting SF and playing at almost every party. From Johnny Fiasco to Frankie Bones, we had real talent back then.

 now you have all these kiddies booking all these EXPENSIVE local dj's who arent even worth the money there getting paid instead of the likes of Derrick Carter, Juan Atkins, DJ Icey, Sandra Collins, Evil Eddie Richards, Mistress Barbara, and Doc Martin.

  promoters need to stop supporting the rise of local talent fees. Dont book these kats if there not going to play for free or reasonable prices. It doesnt make since. Most of these local DJ's are still learning and do not desrve to get paid much less play.

  i dont mean to sound harsh on local talent cause i know theres allot of it here in san francisco. I've seen Jim Hopkins, jeno, tony, and garth. These guys didnt just jump on the decks over night and they certainly didnt start charging $1000 from the start.

  i think the inflation in booking fees in conjunction that everybody is a dj has really created a shadow on this phenomenon overall and has definitly taken the luster off of something that i cherished for so long.

  now a days were lucky if we have a party at all every weekend and most of the parties are not even worth the $15 bucks there charging.

  i've been pushed into clubs in order to hear or see anything worth leaving my house. I'm sure most of us on this list dont really like clubs all that much because of the enviroment they create = meat markets.

  this seems to be the common flaw if you ask me. just go to your local record store and pick up a flyer.

just my .50 cents

the moss factor 

 

 

At 11:03 PM 2/13/2003 -0800, Mike Migurski wrote:


>I spent part of the evening knocked sideways by the sheer force of
>artistic expression contained in that club, and the other part of the
>night frustrated that it was really just a big play-act, a mini-
>burningman-clone intended to make an impression on the city 
supervisors,
>mayoral candidates, and other representatives of the SF establishment 
in
>attendance. In a sense, it's something I think about a lot, as a 
member of
>the SFLNC on one hand, and generally disenchanted raver who wonders
>whether there's anything left to protect, preserve, or promote anymore 
on
>the other.
>
>Shit was real good here in SF when people throwing parties didn't give 
a
>rat's ass what the government, or the media, or their parents, or the
>neighbors thought about what we up to when we inexplicably took off 
for
>entire nights or weekends, returning early sunday morning with a 
slightly
>dazed grin and a hearing problem.

That was when we were a counterculture:)  In the early nineties 
"raving" 
was defined by uncomfortable "agitator" types who were really 
interested in 
creating some mind-opening, transformative experiences.  Many of those 
folks thought raving was over before 1995 -- the Wicked FMRs were over 
by 
then, as were many of the uninhibited parties, both underground and in 
clubs.

I think, as someone suggested on this topic, that the late nineties 
were 
just too fuckin' comfortable around here.  People believing they could 
make 
a million before thirty;  entrepreneurs entering the underground and 
bringing it mainstream -- just not enough energizing discontent, I 
think.

Now we are back to "balls to the wall" days.  As the Chinese say, we 
have 
been cursed with need to live in interesting times once again.

I have said before that there are parallels between the gay subculture 
and 
the rave counterculture.  Both experienced co option in the late 
nineties.  For gays, materialism replaced creativity;  the desire for 
integration overwhelmed the need to build a unique culture;  corporate 
types replaced activists, and the gay pride parade became one big beer 
commercial, IMHO.  Prada shoes, pec implants, commodification of 
desire:  horrible.

Now there is a group called Gay Shame.  They are very similar to the 
people 
I knew in Queer Nation and Act Up in the early nineties.  At a black 
tie 
affair recently for the new Community center, attended by the 
politically 
powerful and Range Rover queens, these queers crashed the party and 
were 
arrested.  Ah...fresh, sweaty, agitators back.

Fine.  I'm with them.  I'm personally tired of attempting to appear 
"responsible" to people I don't respect, who hate me -- and who would 
put 
me in jail no matter how conventional I try to appear.

Same with raves.  Perhaps it's time for a "Ravers Shame" group.  A 
healthy 
society needs a dialectic:  a counterculture.  We were and can be that 
counterpoint.

Love,

Apollo


>Perhaps the east bay looniez throwing tomorrow's Masquerade Di 
Valentino
>will salvage things - I'm definitely going to give them a chance. :)

At 03:17 PM 2/14/2003 -0700, Giles Bowkett wrote:


>raving does have a countercultural component...that is undeniable...some of
>the most brilliant moments of rave music are the moments of ostranenie...a
>Russian word meaning the process by which a true artist can make you see how
>strange some of the things we accept as normal truly are...sampling even the
>announcements on the subway...so that you find yourself underground on a
>train and thinking, this is good...but I prefer the remix...social fictions
>collapse...you glimpse the truth of your life...and in that moment you
>realize what you want to do...there is tremendous power there...

Yes...well put, Giles.


>and if raving seems mainstream in San Francisco...with all the boredom and
>lameness that implies...just remember that everywhere else in the
>country...it is so inimical to the powers that be that they have actually
>attempted to pass laws against not only the gatherings but the music
>itself...


This is certainly true of gay communities in the heartland.  I have felt 
safe until recently in San Francisco.  But local authorities cannot stop 
the feds, even though I believe some of them would like to.

Unfortunately, the hobnailed jackboots of the DEA are pounding the floors 
of clubs and parties here with the intention of shutting us all 
down.  Further, they have ignored states' rights by overriding the peoples' 
medical marijuana legislation.   Conservatives, they call themselves.  Not 
by any definition I've ever heard.  These folks are fascists.

Love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one 
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

From: JBlaze112@aol.com
Message-ID: <1a1.10cc875b.2b7fb693@aol.com>
Date: Sat, 15 Feb 2003 10:28:19 EST
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: AOL 5.0 for Windows sub 103
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Dancing Styles as a Political Metaphor?

so i was thinking about how raves are litterally split up into "rooms" for 
different styles of music and dancing, and somehow it came to me that these 
styles of dance kind of mimick different types of political philosophies. 


House music and break beat dancers are kind of like Capitalists in a sense 
that they form elete circles where only the best, most aggressive dancers are 
given space to dance, in which they will either fail and embarress themselves 
or they will really impress their peers and recieve "props".


Techno and Trance music dancers are more like Socialists because they all 
have equal spaces to dance in, in any way they like to dance, and no one 
dancer is given credit for being "better" than any other dancer (even though 
realistically some people are obviously "better" than others in skill & 
rhythm.)

Junglist and hardcore music dancers are kind of like a metaphor of Anarchy to 
me because they don't stay in one place, there is some type of "props" given 
out to good dancers but in this case the definition of "good" is more like 
crazy or out of control and sometimes just plain pissed off (but with some 
sense of rhythm at the same time.)

So i'm not saying these discription fit each group to a tee! or that there is 
anything wrong with any one of these groups, but u get the picture? Having 
all three rooms in a party is just awsome and it shows that a highly evolved, 
eclectic, diverse group of people are behind the scenes making these events 
happen... Anyone agree with me here? - johnny bzzzz


"So upgrade your grey matter, cuz one day it may matter..." Deltron Zero

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Re: Dancing Styles as a Political Metaphor?

and remember in House and Break beat circles one must often face a competitor 
head to head or multiple competitors (kind of like Capitalism...)

in a Techno or Trance dance floor everyone is on your side and equal to you 
(ideally...but rarely achieved in full, which is the big problem with 
socialism)

on a jungle or hardcore dancefloor, limbs are flying about everywhere, the 
music and vibe can be overwhelming and almost "frenzied" and it's basically a 
free for all (Anarchy)

Christopher Robin is hitler

The Rabbit is Mussolini (The only one to take care of his own shit)
Tigger is China, always real happy, and not caring what that happiness =

is always falling down

That Hitler and Stalin (communism) were always afraid of

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: My sign slogan for the march:   "READ OUR LIPS!"

--part1_168.1ab8da93.2b801b25_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I just thought of that this morning ... I was thinking about how everyone has 
such great signs, and to just say "Listen to all of us!", that's what I want 
to get across.  And, um, also remembering how "Read My Lips", thrown back 
into the elder Mr. Bush's face, was one of the slogans that helped bring him 
down in 1992. 

a quick side note: if you want to see a great movie (an Academy Award winner) 
with a lot of relevance to totay's world, check out "Hearts and Minds." It's 
about Vietnam: what we were doing there and what it did to us and others. 
Invading Iraq might just be the beginning of a terrible saga I would not want 
to see repeated. 

ok ... I hope to see a lot of you cool people at Wish ... Have fun ... Be 
safe ... Be happy that we can party -- a lot of people can't. 
See you also at the march on Sunday. This includes those of you who want to 
show support for the war; you should represent too.  
Take care -- 
John in Berkeley 

--part1_168.1ab8da93.2b801b25_boundary--

Subject: [sfraves] RAVERS FOR PEACE:  Tomorrow

--=====================_438821==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


This may be our last chance to demonstrate to the world and the Bush 
administration our opposition to this immoral war, so let's make sure we 
get our bodies on the line tomorrow -- rain or shine:)

We hope those of you on this list who share our beliefs will join us on 
Sunday to march in solidarity.

MEETING TIME/PLACE ON SUNDAY

The rally and march begin around 11:00 AM at Justin Herman Plaza at the end 
of Market Street.  We should plan to gather there around 10:30 on at the 
fountain on the left hand side of the Plaza as you enter from Market Street 
(that's where the skateboard kids often do their thing.)  Look for the 
Ravers For Peace banner and "Drop Beats Not Bombs" signs.   Also, since we 
cannot have a truck with sound, bring drums, musical instruments, hell, 
boom boxes if you can carry them so we can march to some rhythm.

Be sure to leave early.  Last time public transportation was overwhelmed by 
the large number of marchers, and this promises to be an even larger event.

Looking forward to seeing you all tomorrow!!!

Much love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


just in case you didn't know it, the chinese new year parade took place last night in san francisco...there was a fatty fat crowd, and it poured rain. most of the revelers arrived before the rain, so they were kind of stuck, i supposed....wasn't there...just know about...there's a peace march too in downtown s.f. today, just in case you forgot or didn't know...something to do...please don't drop your banana peels or cans on the ground...give peace a chance....i am pretty darned irresistable, i am finding...that doesn't mean that people agree whether or not i am actually approachable or not...that is actually all timing. ;)

friend:

their offices and the other UN offices with emails to STOP the WAR.
France needs to know that Americans are with them on this.

PLEASE forward this to everyone you can.  The UN email addresses are
below for the Security Council.
Bill Douglas

From sfraves-return-98961-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Feb 17 21:11:42 2003

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 37502 invoked from network); 17 Feb 2003 21:11:40 -0000
Message-ID: <20030217211147.94035.qmail@web12302.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 17 Feb 2003 13:11:47 -0800 (PST)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Nightclub bouncers chain doors shut, mace crowd, 21 dead in panic...

http://www.cnn.com/2003/US/Midwest/02/17/chicago.nightclub/index.html

http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/2771641.stm

Yikes!

This really makes me think of some of the places I've partied, where if a fire
had gotten started, we'd all have been soooo fucked!  Not all THAT many, but
the ones that were bad were REALLY bad.

It's kinda scary, actually, when I think about how I've not really thought
about that myself.  When I get to a party at a new venue, usually the first
thing I do is explore a bit...  Find out where the bathrooms are, where they're
selling water, if they have Red Bull or the like in addition to water, look for
booths from any non-profits that are in attendance, etc.  I'm USED to thinking
about all that.  But I'm just so used to buildings NOT burning down, that I
can't recall haveing actually intently scoped out the fire exits (if any...
they're absent in some cases).

That bouncer types would chain the fire exits shut, in preperation an assault
with pepper spray and mace against their customers, is just extra super
loathesome.  Damn... either one is just plain stupid by itself.  Plain old
common sence says that mace, used in a crowd, is going to hit a lot of
bystanders, and cause people to scatter.  And locking the fire exits... does
that even NEED comment?  The two together is more contemptable by orders of
magnitude!  Hell, and I thought my opinion of, and respect for, those people
was low BEFORE today...

Well, I know ONE thing that's now added to my list of things to look for when
exploreing a new venue...


cya,
john

Subject: [sfraves] Ravers For Peace:   March

--=====================_15000052==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Thanks to all of you who marched with us yesterday.  Incredible vibe at=20
that protest, and it was enhanced for me by walking with my brothers and=20
sisters on this list.

Much love,

Apollo

http://www.nytimes.com/2003/02/17/national/17PROT.html

A Day Late, but Not a Marcher Short, in San Francisco
By DEAN E. MURPHY

AN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 =97 Some people were concerned that the protest
here today would be forgotten, coming as it did the day after
millions of people attended peace rallies around the world.

They need not have worried. The demonstrations on Saturday were like
a big pregame pep rally for peace activists from the San Francisco
Bay Area.

At least 150,000 people marched through the city's financial
district, chanted antiwar slogans and listened to John Lennon's
"Imagine" sung in Arabic. The afternoon of dissent was the largest
antiwar demonstration in San Francisco since the protests against
possible military action in Iraq began last fall.

"We are here to stop this war," the actor Danny Glover shouted from a
stage at Civic Center Plaza.

Another speaker, Rabbi Stephen Pearce of Temple Emanu-El in San
Francisco, said the protesters were delivering an important message
to President Bush and Congress.

"We will not send our sons and daughters to war," Rabbi Pearce said.
"We will not turn our sons and daughters into mortar."

By late in the afternoon, when the demonstration was coming to an
end, the police estimated the crowd at 150,000 to 200,000. At the
same time, organizers, who had volunteers atop buildings videotaping
marchers on Market Street, suggested that the number was closer to
250,000.

The crowds gathering at a staging area near the waterfront grew so
large so quickly that some people began walking toward Civic Center
Plaza more than an hour before the scheduled start. There was simply
no more room at the staging area.

"It is was so wonderful to see the turnout in Europe and New York,"
said Miriam Hutchins, 59, a teacher from Petaluma, Calif. Ms.
Hutchins said she had marched with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King
Jr. in Detroit in 1963 and had attended Vietnam War protests in
Berkeley, Calif.

"This voice is coming from the planet," Ms. Hutchins said. "It
started in Melbourne and is growing around the globe. Now it is San
Francisco's turn."

Originally scheduled for Saturday, the rally was put off until today
to avoid conflicting with a Chinese New Year celebration. While the
change did not dampen enthusiasm, it did create some confusion.

Mike Lamson of Alameda, Calif., and other protesters showed up
downtown on Saturday expecting a peace rally, not a New Year's
parade. Mr. Lamson, 33, said he and his wife, Nicole, and daughter,
Sarah, spent a day sightseeing while waiting for the march today.

"I am honestly not sure how much it does to stop a war, but at the
very least it makes you feel like you are speaking your voice," he
said.

The police said the demonstration was mostly peaceful until a group
of about 500 people broke off late in the day, setting several fires
and vandalizing at least one store. Several arrests were made, the
police said, but no details were available.

For some people here, the biggest worry was not over rowdy peace
advocates but terrorism. Mr. Lamson said he had a few anxious minutes
on the subway as it sped through a tunnel beneath the San Francisco
Bay. Since the code orange terror alert, security has been heightened
at bridges and tunnels.

But the fear of terrorism, Mr. Lamson said, made getting to the
protest all the more important.

"That is one of the most convincing arguments of the antiwar
movement," he said. "An attack on Iraq will stimulate terrorism
against the United States."

Joan Buell, 77, of Cupertino, Calif., also had terrorism on her mind.
She said she was moved by "genuine fear" to attend this, her first
peace rally. Though she questioned how much protests influenced
decisions in Washington, she said she could no longer sit quietly on
the sidelines.

"I am scared, and I'm not kidding," Ms. Buell said of a possible war
with Iraq. "I think the consequence is going to be World War III, and
I am very depressed about it."

Michael N. Nagler, the founder and former chairman of the Peace and
Conflict Studies Department at the University of California, said the
protest could have significance, not in changing Mr. Bush's mind but
in reaching out to potential terrorists.

"This is going to penetrate the consciousness of some of the people
who hate us and make it harder to stereotype us," Professor Nagler
said. "A key element in nonviolent struggles is risk. When you are
willing to take a risk it has a strong emotional impact on the other
party."





Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one=20
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But=20
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ESC live set from M.D.V.

Hey hey all,

This was one cool  little shindig. Cozy venue and great peeps having a good 
time. DDR and Praxis were awsome but dont sell yourself short Mr. ESC you 
were bangin it too. I may be a total househead but  sheeeit if I dont 
appreciate some banging techno as well when it is done right. Richard 
Summerhayes did some proper schoolin on the on the techno tip as well 
especially since he mostly plays house.  Rob bliss was tearing it up in the 
d&b room but I didnt catch much else in there. The house room was bumping 
all night  and Hector from primal closed out that room quite nicely. great 
vibe all night and it was super cool seeing the old school  MW Trust posse 
in full effect, you folks sure have been missed! This party definately took 
me back a decade or so,jeez has it been that long?

my .02,

DJMC

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Dancing Styles as a Political Metaphor?

i agree with you. its nice when you're out a party to
sample one room, then for a different change of pace
to go into another and experience a whole different
atmosphere and vibe. i myself am ecletic when it comes
to edm, and its nice to experience it all in one
night.

Delia

--- JBlaze112@aol.com wrote:
> so i was thinking about how raves are litterally
> split up into "rooms" for 
> different styles of music and dancing, and somehow
> it came to me that these 
> styles of dance kind of mimick different types of
> political philosophies. 
> 
> 
> House music and break beat dancers are kind of like
> Capitalists in a sense 
> that they form elete circles where only the best,
> most aggressive dancers are 
> given space to dance, in which they will either fail
> and embarress themselves 
> or they will really impress their peers and recieve
> "props".
> 
> 
> Techno and Trance music dancers are more like
> Socialists because they all 
> have equal spaces to dance in, in any way they like
> to dance, and no one 
> dancer is given credit for being "better" than any
> other dancer (even though 
> realistically some people are obviously "better"
> than others in skill & 
> rhythm.)
> 
> Junglist and hardcore music dancers are kind of like
> a metaphor of Anarchy to 
> me because they don't stay in one place, there is
> some type of "props" given 
> out to good dancers but in this case the definition
> of "good" is more like 
> crazy or out of control and sometimes just plain
> pissed off (but with some 
> sense of rhythm at the same time.)
> 
> So i'm not saying these discription fit each group
> to a tee! or that there is 
> anything wrong with any one of these groups, but u
> get the picture? Having 
> all three rooms in a party is just awsome and it
> shows that a highly evolved, 
> eclectic, diverse group of people are behind the
> scenes making these events 
> happen... Anyone agree with me here? - johnny bzzzz
> 
> 
> "So upgrade your grey matter, cuz one day it may
> matter..." Deltron Zero
> 
>

Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] mac audio software

on 2/18/03 2:25 PM, Deepak Jagannath at deepakj@myrealbox.com wrote:

> What do you guys recommend.. as far as sequencers.. synths.. audio
> editing.. I come from PC.. so I have no idea what is good out there.

Deepak,

Try checking out Harmony-Central.com - they have ALL sorts of information o=
n
software, interfaces, etc... and links to demos/downloads and all that.

Currently, I use Reason as my primary synth package (hey, it's easy and
works pretty well, even though it's not the most pro thing out there), and
have been doing my multitracking with the rather shabby Deck 3.5... I
purchased eMagic's Logic Audio recently, which is =FCber-powerful, but becaus=
e
of its steep learning curve, I haven't started to use it yet...

I believe the standard for multitracking is probably ProTools or CuBase. As
for synths, there's all sorts of stuff from BitHeadz and Propellerhead that
are status quo on the Mac.  Then there's all the VST stuff, as well as
"Audio Units," Apple's new VST-type scheme that so far is supported by
Logic..

If you go to Apple's web site, you can get an overview of what's out there,

http://www.apple.com/creative/musicaudio/

but be mindful of the Logic bias, since they recently purchased eMagic. :)

Good luck...

 - omid

Subject: Re: [sfraves] mac audio software

Personally I still use Opcode Studio Vision. I love that program. Logic is
just convoluded in my opinion. Cubase was a wannabe Vision product that just
never cut it for me. Unfortunately Opcode is dead thanks to that little
buyout that happened. Gibson bought and killed them as I recall. To think
that OMS is still out there and in use to this day, but the company is long
dead.

Most of the production that I hear of is done on Emagic Logic. I would say
it's in your best interest to learn the program because it has become the
studio standard. Synth wise you can do the vanilla Reason thing, but I'm not
impressed. External gear still wins.

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
design :: www.sninesix.com
photography :: www.innocentchild.com

X-Delivery-Agent: TMDA/0.65 (Johnstown)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] mac audio software


I personally use or have used all of the sequencers mentioned so far, and
I do miss Vision.  There were some things you could do in the track window
that you still can't do to this day in
logic/cubase/digitalperformer/reason/whatever...

Lately I've been using cubase SX a lot with an athlon machine I built.

As a side note, Reason does have it's advantages...  I use reason
primarily for collaboration with other people that have vastly different
studios, or music platforms.  It's super easy to pack up a track and have
it play correctly on a totally new machine.  Even going mac <> pc works
flawlessly.

Also, you can work in reason and when you're ready for final mixdown, just
re-wire it into you're favorite DAW and you can get a better quality mix
out of it.

-ed-

Subject: Re: [sfraves] mac audio software

Has anyone managed to control a machine running Reason with an external
sequencer? I sequence on a mac. I've never liked sequencing on a pc. Don't
ask why, it's just a preference. Anyway - Reason is something that I would
use more if the damn thing would work as an extrenal synth. Everytime I
tried to get the Reason box to listen to the midi being thrown at it nothing
would happen. Using the midi port on an SB Audigy for the Reason machine.
This is why I like the Mac for midi. It just *works* with no BS. I love my
pc, but midi fucks itself hard on it!

ryan.bailey

Subject: Re: [sfraves] mac audio software

edit->prefrences->advanced midi
external control
bus A: select your MP401 device.

then from within the rack:
bus select: a
channel 1: (choose device)
channel 2: (choose device)
etc...

works for me on my pc w/ a MP401 and my laptop w/ my oxygen-8.

-xs

>=20
> I personally use or have used all of the sequencers mentioned so far, and
> I do miss Vision.  There were some things you could do in the track window
> that you still can't do to this day in
> logic/cubase/digitalperformer/reason/whatever...
>=20
> Lately I've been using cubase SX a lot with an athlon machine I built.
>=20
> As a side note, Reason does have it's advantages...  I use reason
> primarily for collaboration with other people that have vastly different
> studios, or music platforms.  It's super easy to pack up a track and have
> it play correctly on a totally new machine.  Even going mac <> pc works
> flawlessly.
>=20
> Also, you can work in reason and when you're ready for final mixdown, just
> re-wire it into you're favorite DAW and you can get a better quality mix
> out of it.
>=20
> -ed-
>=20
>=20

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Candy Kid Masculinity?

Hey Ya'll,
 Is there a candy kid masculinity, or does gender not matter at all?
Masculinity as defined as a set of codes or expectations of how a male is 
expected to act (i.e., No Sissy Stuff, Rambo...) I'm looking to get some 
responses on this listserv after surveying the NM rave listserv to see if 
there were any comparisions.

When I was candy a few years ago (I'm 32 now) I thought of us candy kids as 
ambiguous persons, sexually at least, but not in terms of gender: I could 
tell who was male or female or whatever.

I felt that the Club Kids were more androgonous in terms of gender.

BTW my doctoral dissertation demonstrates the creative interplay between 
the dancing male body and rave trance dance in the cultural context of the 
Albuquerque, New Mexico's rave scene. I find that raves provide boys and 
men a safe, shared space to explore alternative enactments of masculinity, 
such as male femininity (a term I developed in tandem with Judith 
Halberstam's female masculinity) partly due to the lack of homophobic 
harrassment.

Anthony Avery,MA
American Studies
University of New Mexico

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] more tips nrr

--0-1338427378-1045620323=:34817
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

i'm not and nor have i ever been in my entire life seeking out the attention of someone who is totally insensitive or worse.....just the same, i am aware, and also, i know that in the most unhealthy sense, someone thinks they are having or continuing some sort of a relationship...i stopped signing love on e-mails for the most part, because enough people have presumed that when you sign love on your e-mail that you mean to want sex or something along those lines from them....eye contact can mean that to some too....i just try to keep away from it all, but there's so much to keep away from...just feel like writing today and sharing....i am soooooooooooo glad that valentine's season is pretty much over...now, there is some lingering shiiiiiii....ttttt (past your sensors, sucker)....for example, sometimes i can't go and buy a less than $2.00 box of rice without getting yelled at, and nothing good was being yelled, by the way, but it did sort of have to do with men, women and my sex and potential sexual orientation, but i couldn't possibly just be going to get my friggin mutha fugg'in lunch....but, that was yesterday and today is today, afterall.  now, i noticed that some people have to be taught that treating people well feels good, because they are basically mean, so they have to be taught that...then, there is the trouble of learning who it is okay to be nice to, because, really, it is not okay usually, and if it is, how long is it okay to be nice and who is it okay to be nice to for more than one full minute? and is there any escape from the bad parts, because, i don't drink or do drugs when i'm out , but let me tell you something, i don't know about you, but when i go out, it takes me a long, long time to recover from the bullshit parts, and i am not the type of person to start anything..i pretty much try to plan ahead for even the most minute complications, including saying hello accidentally to the wrong person, or even just having the wrong person even know i am alive...now, i understand right now, that could be happening too, but also, it could be too late...i could already be dead right now, and then, basically, you lose, sucker. :)          


---------------------------------
Do you Yahoo!?
Yahoo! Shopping - Send Flowers for Valentine's Day

Subject: Re: [sfraves] mac audio software

Hmmmm,

Plenty of great choices out there. I really have been getting lots of miles 
out of logic lately with reason as a scratch pad for ideas. You might also 
want to check out digital performer from motu, or perhaps ableton live which 
is quite nice. If you have the bux to spend try checking out pro tools, they 
have a new entry level system the digi 02 I believe its called but you may 
outgrow it quickly depending on your needs. in the soft synth/ sampler arena 
most everything out there is cross platform so there are many options, I 
find myself using absynth a bunch. The fm 7 from native insts. is dope as 
well as the pro 53. logic comes bundled with some good soft synths also. 
motu has a really interesting new software sampler coming out soon the mach 
5 and if you really want to get freaky check out kantos by antares but be 
careful it is a total memory hog. i really recomend spending a few bux and 
get a subscription to keyboard mag, eq, or remix for decent tips and product 
reviews  they are great resources.

happy hunting,

DJMC

whatever Play instructions they have there.

AOL users may have problems due to their web caching, so you might just hear
a Live365 commercial over & over. Ugh.

Enjoy :)
