MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.00.2615.200
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2615.200
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid

I sold all my outboard gear and replaced it with Reason and Acid. I'm pretty
happy with that decision.

Reason is an excellent software package, but the truth is I use Acid a lot
more than I use Reason. firstly, Reason is much more complicated, and
secondly, its sequencer sucks ass. it really does, in fact it's the worst
I've ever worked with. the best is the one in Acid, and the second best is
the one in the Akai MPC2000. the sequencer on the Korg ER-1 -- a $100 drum
machine -- is superior to the sequencer in Reason.

besides, Acid is more fun.

it's best for silly remixes:

http://www.neobeatnik.com/rock.mp3

("Rock Steady" by the Whispers vs. "Keep Their Heads Ringing" by Dr. Dre.)

http://www.neobeatnik.com/makai.mp3
http://www.neobeatnik.com/icey.mp3

("Nothing Left" by Orbital, first in the style of Makai "Beneath The Mask"
and then in the style of DJ Icey. I love this song. I think they called it
"Nothing Left" because they got everything right.)

Reason also appears in those little Orbital remixes in the form of tiny
background sounds, acid-style (as opposed to Acid-style). If Acid didn't
have such potent effects (like five different forms of EQ, and excellent
compression) I'd be looking for outboard gear, because Reason itself, so far
as I can tell, is best suited to sounds which are pretty and predictable:

http://www.neobeatnik.com/warble.mp3

(Random ambient stuff.)

The crazy thing about Acid, tho, is that it appears to all eyes not as a
musical instrument but as a toy. I don't understand why, nor do I care --
it's excellent software. Reason is obviously a commodification and emulation
of the technologies that made techno what it is. Acid is likewise a
commodification of jungle's means of production. It's basically just a
software sampler and a very wisely constructed sequencer. It's very easy to
use Acid to emulate jungle effects, even in other genres:

http://www.neobeatnik.com/theireyes.mp3

(Random techno track remixed in old-school Amen jungle style.)

The other nice thing about Acid is that its ease of use makes it the perfect
partner technology to Final Scratch. Final Scratch in and of itself seems
totally useless --

idiot: "dude, now you can spend hours and hours digitizing all your records,
and then when you use the computer, it's just like records, except with
significantly degraded sound quality!"

normal person: "um...cool..."

-- but if you have Final Scratch and Acid it immediately becomes possible to
integrate into your own music just about any song out there. likewise it
takes about five minutes to remix anything in Acid, so it becomes trivial to
guarantee that every song you spin is totally unique.

plus, if you're using a Gnutella client, you can do it all for free.

while it's true that you need something more than Reason and Acid if you
want to do professional recordings, it's true mainly because of copyright
law, and not for any valid musical reason. the combination is incredibly
potent. I've made a dubplate of the above techno track, and I'm seriously
considering pressing up the Orbital bootlegs as a white label -- or actually
I would be, if it were not for my profound respect for copyright law and my
sincere desire to never get caught. so if you ever find those tracks on a
record in a store, it wasn't me.

now one more thing - just because I said Reason's sequencer sucks ass, and
sincerely meant it, does not mean I'm saying Reason itself doesn't have any
value. it's actually a tremendously powerful program, but it's also a lot of
work, while Acid (by contrast) is a lot of fun. but Reason's strength is
absolutely in its tone generation.

anyone who tells you that you can use Reason alone and produce good music is
either incredibly gifted at making mountains out of molehills, or just plain
wrong. Reason's sequencer is very limited and even if you don't agree that
it does indeed suck ass, the difference between Reason's compressors and
those found in Acid (or, indeed, in real life) is like the difference
between playing Gran Turismo and actually driving a car.

however the tone generation kicks ass, which is why I would recommend
getting Reason as well as Acid. Acid on its own quickly degenerates into
silliness. add good tone generation, however, and you can do some pretty
cool shit.

also I think to be perfectly honest a lot of people are scared to criticize
Reason or praise Acid, for the simple reason that Reason is obviously for
real musicians, and Acid is obviously a toy. but "real" bassists considered
the TB303 a toy when it was first released, and "real" musicians in general
considered DJing beneath them for decades.

so, my advice would be, get Reason, Acid, and possibly a sequencer program.
I say possibly because the truth is that MIDI is such a simple protocol that
it would be easy to write your own sequencer in Perl. in fact there are
multiple MIDI Perl packages on CPAN that are worth considering for this
purpose, and I believe that an open-source emulation of the MPC2000
sequencer is also under development somewhere out there on the net. (but I
think they're writing it in C.)


Giles


ps: I've had countless problems with mp3-encoding the dj icey ripoff. there
are some intentional skips in there, but there might be some unintentional
ones as well. also, apologies for the overall quality of the mp3 encoding, I
only have 50MB on my web space.






---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

--- Giles Bowkett <gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com> wrote:
> I sold all my outboard gear and replaced it with
> Reason and Acid. I'm pretty
> happy with that decision.
> 
> Reason is an excellent software package, but the
> truth is I use Acid a lot
> more than I use Reason. firstly, Reason is much more
> complicated, and
> secondly, its sequencer sucks ass. it really does,
> in fact it's the worst
> I've ever worked with. the best is the one in Acid,
> and the second best is
> the one in the Akai MPC2000. the sequencer on the
> Korg ER-1 -- a $100 drum
> machine -- is superior to the sequencer in Reason.
> 
> besides, Acid is more fun.
> 
> it's best for silly remixes:
> 
> http://www.neobeatnik.com/rock.mp3
> 
> ("Rock Steady" by the Whispers vs. "Keep Their Heads
> Ringing" by Dr. Dre.)
> 
> http://www.neobeatnik.com/makai.mp3
> http://www.neobeatnik.com/icey.mp3
> 
> ("Nothing Left" by Orbital, first in the style of
> Makai "Beneath The Mask"
> and then in the style of DJ Icey. I love this song.
> I think they called it
> "Nothing Left" because they got everything right.)
> 
> Reason also appears in those little Orbital remixes
> in the form of tiny
> background sounds, acid-style (as opposed to
> Acid-style). If Acid didn't
> have such potent effects (like five different forms
> of EQ, and excellent
> compression) I'd be looking for outboard gear,
> because Reason itself, so far
> as I can tell, is best suited to sounds which are
> pretty and predictable:
> 
> http://www.neobeatnik.com/warble.mp3
> 
> (Random ambient stuff.)
> 
> The crazy thing about Acid, tho, is that it appears
> to all eyes not as a
> musical instrument but as a toy. I don't understand
> why, nor do I care --
> it's excellent software. Reason is obviously a
> commodification and emulation
> of the technologies that made techno what it is.
> Acid is likewise a
> commodification of jungle's means of production.
> It's basically just a
> software sampler and a very wisely constructed
> sequencer. It's very easy to
> use Acid to emulate jungle effects, even in other
> genres:
> 
> http://www.neobeatnik.com/theireyes.mp3
> 
> (Random techno track remixed in old-school Amen
> jungle style.)
>

> use makes it the perfect
> partner technology to Final Scratch. Final Scratch
> in and of itself seems
> totally useless --

> digitizing all your records,

> significantly degraded sound quality!"

> have a new entry level system the digi 02 I believe its called but you may
> outgrow it quickly depending on your needs. in the soft synth/ sampler arena
> most everything out there is cross platform so there are many options, I
> find myself using absynth a bunch. The fm 7 from native insts. is dope as
> well as the pro 53. logic comes bundled with some good soft synths also.
> motu has a really interesting new software sampler coming out soon the mach
> 5 and if you really want to get freaky check out kantos by antares but be
> careful it is a total memory hog. i really recomend spending a few bux and
> get a subscription to keyboard mag, eq, or remix for decent tips and product

i had to change my cold, plain emotionless title a couple of times, and then finally, i settled on this one...so, basically, i saw the back of your head...not you, YOU, you. i tried to get away, and i hope i did, but also, today i was thinking, maybe not, maybe it would be really cool...i'm not talking to you, i am talking to YOU, you....anyway though, someone yelled out my frigg'in name and maybe some telltale exact details of who i was at the time, and so, well, maybe you caught a small glimpse of my ass or something, but still, i am a much better musician than you, probably...okay, and with that said, basically, i could be talking to just about anybody, which is why i share...keep on move'in. :)

> > for copyright law and my
> > sincere desire to never get caught. so if you ever
> > find those tracks on a
> > record in a store, it wasn't me.
> > 
> > now one more thing - just because I said Reason's
> > sequencer sucks ass, and
> > sincerely meant it, does not mean I'm saying Reason
> > itself doesn't have any
> > value. it's actually a tremendously powerful
> > program, but it's also a lot of
> > work, while Acid (by contrast) is a lot of fun. but
> > Reason's strength is
> > absolutely in its tone generation.
> > 
> > anyone who tells you that you can use Reason alone
> > and produce good music is
> > either incredibly gifted at making mountains out of
> > molehills, or just plain
> > wrong. Reason's sequencer is very limited and even
> > if you don't agree that
> > it does indeed suck ass, the difference between
> > Reason's compressors and
> > those found in Acid (or, indeed, in real life) is
> > like the difference
> > between playing Gran Turismo and actually driving a
> > car.
> > 
> > however the tone generation kicks ass, which is why
> > I would recommend
> > getting Reason as well as Acid. Acid on its own
> > quickly degenerates into
> > silliness. add good tone generation, however, and
> > you can do some pretty
> > cool shit.
> > 
> > also I think to be perfectly honest a lot of people
> > are scared to criticize
> > Reason or praise Acid, for the simple reason that
> > Reason is obviously for
> > real musicians, and Acid is obviously a toy. but
> > "real" bassists considered
> > the TB303 a toy when it was first released, and
> > "real" musicians in general
> > considered DJing beneath them for decades.
> > 
> > so, my advice would be, get Reason, Acid, and
> > possibly a sequencer program.
> > I say possibly because the truth is that MIDI is
> > such a simple protocol that
> > it would be easy to write your own sequencer in
> > Perl. in fact there are
> > multiple MIDI Perl packages on CPAN that are worth
> > considering for this
> > purpose, and I believe that an open-source emulation
> > of the MPC2000
> > sequencer is also under development somewhere out
> > there on the net. (but I
> > think they're writing it in C.)
> > 
> > 
> > Giles
> > 
> > 
> > ps: I've had countless problems with mp3-encoding
> > the dj icey ripoff. there
> > are some intentional skips in there, but there might
> > be some unintentional
> > ones as well. also, apologies for the overall
> > quality of the mp3 encoding, I
> > only have 50MB on my web space.
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> >
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> > To unsubscribe, e-mail:
> > sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> > For additional commands, e-mail:
> > sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
> > 
> 
>

>

>From: Moshen <moshen@catch22.org>
>Reply-To: Moshen <moshen@catch22.org>
>To: Chris Jackson <resourcemusic_usa@yahoo.com>
>CC: Giles Bowkett <gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com>,sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid
>Date: Wed, 19 Feb 2003 15:53:10 -0800
>
>Just curious, what did you think was lacking in the sound quality
>and how was the sound being outputted?   I have reason going out
>to a PC soundcard and it sounds like shit too but I think
>if you had a digital out to a decent DAC it may sound better?
>
>moshen
>
>On Wed, Feb 19, 2003 at 01:11:20PM -0800, Chris Jackson wrote:
> > Sorry to say, but Reason is seriously lacking with the
> > sound output it spits out.  Really crappy.  I've
> > played with it on a number of occasions, and , well
> > yes, it's really cool with all its bells and
> > whistles...but the sound quality is not one of
> > professionals.  As far as the sequencer is
> > concerned...oh yes, I will surely agree...the worst
> > EVER!  Maybe you should try Logic, because Acid and
> > the MPC aren't very good sequencers either..
> >
> > just a thought,
> >
> > chris
> >
> > --- Giles Bowkett <gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com> wrote:
> > > I sold all my outboard gear and replaced it with
> > > Reason and Acid. I'm pretty
> > > happy with that decision.
> > >
> > > Reason is an excellent software package, but the
> > > truth is I use Acid a lot
> > > more than I use Reason. firstly, Reason is much more
> > > complicated, and
> > > secondly, its sequencer sucks ass. it really does,
> > > in fact it's the worst
> > > I've ever worked with. the best is the one in Acid,
> > > and the second best is
> > > the one in the Akai MPC2000. the sequencer on the
> > > Korg ER-1 -- a $100 drum
> > > machine -- is superior to the sequencer in Reason.
> > >
> > > besides, Acid is more fun.
> > >
> > > it's best for silly remixes:
> > >
> > > http://www.neobeatnik.com/rock.mp3
> > >
> > > ("Rock Steady" by the Whispers vs. "Keep Their Heads
> > > Ringing" by Dr. Dre.)
> > >
> > > http://www.neobeatnik.com/makai.mp3
> > > http://www.neobeatnik.com/icey.mp3
> > >
> > > ("Nothing Left" by Orbital, first in the style of
> > > Makai "Beneath The Mask"
> > > and then in the style of DJ Icey. I love this song.
> > > I think they called it
> > > "Nothing Left" because they got everything right.)
> > >
> > > Reason also appears in those little Orbital remixes
> > > in the form of tiny
> > > background sounds, acid-style (as opposed to
> > > Acid-style). If Acid didn't
> > > have such potent effects (like five different forms
> > > of EQ, and excellent
> > > compression) I'd be looking for outboard gear,
> > > because Reason itself, so far
> > > as I can tell, is best suited to sounds which are
> > > pretty and predictable:
> > >
> > > http://www.neobeatnik.com/warble.mp3
> > >
> > > (Random ambient stuff.)
> > >
> > > The crazy thing about Acid, tho, is that it appears
> > > to all eyes not as a
> > > musical instrument but as a toy. I don't understand
> > > why, nor do I care --
> > > it's excellent software. Reason is obviously a
> > > commodification and emulation
> > > of the technologies that made techno what it is.
> > > Acid is likewise a
> > > commodification of jungle's means of production.
> > > It's basically just a
> > > software sampler and a very wisely constructed
> > > sequencer. It's very easy to
> > > use Acid to emulate jungle effects, even in other
> > > genres:
> > >
> > > http://www.neobeatnik.com/theireyes.mp3
> > >
> > > (Random techno track remixed in old-school Amen
> > > jungle style.)
> > >
> > > The other nice thing about Acid is that its ease of
> > > use makes it the perfect
> > > partner technology to Final Scratch. Final Scratch
> > > in and of itself seems
> > > totally useless --
> > >
> > > idiot: "dude, now you can spend hours and hours
> > > digitizing all your records,
> > > and then when you use the computer, it's just like
> > > records, except with
> > > significantly degraded sound quality!"
> > >
> > > normal person: "um...cool..."
> > >
> > > -- but if you have Final Scratch and Acid it
> > > immediately becomes possible to
> > > integrate into your own music just about any song
> > > out there. likewise it
> > > takes about five minutes to remix anything in Acid,
> > > so it becomes trivial to
> > > guarantee that every song you spin is totally
> > > unique.
> > >
> > > plus, if you're using a Gnutella client, you can do
> > > it all for free.
> > >
> > > while it's true that you need something more than
> > > Reason and Acid if you
> > > want to do professional recordings, it's true mainly
> > > because of copyright
> > > law, and not for any valid musical reason. the
> > > combination is incredibly
> > > potent. I've made a dubplate of the above techno
> > > track, and I'm seriously
> > > considering pressing up the Orbital bootlegs as a
> > > white label -- or actually
> > > I would be, if it were not for my profound respect
> > > for copyright law and my
> > > sincere desire to never get caught. so if you ever
> > > find those tracks on a
> > > record in a store, it wasn't me.
> > >
> > > now one more thing - just because I said Reason's
> > > sequencer sucks ass, and
> > > sincerely meant it, does not mean I'm saying Reason
> > > itself doesn't have any
> > > value. it's actually a tremendously powerful
> > > program, but it's also a lot of
> > > work, while Acid (by contrast) is a lot of fun. but
> > > Reason's strength is
> > > absolutely in its tone generation.
> > >
> > > anyone who tells you that you can use Reason alone
> > > and produce good music is
> > > either incredibly gifted at making mountains out of
> > > molehills, or just plain
> > > wrong. Reason's sequencer is very limited and even
> > > if you don't agree that
> > > it does indeed suck ass, the difference between
> > > Reason's compressors and
> > > those found in Acid (or, indeed, in real life) is
> > > like the difference
> > > between playing Gran Turismo and actually driving a
> > > car.
> > >
> > > however the tone generation kicks ass, which is why
> > > I would recommend
> > > getting Reason as well as Acid. Acid on its own
> > > quickly degenerates into
> > > silliness. add good tone generation, however, and
> > > you can do some pretty
> > > cool shit.
> > >
> > > also I think to be perfectly honest a lot of people
> > > are scared to criticize
> > > Reason or praise Acid, for the simple reason that
> > > Reason is obviously for
> > > real musicians, and Acid is obviously a toy. but
> > > "real" bassists considered
> > > the TB303 a toy when it was first released, and
> > > "real" musicians in general
> > > considered DJing beneath them for decades.
> > >
> > > so, my advice would be, get Reason, Acid, and
> > > possibly a sequencer program.
> > > I say possibly because the truth is that MIDI is
> > > such a simple protocol that
> > > it would be easy to write your own sequencer in
> > > Perl. in fact there are
> > > multiple MIDI Perl packages on CPAN that are worth
> > > considering for this
> > > purpose, and I believe that an open-source emulation
> > > of the MPC2000
> > > sequencer is also under development somewhere out
> > > there on the net. (but I
> > > think they're writing it in C.)
> > >
> > >
> > > Giles
> > >
> > >
> > > ps: I've had countless problems with mp3-encoding
> > > the dj icey ripoff. there
> > > are some intentional skips in there, but there might
> > > be some unintentional
> > > ones as well. also, apologies for the overall
> > > quality of the mp3 encoding, I
> > > only have 50MB on my web space.
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >

> > > > so it becomes trivial to
> > > > guarantee that every song you spin is totally
> > > > unique.
> > > >
> > > > plus, if you're using a Gnutella client, you
> can do
> > > > it all for free.
> > > >
> > > > while it's true that you need something more
> than
> > > > Reason and Acid if you
> > > > want to do professional recordings, it's true
> mainly
> > > > because of copyright
> > > > law, and not for any valid musical reason. the
> > > > combination is incredibly
> > > > potent. I've made a dubplate of the above
> techno
> > > > track, and I'm seriously
> > > > considering pressing up the Orbital bootlegs
> as a
> > > > white label -- or actually
> > > > I would be, if it were not for my profound
> respect
> > > > for copyright law and my
> > > > sincere desire to never get caught. so if you
> ever
> > > > find those tracks on a
> > > > record in a store, it wasn't me.
> > > >
> > > > now one more thing - just because I said
> Reason's
> > > > sequencer sucks ass, and
> > > > sincerely meant it, does not mean I'm saying
> Reason
> 
=== message truncated ===

From: Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

In-Reply-To: <F14Og0xF195jwsTMUBz00027e88@hotmail.com>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid (Samples included)

on 2/19/03 4:31 PM, _ fable _ at fable4our@hotmail.com wrote:

> Its very strange that you guys think that reason's sound is shitty.  I think
> it sounds great, crisp and clear, even after I burn it onto a cd.

Yeah, I've found that, based on what instruments you use, Reason's sound can
be excellent... The thing I've had the most trouble with is the frequency
ranges of the various bass sounds. Some sound really dulled and flat, while
others come out very bright - it's hard to find a middle ground without
tweaking with one sound for what seems like hours... But for the price, it's
hard to argue with it. It just seems to take a lot of work to get some good
sounds out.

At first, I thought Reason was weak and figured I'd better invest in a good
amount of new hardware.. But then I found ways of making  tracks sound
less... loop-based, I guess, and more like natural songs.

A couple of the tracks I've been working with, no one had guessed that I
made them in Reason. You can check out bits here:

http://tavallai.com/music/clips/heart.mp3
http://tavallai.com/music/clips/thought.mp3
http://tavallai.com/music/clips/mine.mp3

However, I'm still slowly trying to collect more and more gear as the need
comes along, as I'm a firm believer in having as many toys as possible ;)

  - omid

Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid

Hey,

It appears that to some degree that reason is becoming quite popular in the 
studio. I used to laugh when I ran into someone who used reason as the only 
tool for track composition, but some friends of mine just sold some cuts 
using only  reason and the tracks are quite nice. Even crazier, the last 
time evil eddie richards was in town we got to talking about studio stuff 
and gear and his main piece of software was reason which accounts for about 
80% of his tracks, I know that most of his stuff is super minimal tech house 
but I'll be damned if his cuts dont sound great. All that aside I will still 
opt for a decent combo of hardware and software.

Cheers,

DJMC

Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid

It's one thing if he's using Reason to create the tracks, but final output
is he using a real ProTools setup or something else to cleanup the sound?
Canned is the term I would use to describe the output from Reason without
any post-processing. To use just Reason, it's virtual mixer, effects and so
on to produce a straight to cd recording doesn't cut it. If Reason is
treated as any other piece of outboard gear that has it's own quirks then I
can see a better use of it. Running Reason through an external mixer or a
real ProTools setup to cleanup the output seems to be the logical step in a
professional setup.

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
www.sninesix.com
www.innocentchild.com

----- Original Message -----
From: "larry melman" <whoosenation@hotmail.com>
To: <resourcemusic_usa@yahoo.com>; <thockin@hockin.org>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, February 19, 2003 7:24 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid


Hey,

It appears that to some degree that reason is becoming quite popular in the
studio. I used to laugh when I ran into someone who used reason as the only
tool for track composition, but some friends of mine just sold some cuts
using only  reason and the tracks are quite nice. Even crazier, the last
time evil eddie richards was in town we got to talking about studio stuff
and gear and his main piece of software was reason which accounts for about
80% of his tracks, I know that most of his stuff is super minimal tech house
but I'll be damned if his cuts dont sound great. All that aside I will still
opt for a decent combo of hardware and software.

Cheers,

DJMC

From sfraves-return-99020-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Feb 20 04:02:39 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-99020-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 45800 invoked by uid 1103); 20 Feb 2003 04:02:38 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 45786 invoked from network); 20 Feb 2003 04:02:38 -0000
Message-ID: <20030220040249.39914.qmail@web80409.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 19 Feb 2003 20:02:49 -0800 (PST)
From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <F267FDCjoDUS84zr4T900004767@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid

What Reason's really turned out to be ideal for, in my opinion, is
portable studio setups.  An iBook, an Oxygen8, some headphones, and
you're off and composing anywhere- like at work :)

Also, if you're using multiple machines (i.e. - laptop for composing
wherever and desktop machine in the studio, or collaborating with a
distant friend), as long as you keep your sample sets in parity between
the machines, you can take your songs (~50-150k) and send them easily
in email and other size-challenged formats.  

For drum programming, the ReDrum is pretty awesome, definitely another
invaluable tool in the sequencer/sampler box.  The synths do,
admittedly, have their anemic moments- and the stock patches are
completely bunk.  However, the NN-XT is a pretty awesome sampler and is
exceedingly quick to work with.

Being a hardware sequencer junkie, I must say that I actually dig
Reason's sequencer- it reminds me of Vision in a way, which is a
program I miss.  I'm really not all that into the
Logic/Cubase/Performer thing..  For my stuff, I'm just trying to
capture what's played, and have decent playback timing.  A good swing
algorithm is important, too.  Reason seems to have better timing than
most seq/midi interface/synth setups, and I'm thinking that may be
because the sounds are generated internally and thus may be quicker to
respond.

In any case, it gets a lot of use around here- I never end up finishing
in Reason, though- too limiting.  Most of my work is done with audio,
and for that I use Pro Tools.  Reason's effects are pretty cool, and
have that propellerhead sound..  ..but that's all they have.  After you
use a couple of delays and verbs, there's just this.. this...
REASONiness that jumps out at you, which can be good or bad.  For
grittier music, it's generally too clean, too.. um.. teutonic
sounding..  Or something.

So, through the plug-in wringer it goes, and comes out sounding more
like hardware, with more separation of the individual elements.  The
mixer within Reason is a bit foggy sometimes.  It can sound quite nice
if you want fog, but often it's a little constricting.

Sometimes I've prefered tracks that were based on Reason parts better
than those done with some pretty good hardware.  Part of that, I think,
is that the mobile setup allows me to capture an idea faster.

Anyway, yeah.  Audio rant #136.

cheers,
George C
www.djorigami.com

--- larry melman <whoosenation@hotmail.com> wrote:

Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid


On Wed, 19 Feb 2003, georgeC wrote:
-&e->For drum programming, the ReDrum is pretty awesome, definitely another

Redrum is like an MPC2000 (which I used to own) except with better
sequencing.

-&e->invaluable tool in the sequencer/sampler box.  The synths do,
-&e->admittedly, have their anemic moments- and the stock patches are
-&e->completely bunk.  However, the NN-XT is a pretty awesome sampler and is
-&e->exceedingly quick to work with.

-&e->Being a hardware sequencer junkie, I must say that I actually dig
-&e->Reason's sequencer- it reminds me of Vision in a way, which is a
-&e->program I miss.  I'm really not all that into the

I was gonna say that.  Once you learn it well, it reminded me of pro24 (a
product that later became cubase) or vision.  Copy management, editing,
and all that are reasonably powerful and really easy to learn assuming
YOU READ THE FUCKING MANUAL.

Some people demand more control than Reason's sequencer (myself included a
lot of the time, esp when making the basic rhythym of a track... or Chris
Jackson who is so meticulous about timing that I wig out when we work on
tracks together cuz he'll just be zoomed in on two notes and moving them
around a nanometer back and forth at full zoom to get the swing down
perfect)

-&e->Logic/Cubase/Performer thing..  For my stuff, I'm just trying to
-&e->capture what's played, and have decent playback timing.  A good swing
-&e->algorithm is important, too.  Reason seems to have better timing than
-&e->most seq/midi interface/synth setups, and I'm thinking that may be
-&e->because the sounds are generated internally and thus may be quicker to
-&e->respond.

My gripe with reason is that tight timing starts to fail you if you use a
lot of in line effects.  I don't think the sequencer 'plays ahead' to
compensate for the latency caused by some of the effects... and you can't
impose a playback 'compensation' delay at the per track level.

-&e->In any case, it gets a lot of use around here- I never end up finishing
-&e->in Reason, though- too limiting.  Most of my work is done with audio,
-&e->and for that I use Pro Tools.  Reason's effects are pretty cool, and
-&e->have that propellerhead sound..  ..but that's all they have.  After you
-&e->use a couple of delays and verbs, there's just this.. this...
-&e->REASONiness that jumps out at you, which can be good or bad.  For
-&e->grittier music, it's generally too clean, too.. um.. teutonic
-&e->sounding..  Or something.

http://www.saturn5.com/andy/esc-overall-rmx-portion.aif

I'll throw this in for anybody who doubts it's ability to get gritty
sounds.  This segment is a full resolution fragment of a remix I did for
ESC's Overall (a tasty little uptempo number lying on the fringe between
techno and hardcore).  Ed sent me the track in Reason format, and not
having ever used it to really do a track, I decided this was as good a
time as any to try my hand at it.

I picked a couple sounds I liked from the original composition, sample
raided a couple others (just opened them up in Peak and took little cuts,
then enveloped them so they'd sound like drums) and added a couple little
shrill squealy thing with the Maelstrom synth and slapped the drums I cut
up into ReDrum.  For a little rhythmic inspiration, I also 'stole' the
timing from a classic loop I had here (opening theme to Hawaii-Five-0
slowed down a bit) by importing it as a *.rex file and then bouncing the
rex's timing to the sequencer, and using that sequence to trigger a
different rex loop by changing what instrument that seq track was assigned
to (taken from the original ESC arrangement, get it?).

Only post processing was loading the exported file output into Peak and
running Waves' L1 processor on it in order to up the levels a tad.

Is it the next dancefloor anthem?  Doubtful.  It sounds like Drop Bass
Network vs. Aphex Twin, but it's what I was in the mood to make at the
moment and I'm generally pleased with the results.

I think the reason a lot of tracks that are done in Reason sound 'off' is
because a lot of novice producers use Reason... and more seasoned
producers are more familiar with analog mixer based setups where things
work a certain way (for example, in Reason *enabling* the EQs on the
mixer, or carelessly routing effects without making sure they're not
sending back the same signal to the mixer causes smear in the form of
phase error and very short delays causing all sorts of problems... ).

In the end, you can do a hell of a lot more with it than say an 808 and a
303... it's a lot cheaper and a lot easier to use for most stuff.  For my
work I prefer Logic and the mix of fruity hardware and software I've got
here... but it's a great quick arrangement tool as well as a great way of
getting loops together.

Hell, I'd be down if anybody else is to do an SFR MP3 compilation of
remixes of each others' original work... any takers?  Maybe even get
Hyperreal to host it as a downloadable community perk?  If we use Reason
as a base format, we could just assign works to remixers and have tracks
ready inside a couple weeks.  Then the album as a full length cd could be
sold to help support Hyperreal.org online (containing the original and
remixed versions).

andyw

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Re: [sacdrama] County Sheriff (was: Wake Up Call to the Scene)

this just goes to show you never know when you you might find intelligent
conversation on this [sacdrama] list. i agree strongly with the point that
jimmy is making:  regardless of what you consider right or wrong, the laws
of our government must be enforced. if you dont like those laws, then you
should work to change them, not disobey them. our society could not exist
if the laws we (you, me, your parents, your neighbors, etc) made were not
enforced.

thank you rick for your feedback and for taking the time to listen to the
people who really care about the scene, who are here to dance and enjoy
themselves.

for better or worse, raving, and to a lesser degree the electronic music
scene, has been associated with drug use. why else would we laugh at
pill-munching pac-man jokes? i dont know how to change that, but you might
want to rethink the next email you send complaining about how the 'scene'
is dead. maybe thats a good thing. maybe the old 'scene' needs to die, the
old image along with it.

if we can make "drug use" socially unacceptable at parties, then people
will be less likely to participate in those activities. it takes more than
just promoters, djs, or words on a mailing list to make a difference. it
takes a change of attitude on each of our behalves. instead of
pointing the kid who just asked you if you were rolling to the nearest
e-puddle, give him the evil eye. reverse that peer pressure. make him feel
uncomfortable to be there, putting our scene at risk. thats how we'll make
our lives, those of our community, and our officers better.

but please remember, the officers that serve our community have a job that
is probably a lot tougher than yours. while we're all out surfing titty
sites and complaining about how bored we are at work, they're out there
risking their lives to protect your rights and freedoms. they're the ones
that allow you to feel safe in your home. i dont know about you, but i
know i dont have to wear a bulletproof vest to work in the morning. i'm
extremely grateful that there are those that choose to; they have my
deepest gratitude and respect.

that being said, i must take this time now to take now to take issue with
the approach the government and law enforcement take at discouraging the
public from drug use. i understand doom's frustration. i think its the
feeling that people who do such little harm to society (or perhaps thats
their mistake, assuming that?) by partaking in extralegal substances
should be the focus of such a well funded 'war.'

"George Bush says 'we are losing the war on drugs'. Well you know what
that implies? There's a war going on, and people on drugs are winning it!
Well what does that tell you about drugs? Some smart, creative
motherfuckers on that side." -- Bill Hicks [1]

i could expound my own opinions here, but frankly i dont have the time nor
would it be as effective as if you did your own research. [2] so i've
included at the bottom in the notes some links for you to read. i wont
push any ideas down your throat, you are free to think freely. take
everything with a grain of salt, and think for yourselves. thats really
the only thing i ever expect of people.

but before i finish, i must emphasize one point. drugs _CAN_ be very bad
for you and everyone else around you if you let them. this is why we have
laws against them, people use them irresponsibly. there are a lot of
irresponsible people in the world, please dont be one of them. remember,
drugs can ruin your life.

drugs are like tools, just like a hammer or a crowbar. unfortunately,
they're more like lock picks. it seems that if you get caught with them,
people will assume you are a theif, which is what a lot of people who
carry around lock picks hidden in their underwear are. but there are a few
that use them to educate themselves, to find their place in the universe,
the meaning of why they are here. they must hide their tools for fear of
being labeled a thief or simply locked up because they make a good target.
so tread lightly, be respectful of others, and please think responsibly.


mae
---
Sed Quis Custodiet Ipsos Custodes? -- Roman satirist Juvenal

[1] To find out more information on Bill Hicks, i recommend these link
    short bio with links:   http://www.disinfo.com/pages/dossier/id1025/pg1/
    salon arcticle w/mp3's:  http://archive.salon.com/audio/nonfiction/2001/07/10/bhicks/index
    his home on the web: http://www.sacredcow.com/enter.html

[2] Other resources i recommend:

Books:
   Buzzed: The Straight Facts About the Most Used and Abused Drugs from Alcohol to Ecstasy.

Links:

Beyond Prohibition: The Case for Drug Legalization - Gary E. Johnson Governor of New Mexico:
a very refreshing view on drug use by a politician, a governor no less.
may just make you want to move to NM.
http://www.google.com/search?q=%22Beyond+Prohibition%3A+The+Case+for+Drug+Legalization%22

Re: "Largest Drug Chain in New York":
a good explanation of why kids should stay away from drugs
http://groups.google.com/groups?selm=MPG.10267e1a3a27408998978d%40news.newsguy.com&oe=UTF-8&output=gplain

Against Legalization - Hakim Bey: an interesting read about why the
current situation of prohibition is actually not as bad as we think.
http://www.cognitiveliberty.org/1jcl/1jcl34.htm

> Date: Fri, 14 Feb 2003 18:35:29 +0000
> From: His Highness <the_emperor99@hotmail.com>
> To: the_emperor99@hotmail.com
> Subject: [sacdrama] Fwd: Wake Up Call to the Scene

> From: Syd Gris <sydg@earthlink.net>
> To: <save@ourdancescene.com>
> Subject: Wake Up Call to the Scene
> Date: Wed, 12 Feb 2003 12:55:18 -0800
>
> I'm sending out this e mail to my friends and concerned people in the dance
> music scene, in the hopes of getting people's help spreading the word about
> what's going on.
>
> What's going on is the dance music scene is slowly but surely under attack.
> It is under attack by those that see no distinction between the people who
> do illegal drugs (which exist in every music, art, and cultural scene) and
> the dance music scene itself.  The last couple of years has seen the closure
> of many great clubs such as Twilo in NYC and Buzz in DC.  Just this past
> weekend the NY Police shut down two major clubs there, Exit and Sound
> Factory because of drug use they saw and buys they were involved in.
>
> On the same weekend here in SF, undercover police were at 1015 Folsom, DNA
> Lounge, and other commercial venues, as well as even underground parties
> they would have had to go through some trouble to locate.  In every party
> it's the same.  Normal looking party go-er asks people in the party if they
> can buy any illegal drugs, usually ecstasy.  In some cases, naive person may
> try and help this person out, only to be busted later.  It's happening every
> weekend.  They may not make a bust every time, but they are gathering data
> and contacts to make bigger arrests later and make a case to shut down our
> favorite spots to go dancing and hear music.
>
> We all know we can't stop people from making individual decisions about what
> they choose to do.  But we can spread the word amongst our friends that this
> is happening, and we need to be aware of it.
>
> If someone in a club or party asks you if you know where to get illegal
> drugs, do us all a favor.  Tell them YES, wait right here, and then go
> inform security so they can be thrown out of the party immediately.  You may
> ruin someone's night just trying to have fun, but obviously that's well
> worth protecting our scene.
>
> Make no mistake, the police are trying to shut down venues where electronic
> dance music is played.  They are doing this because of the actions of a
> minority of the people that come to the parties, and it's jeopardizing all
> of us.  We in the scene know it is a positive movement, bringing people from
> many different walks of life together to connect and share.  We must not from
> many different walks of life together to connect and share.  We must not
> just assume everything is going to be OK, it will not be unless we make it
> so.
>
> Please spread the word, and help save the scene.
>
> Thanks,
>
> Syd Gris
>
>

> >

> >MIGHT HELP US CLUB EMPLOYEES AND MANAGEMENT KEEP THOSE UNDESIRABLE AND EVIL
> >PEOPLE WHO JUST MIGHT RUIN IT FOR "ALL OF US" OUT OF "OUR" PARTIES.


> Date: Fri, 14 Feb 2003 10:53:49 -0800
> From: Jimmy Zimms <jimmyzimms@hotmail.com>
>
> The nice bit in this person's email was the point that if someone asks you
> for drugs REPORT THEM!
>
> Too many times emails and pleas like this resort to subjective points and
> not concrete realities.
>
> Morally, drug use is a personal choice but this is not about
> coulda/shoulda situations. This is about the law and the realities of law
> enforcement. S1 Drug are illegal, period. IMHO opinion this is an issue
> that the government has no right to legislate but that does not change the
> point that possessing them, consuming them, assisting in their trafficking
> IS ILLEGAL.
>
> I do believe that the DEA and local law enforcement agencies have focused
> too much engery into busting small time users (on the streets as well as
> the music scenes) than getting to the root of the problem. But the
> flagrant abuses of S1 laws and frequent cases of underage overdoeses has
> resulted in this situation.
>
> If you don't believe the law(s) are right then do something about them:
> Write your representatives, register/vote as a Libertarian, spark public
> debate, attend rallies, etc. DO SOMETHING ABOUT IT! In the mean time
> prtect yourself, protect the people around you, protect your freedoms.

> Date: Fri, 14 Feb 2003 14:55:16 EST
> From: Sactoapr@aol.com
>
>         Now I know I've been out of things for a while now, but law
> enforcement is not going to change the views they have until there is a
> defiant change in the usage of illegal substances.
>
> I myself know that there are two different sides to the "scene." I was on the
> side hurting the image while I was going to events. The stronger side needs
> to stand up like said in a previous e-mail. Report anything that you see that
> doesn't belong, or that you wish to not have at an event.
>
> Don't think of law enforcement as trying to take peoples fun away. To be
> able to choose what club you want to go to is a great thing. We just have a
> job to do, that job is to up hold the laws, weather it be Sacramento County,
> SF or where ever it my be. Our goal is to prevent people from committing
> crimes. So do your part if you really believe in what you are doing, if not
> things are going to start coming down a lot harder.

> nothing to abridge the rights of anyone else?

> compounds) deemed by the government to have no "medical value".

On Wed, 19 Feb 2003, AndyW wrote:

>=20
> On Wed, 19 Feb 2003, georgeC wrote:
> -&e->For drum programming, the ReDrum is pretty awesome, definitely anoth=
er
>=20
> Redrum is like an MPC2000 (which I used to own) except with better
> sequencing.
>=20
> -&e->invaluable tool in the sequencer/sampler box.  The synths do,
> -&e->admittedly, have their anemic moments- and the stock patches are
> -&e->completely bunk.  However, the NN-XT is a pretty awesome sampler and=
 is
> -&e->exceedingly quick to work with.
>=20
> -&e->Being a hardware sequencer junkie, I must say that I actually dig
> -&e->Reason's sequencer- it reminds me of Vision in a way, which is a
> -&e->program I miss.  I'm really not all that into the
>=20
> I was gonna say that.  Once you learn it well, it reminded me of pro24 (a
> product that later became cubase) or vision.  Copy management, editing,
> and all that are reasonably powerful and really easy to learn assuming
> YOU READ THE FUCKING MANUAL.
>=20
> Some people demand more control than Reason's sequencer (myself included a
> lot of the time, esp when making the basic rhythym of a track... or Chris
> Jackson who is so meticulous about timing that I wig out when we work on
> tracks together cuz he'll just be zoomed in on two notes and moving them
> around a nanometer back and forth at full zoom to get the swing down
> perfect)
>=20
> -&e->Logic/Cubase/Performer thing..  For my stuff, I'm just trying to
> -&e->capture what's played, and have decent playback timing.  A good swing
> -&e->algorithm is important, too.  Reason seems to have better timing than
> -&e->most seq/midi interface/synth setups, and I'm thinking that may be
> -&e->because the sounds are generated internally and thus may be quicker =
to
> -&e->respond.
>=20
> My gripe with reason is that tight timing starts to fail you if you use a
> lot of in line effects.  I don't think the sequencer 'plays ahead' to
> compensate for the latency caused by some of the effects... and you can't
> impose a playback 'compensation' delay at the per track level.
>=20
> -&e->In any case, it gets a lot of use around here- I never end up finish=
ing
> -&e->in Reason, though- too limiting.  Most of my work is done with audio,
> -&e->and for that I use Pro Tools.  Reason's effects are pretty cool, and
> -&e->have that propellerhead sound..  ..but that's all they have.  After =
you
> -&e->use a couple of delays and verbs, there's just this.. this...
> -&e->REASONiness that jumps out at you, which can be good or bad.  For
> -&e->grittier music, it's generally too clean, too.. um.. teutonic
> -&e->sounding..  Or something.
>=20
> http://www.saturn5.com/andy/esc-overall-rmx-portion.aif
>=20
> I'll throw this in for anybody who doubts it's ability to get gritty
> sounds.  This segment is a full resolution fragment of a remix I did for
> ESC's Overall (a tasty little uptempo number lying on the fringe between
> techno and hardcore).  Ed sent me the track in Reason format, and not
> having ever used it to really do a track, I decided this was as good a
> time as any to try my hand at it.
>=20
> I picked a couple sounds I liked from the original composition, sample
> raided a couple others (just opened them up in Peak and took little cuts,
> then enveloped them so they'd sound like drums) and added a couple little
> shrill squealy thing with the Maelstrom synth and slapped the drums I cut
> up into ReDrum.  For a little rhythmic inspiration, I also 'stole' the
> timing from a classic loop I had here (opening theme to Hawaii-Five-0
> slowed down a bit) by importing it as a *.rex file and then bouncing the
> rex's timing to the sequencer, and using that sequence to trigger a
> different rex loop by changing what instrument that seq track was assigned
> to (taken from the original ESC arrangement, get it?).
>=20
> Only post processing was loading the exported file output into Peak and
> running Waves' L1 processor on it in order to up the levels a tad.
>=20
> Is it the next dancefloor anthem?  Doubtful.  It sounds like Drop Bass
> Network vs. Aphex Twin, but it's what I was in the mood to make at the
> moment and I'm generally pleased with the results.
>=20
> I think the reason a lot of tracks that are done in Reason sound 'off' is
> because a lot of novice producers use Reason... and more seasoned
> producers are more familiar with analog mixer based setups where things
> work a certain way (for example, in Reason *enabling* the EQs on the
> mixer, or carelessly routing effects without making sure they're not
> sending back the same signal to the mixer causes smear in the form of
> phase error and very short delays causing all sorts of problems... ).
>=20
> In the end, you can do a hell of a lot more with it than say an 808 and a
> 303... it's a lot cheaper and a lot easier to use for most stuff.  For my
> work I prefer Logic and the mix of fruity hardware and software I've got
> here... but it's a great quick arrangement tool as well as a great way of
> getting loops together.
>=20
> Hell, I'd be down if anybody else is to do an SFR MP3 compilation of
> remixes of each others' original work... any takers?  Maybe even get
> Hyperreal to host it as a downloadable community perk?  If we use Reason
> as a base format, we could just assign works to remixers and have tracks
> ready inside a couple weeks.  Then the album as a full length cd could be
> sold to help support Hyperreal.org online (containing the original and
> remixed versions).
>=20
> andyw
>=20
>=20
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>=20
--

g> On Wed, 19 Feb 2003, AndyW wrote:

>> 
>> On Wed, 19 Feb 2003, georgeC wrote:
>> -&e->For drum programming, the ReDrum is pretty awesome, definitely another
>> 
>> Redrum is like an MPC2000 (which I used to own) except with better
>> sequencing.
>> 
>> -&e->invaluable tool in the sequencer/sampler box.  The synths do,
>> -&e->admittedly, have their anemic moments- and the stock patches are
>> -&e->completely bunk.  However, the NN-XT is a pretty awesome sampler and is
>> -&e->exceedingly quick to work with.
>> 
>> -&e->Being a hardware sequencer junkie, I must say that I actually dig
>> -&e->Reason's sequencer- it reminds me of Vision in a way, which is a
>> -&e->program I miss.  I'm really not all that into the
>> 
>> I was gonna say that.  Once you learn it well, it reminded me of pro24 (a
>> product that later became cubase) or vision.  Copy management, editing,
>> and all that are reasonably powerful and really easy to learn assuming
>> YOU READ THE FUCKING MANUAL.
>> 
>> Some people demand more control than Reason's sequencer (myself included a
>> lot of the time, esp when making the basic rhythym of a track... or Chris
>> Jackson who is so meticulous about timing that I wig out when we work on
>> tracks together cuz he'll just be zoomed in on two notes and moving them
>> around a nanometer back and forth at full zoom to get the swing down
>> perfect)
>> 
>> -&e->Logic/Cubase/Performer thing..  For my stuff, I'm just trying to
>> -&e->capture what's played, and have decent playback timing.  A good swing
>> -&e->algorithm is important, too.  Reason seems to have better timing than
>> -&e->most seq/midi interface/synth setups, and I'm thinking that may be
>> -&e->because the sounds are generated internally and thus may be quicker to
>> -&e->respond.
>> 
>> My gripe with reason is that tight timing starts to fail you if you use a
>> lot of in line effects.  I don't think the sequencer 'plays ahead' to
>> compensate for the latency caused by some of the effects... and you can't
>> impose a playback 'compensation' delay at the per track level.
>> 
>> -&e->In any case, it gets a lot of use around here- I never end up finishing
>> -&e->in Reason, though- too limiting.  Most of my work is done with audio,
>> -&e->and for that I use Pro Tools.  Reason's effects are pretty cool, and
>> -&e->have that propellerhead sound..  ..but that's all they have.  After you
>> -&e->use a couple of delays and verbs, there's just this.. this...
>> -&e->REASONiness that jumps out at you, which can be good or bad.  For
>> -&e->grittier music, it's generally too clean, too.. um.. teutonic
>> -&e->sounding..  Or something.
>> 
>> http://www.saturn5.com/andy/esc-overall-rmx-portion.aif
>> 
>> I'll throw this in for anybody who doubts it's ability to get gritty
>> sounds.  This segment is a full resolution fragment of a remix I did for
>> ESC's Overall (a tasty little uptempo number lying on the fringe between
>> techno and hardcore).  Ed sent me the track in Reason format, and not
>> having ever used it to really do a track, I decided this was as good a
>> time as any to try my hand at it.
>> 
>> I picked a couple sounds I liked from the original composition, sample
>> raided a couple others (just opened them up in Peak and took little cuts,
>> then enveloped them so they'd sound like drums) and added a couple little
>> shrill squealy thing with the Maelstrom synth and slapped the drums I cut
>> up into ReDrum.  For a little rhythmic inspiration, I also 'stole' the
>> timing from a classic loop I had here (opening theme to Hawaii-Five-0
>> slowed down a bit) by importing it as a *.rex file and then bouncing the
>> rex's timing to the sequencer, and using that sequence to trigger a
>> different rex loop by changing what instrument that seq track was assigned
>> to (taken from the original ESC arrangement, get it?).
>> 
>> Only post processing was loading the exported file output into Peak and
>> running Waves' L1 processor on it in order to up the levels a tad.
>> 
>> Is it the next dancefloor anthem?  Doubtful.  It sounds like Drop Bass
>> Network vs. Aphex Twin, but it's what I was in the mood to make at the
>> moment and I'm generally pleased with the results.
>> 
>> I think the reason a lot of tracks that are done in Reason sound 'off' is
>> because a lot of novice producers use Reason... and more seasoned
>> producers are more familiar with analog mixer based setups where things
>> work a certain way (for example, in Reason *enabling* the EQs on the
>> mixer, or carelessly routing effects without making sure they're not
>> sending back the same signal to the mixer causes smear in the form of
>> phase error and very short delays causing all sorts of problems... ).
>> 
>> In the end, you can do a hell of a lot more with it than say an 808 and a
>> 303... it's a lot cheaper and a lot easier to use for most stuff.  For my
>> work I prefer Logic and the mix of fruity hardware and software I've got
>> here... but it's a great quick arrangement tool as well as a great way of
>> getting loops together.
>> 
>> Hell, I'd be down if anybody else is to do an SFR MP3 compilation of
>> remixes of each others' original work... any takers?  Maybe even get
>> Hyperreal to host it as a downloadable community perk?  If we use Reason
>> as a base format, we could just assign works to remixers and have tracks
>> ready inside a couple weeks.  Then the album as a full length cd could be
>> sold to help support Hyperreal.org online (containing the original and
>> remixed versions).
>> 
>> andyw

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Date: Wed, 19 Feb 2003 23:41:50 -0800 (PST)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: DeezzerRec@aol.com

In-Reply-To: <1c8.5591580.2b85b81e@aol.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid


Dominic,

Are you a friggin tool or what?

When the world needed another progressive trance act like I need another
testicle, you were there, banging the trance, riding the trend.  Get off
your high horse and play nice.

I didn't say that Reason is the end all be all, in fact I said that I use
other software when I have a choice.  But just like real music can be made
on a machine rather than some human playing devices of wood and brass...
so can an electronic musician work out their sound on just about any
viable piece of gear.  And reason is, despite some serious shortcomings, a
very economical and viable piece of virtual gear capable of a wide
pallete of sounds and possiblities.

Nothing else will get a studio started faster with more potential for less
money.  Sure, tools like Acid, Reason, and Live will be used to generate
piles and piles of absolute shit, as were the 808, 909, 303, Alpha Juno,
Jupiter 8, OBX, Fender Stratocaster, Marine Band Harmonica, etc before
them.  I have a complete studio with piles of synths, samplers, effects,
etc... but the question was WHAT SOFTWARE SHOULD THIS PERSON GET STARTEE
WITH not "where is Reflector playing next and could you please throw in a
jab while you're at it".

donkey.
andyw

On Wed, 19 Feb 2003 DeezzerRec@aol.com wrote:
-&e->Expression is limited with one group of mathematicians...electronic music is
-&e->already criticized for it all sounding the same, and Reason helps reassure
-&e->this.
-&e->
-&e->Get Real Synthesizers...
-&e->Different Companies with different mathematicians...
-&e->
-&e->and when you have real synthesizers, you can play it out live too, like
-&e->Reflector will at the Agenda Louge, 10:30 March 7th....email for glist...
-&e->
-&e->

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: TECHNO on An Epiphany Of Sound tomorrow. (fwd)

Right now is the time for another edition of An Epiphany Of Sound.
This week is Lisa Fox, bringing you the beats from minimal techno, to
electro, to techouse, to straight techno.  She promises to be nice to
your ears, unless you call in begging for a aural spanking.

Remember, we're on every Thur. from 9a-Noon Pacific at 90.1 FM and
online at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu

Later.

-- 
"An Epiphany of Sound" - 90.1 FM Thursdays from 9AM-Noon Pacific.
(Also on the web at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu/).  Playlists
and humor list archives at http://www.kzsu.org/~dougm

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

>From: gba <gba@ambreaks.com>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid
>Date: Wed, 19 Feb 2003 22:15:54 -0800
>
>incidently andy, i was thinking the same idea. we need an sfr compilation.
>i'd be interesting in organizing this, anyone else down?
>
>-xs
>
>On Wed, 19 Feb 2003, AndyW wrote:
>
> >
> > On Wed, 19 Feb 2003, georgeC wrote:
> > -&e->For drum programming, the ReDrum is pretty awesome, definitely 
>another
> >
> > Redrum is like an MPC2000 (which I used to own) except with better
> > sequencing.
> >
> > -&e->invaluable tool in the sequencer/sampler box.  The synths do,
> > -&e->admittedly, have their anemic moments- and the stock patches are
> > -&e->completely bunk.  However, the NN-XT is a pretty awesome sampler 
>and is
> > -&e->exceedingly quick to work with.
> >
> > -&e->Being a hardware sequencer junkie, I must say that I actually dig
> > -&e->Reason's sequencer- it reminds me of Vision in a way, which is a
> > -&e->program I miss.  I'm really not all that into the
> >
> > I was gonna say that.  Once you learn it well, it reminded me of pro24 
>(a
> > product that later became cubase) or vision.  Copy management, editing,
> > and all that are reasonably powerful and really easy to learn assuming
> > YOU READ THE FUCKING MANUAL.
> >
> > Some people demand more control than Reason's sequencer (myself included 
>a
> > lot of the time, esp when making the basic rhythym of a track... or 
>Chris
> > Jackson who is so meticulous about timing that I wig out when we work on
> > tracks together cuz he'll just be zoomed in on two notes and moving them
> > around a nanometer back and forth at full zoom to get the swing down
> > perfect)
> >
> > -&e->Logic/Cubase/Performer thing..  For my stuff, I'm just trying to
> > -&e->capture what's played, and have decent playback timing.  A good 
>swing
> > -&e->algorithm is important, too.  Reason seems to have better timing 
>than
> > -&e->most seq/midi interface/synth setups, and I'm thinking that may be
> > -&e->because the sounds are generated internally and thus may be quicker 
>to
> > -&e->respond.
> >
> > My gripe with reason is that tight timing starts to fail you if you use 
>a
> > lot of in line effects.  I don't think the sequencer 'plays ahead' to
> > compensate for the latency caused by some of the effects... and you 
>can't
> > impose a playback 'compensation' delay at the per track level.
> >
> > -&e->In any case, it gets a lot of use around here- I never end up 
>finishing
> > -&e->in Reason, though- too limiting.  Most of my work is done with 
>audio,
> > -&e->and for that I use Pro Tools.  Reason's effects are pretty cool, 
>and
> > -&e->have that propellerhead sound..  ..but that's all they have.  After 
>you
> > -&e->use a couple of delays and verbs, there's just this.. this...
> > -&e->REASONiness that jumps out at you, which can be good or bad.  For
> > -&e->grittier music, it's generally too clean, too.. um.. teutonic
> > -&e->sounding..  Or something.
> >
> > http://www.saturn5.com/andy/esc-overall-rmx-portion.aif
> >
> > I'll throw this in for anybody who doubts it's ability to get gritty
> > sounds.  This segment is a full resolution fragment of a remix I did for
> > ESC's Overall (a tasty little uptempo number lying on the fringe between
> > techno and hardcore).  Ed sent me the track in Reason format, and not
> > having ever used it to really do a track, I decided this was as good a
> > time as any to try my hand at it.
> >
> > I picked a couple sounds I liked from the original composition, sample
> > raided a couple others (just opened them up in Peak and took little 
>cuts,
> > then enveloped them so they'd sound like drums) and added a couple 
>little
> > shrill squealy thing with the Maelstrom synth and slapped the drums I 
>cut
> > up into ReDrum.  For a little rhythmic inspiration, I also 'stole' the
> > timing from a classic loop I had here (opening theme to Hawaii-Five-0
> > slowed down a bit) by importing it as a *.rex file and then bouncing the
> > rex's timing to the sequencer, and using that sequence to trigger a
> > different rex loop by changing what instrument that seq track was 
>assigned
> > to (taken from the original ESC arrangement, get it?).
> >
> > Only post processing was loading the exported file output into Peak and
> > running Waves' L1 processor on it in order to up the levels a tad.
> >
> > Is it the next dancefloor anthem?  Doubtful.  It sounds like Drop Bass
> > Network vs. Aphex Twin, but it's what I was in the mood to make at the
> > moment and I'm generally pleased with the results.
> >
> > I think the reason a lot of tracks that are done in Reason sound 'off' 
>is
> > because a lot of novice producers use Reason... and more seasoned
> > producers are more familiar with analog mixer based setups where things
> > work a certain way (for example, in Reason *enabling* the EQs on the
> > mixer, or carelessly routing effects without making sure they're not
> > sending back the same signal to the mixer causes smear in the form of
> > phase error and very short delays causing all sorts of problems... ).
> >
> > In the end, you can do a hell of a lot more with it than say an 808 and 
>a
> > 303... it's a lot cheaper and a lot easier to use for most stuff.  For 
>my
> > work I prefer Logic and the mix of fruity hardware and software I've got
> > here... but it's a great quick arrangement tool as well as a great way 
>of
> > getting loops together.
> >
> > Hell, I'd be down if anybody else is to do an SFR MP3 compilation of
> > remixes of each others' original work... any takers?  Maybe even get
> > Hyperreal to host it as a downloadable community perk?  If we use Reason
> > as a base format, we could just assign works to remixers and have tracks
> > ready inside a couple weeks.  Then the album as a full length cd could 
>be
> > sold to help support Hyperreal.org online (containing the original and
> > remixed versions).
> >
> > andyw
> >
> >
> > ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> > To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> > For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
> >

andy.

I was stating my opinion on the subject.
"just get reason and acid" would be objected by most people in the industry.  
Sure there is everything there, but that everything all has that "reason" 
sound.  The way you get out of this is to have different synths. 

You seem to attack me as if you have hate in your heart.  Sorry I'm not 
living in your world, this is not your world, it is ours, our sfraves.org, it 
is our electronic music...

You also mentioned I may have been riding with the trend...if I was riding 
with the trend I would've been a DJ, I took it one step further and did it 
live.  And if all of this is a trend, the trend is over, and I should 
stop...but I am still doing it.  So you obviously don't know me.

andy says:
> Copy management, editing,
> and all that are reasonably powerful and really easy to learn assuming
> YOU READ THE FUCKING MANUAL.

(the scene: a lawn in Oregon. cloudy skies. Andy and Giles are sitting in
lawn chairs. Andy appears to be asleep. Giles is talking to somebody.)

Giles: Dude, the Korg Prophecy, it's amazing, but I can't deal with the
manuals, there's like the little manual and the big manual, it's like, the
beginner manual and the advanced manual, the operations manual and the sound
design manual, I mean, this keyboard is cool, the sounds are incredible, but
it's just so damn complicated, I wouldn't even read one manual, unless they
did it as a comic book, but this thing has two manuals, and I just can't
deal with two different manuals--

Andy: MANUALS?!

(Andy roars to life from an apparent coma, knocking over three chairs, two
tents, and a bong. In the background comes the sound of a woman screaming
"What's that thing?" and her friends reassuring her, "It's just Andy." Giles
cowers before the awakened beast.)

Andy: Manuals?

Giles: Manuals.

Andy: Did you say manuals?!

Giles: No.

Andy: Derrick May didn't use manuals! Juan Atkins didn't use manuals!

Giles: Uh...

Andy: Manuals!

(Andy grunts, falls over, and lapses back into unconsciousness.)

> Hell, I'd be down if anybody else is to do an SFR MP3 compilation of
> remixes of each others' original work... any takers?

um. can I use Acid?


Giles

"An Epiphany of Sound" - 90.1 FM Thursdays from 9AM-Noon Pacific.
(Also on the web at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu/).  Playlists

From sfraves-return-99042-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Feb 20 19:25:24 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-99042-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 93020 invoked by uid 1103); 20 Feb 2003 19:25:24 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 92841 invoked from network); 20 Feb 2003 19:25:22 -0000
Message-ID: <20030220192521.32308.qmail@web41110.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 20 Feb 2003 11:25:21 -0800 (PST)
From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <F172kK5LqN33HFnwpGR000056fd@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] compilation contemplation (was: just get Reason and Acid)


> >From: gba <gba@ambreaks.com>
> >To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> >Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid
> >Date: Wed, 19 Feb 2003 22:15:54 -0800
> >
> >incidently andy, i was thinking the same idea. we
> >need an sfr compilation.
> >i'd be interesting in organizing this, anyone else
> >down?


i produced the second compilation album for the
SoCal-Raves list, "SCR.COMP.002", and it was a lot of
expense, hassle and hard work.  honestly, i had fun
doing it and i'd be more than happy to lend advice to
anyone interested.  

here's some press i got about the album if you want to
read about it: 
http://www.ocweekly.com/ink/02/02/music-asch.php

<BSP>
better still, if you want to buy one, you can pick 'em
up from http://www.pureacidmixtapes.com  - just type
in "SCR Comp.002" in the search field (without the
quotes).
</BSP>

Licensing of tracks, artwork, professional printing,
mastering, replication and packaging for a 1000 unit
run (which is usually the minimum for replication) is
going to cost you somewhere in the $3.5k - $4.5k
range, depending on how good your contacts are and how
cheap they'll work.

it isn't all milk & honey, though.  in the end i wound
up with a lot of CDs that just won't sell, even though
the music on them is really good.  when i tried
marketing the CDs here on SFR, i got royally bitched
out and told that i should be giving them away for
free.

so, i'd say that if you've got $4k to blow, go for it.
 if not, just collect the tracks, put 'em up as MP3s
on a website for free and call it a day.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] compilation contemplation (was: just get Reason and
 Acid)

>so, i'd say that if you've got $4k to blow, go for it. if not, just
>collect the tracks, put 'em up as MP3s on a website for free and call it
>a day.

No reason to spend 4 grand on a run of CD's - you can get excellent
quality professional dupes done for $1.70 apiece (for cd sleeves) or $2.50
apiece (for jewel cases) for a run of 1000 cds... which is a lot of cd's.
That includes on-disk 4-color silkscreening, and full-color packaging
artwork, mind you.

For a list like SFR, seems to me that a few hundred discs is plenty.
Or maybe get hyperreal to host an disk image, MP3's, tracklistings, and
PDF files of cover artwork so people can make their own physical
artifacts. :D

I'd be happy to help. Not a musician.

-mike.

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 2333 invoked from network); 20 Feb 2003 20:56:24 -0000
Message-ID: <20030220205622.71647.qmail@web41201.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 20 Feb 2003 12:56:22 -0800 (PST)
From: elias smith <elias_smith@yahoo.com>
To: larry melman <whoosenation@hotmail.com>, resourcemusic_usa@yahoo.com,
  thockin@hockin.org
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <F267FDCjoDUS84zr4T900004767@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid

Reason, Rewire, Cubase/Logic, outboard effects or
VST/DirectX/Native plug-ins. Reason's "flat" sound is
something to take into consideration but there's these
little tricks known in music recording called
PROCESSING and MASTERING.

Seeming as how Reason is primarily sample based, you
can import your own samples, run it rewire into Waves
plug-ins for instance, or an outboard compressor like
a Focusrite or even a shitty Alesis 3630, and I
guarantee the common candy raver wouldn't know the
difference. 
This also allows you to sequence Reason with your
favorite outboard synths like a Virus or Nord, or any
synth or drum machine plug-in. 

I find myself using Reason mainly as a Redrum plug-in
for Cubase, as I find there are better plug-in
samplers and synths out there than the Subtractor or
NN-19. I like the Redrum because it is extremely
versatile and easy to use and sounds 200% better when
bussed through my Aphex and Focusrite. Granted the
Redrum is a sampler and you can do the same things
with Battery or any sampler, it's too useful and easy
that I can't pass it up and you can open up ten
Redrums if you please. Pretty much, Reason has become
my main drum machine with the combination of external
DSP.
Why pass a good thing just because people refer to it
as a "toy"?
-g

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] War is a force that gives us meaning

There was an incredible broadcast sunday atfernoon on KQED, with a speech
by Christopher Hedges, in which he contrasts the myth of war - that it
benefits society by providing a shared quest and common suffering - with
the realities of chaos and destruction that he has witnessed firsthand as
a war correspondent in places like Sarajevo and elsewhere, and the
post-war emotional havoc created in the lives of the soldiers who fight.

He is a slightly stilted speaker, which to my ear made him sound more
/real/ and less polished or calculated than your typical pundit. Really a
great speech, which is reproduced here in realaudio (sorry) format:

	http://streams.wgbh.org/forum/forum.php?lecture_id=1123

-mike.

From sfraves-return-99051-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Feb 20 21:28:40 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-99051-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 18712 invoked by uid 1103); 20 Feb 2003 21:28:39 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 18698 invoked from network); 20 Feb 2003 21:28:37 -0000
Message-ID: <20030220212835.50644.qmail@web12301.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 20 Feb 2003 13:28:35 -0800 (PST)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: maestro@dv8.org, Sactoapr@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org,
  sacraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Re: [sacdrama] County Sheriff (was: Wake Up Call to the Scene)

Try taking off your blinders.  You seem to have "the law" confused with "what
is right".  They are NOT one and the same.  In fact, they are, all too
frequently, entirely different.

You should go back and re-read the works of Henry David Thoreau.  He's a far
more eloquent writer than I, and any summary I could write would not do him
justice.  But the general point he makes is that when the law is WRONG, not
only are you justified in breaking it, but you have, in fact, a moral
OBLIGATION to do so.

Now, I'm not saying that anyong should feel *obligated* to drop E at a party. 
That'd be rathar stupid a claim for me to make.  And honestly, many of the
parties I've been to of late would have been better experiences if there *were*
less drug use.  But that's not for ME to decide.  That's not for YOU to decide.
 That's not a decision for ANYONE, except for the individual who is making the
decision wether or not to use any given substance.  And NO ONE has ANY moral
right to interject themselves into that individual's decision.

The laws, drug-related or not, that are used to suppress the rave scene are
WRONG.  (Hell... drug laws in general, but that's a tangental issue.)  And
respect is not a given, it is earned or lost.  As such, I HAVE no respect for
the people who write/enforce those laws.  It is NOT a defence.  "I was just
following orders/the law" does NOT excuse their behavior.  This has been
established as a precept of civilized society for the better part of a century
now.  Those people who hide behind that shield deserve NOTHING more than every
possible contempt and loathing.

What it all boils down to is that WE are *NOT* the ones in the wrong.  The cops
are.  As such, THEY have the moral obligation to change THEIR behavior, not us
or ours.  Maybe it's hopelessly naieve and unpratical to expect the police to
develop a sence of what is right and wrong, and to cease infringing on the
natural rights of the individual.  But that IS the way it's SUPPOSED to be. 
And we should NEVER lose sight of that.


cya,
john

http://taxes.yahoo.com/

X-URL: http://www.ambreaks.com

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] sfr music compilation

ok i think we're getting the ball rolling with this, thusfar the ideas i've
had and seen discussed are:
1) free mp3/iso or dupe-cd
2) no post-production engineer, straight from artist to cd.

some rules for the comp?
1) must be original work from a person on sfr.
2) can be a remix of other artists on sfr.
3) can be done using any system, so long as versions being submitted for a
   remix are in a easily re-rendered form.

so, a cd of only sfr artists or remixes of sfr artists work by other sfr
artists.

-xs

>

>1) must be original work from a person on sfr.

>3) can be done using any system, so long as versions being submitted for a

>

Joining me tonight on the decks for our inaugural Thursday is hip hop party rocker DJ Ro aka Roger Premo - bringing the finest classics and some of the best "left" coast underground selections around.

thats Ghett $et at the Skylark, 3089 Valencia @16th, from 6-?
happy hour is 5-8 with $2 pints on tap and bargain well drinks too.
peace,
DJ Baby Daddy
http://ghettoblasta.net
...

Also tonight! Bfamily takes over at the Top...
DJs Jay Walker & Joe Encarnacion, along with an all-new live PA set by Jack 
Buser should be enough to keep you amused for the night and well after.

From sfraves-return-99096-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Feb 21 00:56:15 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-99096-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
