list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 29119 invoked from network); 21 Feb 2003 00:56:10 -0000
Date: Thu, 20 Feb 2003 16:55:05 -0800 (PST)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: _ fable _ <fable4our@hotmail.com>
cc: gba@ambreaks.com, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <F136ftWmF5LV69ArTCS00006821@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0302201549340.21812-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] sfr music compilation


Some ideas I ran over...

* They must be sample clean.  No tracks using samples' of other artists'
works may be entered.  Sorry, but we can't afford to put SFR or Hyperreal
in any sort of intellectual property liability.

* Must be unique to this compilation (not a track existing elsewhere,
owned by a label or publishing house, etc).

* I'd like to release this as a GPL like license (does anybody have any
info on that offical 'free' music license).  Meaning that it can be used
wherever, whenever by anybody, but they gotta drop your name and give
proper credit.

* Must be submitted in full resolution format.  I'd like to seriously
consider at least a CD-R pool that could honor requests for non-compressed
CD's to be made available, with proceeds (if any) going to Hyperreal.
There are professional services that can do as needed CD-R runs with
pretty labels and all that.

* Mastering should be available for those tracks needing it.  I could do
this, I also happen to know a grumpy techno guy that does *great* work
(Chris?).

* To be eligible to do a remix, you have to submit a track.  If you submit
a track, keep individual sounds you used in the production available
should someone want to do a remix and wants chunkage.

* I'd like to arbitrate in the case of too many tracks coming in.  My main
criteria would be : representation of genres in a way that is
representative of SFR's participants, quality of production, and lastly
how much I like the tune.  Although I am a very opinionated and vocal
member of this list, I love a lot of different styles of music, and like
to think I'm very fair when put in a judging capacity.  I am really
*hoping* to see at least two trance tracks, one hardcore track, one techno
track, one breaks track, one jungle track, one 2-step track, two house
tracks, one electro track, one progressive track, an ambient or IDM track
(and yes, at some point I have danced to all of the above... even ambient
which scares some people).  There's a shitload of really serious talent on
this list, and my intention would be to not bias anything to my personal
agenda but to represent the diversity of audio creativity on this list as
a form of education to those who think we're all clones.  If you have an
issue with this, we could take the arguement to the SFR list where I'd
state my case and you yours and do a web poll for results.

* Tracks should be less than 5 minutes.  I'd like a full CD of music from
many artists.

* What's in it for you?  Hyperreal is a major resource for data about
dance music events.  Having your name on this compilation would be a good
thing.  If you submit a track that doesn't end up on the compilation, you
still have your dope track.  No harm, no foul.

* How would it get distributed (mp3)?  We could create an MP3.com 'artist'
called SFRaves and do it that way with links from SFR, or have them on SFR
outright, or link them to someone that is confident their server can
handle whatever bandwidth is generated quickly for a period of one year.

* How it would get manufactured/distributed locally?  I could foot the
inital bill for a small CD-R run, we could pool out either cd
manufacturing or paying in $20 for each artist, etc.  I'd perfer not to
worry about this until other areas of this are good to go.  It doesn't
cost a thing to get the idea going and see what the artists + sfr list
decide down the road.

* How would it be promoted?  Each artist could make cd copies available as
giveaways, site links, etc.  We could probably get a MP3 featured artist
if we wanna go that route and some press as a result of it being a
GNU-license release.

* What about the annoying list traffic for people who don't care?  We
could keep discussion about it on list with a unique subject line to make
life easy but still keep the general population of SFR informed, or create
a dedicated list for this subject with updates to SFR as we hit
milestones.

* What sorta of timeline are we talking about?  I'm thinking till April
10th for submissions, April 30th as a late day for remixes (seeing as
completed track would have to happen first *derf*) with a projected
release date of June 1st.

Sorry, in a past life I was a project manager...
andyw


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] ACID vs Cubase SX

So it's mentioned that the sequencer in ACID is pretty great.  4.0 seems 
to be the first version of ACID with an actual MIDI sequencer, and I was 
wondering what people's thoughts were on this sequencer compared to, 
say, Cubase SX?  Both have great audio engines, i know, and both have 
good effects, and are compatible with VST instruments/effects.  The new 
sequencer, however, I have no experience with, but if it's as functional 
and as well-interfaced as the one on Cubase, then I'm seriousely 
thinking of getting that at a better price, and with really great 
looping tools.  Plus, it should interface really well with SoundForge, 
my favourite sound editing program.  

Interested to hear any thoughts . . .
.:nomadic:/

Subject: Re: [sfraves] sfr music compilation

Maybe since it seems like a lot of tracks will be submitted this might be a
good or semi good idea. How about this; (the drumnbassarena.com did this for
a mix of original jungle tracks). Lets say we break it down to these
catagories: trance, house, techno, jungle, ambient+idm+dub+triphop. Then
each track with the producers name is put up under the the type of music
they spin with voting tabs. Listers can vote for a week. Must be a
registered SFR so you can only vote once. Then just par down the tracks from
there. You could even get a nice little SFR producers page outta that, and a
place for heads to get to know the producers, and finally show that some of
the dj's around here why they need to be a bit more APPRECIATED of the
excellent producers outta the bay.
-hakthedj

>> From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
>> To: _ fable _ <fable4our@hotmail.com>
>> CC: gba@ambreaks.com, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>> Subject: Re: [sfraves] sfr music compilation
>> Date: Thu, 20 Feb 2003 16:55:05 -0800 (PST)
>> 
>> 
>> Some ideas I ran over...
>> 
>> * They must be sample clean.  No tracks using samples' of other artists'
>> works may be entered.  Sorry, but we can't afford to put SFR or Hyperreal
>> in any sort of intellectual property liability.
>> 
>> * Must be unique to this compilation (not a track existing elsewhere,
>> owned by a label or publishing house, etc).
>> 
>> * I'd like to release this as a GPL like license (does anybody have any
>> info on that offical 'free' music license).  Meaning that it can be used
>> wherever, whenever by anybody, but they gotta drop your name and give
>> proper credit.
>> 
>> * Must be submitted in full resolution format.  I'd like to seriously
>> consider at least a CD-R pool that could honor requests for non-compressed
>> CD's to be made available, with proceeds (if any) going to Hyperreal.
>> There are professional services that can do as needed CD-R runs with
>> pretty labels and all that.
>> 
>> * Mastering should be available for those tracks needing it.  I could do
>> this, I also happen to know a grumpy techno guy that does *great* work
>> (Chris?).
>> 
>> * To be eligible to do a remix, you have to submit a track.  If you submit
>> a track, keep individual sounds you used in the production available
>> should someone want to do a remix and wants chunkage.
>> 
>> * I'd like to arbitrate in the case of too many tracks coming in.  My main
>> criteria would be : representation of genres in a way that is
>> representative of SFR's participants, quality of production, and lastly
>> how much I like the tune.  Although I am a very opinionated and vocal
>> member of this list, I love a lot of different styles of music, and like
>> to think I'm very fair when put in a judging capacity.  I am really
>> *hoping* to see at least two trance tracks, one hardcore track, one techno
>> track, one breaks track, one jungle track, one 2-step track, two house
>> tracks, one electro track, one progressive track, an ambient or IDM track
>> (and yes, at some point I have danced to all of the above... even ambient
>> which scares some people).  There's a shitload of really serious talent on
>> this list, and my intention would be to not bias anything to my personal
>> agenda but to represent the diversity of audio creativity on this list as
>> a form of education to those who think we're all clones.  If you have an
>> issue with this, we could take the arguement to the SFR list where I'd
>> state my case and you yours and do a web poll for results.
>> 
>> * Tracks should be less than 5 minutes.  I'd like a full CD of music from
>> many artists.
>> 
>> * What's in it for you?  Hyperreal is a major resource for data about
>> dance music events.  Having your name on this compilation would be a good
>> thing.  If you submit a track that doesn't end up on the compilation, you
>> still have your dope track.  No harm, no foul.
>> 
>> * How would it get distributed (mp3)?  We could create an MP3.com 'artist'
>> called SFRaves and do it that way with links from SFR, or have them on SFR
>> outright, or link them to someone that is confident their server can
>> handle whatever bandwidth is generated quickly for a period of one year.
>> 
>> * How it would get manufactured/distributed locally?  I could foot the
>> inital bill for a small CD-R run, we could pool out either cd
>> manufacturing or paying in $20 for each artist, etc.  I'd perfer not to
>> worry about this until other areas of this are good to go.  It doesn't
>> cost a thing to get the idea going and see what the artists + sfr list
>> decide down the road.
>> 
>> * How would it be promoted?  Each artist could make cd copies available as
>> giveaways, site links, etc.  We could probably get a MP3 featured artist
>> if we wanna go that route and some press as a result of it being a
>> GNU-license release.
>> 
>> * What about the annoying list traffic for people who don't care?  We
>> could keep discussion about it on list with a unique subject line to make
>> life easy but still keep the general population of SFR informed, or create
>> a dedicated list for this subject with updates to SFR as we hit
>> milestones.
>> 
>> * What sorta of timeline are we talking about?  I'm thinking till April
>> 10th for submissions, April 30th as a late day for remixes (seeing as
>> completed track would have to happen first *derf*) with a projected
>> release date of June 1st.
>> 
>> Sorry, in a past life I was a project manager...
>> andyw
> 
>

I think another option could be to set up a producer page on Hyperreal, that 
people can upload their originals or remixes to.  Rather than having a 
predetermined set of songs people to download, they have their options of 
what to listen to.  And if somebody wants to have a new song posted, and 
currently have a song up, they should have to remove the older track to make 
room for the new one.  That helps keep the drive space down, and lets people 
hear what's new and current for that particular artist.  Just a thought...

----- Original Message -----=20
From: Schaefer, Susan C -ND=20
To: itswidow@hotmail.com=20
Sent: Thursday, February 20, 2003 8:55 AM
Subject: BayAreaRavers.com


Hey -=20

I work for Peter Jennings Productions documentary production company and =
I am trying to canvass the San Francisco Bay area to find any Ecstasy =
users who would be willing to go on camera and discuss positive =
experiences they have had with ecstasy. We are not looking to single out =
rave culture nor imply that ecstasy is synonymous with rave culture - as =
I completely understand that for most people it is about the music and =
not about the drugs. We will be shooting interviews in San Francisco on =
Sat, Feb 22 from approx. 10am-1pm.

We are looking for a wide demographic of people - young, old, rich, =
poor, black, white, yellow, brown, gay, straight, business man, guy on =
the street, urban, suburban - you get the idea. Ecstasy - like no other =
drug before it - is an incredibly democratic drug in that is not limited =
to one section of the population (as crack would be considered a "drug =
of the poor" and cocaine would be considered a "yuppie" drug). We are =
trying to represent this diversity of users in our documentary. But more =
importantly, we want to focus on the good experiences that people have =
with ecstasy - why they take it, how they feel it benefits their life, =
what sort of impact it has had on them and their circle of friends.=20

The documentary we are doing is not meant to be moral or political. It =
is simply taking a real approach to the drug and looking at why the =
government has reacted so badly to a drug that has, relatively speaking, =
few side effects and a great potential for therapeutic uses. This =
documentary is not promoting the use of ecstasy. But what we want to do =
is take a rational approach to drug use and say - look. People are going =
to use drugs. And there is a reason they are. Why - because it effects a =
lot of people's lives in a positive way. And here is this drug Ecstasy. =
In terms of drugs that are out there, it has relatively few side =
effects. So why has the government put it on the same level as crack and =
heroine? Why are there stiff legal penalties that are ruining people's =
lives and putting them in prison for mandatory minimum sentences? Why =
does the government throw so much money at scientists producing dubious =
brain scans who are attempting to demonize ecstasy? This is a drug that =
countless well respected psychiatrists have used with patients. They =
have praised this drug as a powerful tool to improve people's lives and =
help deal with psychological problems. There are many users out there =
who can talk intelligently and in a meaningful way about why ecstasy has =
been a positive experience for them (that's where you come in).=20

Anyway - that's generally the angle our documentary is taking. We are =
interviewing people like chemist Sasha Shulgin, Wade Hampton (wish FM), =
psychiatrists Ralph Metzner and George Greer, and have talked to the =
head of DanceSafe (who is familiar with our project). If you are =
interested in participating, please email me or give me a call so we can =
chat a little.  We hope for this to be a different kind of documentary, =
not one about anti-drug propaganda or one intent on demonizing rave =
culture. We hope that this will bring more honest views about Ecstasy to =
light.  Again, we will be shooting in San Francisco this coming Sat, Feb =
22nd from approx. 10am-1pm. If you think this would be appropriate to =
forward to members of your website or friends you may have, please do =
so.



Thank you,=20

Susan Schaefer=20
Peter Jennings Productions=20
New York, NY=20
212-456-5850=20
Susan.C.Schaefer.-nd@abc.com=20

------=_NextPart_000_001C_01C2D91D.30DA5850--

Susan's message has been circulating around - the general concensus mong
most people I know who've received it, is to ignore it. It's too risky to
talk to major newsmedia who are trying to appease you to go on-camera
talking about illegal acts, and IMHO the media have a long way to go
before they can be trusted to present balanced views on the drug war. ABC
is owned by Disney, the "family company", which should be a pretty major
indicator that they lack the incentive to present balanced views about e
use.

 Cheese <itswidow@hotmail.com> wrote:BayAreaRavers.comThis is DEFINITELY rave related!

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Schaefer, Susan C -ND 
To: itswidow@hotmail.com 
Sent: Thursday, February 20, 2003 8:55 AM
Subject: BayAreaRavers.com


Hey - 

I work for Peter Jennings Productions documentary production company and I am trying to canvass the San Francisco Bay area to find any Ecstasy users who would be willing to go on camera and discuss positive experiences they have had with ecstasy. We are not looking to single out rave culture nor imply that ecstasy is synonymous with rave culture - as I completely understand that for most people it is about the music and not about the drugs. We will be shooting interviews in San Francisco on Sat, Feb 22 from approx. 10am-1pm.

We are looking for a wide demographic of people - young, old, rich, poor, black, white, yellow, brown, gay, straight, business man, guy on the street, urban, suburban - you get the idea. Ecstasy - like no other drug before it - is an incredibly democratic drug in that is not limited to one section of the population (as crack would be considered a "drug of the poor" and cocaine would be considered a "yuppie" drug). We are trying to represent this diversity of users in our documentary. But more importantly, we want to focus on the good experiences that people have with ecstasy - why they take it, how they feel it benefits their life, what sort of impact it has had on them and their circle of friends. 

The documentary we are doing is not meant to be moral or political. It is simply taking a real approach to the drug and looking at why the government has reacted so badly to a drug that has, relatively speaking, few side effects and a great potential for therapeutic uses. This documentary is not promoting the use of ecstasy. But what we want to do is take a rational approach to drug use and say - look. People are going to use drugs. And there is a reason they are. Why - because it effects a lot of people's lives in a positive way. And here is this drug Ecstasy. In terms of drugs that are out there, it has relatively few side effects. So why has the government put it on the same level as crack and heroine? Why are there stiff legal penalties that are ruining people's lives and putting them in prison for mandatory minimum sentences? Why does the government throw so much money at scientists producing dubious brain scans who are attempting to demonize ecstasy? This is a drug that countless well respected psychiatrists have used with patients. They have praised this drug as a powerful tool to improve people's lives and help deal with psychological problems. There are many users out there who can talk intelligently and in a meaningful way about why ecstasy has been a positive experience for them (that's where you come in). 

Anyway - that's generally the angle our documentary is taking. We are interviewing people like chemist Sasha Shulgin, Wade Hampton (wish FM), psychiatrists Ralph Metzner and George Greer, and have talked to the head of DanceSafe (who is familiar with our project). If you are interested in participating, please email me or give me a call so we can chat a little. We hope for this to be a different kind of documentary, not one about anti-drug propaganda or one intent on demonizing rave culture. We hope that this will bring more honest views about Ecstasy to light. Again, we will be shooting in San Francisco this coming Sat, Feb 22nd from approx. 10am-1pm. If you think this would be appropriate to forward to members of your website or friends you may have, please do so.



Thank you, 

Susan Schaefer 
Peter Jennings Productions 
New York, NY 
212-456-5850 
Susan.C.Schaefer.-nd@abc.com 



---------------------------------
Do you Yahoo!?
Yahoo! Tax Center - forms, calculators, tips, and more

Subject: [sfraves] Resistance 002: DJ Tronic-Organized Chaos EP: Now Available! :)  bsp

Yes! Finally! After what seemed like a bit of an eternity, Resistance 
Recordings' 2nd release, DJ Tronic's "Organized Chaos EP" is NOW AVAILABLE! 
Here's a rundown about the release:

RES-002: DJ TRONIC - "ORGANIZED CHAOS EP" : *NEW RELEASE!*
     THE SECOND RELEASE FROM RESISTANCE RECORDINGS IS BROUGHT TO YOU AGAIN 
BY UP-AND-COMER DJ TRONIC. AFTER HIS "ANGER MANAGEMENT EP" SELLING QUICKLY 
ALL ACROSS THE USA, CANADA, AND EUROPE, WE HERE HAVE HIGH HOPES FOR WHAT WE 
FEEL IS SOME OF DJ TRONIC'S BEST WORK ALL PUT ON TO ONE RECORD... THE 
"ORGANIZED CHAOS EP". 4 TRACKS OF US HARD HOUSE AND HARDCORE MADNESS ARE THE 
SCORE HERE, SURE TO BRING THE PAIN AND GET THE PEOPLE UP AND MOVIN' ON ANY 
DANCEFLOOR! ALSO, MAKING HIS DEBUT APPEARANCE, PRODUCER CIRCLE K COMES 
CORRECT TO BANG OUT AN ABSOLUTELY SLAMMIN' REMIX OF DJ TRONIC'S "HARDCORE 
POWER"!


As with every release, we appreciate your support! To order the "Organized 
Chaos EP", please visit our website:

http://www.resistancerecordings.com -- and visit our ONLINE STORE. :)

RES-002: DJ TRONIC - "Organized Chaos EP" Audio Samples:

A1: Iced Cold: http://www.resistancerecordings.com/audio/icedcold.mp3
A2: Dull Disko Nutz: 
http://www.resistancerecordings.com/audio/dulldiskonutz.mp3
B1: Hardcore Power: 
http://www.resistancerecordings.com/audio/hardcorepower.mp3
B2: Hardcore Power (Circle K Remix): 
http://www.resistancerecordings.com/audio/hardcorepower_circle_k_remix.mp3

You can hear audio clips of this release, past releases, and of course 
future releases on our website!


Or, you can also purchase it online from some of these fine online 
retailers:

Majestic: http://www.majesticstore.com
PlanetXUSA: http://www.planetxusa.com
Phusion Records: http://www.phusionrecords.com

If you're located in the San Francisco Bay area, we ask that you purchase 
our releases from the following record stores:

Solid Grooves: Santa Clara
Skills DJ Workshop: Berkeley

Support your local record store!


We'd like to thank everyone for your continuing support of the Hard Beats! 
If you are looking for our records in your area, and don't see them in your 
local record shop, ask for them! If you have any questions, please don't 
hesitate to contact us: djtronic00@yahoo.com

Coming soon from Resistance Recordings USA:

RES-003: Get Up! EP: DJ Tronic & Valerie Sparks - March 2003
RES-004: Run for the Border EP: DJ Junkinx vs. DJ Tronic - May 2003
RES-005: Worse Case Scenerio: Circle K vs. DJ Tronic - July 2003

http://www.resistancerecordings.com

Hi Carlos,

There is Ravin Beats USA (based in LA)... SSU in Sacramento... then there is
also Pitched Up over in the Mid West...

Personally, i think that the track sounds more of an SSU track then either
Pitched Up or Ravin Beats...

but either way, you would get better feedback on the track by sending it to
either BayAreaHappycore@yahoogroups.com or happyusa@yahoogroups.com (both of
which you will have to subscribe to through www.yahoogroups.com)

hope that helps

Timothy
**Cheese**

Subject: RE: [sfraves] a letter from ABC to ME?!?!?!

At the same time though, it would be good to have positive
representation instead of people who do way too much and give it a bad
name just by being on the show.  Its just those who do it occasionally
are typically not going to want to go and broadcast it to the world.

I'd really like to see someone spin the angle about shyness and
nonacceptance in normal society and finding extasy and being able to
make friends and start feeling good about themselves for the first time,
preferably by someone who doesn't go overboard on it.

I'd do it but for me, the raves alone were enough at first to break me
out of my shell.  I din't know about extasy until about 4 years later
and although I've had positive expieriences, its not something I like
that much.

Susan's message has been circulating around - the general concensus mong
most people I know who've received it, is to ignore it. It's too risky
to talk to major newsmedia who are trying to appease you to go on-camera
talking about illegal acts, and IMHO the media have a long way to go
before they can be trusted to present balanced views on the drug war.
ABC is owned by Disney, the "family company", which should be a pretty
major indicator that they lack the incentive to present balanced views
about e use.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] a letter from ABC to ME?!?!?!

>I'd really like to see someone spin the angle about shyness and
>nonacceptance in normal society and finding extasy and being able to make
>friends and start feeling good about themselves for the first time,
>preferably by someone who doesn't go overboard on it.
>

>out of my shell.  I din't know about extasy until about 4 years later and
>although I've had positive expieriences, its not something I like that

I completely agree, having had much the same experience as you're
describing... I'm just not convinced that Peter Jennings should be the one
to tell the world. It sounds like thousands of people have received this
message - I was cc'ed along with every other e-mail address on the
viberation.com site, and people have posted to other lists I'm on with
copies of the letter - so I suspect that ABC is looking to get a broad
range of users to choose from. Your typical TV news segment on such a
topic might interview 2 or 3 individuals in-depth - with a large pool of
willing interviewees, they're free to pick the most whacked, fruitcake
wierdos available to kick up the ratings a bit.

I hate being a complete cynic, sometimes. :P

Subject: RE: [sfraves] a letter from ABC to ME?!?!?!


>I'd really like to see someone spin the angle about shyness and 
>nonacceptance in normal society and finding extasy and being able to 
>make friends and start feeling good about themselves for the first 
>time, preferably by someone who doesn't go overboard on it.
>
>I'd do it but for me, the raves alone were enough at first to break me 
>out of my shell.  I din't know about extasy until about 4 years later 
>and although I've had positive expieriences, its not something I like 
>that much.

I completely agree, having had much the same experience as you're
describing... I'm just not convinced that Peter Jennings should be the
one to tell the world. It sounds like thousands of people have received
this message - I was cc'ed along with every other e-mail address on the
viberation.com site, and people have posted to other lists I'm on with
copies of the letter - so I suspect that ABC is looking to get a broad
range of users to choose from. Your typical TV news segment on such a
topic might interview 2 or 3 individuals in-depth - with a large pool of
willing interviewees, they're free to pick the most whacked, fruitcake
wierdos available to kick up the ratings a bit.

I hate being a complete cynic, sometimes. :P

me feel a little more comfotable [rti could still send
the wrong stamper]!  i've been a little edgy ever
since Garth's Greyhound Label was shipped 300 of my
promos...he in turn stickered and put one sheets in
the records and sent them out to his disti's and dj's
as his newest release!  a few days later the mistake
was noticed by a distributor who knew what my next
release was and brought it to my attention!  a gave
garth a hard time for not checking the cat. number or
at least listening to the first one in the box [like i
normally do]!  I'll bet he does now...

Date: Fri, 21 Feb 2003 13:07:30 -0800
To: "Bryan Oley" <kandymanz@earthlink.net>, "Rayn" <acydrayn@hotmail.com>,
   "'Mike Migurski'" <mike@saturn5.com>, "'Cheese'" <itswidow@hotmail.com>
From: blindspot <blindspot@mac.com>
Cc: "'Argumentative Fools'" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] a letter from ABC to ME?!?!?!

I agree with those jaded souls who are perhaps suspicious about this 
email from ABC. Yet, there are millions of people in this country who 
have experienced ecstacy first hand and have a pretty good feeling 
about it over all.

Does their experience somehow not count as truth?

Of course there are the abusers who spoil it for the rest of us, but 
ANYTHING, not just illegal and relatively harmless drugs, can be 
abused and spoiled for the rest of us.

Yes it's true that ABC is owned by Disney, who also owns a shitload 
of other media outlets. But wasn't Disney relatively progressive on 
homosexual lifestyle issues in comparison to other large 
multinational corporations? Didn't this reflect in their TV show 
depictions, e.g. Ellen, etc.?

Is there a chance that Disney/ABC is going to try and progressively 
portray ecstacy use? Seems like somebody should send some questions 
back up thru Susan Schaefer like these:


* What is is ABC going to do with such interviews?

* What is ABC trying to accomplish?

* What is the timeline for the running of this documentary?

* What sort of guarantees can be obtained to prove that ABC will run 
a truly objective story?

* What kind of protections can ABC give to interviewees to prevent 
negative consequences to their cooperation?

* Will ABC be paying people to participate in this?


All in all it seems to good be true that a major media outlet would 
want depict the benign reality of ecstacy use without some hidden 
agenda.

Hope I'm not too jaded,

BS



At 09:36 -0800 2/21/03, Bryan Oley wrote:
>Its been spread among those of us at DanceSafe as well, we are kind of 50/50
>on it for one reason..
>
>Although ABC has been "ok" as far as their objectivity overall, this story
>seems to be just aching to be made into a media circus.. and since it
>appears well over 2000+ emails were sent out to various sources, up to and
>including people and orgs that have nothing to do with the Rave, Drug, or
>psychadelic scene.. it smacks of "we will take who we can get"
>
>So, the debate is on over if and who will take it.
>
>-B

>all.

>

>ANYTHING, not just illegal and relatively harmless drugs, can be abused and 
>spoiled for the rest of us.

>lifestyle issues in comparison to other large multinational corporations? 
>Didn't this reflect in their TV show depictions, e.g. Ellen, etc.?
>

>ecstacy use? Seems like somebody should send some questions back up thru 
>Susan Schaefer like these:
>
>
>* What is is ABC going to do with such interviews?
>
>* What is ABC trying to accomplish?
>
>* What is the timeline for the running of this documentary?
>
>* What sort of guarantees can be obtained to prove that ABC will run a 
>truly objective story?
>
>* What kind of protections can ABC give to interviewees to prevent negative 
>consequences to their cooperation?
>
>* Will ABC be paying people to participate in this?
>
>
>All in all it seems to good be true that a major media outlet would want 
>depict the benign reality of ecstacy use without some hidden agenda.
>
>Hope I'm not too jaded,
>

>From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
>To: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
>CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid
>Date: Wed, 19 Feb 2003 20:58:47 -0800 (PST)
>
>
>On Wed, 19 Feb 2003, georgeC wrote:
>-&e->For drum programming, the ReDrum is pretty awesome, definitely another
>
>Redrum is like an MPC2000 (which I used to own) except with better
>sequencing.
>
>-&e->invaluable tool in the sequencer/sampler box.  The synths do,
>-&e->admittedly, have their anemic moments- and the stock patches are
>-&e->completely bunk.  However, the NN-XT is a pretty awesome sampler and 
>is
>-&e->exceedingly quick to work with.
>
>-&e->Being a hardware sequencer junkie, I must say that I actually dig
>-&e->Reason's sequencer- it reminds me of Vision in a way, which is a
>-&e->program I miss.  I'm really not all that into the
>
>I was gonna say that.  Once you learn it well, it reminded me of pro24 (a
>product that later became cubase) or vision.  Copy management, editing,
>and all that are reasonably powerful and really easy to learn assuming
>YOU READ THE FUCKING MANUAL.
>
>Some people demand more control than Reason's sequencer (myself included a
>lot of the time, esp when making the basic rhythym of a track... or Chris
>Jackson who is so meticulous about timing that I wig out when we work on
>tracks together cuz he'll just be zoomed in on two notes and moving them
>around a nanometer back and forth at full zoom to get the swing down
>perfect)
>
>-&e->Logic/Cubase/Performer thing..  For my stuff, I'm just trying to
>-&e->capture what's played, and have decent playback timing.  A good swing
>-&e->algorithm is important, too.  Reason seems to have better timing than
>-&e->most seq/midi interface/synth setups, and I'm thinking that may be
>-&e->because the sounds are generated internally and thus may be quicker to
>-&e->respond.
>
>My gripe with reason is that tight timing starts to fail you if you use a
>lot of in line effects.  I don't think the sequencer 'plays ahead' to
>compensate for the latency caused by some of the effects... and you can't
>impose a playback 'compensation' delay at the per track level.
>
>-&e->In any case, it gets a lot of use around here- I never end up 
>finishing
>-&e->in Reason, though- too limiting.  Most of my work is done with audio,
>-&e->and for that I use Pro Tools.  Reason's effects are pretty cool, and
>-&e->have that propellerhead sound..  ..but that's all they have.  After 
>you
>-&e->use a couple of delays and verbs, there's just this.. this...
>-&e->REASONiness that jumps out at you, which can be good or bad.  For
>-&e->grittier music, it's generally too clean, too.. um.. teutonic
>-&e->sounding..  Or something.
>
>http://www.saturn5.com/andy/esc-overall-rmx-portion.aif
>
>I'll throw this in for anybody who doubts it's ability to get gritty
>sounds.  This segment is a full resolution fragment of a remix I did for
>ESC's Overall (a tasty little uptempo number lying on the fringe between
>techno and hardcore).  Ed sent me the track in Reason format, and not
>having ever used it to really do a track, I decided this was as good a
>time as any to try my hand at it.
>
>I picked a couple sounds I liked from the original composition, sample
>raided a couple others (just opened them up in Peak and took little cuts,
>then enveloped them so they'd sound like drums) and added a couple little
>shrill squealy thing with the Maelstrom synth and slapped the drums I cut
>up into ReDrum.  For a little rhythmic inspiration, I also 'stole' the
>timing from a classic loop I had here (opening theme to Hawaii-Five-0
>slowed down a bit) by importing it as a *.rex file and then bouncing the
>rex's timing to the sequencer, and using that sequence to trigger a
>different rex loop by changing what instrument that seq track was assigned
>to (taken from the original ESC arrangement, get it?).
>
>Only post processing was loading the exported file output into Peak and
>running Waves' L1 processor on it in order to up the levels a tad.
>
>Is it the next dancefloor anthem?  Doubtful.  It sounds like Drop Bass
>Network vs. Aphex Twin, but it's what I was in the mood to make at the
>moment and I'm generally pleased with the results.
>
>I think the reason a lot of tracks that are done in Reason sound 'off' is
>because a lot of novice producers use Reason... and more seasoned
>producers are more familiar with analog mixer based setups where things
>work a certain way (for example, in Reason *enabling* the EQs on the
>mixer, or carelessly routing effects without making sure they're not
>sending back the same signal to the mixer causes smear in the form of
>phase error and very short delays causing all sorts of problems... ).
>
>In the end, you can do a hell of a lot more with it than say an 808 and a
>303... it's a lot cheaper and a lot easier to use for most stuff.  For my
>work I prefer Logic and the mix of fruity hardware and software I've got
>here... but it's a great quick arrangement tool as well as a great way of
>getting loops together.
>
>Hell, I'd be down if anybody else is to do an SFR MP3 compilation of
>remixes of each others' original work... any takers?  Maybe even get
>Hyperreal to host it as a downloadable community perk?  If we use Reason
>as a base format, we could just assign works to remixers and have tracks
>ready inside a couple weeks.  Then the album as a full length cd could be
>sold to help support Hyperreal.org online (containing the original and
>remixed versions).
>
>andyw
>
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Re: SFR music compilation

At 07:02 PM 2/20/2003 +0000, you wrote:
>Hell, I'd be down if anybody else is to do an SFR MP3 compilation of
>remixes of each others' original work... any takers?

I'm down... I am just finishing up a track/remix project that is a big 
milestone in production for myself. Already did some preliminary club 
testing; hope to get by :code/DNA before it starts next week to check it 
out there.

 >so, i'd say that if you've got $4k to blow, go for it.
if not, just collect the tracks, put 'em up as MP3s
on a website for free and call it a day.

As Andy mentioned CDR duplication would be a good option; you can get 
silver/silver CDRs with thermal printing on CD and a color insert on demand 
in 100 or 200 lots. Going this route would also make creating a double CD 
quite manageable; which at this point seems like it will be necessary if 
multiple genres are included on this comp with 2+ remixers per genre. I 
believe a release of 100 double CDR comps duplicated with cases & inserts 
would be no more than ~$325 with a little time invested by a couple of 
people; for a couple more $$$ ~$410 very little work at all outside post 
production efforts. A portion of the 1st 100 comps recoups up front costs 
and funds the 2nd 100, etc.

Andy's ideas <clipped>
 >Some ideas I ran over...
* They must be sample clean.
* Mastering should be available for those tracks needing it.

I think this is all good input; I definitely like the music license part. 
I'd also be glad to contribute (free) my post production skills for this 
"SFR compilation". I am working with some great hardware (Manley Massive 
Passive EQ and Cranesong STC-8 compressor mostly)...

Best,
--Mike

Egregious
"Spiritual renewal through music for those outside the heard."
http://www.egregious.net/
http://audio.egregious.net/

okay, so i should probably give a good example of the kind of classic disco song i mean...do you know the one that goes, "don't leave me this way..." and the chorus goes, "Baby! my heart is full of love!"?...i don't know who sings that, but it is just the kind of song that brings feelings of love and reminscene into the hearts of many, particularly those who are familiar with the Castro scene in s.f.....the gay community in s.f. didn't just do a lot for music and dance. they've done a lot and continue to do things to liberate the spirits and to promote the health of many...you don't have to be homosexual either to understand, benefit or appreciate it. pure joy. that is why gay pride is so well celebrated yearly in the city by everyone. :)

Subject: [sfraves] i forgot something nrr

--0-2038143845-1045946833=:71875
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


i was going to share a couple of things that might make you laugh...i am good at making people laugh. :) :)....okay, the first one made me mad at first, but also, it made me laugh too, and i might have mentioned it here, maybe not, but even if i did, it was making me laugh again this morning, so maybe you too:

i was in a store trying on a dress one day, and when i came out of the dressing room to see what i looked like in the larger mirror, there was a young man...maybe around 21 or 22 years old... sitting in one of those chairs that is typically at the end of a dressing room waiting for his girlfriend...when he saw me, he made a series of comments on the dress, but the funniest one was, "yeah, that looks really nice on you, especially when you go braless like that."....okay keep reading:

the next funny thing happened more recently, like last night, was when i was visiting a friend...he is a very big man, and while he is not afraid of smart women nor is he a total homophobe, he is also very classically masculine in appearance and role and very, very straight....when i saw him, i told him that he looked nice and that i thought his shirt was cool (because it was, and i never lie about things like that to a man...if a man is striking, he is striking, and it just can't be helped ), and he said, "thank you" and told me that while it was a man's shirt, that it was something that he bought for his sister, and then he snagged it out of her closet and don't i do things like that too? and i said, "yes, sometimes, i wear men's clothing, but usually not their pants, because their pants are much too big. " and he says, "well, that's good. a man wouldn't want to wear a pair of tight fitting pants. " and i said, "well, a lot of french men wear tight black levi's", and he says, "i'm not into those european guys." :) :) :)

At 12:17 PM 2/22/2003 -0800, Geri Dahl wrote:

>okay, so i should probably give a good example of the kind of classic 
>disco song i mean...do you know the one that goes, "don't leave me this 
>way..." and the chorus goes, "Baby! my heart is full of love!"?...i don't 
>know who sings that, but it is just the kind of song that brings feelings 
>of love and reminscene into the hearts of many, particularly those who are 
>familiar with the Castro scene in s.f.....the gay community in s.f. didn't 
>just do a lot for music and dance. they've done a lot and continue to do 
>things to liberate the spirits and to promote the health of many...you 
>don't have to be homosexual either to understand, benefit or appreciate 
>it. pure joy. that is why gay pride is so well celebrated yearly in the 
>city by everyone. :)


"Don't Leave Me This Way"

Two versions.  Thelma Houston's on a 12" in 1977 was the big disco hit.  In 
the same year P.I.R. (Philly International Records) released a double album 
with eight Tom Moulton mixes of the greatest hits of P.I.R. and of that 
album most of the titles were also released on a 12" promo single, also the 
Harold Melvin & the Blue notes classic, but in a edit version of almost 
eight minutes, three minutes less than the Tom Moulton album version on 
'Philadelphia Classics'



Don't leave me this way

I can't survive I can't stay alive, without your love Oh baby

Don't leave me this way,

no I can't exist ... I'll surely miss your tender kiss

Don't leave me this way



Ahhh, baby!

My heart is full of love and desire for you

Now com'on down and do what you gotta do

You started this fire down in my soul

Now can't you see it's burning out of control

Com'on, satisfy the need in me

'Cause only your good lovin' can set me free



Don't, don't you leave me this way,

no don't you understand I'm at your command

Oh baby please, please, don't leave me this way ... nooo baby

Don't leave me this way,

no I can't survive

I can't stay alive without your love Baby,

don't leave me this way



Ahhh, baby! My heart is full of love and desire for you

So com'on down and do what you got to do

You started this fire down in my soul

Now can't you see it's burning out of control

So com'on, satisfy the need in me

'Cause only your good lovin' can set me free



Need you lovin', baby ... need it ... need it ...

Satisfy the need in me Satisfy the need in me



Well baby, come and satify the need in me

Whoa baby, come and satify the need in me

Oh baby Don't leave me this way

Don't leave me this way No,

don't leave me this way No,

don't leave me this way, baby

Don't leave ... Don't leave me this way babe ...

Oh, baby ...

becomes transformed."

-H. L. Mencken

	charset="iso-8859-1"

X-MSMail-Priority: Normal

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] sfr music compilation

> * They must be sample clean.  No tracks using samples' of other artists'
> works may be entered.  Sorry, but we can't afford to put SFR or Hyperreal
> in any sort of intellectual property liability.

bleah!!

I'm not going to an Internet party where nobody breaks the law...no matter
how much I like whoever's throwing it. :-p

besides, what if I made a hoover out of the flanged guitar riff from "Don't
Crash The Car Tonight" by Mary's Danish? what if I took a drum loop from
Jesus & Mary Chain "Sidewalking"? Obviously an Acid remix project called
"The Jesus & Mary's Danish" would catch anyone's eye, but it's very easy to
sample obscure music nobody else owns and sneak all kinds of illegal samples
into a track without ever getting caught. A split-second of the guitar
feedback at the end of Ani DiFranco's "Untouchable Face" is as easily hidden
in a track as a single pill or a tiny piece of paper is on a raver. It's
like the war on drugs - the fundamental ridiculousness of the law in
question is demonstrated by its total unenforceability.

Besides, being able to draw on obscure music nobody else owns is one of the
things that makes DJing an art form in the first place.

> * What about the annoying list traffic for people who don't care?  We
> could keep discussion about it on list with a unique subject line to make
> life easy but still keep the general population of SFR informed, or create
> a dedicated list for this subject with updates to SFR as we hit
> milestones.

no dude, we make it a livejournal community. e-mail is technologically
ill-suited to this type of purpose. read the o'reilly book with the sea
otters.

> Sorry, in a past life I was a project manager...

in my past life I came in stoned out of my gourd at 11am every day and took
home three grand a week. and I worked at a bank. :-p


Giles

yes...lots of people have done this classic over time.  one of my 
favorites.  every time i hear it i think back on those days of red hot 
energy on the dance floor.  the dancers used to go wild when the refrain 
"Ahhh, baby, my heart is full of love and desire for you..." came up.

sexual desire....

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Ex-NFL star Stepnoski: Marijuana not harmful

--=====================_1942636==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Ex-NFL star Stepnoski: Marijuana not harmful

Athlete says he used drug throughout 13-year career

By John McFarland

ASSOCIATED PRESS

Saturday, February 22, 2003

DALLAS -- Former Dallas Cowboys offensive lineman Mark Stepnoski considers
himself living proof that long-held beliefs about marijuana are wrong.

He acknowledges smoking pot for the past 20 years, so, according to
opponents of the drug, he should be a slothful burnout with blackened
lungs, a bit of a dim bulb after baking so many brain cells.

Yet Stepnoski is articulate and remains in top physical condition a year
after finishing a 13-year career as one of the NFL's top centers -- all
while regularly smoking marijuana, he says.

He feels so strongly that purported facts about marijuana are myths that
he's dedicated his retirement time to setting the record straight.

Stepnoski, 36, recently "came out" as a weed smoker when he took the
volunteer position as president of the Texas chapter of the National
Organization for Reform of Marijuana Laws. He's bankrolling NORML's
lobbyist in Austin and has joined the organization's national advisory board.

"Marijuana doesn't prevent you from going out and accomplishing what you
want to," he said. "Since I was a kid, I wanted to play in the NFL; I
wanted to be as good as I could; I wanted to play on a winning team; I
wanted to play professional football. Even though I occasionally used
marijuana, it never prevented me from ever attaining those goals."

Stepnoski knew how to pass NFL-mandated drug tests. And although he saw
drugs ruin the lives and careers of teammates, he remains convinced that
marijuana, used responsibly, is no worse than alcohol.

He says he doesn't want children to use drugs, but he believes he should
share his views about marijuana.

"We should be truthful to kids and educate them," Stepnoski said.

Among the many areas where Stepnoski and NORML disagree with the government
are whether money is wasted enforcing marijuana laws and whether the drug
causes long-term health problems and leads to other drug use.

"It's really kind of sad that someone who could use his role as a role
model for young children chooses not to use it constructively, but to use
it for something that has caused devastation for families throughout this
country," said Jennifer de Vallance, a spokeswoman for the White House
Office of National Drug Control Policy.

Stepnoski began researching marijuana's effects shortly after he started
lighting up during his high school days in Erie, Pa.

"I was serious about training and diet and everything else," he said.
"That's one of the reasons I looked into marijuana so much, because I would
use it, and it didn't seem to have a negative effect."

He says it never did. Not once does he recall shortness of breath because
of damaged lungs or lethargy from what drug opponents call amotivational
syndrome.

"I was in the best shape of any offensive lineman we had on the team," said
Stepnoski, who won two Super Bowls, made the Pro Bowl five times and helped
clear the way for many of Emmitt Smith's NFL-record 17,162 rushing yards.

"As far as lethargy, amotivational syndrome is a myth. You can't play in
the NFL for 13 years if you have amotivational syndrome. You just can't do
it."

So how many others do it? Stepnoski, who played nine seasons with the 
Cowboys and four with
Houston/Tennessee, passes on that one.

"If you accept the fact that a sports team is a microcosm of society, then
yes, drug use exists," he said. "So does alcohol and tobacco use."

The NFL tests players with a clean drug record only once a year -- and
always during the three months before the season. Stepnoski said that made
passing the tests a breeze.

"You just quit until you take the test, and that's it; you're done," he
said. "It wasn't hard to quit because it's not addictive. I didn't cheat. I
went in and took the test. I was by the book, so people shouldn't get mad
and think I faked somebody out."

Drug use among some of Stepnoski's Dallas teammates has been
well-documented. The extreme cases include fellow linemen Mark Tuinei dying
of an overdose in 1999 and Nate Newton recently being incarcerated after
convictions for transporting large amounts of marijuana.

Stepnoski said it's not fair to lump him in with them.

Several prominent teammates from the 1990s Cowboys declined to discuss
Stepnoski's new role or didn't return calls seeking comment.

They have talked to Stepnoski, though, and he says the feedback has been
positive.

"I've not had one guy be critical of what I'm doing," he said. "I'm sure
some of them may feel that way but just don't voice their opinions."

The NFL had no comment either, except to stand behind its testing policy.

"It's somewhat more random than knowing the exact date," league spokesman
Greg Aiello said. "We have the strongest and most comprehensive drug policy
in sports."

Stepnoski got started with NORML during his playing days by making
donations to receive literature. He was asked to be more involved but knew
it was a bad idea.

"It would have been such a huge headache for me and for my teammates and my
coaches that I'd have to be crazy to do it," said Stepnoski, who agreed to
step up his involvement after the 2001 season.

Although legalization is the ultimate goal, NORML's focus in Texas is on
persuading the Legislature to downgrade possession from a Class B to a
Class C misdemeanor. That would make it about as damaging legally as a
speeding ticket.

Measures to legalize marijuana for medical reasons didn't even get out of
committee for a full vote in the Texas House the past two sessions. And
voters in November defeated marijuana law reform measures in three states:
Nevada, South Dakota and Arizona.

Even so, Stepnoski said he's confident.

"I knew this was going to be rough waters occasionally, at least publicly,"
he said. "But again, I don't feel deterred because I have the truth on my
side."



Moksha Tribe

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one 
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

recognition. it is essentially a new riff now.

"Don't Leave Me This Way"

Two versions.  Thelma Houston's on a 12" in 1977 was the big disco hit.  In the same year P.I.R. (Philly International Records) released a double album with eight Tom Moulton mixes of the greatest hits of P.I.R. and of that album most of the titles were also released on a 12" promo single, also the Harold Melvin & the Blue notes classic, but in a edit version of almost eight minutes, three minutes less than the Tom Moulton album version on 'Philadelphia Classics'

Subject: Re: [sfraves] few hours left :: records on ebay <bsp>


Cheese and list people in general:

Please...

Do not crosspost.  It has the potential to create heinous amounts of reply
spackle from people who don't know each other, etc.

Please post sales only once (you've posted on this lot of sales at least
three time now).  You haven't had a single bid on any of this, and you've
posted several times!

Just a tip, in regards to EBay... start low if you want to lure people in.
If you're worried about selling stuff too low, put a reserve on it, but
let people buy into something at what they would consider a deal.  Prices
rarely rise when you're asking new prices on used gear from the get go.
Bidding wars usually only happen when people who already have thought they
were gonna get something realize their purchase is in jeapordy.  The
reality is you can't sell stuff for what you want for it, but rather what
people are willing to pay.

That said, it's fair to expect about 30-60% of new value for used records,
unless you've got an original pressing of Halcyon, early Cybotron or
Powerpill or something that is known to be at least somewhat rare.  Also
of note, you should include audio shreds to indicate what people are
buying (especially in a genre like happycore, where a lot of buyers might
not have massive knowledge of what they're getting into cause they genre
dates back to at least 95 but would jump at a track if you left them a
choice sample to listen to).

Also, in the case of records... shipping one record SUCKS and keeps it
from being a good deal.  Lot the stuff up.  That way you get screwed less
by Ebay, and everybody gets a better deal as you ship 5 records to one
customer instead of one record each to 5.

just my $.02, good luck.
andyw

andyw-mutorsoundsystem-andy@saturn5.com
\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\
you best get off your horse, drink your milk, get the freak out...

this should *not* be newsworthy.

period.

but we let it happen and *continue* to do so.

Carl Sagan had to die before he could even admit that he preferred =
cannabis to other forms of intoxicants, or risk having his entire body =
of work ruined and discredited.

what's up with that?

Last election season in the USA USA USA only one cannabis initiative =
passed.

It was the one where the City of San Francisco authorized the use of =
vacant lots to be tended by the "homeless" to cultivate cannabis for =
patients.

The one in Las Vegas, NV, where a cannabis user could walk around with =
up to 3 z's of primo in their pocket for recreational purposes, that one =
failed miserably.=20

due to lack of financial support from the 30 million recreational =
cannabis users it directly affected.

If 1% of that 30 million gave up what they spend in a week on cannabis =
there would have been more than enough to spend on ads to counter to =
campaign the Feds mounted in October against it.

Coulda, shoulda, woulda, but it dinnt happen, now did it?

In San Francisco, local wag for the SF Chronicle, Rob Morse, snidely =
asked how many armed guards would be needed to guard the cannabis =
gardens.

i wrote him a brief note in answer to that, where i said that the =
cannabis gardens will need as many armed guards around them as the =
average Anheiser Beer truck presently needs.

i also stated that a legitimately state licensed, and permitted cannabis =
delivery vehicle rolling down the 101 should raise as many eyebrows as =
said beer truck.

mofo never wrote back, nor did he put *that* in his column, as well as =
my other point that the only thing making the cannabis have *any* value =
was its 'illegality,' due to it being an 'illicit' substance.

smug, self-satisfied prick, he's got no problem with his cronies =
scotches y should he give a patootie about meand my friends bud?

whatever.

i am so sick and tired of being treated like a second class citizen over =
this shit and i'm wondering when everyone else will not only feel the =
same way but actually *do* something about this past paying $5,000.00 a =
pound for the privilege of getting arrested for it?

nic

----- Original Message -----=20
From: Apollo=20
To: RGs=20
Sent: Sunday, February 23, 2003 3:51 PM
Subject: RG: RE: Sports Rant....


Ex-NFL star Stepnoski: Marijuana not harmful

Athlete says he used drug throughout 13-year career

By John McFarland

ASSOCIATED PRESS

Saturday, February 22, 2003

DALLAS -- Former Dallas Cowboys offensive lineman Mark Stepnoski =
considers=20
himself living proof that long-held beliefs about marijuana are wrong.

He acknowledges smoking pot for the past 20 years, so, according to=20
opponents of the drug, he should be a slothful burnout with blackened=20
lungs, a bit of a dim bulb after baking so many brain cells.

Yet Stepnoski is articulate and remains in top physical condition a year =

after finishing a 13-year career as one of the NFL's top centers -- all=20
while regularly smoking marijuana, he says.

He feels so strongly that purported facts about marijuana are myths that =

he's dedicated his retirement time to setting the record straight.

Stepnoski, 36, recently "came out" as a weed smoker when he took the=20
volunteer position as president of the Texas chapter of the National=20
Organization for Reform of Marijuana Laws. He's bankrolling NORML's=20
lobbyist in Austin and has joined the organization's national advisory =
board.

"Marijuana doesn't prevent you from going out and accomplishing what you =

want to," he said. "Since I was a kid, I wanted to play in the NFL; I=20
wanted to be as good as I could; I wanted to play on a winning team; I=20
wanted to play professional football. Even though I occasionally used=20
marijuana, it never prevented me from ever attaining those goals."

Stepnoski knew how to pass NFL-mandated drug tests. And although he saw=20
drugs ruin the lives and careers of teammates, he remains convinced that =

marijuana, used responsibly, is no worse than alcohol.

He says he doesn't want children to use drugs, but he believes he should =

share his views about marijuana.

"We should be truthful to kids and educate them," Stepnoski said.

Among the many areas where Stepnoski and NORML disagree with the =
government=20
are whether money is wasted enforcing marijuana laws and whether the =
drug=20
causes long-term health problems and leads to other drug use.

"It's really kind of sad that someone who could use his role as a role=20
model for young children chooses not to use it constructively, but to =
use=20
it for something that has caused devastation for families throughout =
this=20
country," said Jennifer de Vallance, a spokeswoman for the White House=20
Office of National Drug Control Policy.

Stepnoski began researching marijuana's effects shortly after he started =

lighting up during his high school days in Erie, Pa.

"I was serious about training and diet and everything else," he said.=20
"That's one of the reasons I looked into marijuana so much, because I =
would=20
use it, and it didn't seem to have a negative effect."

He says it never did. Not once does he recall shortness of breath =
because=20
of damaged lungs or lethargy from what drug opponents call amotivational =

syndrome.

"I was in the best shape of any offensive lineman we had on the team," =
said=20
Stepnoski, who won two Super Bowls, made the Pro Bowl five times and =
helped=20
clear the way for many of Emmitt Smith's NFL-record 17,162 rushing =
yards.

"As far as lethargy, amotivational syndrome is a myth. You can't play in =

the NFL for 13 years if you have amotivational syndrome. You just can't =
do=20
it."

So how many others do it? Stepnoski, who played nine seasons with the =
Cowboys and four with=20
Houston/Tennessee, passes on that one.

"If you accept the fact that a sports team is a microcosm of society, =
then=20
yes, drug use exists," he said. "So does alcohol and tobacco use."

The NFL tests players with a clean drug record only once a year -- and=20
always during the three months before the season. Stepnoski said that =
made=20
passing the tests a breeze.

"You just quit until you take the test, and that's it; you're done," he=20
said. "It wasn't hard to quit because it's not addictive. I didn't =
cheat. I=20
went in and took the test. I was by the book, so people shouldn't get =
mad=20
and think I faked somebody out."

Drug use among some of Stepnoski's Dallas teammates has been=20
well-documented. The extreme cases include fellow linemen Mark Tuinei =
dying=20
of an overdose in 1999 and Nate Newton recently being incarcerated after =

convictions for transporting large amounts of marijuana.

Stepnoski said it's not fair to lump him in with them.

Several prominent teammates from the 1990s Cowboys declined to discuss=20
Stepnoski's new role or didn't return calls seeking comment.

They have talked to Stepnoski, though, and he says the feedback has been =

positive.

"I've not had one guy be critical of what I'm doing," he said. "I'm sure =

some of them may feel that way but just don't voice their opinions."

The NFL had no comment either, except to stand behind its testing =
policy.

"It's somewhat more random than knowing the exact date," league =
spokesman=20
Greg Aiello said. "We have the strongest and most comprehensive drug =
policy=20
in sports."

Stepnoski got started with NORML during his playing days by making=20
donations to receive literature. He was asked to be more involved but =
knew=20
it was a bad idea.

"It would have been such a huge headache for me and for my teammates and =
my=20
coaches that I'd have to be crazy to do it," said Stepnoski, who agreed =
to=20
step up his involvement after the 2001 season.

Although legalization is the ultimate goal, NORML's focus in Texas is on =

persuading the Legislature to downgrade possession from a Class B to a=20
Class C misdemeanor. That would make it about as damaging legally as a=20
speeding ticket.

Measures to legalize marijuana for medical reasons didn't even get out =
of=20
committee for a full vote in the Texas House the past two sessions. And=20
voters in November defeated marijuana law reform measures in three =
states:=20
Nevada, South Dakota and Arizona.

Even so, Stepnoski said he's confident.

"I knew this was going to be rough waters occasionally, at least =
publicly,"=20
he said. "But again, I don't feel deterred because I have the truth on =
my=20
side."



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.com

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

is not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a =
purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one =
becomes transformed." =20
-Heinrich Zimmer

But there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken=20

From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] just get Reason and Acid


On Sat, 22 Feb 2003, Chris Jackson wrote:
-&e->
-&e->> The MPC isn't a good sequencer?!?!!
-&e->>
-&e->> are you sure?
-&e->>
-&e->>
-&e->> Giles
-&e->
-&e->
-&e->Well...it's a good sequencer if you like hovering over
-&e->the damn thing squinting your eyes!  Not only does it
-&e->fuck with your eyes, but it also gives you one hell of
-&e->a neck/ backache...to each is own, I guess..

As a guy who *really tried* on an MPC2000 for at least a year...

It also gets timing hiccups when looping, crashed more often than my mac
does, maxed out at what... 32Mb of Ram and didn't allow sound loading on
the fly.  Oh, and no resampling meaning that unless you're just ganking
other people's loops... you'll need another MPC or a computer to do
anything useful with it.  Didn't import loop points when importing wav
files, not capable of playing pitches from midi input, etc.

Need I say more?

The interface is cool, I like the pads, but Akai has made those available
as a seperate device.  The clock/sampler/effects, etc for it generally
lack.  Compared to a PC, it pales... and having worked with a friend's
ASR-X as well as some keyboard based sampler/workstations I can't say it's
the strongest "all in one" unit either.

If you consider it *just* a drum machine that plays samples (with maybe a
hit and a bass sample ala hip hop), it's _SICK_ because of it's ease of
use, but as a sequencer it's weak, and as a sampler it's weak.  After
moderate wear... maybe a year of use and two visits to 2nd & jackson for
live sets, I had lines going out on the display and it had killed it's
second zip drive thanks to a SCSI control issue MPC-Headz refer to as
"CLICK OF DEATH".

The fun factor for the piece is high, I miss it from time to time, but I'm
making better music since I sold it.

andyw

> As a guy who *really tried* on an MPC2000 for at least a year...

> The fun factor for the piece is high, I miss it from time to time, but I'm

no disagreements there...I sold mine too...still...this is a silly
conversation...first because not one of us actually owns an MPC...and
secondly because DJ Krust and Roni Size can sway me completely just by
showing up in a Mecca ad with one in their hands...which they've done...just
like Underworld persuaded me by having one in their stage setup...

same way I remain convinced Reason is a top-notch musical instrument,
irrespective of what anybody might say, because I've heard what Terminalhead
can do with it...

I mean yes, the MPC's less sophisticated than a software sequencer, and God
knows it's notoriously unreliable, but tons of people have made tons of
terrific records with it, haven't they?

what other metric is there?


Giles


(ps: on the other hand, it's only fair to point out that nobody has actually
spoken up to say, "you know what, I bought an MPC, and I kept it.")

Subject: [sfraves] [NRR] Rane MP-22z & Coffin for Sale


Single owner Rane MP-22z for sale.

World standard mixer for banging techno/house/trance, four band EQs per
channel, rotary input select allows using one CD player on either channel
instead of vinyl, balanced outputs, active crossfader with adjustable
curve for everything from classic Rane "dipped" crossfader to modern flat
mix to aggressive scratching curves, and legendary reliability.  AUX IN
allows use of another mixer direct to outs enabling easy 2x4 setups, and
the switches on the underside can allow you to control what outputs get
the microphone... so you can pipe the vinyl mix to the monitors without
the MC's mic causing feedback.  4 pairs of outputs (main, aux1, aux2,
tape) allowing you to provide for all your output needs).  The headphone
cue is among the loudest and cleanest of and on the market, allowing
accurate monitoring in any environment.  The excellent audio specs of this
mixer and 12 LED per channel level meters make it a natural for use with
large sound systems, studio mixtape recording, or just as a quality home
dj mixer that is representative of what you'll see a lot of when you play
out.

Condition - well loved.  Spent most of it's life permanently mounted in a
heavy duty coffin (see below).  100% operational, all the labels for all
the knobs are fine, but some of the screws have lost their paint and
there's a small scratch next to the crossfader.  Great condition overall
and a great deal... the power supply connector even has the little spring
doohickey on it to keep it locked in during use.

$420 cash OBO, and if you're interested I can demo all it's features when
you pick it up (sunnyvale) and throw in a basic DJ lesson if you're new to
all of this.  Free delivery (& setup if you want help) also available.

Also for sale - Genz Benz seriously heavy duty coffin.  Not for the faint
of heart (it's pretty heavy), this coffin is the best built I've ever seen
for 2 decks and a 19" standard mixer.  $100 cash OBO.  You can buy a new
coffin for around that, but this one is built with three handles, recessed
locking hardware, 1" of insulating foam to protect your decks, and thicker
wood than I remember seeing on any other coffin (just measured it - 3/4").

andyw

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Alex the Snow Party Stud

Alex, I'm sure I speak for everyone in giving you and your crew mad props 
for pulling off the mother of all renegades. You worked really hard and it 
was evident in the quality of the production. I overheard people saying how 
they couldn't believe this was a free party. Nice layout, minimal but 
effective decorations. Lighted walkway and blacklights were a nice touch. 
But where was the hot chocolate and cider? Did i somehow miss that. Talent 
and music was excellent and had enough diversity. So many familiar faces. 
Osby, who made the trip up with Delia, made his entrance representing the 
bay (it's always an "entrance" when osby shows up;) nice to see you and 
Delia again, Osby. Good to see both a solid SFraves and Sacraves group of 
peeps in attendance. Good times had by all.

Thank you Alex and middle ground productions for a winter wonderland 
experience of music and community. This one I won't soon forget


Paul Gordon

"It is one of life's mysteries how an ounce of understanding, cleanses an 
ocean of mistrust and hate"
(The Outer Limits)

Subject: [sfraves] The Snow Party was Sooooooooo Dope!

OK... I didn't really plan on doing 2 much on Saturday really!!  I =
mean... originally the game plan I had set up was 2 hang out w/ my Bro =
again & jus' have a chill day/ evening la la la!  BUt like in the =
afternoon, Delia called me & asked me if I wanted 2 go 2 the snow party! =
 LoL...I so didn't think about goin' @ all, esp even when that long ass =
tired thread was goin' on, I kinda felt like I dunno, that thread =
thingie on the list during the week really I dunno.... but I didn't =
think I was gonna be gion' @ all!

So after a few confissing things w/ meeting up & stuff, Matt comes by my =
pad& like picks me up w/ Delia & Oh My Goodness, Hello 2Day... Sean =
Grifith (sp) was in the car 2 & I been hella wanting 2 meet this cat 4 a =
while now!!  So it was Groovy havin' all these SFR freaks in 1 car goin' =
 this party 2gether!!  Fun Fun Fun!!  Actually Matt was kinda tired or =
whatever & so I ended up driving like all the way there kinda!!  Hello =
2Day, we even got stuck in a ditch 4 a moment on the way there =3D(  BUt =
we were all safe =3D)

After a very long, confussing, almost kinda dangerous trip up 2 the =
location... we finally made it!!  OH MY gosh... such an Awesome =
location!!  There was snow at various parts & it was in this Groovy =
place in the woods & the snow!!  SNOW!!!  SO Dope!

All the DJs I saw were Groovy!!  I mean... Dragn'fly's set was Dope as =
usual!!  OK... if I'm right about what she spun... she kinda started out =
her set w/ some Techno.... right?... then like totally went in2 Trance!! =
 I Loved it! Oh Gosh... it was so Awesome seein' this Chica after a few =
months & catchin' up!!!  Fuck The DJ! =3DP

His Highness spun this Jammin' Diva Vocal Disco-ee House set!!  Oh My =
Gosh man... Loved it!!  I was totally dancin' my ass off!!!  It was CooL =
'cause I haven't seen His Highness in a while so we spent time talkin' & =
tryin' 2 make plans 2 kick it soon!

OK... Cantos spun some really Wicked HOuse that night!!  Man...  it was =
jus fun Groovyin' 2 his set & it was kinda of a change from when I been =
hearin him spin Breakbeats!!  Grrrrrr... no Breakbeats from Cantos that =
night >=3DO  Well... next time!!  But he spun alota Groovy Progressive, =
Dark, house!!  I Loved it!

OK... what totally took me over & got me all twacked (in a Groovy way) =
was when I was in the Jungle section!!  OK... when we got there, Billy =
Lane was on & man... I Loved his set!! Busted out hella Hard Beats & I =
found myslef goin' there more 2 dance than other sections of the party =
during that set!!  Yummm!

Then after him came on this DJ who started out spinning Reggae & Hip Hop =
& I was kinda grrrrr... I didn't wanna dance 2 that!  BUt I came back =
later & the same DJ was spinning Jungle & ooooooooooooooh.... I was =
hooked again to that area!!  I mean... every track this Dude came out w/ =
was Sick!!  I mean totally man!!  So I was danicng my ass off & =
yelling!!  LoL.... then there was a moment while this DJ dude was =
spinning & he yelled to me, "Dude... You Rock!!"  LoL... that was =
Awesome when he said that & I was still hella Groovin', but like started =
blushing!!  But it was Groovy 'cause this girl I was dancing next to =
gave me this Awesome compliment about my dancing & she even called me a =
"Hardcore Junglist"  LoL...Wow... that was such a nice thing 2 say & I =
dunno!! =20

I was jus' feelin' the vibe of 1 of the Genre's I Looooooove (Jungle) & =
the whole setting of dancing in the Jungle in the snow & it was all like =
Mystical & Magical & hmmm.... So yeah... I talked 2 this DJ after he was =
done spinning & he's DJ EMP aka Steve the Sound Guy & we exchanged =
contact info so he could send me a demo CD & tell me where's he gonna =
spin next & all that!!!  Such A Dope SEt!

But the 1 thing I realized about this party was after U saw some1 once & =
kicked it, that might be the most you'll ever see them that night!!  =
LoL... Mickey J was there & spun a set which I still feel so mondo bad 4 =
missing, but he 4gave me I think!  Anywaze... we talked 4 like 10 =
minutes & I went 2 get water & when I got back 2 where we were =
talkin'... he was gone & I didn't see him anymore @ the party!! =3D(

BUt the night was so Dope!!  I mean... I still so After Party High right =
now 'cause it was such a Memorable, Magical night!  I met soooo many =
people from all over the Bay who were there as well as hella people from =
Sac!!  LoL... it was so Neat!

On of the best part was when it started to get bright & the day was like =
eaking up... you could totally see like the whole forest & whole section =
were in that night & it was jus' Amazing!!!  I mean... as far as I could =
see.. there was snow covering the whole ground!!  There's this beautiful =
stream that was in the back by the hill... Maaaan... everything was jus' =
Beautiful & totally made me appreciate where I was the whole night!

Thanks 2 the Crew who threw that if you're on SFR!!!  Man... that party =
totally Awesome!!  I hella regret not having a camera 2 take pixes... =
but I got the pictures in my head of the night.....

I sooooooo needed this party!!!  Wow!!  Delia, Sean, Matt.... thanks 4 =
the adventure! =3D)

Take Care {8O)
Peace-=3D-=3D->O=A7bY

#1 Rule Of The Outdoor Underground

Please Respect the area you're partying in!  Keep the area the way you =
found it... CLEAN!!! =20

Whenever I smoked a ciggie... i popped the cherry & put the ciggy butt =
in my back pocket!  I kept all my candy wrappers in my hoodie pocket =
which zipped up....

All I'm sayin' is don't liter in a beautiful place, ya know!!  It's =
totally lame 2 use as an excuse that something will bio-degrade & it's =
OK 2 liter that piece of garbage whatever.... it' s  like totally not =
right man =3D(   I cleaned up as much as I coulda w/ every lil' piece of =
trash I saw @ the location & alota know that when I stay afterwards 2 =
help clean.... I really cleeeeeeean up!  All I'm sayin' is that it's be =
really gross 2 go back 2 that location a year later of even a few months =
& still see that same bottle of Jack, or that pile of ciggy butts in the =
whole, or like stuff people did throw away, ya know =3D(  OK.... I'll =
jump off my soap Box now.... ::::JuMp:::::

OK... sorry 4 the vent... but PLease... liter sucks.... unless U do it =
the City & there's street sweepers who clean it up... that's kinda OK =

files on my HD.  i mean, like wack stuff-- - Dean
Martin, Madonna, sound effects of elephants and
tigers.

has this disorder whereby collecting things (stones,
screws, trading cards, etc) is a compensation for
intense insecurities... thus the nature of
compulsively collecting the Pokemon cards.

i think this weekend i'm going to go out and dump some
money back into the record industry; keep the karma
going.

i'm wondering how many mp3's some of you people have.

peace,

label."  sometimes you get good stuff.
