Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Davis man puts his life on the line in Baghdad

--=====================_1838040==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

http://www.davisenterprise.com/display/inn_news/311NEW1.TXT



Sunday, February 23, 2003


Davis man puts his life on the line in Baghdad

By Crystal Ross O'Hara/Enterprise staff writer

A Davis native has traveled to Baghdad, volunteering to be a
human shield in case of an attack against Iraq.

Sean Logan, 22, a 1998 Davis High School graduate who has been
living in San Francisco for the past three years, arrived in
Baghdad on Feb. 16. He traveled there in a double-decker bus
from Italy with a group of about 150 human shield volunteers
from the London-based group Truth, Justice, Peace Action.

"I'm going to Baghdad to be a human shield.  Trying to stop this
war," he said in a phone message last week to his parents, Bob
and Mary Logan of Davis.  "Tell everyone not to blow up Baghdad.
I love you.  See you if I get back."

In an interview Saturday, Bob and Mary Logan said they were
shocked that their son had made it all the way to Baghdad, but
were not surprised that he would volunteer to do such a thing.

"I was afraid.  I was very sad.  I was worried," Mary Logan said.
"But then, after I got over that, I was very proud of him."

The Logans -- who include sisters Jenny, 19; Erin, 25; and
Heather, 27 -- say Sean has spent the past several years pursuing
a career in art and music while helping the homeless in San
Francisco.  His trip to Iraq is just an extension of that
community-based work, they say.

"His view of globalization is global brotherhood and he wants
to show brotherhood with the Iraqi people," Mary Logan said.

Bob Logan said his son is not a supporter of Saddam Hussein,
rather a supporter of the Iraqi people.

"Sean says an Iraqi life is as important as an American life,"
he said.

He said he does not know at this time where Sean could be placed
in the event of a war, but said it is his son's intention to
become a shield at a hospital or an orphanage.  He said Sean hopes
that by placing an American life in danger he can prevent the
American military from firing on civilian targets.

The international group's visit to Iraq is bound to be
controversial.  Ken Nichols O'Keefe, a 33-year-old Gulf War
veteran who has renounced his U.S. citizenship, organized it.

On his Web site, O'Keefe states that one of the reasons he is
returning to Iraq is "to pay penance for my participation in
the first Gulf War as a U.S. Marine and personally apologize
to the Iraqi people."

U.S. government officials have harshly criticized Iraqi leader
Saddam Hussein's use of human shields during the Gulf War.  At
a news conference Wednesday, Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld
said Saddam often constructs military facilities near hospitals,
schools and orphanages.

"Deploying human shields is not a military strategy, it's murder,
a violation of the laws of armed conflict, and a crime against
humanity, and it will be treated as such," Rumsfeld said.

At the same news conference, Gen. Richard Meyers, chairman of
the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said any use of human shields would
be considered a war crime, even if those shields were volunteers.

"(If) death or serious injury to a noncombatant resulted from
these efforts, the individuals responsible for deploying any
innocent civilians as human shields could be guilty of grave
breaches of the Geneva Conventions," Meyers said.

The Logans hope their son will never have to be used in that
way.

"He just wanted to go there to try to stop the war by bringing
attention to it," Bob Logan said.

The Logans have not spoken to their son since he arrived in
Baghdad.  However, messages can be sent to him through the TJP
Action Web site at www.humanshields.org by clicking on the
"feedback" button on the left side of the page.

-- Reach Crystal Ross O'Hara at cohara@davisenterprise.net


Sunday, February 23, 2003

Moksha Tribe

-Helen Keller

becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

Don't fret Boomy. My collection of mp3's is nearly 40gigs now. That's
somewhere around 6,000+ files. I used to work at a .com where we were a
content delivery network for the music industry so I made use of that and
grabbed lots of music. I'm going to start encoding my entire cd collection
to MP3 soon as well. It's just a convenience factor. 60% of my cd's are in a
giant box that acts as my printer stand right now. Seems like a waste so
encoding to MP3 I go!

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
design :: www.sninesix.com
photography :: www.innocentchild.com

ok, i think i have an mp3 addiction.  i have 1,728
files on my HD.  i mean, like wack stuff-- - Dean
Martin, Madonna, sound effects of elephants and
tigers.

I once heard that the Japanese guy who created Pokeman
has this disorder whereby collecting things (stones,
screws, trading cards, etc) is a compensation for
intense insecurities... thus the nature of
compulsively collecting the Pokemon cards.

i think this weekend i'm going to go out and dump some
money back into the record industry; keep the karma
going.

i'm wondering how many mp3's some of you people have.

peace,
boomerang

PS:  a cool keyword to search for mp3's is "white
label."  sometimes you get good stuff.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Oh Yeah... 1 More thing...PLEASE

	Living up here in Oregon we go crazy about outdoor party sites
being clean. There are activist groups that will picket events thrown by
people who are known to litter the forest. It is tough to keep
everything in your pockets especially trash we hold the promoters up
here responsible for leaving locations as clean as they were found. It
is very important especially in this day and age where a camera crew is
looking for any way to bash this scene of ours. We usually pack out one
or two full size trucks loaded with trash after events most of the trash
is even left by loggers. Just a few thoughts. Peace

Jason Philips
OH records
Problematic Beats

Subject: RE: [sfraves] mp3 addiction (nrr)

I hear ya.. I've got 2200 songs in my Final Scratch directory alone and
that's not everything from all the hard drives in the house.  I spent at
least 15 hours this weekend copying, organizing etc of my MP3's and I'm
still only halfway done. 

A few months back I definitely started getting over the 'I'm fucking
over the RIAA, YAY' and realized that a lot of the music I have is
independent/weird stuff and have started purchasing albums from those
who I really like that I've downloaded over the past 3 and a half years
of broadband abuse.  That and I typically buy at community shops instead
of the major conglomerates unless I can't find it anywhere else.  With
more of our money going overseas to 5 consultants for the price of 1
american worker, I'm trying to stop giving money to multinational
corporations as much as possible and keep the money in our local
communities because..  Well.. With 500k jobs being lost to automation
every year from the late 70's and now people losing their jobs to people
who are insanely dedicated workers in poorer countries, we're not going
to have much money in the lower class pockets here anymore.  If anyone
has read anything about the flow of money throughout history, I think
we're about to hit another major change as the flow jumps east again and
will have gone full circle back to Asia.  Interesting times...

-Rayn

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] mp3 addiction (nrr)

A friend of mine has a 40GB external hard drive and 15GB on an 
internal PowerBook drive full and will soon be in need of another. 
He's been collecting them for a while. Got lots off of Hotline back 
before Napster. Then got lots in the Napster Days. Then got lots 
during the excellent AudioGalaxy days. Now he uses LimeWire. he's on 
a Mac so it's a bit different than using PC methods.

He also decided that having racks of CDs was waste of physical space 
in his immediate living environs, so he ripped them all and began 
selling them back to record stores. Often he'll take advantage of the 
70%  no questions asked return policy at Ameoba. He says it 
drastically reduces the amount of money he has to spend to pick up 
new music on CDs. He also likes to borrow CDs from friends and rip 
them.

He says he really believes in what he calls the "digital 
entertainment box". He longs for the future he envisions when he will 
be able keep all his media (music, movies, books, magazines, games) 
all in one small box (a hard drive) and use various portable output 
devices (ipod, laptop, eBook, PDA,  etc.) to enjoy them. He says it 
reduces the physical clutter in his life and is also better for the 
environment. He's not attached to the physical material of media 
product. He says there is just too damn much of it to get sentimental 
about cover art, liner notes, and packaging. He just loves the music.

I think he's basically trying to recreate what I call his "own 
personal radio". Since radio now sucks more than it ever has, he is 
trying to replace the magic that it might of once held for him. He 
says "There's just something though about having a little magic box 
that emanates forth such beautiful sounds."

He likes it this way. Ain't technology great?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] sfr music compilation

On Sat, 22 Feb 2003 15:24:02 -0700, Giles Bowkett <gilesbowkett@neobeatnik.com> wrote:

>> * They must be sample clean.  No tracks using samples' of other artists'
>> works may be entered.  Sorry, but we can't afford to put SFR or Hyperreal
>> in any sort of intellectual property liability.
>
> bleah!!
>
> I'm not going to an Internet party where nobody breaks the law...no matter
> how much I like whoever's throwing it. :-p
>
> besides, what if I made a hoover out of the flanged guitar riff from "Don't
> Crash The Car Tonight" by Mary's Danish? what if I took a drum loop from
> Jesus & Mary Chain "Sidewalking"?

Yeah yeah-we all know it can be done-but what's the point really?
So I sample something and pitch it and twist it until it's a squealing blip.
Well yay-I prolly coulda made that same squealing blip in other ways-
And unless you get off on telling people about how you sampled some noise and mangled it, I see no need to do that at all.
Sure-if you *really* have to you probably could, and nobody would ever catch you-yay.But maybe you'd like to challenge yourself?
Just this once?
The point of Andy's statement above is right there-it's liability.

> Besides, being able to draw on obscure music nobody else owns is one of the
> things that makes DJing an art form in the first place.

DJ != Producer

In-Reply-To: <p04330105ba801d937f2f@[172.16.2.25]>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 24 Feb 2003 20:05:15.0406 (UTC) FILETIME=[0BD102E0:01C2DC40]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] mp3 addiction (nrr)

I'm waiting for the day when solid state drives are huge and cheap
before I do anything like that.  With movable parts hard drives are
still too unstable for me to devote myself to them completely.  Unless
you have a raid array, putting everything on hard disk with no real way
to be able to back it all up is really taking a chance.

As for personal radio I've fallen in love with the Launch.com service
offered by Yahoo.  They don't have everything available by the artists
but the selection they have is amazing.  You configure your station how
you want by rating songs, it will throw in random songs from similar
artists you haven't configured yet etc and you slowly build youself a
station that fits you and your tastes.  They also just added a moods
feature that allows you to play music based on your moods as opposed to
playing everything from your interests.  The free service has a 15 - 30
second commecial about every 8 songs and it is really not annoying at
all, and the pay service is pretty cheap if you want to get rid of
commercials and take advantage of a few more features.

Here's the link to my station that I have configured so you can take a
look at what you can do with it.  I have very eclectic tastes that are
definitely reflected here.
http://launch.yahoo.com/lc/?rt=0&rp1=0&rp2=1208269951

-Rayn

-----Original Message-----
From: blindspot [mailto:blindspot@mac.com] 
Sent: Monday, February 24, 2003 11:23 AM
To: boomboom@boomerangfidget.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] mp3 addiction (nrr)


A friend of mine has a 40GB external hard drive and 15GB on an 
internal PowerBook drive full and will soon be in need of another. 
He's been collecting them for a while. Got lots off of Hotline back 
before Napster. Then got lots in the Napster Days. Then got lots 
during the excellent AudioGalaxy days. Now he uses LimeWire. he's on 
a Mac so it's a bit different than using PC methods.

He also decided that having racks of CDs was waste of physical space 
in his immediate living environs, so he ripped them all and began 
selling them back to record stores. Often he'll take advantage of the 
70%  no questions asked return policy at Ameoba. He says it 
drastically reduces the amount of money he has to spend to pick up 
new music on CDs. He also likes to borrow CDs from friends and rip 
them.

He says he really believes in what he calls the "digital 
entertainment box". He longs for the future he envisions when he will 
be able keep all his media (music, movies, books, magazines, games) 
all in one small box (a hard drive) and use various portable output 
devices (ipod, laptop, eBook, PDA,  etc.) to enjoy them. He says it 
reduces the physical clutter in his life and is also better for the 
environment. He's not attached to the physical material of media 
product. He says there is just too damn much of it to get sentimental 
about cover art, liner notes, and packaging. He just loves the music.

I think he's basically trying to recreate what I call his "own 
personal radio". Since radio now sucks more than it ever has, he is 
trying to replace the magic that it might of once held for him. He 
says "There's just something though about having a little magic box 
that emanates forth such beautiful sounds."

He likes it this way. Ain't technology great?

I totally agree - this was an awesome event. Two things I love, the woods and jungle in the same place, with a great crowd. Great lineup of djs, and three 'rooms' of music to please any punter. I think this is closest thing I have found yet to 'the rave experience', and am very glad that during my time in the US I was able to get out to this event. Totally great event, and the icey roads where worth the struggle. I especially liked DJ EMP's set with the jungle - I liked his throwing down the reggae for a bit, and I can honestly say I haven't seen a DJ having that much fun behind the decks in a long time.

Will definitely get out to Sacto with a few aussie mates as soon as possible.

Matt.

However was worth it for the comical value of having one dude allegedly say "I thought he was a giant bug"]

----Original Message Follows----
From: blindspot <blindspot@mac.com>
To: boomboom@boomerangfidget.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] mp3 addiction (nrr)
Date: Mon, 24 Feb 2003 11:23:16 -0800

A friend of mine has a 40GB external hard drive and 15GB on an internal 
PowerBook drive full and will soon be in need of another. He's been 
collecting them for a while. Got lots off of Hotline back before Napster. 
Then got lots in the Napster Days. Then got lots during the excellent 
AudioGalaxy days. Now he uses LimeWire. he's on a Mac so it's a bit 
different than using PC methods.

He also decided that having racks of CDs was waste of physical space in his 
immediate living environs, so he ripped them all and began selling them back 
to record stores. Often he'll take advantage of the 70%  no questions asked 
return policy at Ameoba. He says it drastically reduces the amount of money 
he has to spend to pick up new music on CDs. He also likes to borrow CDs 
from friends and rip them.

He says he really believes in what he calls the "digital entertainment box". 
He longs for the future he envisions when he will be able keep all his media 
(music, movies, books, magazines, games) all in one small box (a hard drive) 
and use various portable output devices (ipod, laptop, eBook, PDA,  etc.) to 
enjoy them. He says it reduces the physical clutter in his life and is also 
better for the environment. He's not attached to the physical material of 
media product. He says there is just too damn much of it to get sentimental 
about cover art, liner notes, and packaging. He just loves the music.

I think he's basically trying to recreate what I call his "own personal 
radio". Since radio now sucks more than it ever has, he is trying to replace 
the magic that it might of once held for him. He says "There's just 
something though about having a little magic box that emanates forth such 
beautiful sounds."

He likes it this way. Ain't technology great?

> A friend of mine has a 40GB external hard drive and 15GB on an

> He's been collecting them for a while. Got lots off of Hotline back 
> before Napster. Then got lots in the Napster Days. Then got lots 
> during the excellent AudioGalaxy days. Now he uses LimeWire. he's on 
> a Mac so it's a bit different than using PC methods.
> 
> He also decided that having racks of CDs was waste of physical space 
> in his immediate living environs, so he ripped them all and began 
> selling them back to record stores. Often he'll take advantage of the 
> 70%  no questions asked return policy at Ameoba. He says it 
> drastically reduces the amount of money he has to spend to pick up 
> new music on CDs. He also likes to borrow CDs from friends and rip 
> them.
> 
> He says he really believes in what he calls the "digital 
> entertainment box". He longs for the future he envisions when he will 
> be able keep all his media (music, movies, books, magazines, games) 
> all in one small box (a hard drive) and use various portable output 
> devices (ipod, laptop, eBook, PDA,  etc.) to enjoy them. He says it 
> reduces the physical clutter in his life and is also better for the 
> environment. He's not attached to the physical material of media 
> product. He says there is just too damn much of it to get sentimental 
> about cover art, liner notes, and packaging. He just loves the music.
> 
> I think he's basically trying to recreate what I call his "own 
> personal radio". Since radio now sucks more than it ever has, he is 
> trying to replace the magic that it might of once held for him. He 
> says "There's just something though about having a little magic box 
> that emanates forth such beautiful sounds."
> 
> He likes it this way. Ain't technology great?
>

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 26568 invoked from network); 24 Feb 2003 21:34:54 -0000
Message-ID: <3E5A8FF4.8010707@mail.netwiz.net>
Date: Mon, 24 Feb 2003 13:34:44 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <npm@mail.netwiz.net>
Reply-To: npm@netwiz.net
Organization: 5214-F Diamond Heights Blvd #635, San Francisco, CA 94131
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.0.2) Gecko/20021216
X-Accept-Language: en-us, en
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: _ fable _ <fable4our@hotmail.com>
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <F156CuHxM1TtAQyTvHP00005085@hotmail.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]Callin all Reason Pro's nrr (laptop advice)

_ fable _ wrote:
> Wassup to all the musicians out there.  I am gonna be buying a laptop in 
> the next few months.  I want to be able to load cakewalk sonar and 
> reason 2.0 on it.  Is this possible?  I heard there are lots of problems 
> with it.  I wont need to save tons of songs on it or nothin, thats what 
> my desktop is for.  I just want to be able to cut up a track and what 
> not while I am on the go.

There's no reason why this shouldn't be a problem, except that you're
at the mercy of whatever audio chip is installed in the laptop. Unfortunately
laptop audio tends to sound pretty bad (it'll pickup all sorts of
"computer" sounding audio noise); also, the drivers available may
not be able to get you the low level of latency you need. If you
are planning on using the laptop's internal sound, make sure at least
WDM drivers are available. Also turn off all windows sounds as
this will cause potential contention (dropouts) as well as hearing
windows sounds in your music. A better bet is an external audio
I/O over firewire (which is fast and isolates the audio from computer noise).
I believe MOTU, Roland and one other manufacturer whose name I forget
have firewire-based external audio interfaces. There's also USB interfaces
but they may not be glitch-free or low-latency.

I have successfully used A Dell Inspiron 4100 (1.2G PIII-M, 256M,
running Win2K, MOTU 828 firewire audio attached to an ADS Pyro
Cardbus firewire card. I am able to get less than 10 mS latency
using Sonar in this setup (using WDM drivers).
In Sonar 2.2, you can also get ASIO driver support (which is also
supported by the MOTU 828 2.0 drivers), which can potentially
give you as low as 2.2 mS latency (using 96 sample buffer in the 828).

Of course, your results may vary, depending on how many DXi plugins you
use, etc. Disk speed, sample rates  and bitwidth of tracks you're mixing,
etc etc etc. I havent tried using Rewire or reason 2.0 in Sonar, so that may
be an additional source of slowness. (Is there any reason why the Cyclone
DXi or Cakewalk's upcoming "project 5" won't substitute for Reason?)

Nowadays, you can prolly do well with a more modern laptop (say 2Ghz P4-M).
Try getting at least 5000+RPM ATA-100 drives ((7200 if available), and make
sure the bus is fast (you should be able to find 300+Mhz bus laptops now).
Also, you might consider getting one of those "desktop replacement" laptops
that uses a regular P4 and regular bus... this may get you better disk/memory
and processor bandwidth, which underlies the performance you'll see doing
audio on a computer.

I just started using Sonar 2.2 with the same (external) MOTU 828 and MOTU 
MTP-AV interfaces on a 3.05Ghz P4 desktop with 1G of RamBus (PC 1066) Ram, 
533Mhz bus, 7200 RPM ATA-100, drives, Windows XP Pro, and things are a lot 
smoother and less limited feeling than on the laptop.  By using external Audio 
and MIDI interfaces, I can use the same hardware on my laptop as I do on my 
desktop.

Bottom line: you'll need every ounce of processing power, memory bandwidth,
disk I/O and memory for doing audio. So unless you want to waste a lot of
time and incur a lot of frustration, go out and buy the fastest available...

PS: if anybody needs help getting desktop or laptop audio working, or needs
to tap into my vast expertise in making computer audio work successfully
with Windows, I am available for consulting on all aspects of Windows
based audio and multimedia. :-)

-- 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From: Gabriel Black <sierra_audio@sbcglobal.net>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves]Callin all Reason Pro's nrr (laptop advice)

Yes it works, The laptop studio is quite a reality
now. With a Midiman quatro soundcard and oxygen8 midi
controller, I feel I can do anything I could with a
full rack of gear, but without all the hastle of
cords, space, sync, and cost. I'm running a p4 @2ghz
laptop and having great results. There is a p4 cpu
spike bug that's quite annoying, but I haven't lost
any work so might want to check out an athlon cpu as
well. Mine has 500megs of DDR ram and a 40 gig HD.
Also, there is a program called Orion out there, that
IMHO clowns on reason, but will rewire it if you so
desire. Reason's sequencer and lack of Vsti support
make it undesireable for me. Here's a track I did
completely on orion, it will stream if you have real
audio.

http://www.dancetech.com/members/my_tracks/ram/streamer.cfm?filename_audio=DT_ACF8C17018730.mp3&dt_track_id=2766

Peace,
Gabriel

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 48011 invoked by uid 1103); 24 Feb 2003 22:17:14 -0000

X-Originating-IP: [209.179.216.63]
From: "larry melman" <whoosenation@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Mon, 24 Feb 2003 14:17:10 -0800
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F108aXW8WEbtg1zCY5P0001adf3@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 24 Feb 2003 22:17:10.0715 (UTC) FILETIME=[79B550B0:01C2DC52]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Whats in yer rig???

Hey gear freaks,

After following several threads about the pros and cons of certain equipment 
out there I noticed that there are a boatload of peeps on the list with a 
bunch of gear. Rather than argue over what piece of gear or software is the 
best I thought it would be cool to see what people out there are using in 
their rigs. I just got done with a remodel /addition on my house and had the 
opportunity  to design a dedicated room for all my equipment complete with 
soundproofed walls and sound treatments for the floor and ceiling. There are 
also auralex bass traps and foam wedges placed throughout the room for 
optimal sound. I currently get roughly 70 db of noise reduction from the 
sound proofing. The entire room has a dedicated power line seperate from the 
rest of the house to prevent any natsy surges or dips. Almost all my old 
analog stuff has been sold, I sampled everything I need, to give me more 
work space. The room dimensions are  12 x 18. I'd love to compare notes.

Here is a roster of the current rig

computer: apple dual g4/1ghz, apple dual g4/450, (2) 18 gb seagate barracuda 
external drive
console: tascam dm-24  32ch/ 8 bus digital mixer
recorders: hhb cd recorder, tascam da -45 hr dat recorder, sony dual casette
amplifier: crown k2
monitors:  (2)mackie hr 824, sony mdr v6 headphones
misc hardware: (2) pb 48 dbx 1/4 trs patch bay, dtp motu universal 
sychcronizer, mtp av motu midi interface, 2408 mk3 pci digital recording 
system, 24 io motu interface
power conditioning: furman pl - plus
microphones: audio technica at 4047, audio technica at 4041, audix 
hypercardioid drum mic dp1
mic preamps: presonus digitube digital mk preamp, aphex dual channel tube 
mic preamp
effects/ outboard: cl 44 presonus compressor/limiter, tla50  summit audio 
leveling amp, 882 bbe sonic maximizer, 2231 dbx dual 31 band graphic eq, 
studioquad 4 digitech multi effects processor, mpx 200 lexicon 2ch effects 
processor
keyboards/samplers:korg triton rack, nord lead 3, emu proteus 2000, (2) 
oberheim matrix 1000, roland tb 303, emu e4xt ultra sampler, roland a - 37 
midi controler, emu launch pad.
software: emagic logic platinum 5, emagic sound diver, ableton live, bias 
peak, recycle, apogee session tools, applied acoustics lounge lizard, 
antares kantos, reason 2.0, rebirth, Native instruments absynth, ni b3, pro 
52, dynamo, battery vst, fm -7, kontact, ppg wave
drums/bass: roland hdp 15, roland spd 20, alesis dm pro, novation drum 
station, lp bongos, lp conga, fender bass 5 string
dj stuff:  (2)technics 1200s, vestax pmc 170a
misc: ps2

future purchases: tc works powercore, mackie uad card, roland v drums stage 
kit,  sit down ms pac man machine

If anyone needs some gear advice or tips on soundproofing hit me up 
privately and we can chat.

but this one goes to 11,
DJMC

references to form elements from the document collection? wtf?) I'm sure
this very thing's been done well before -- I just wonder why *this* one
ended up getting forwarded to three separate lists I'm on... /sigh/.

At 12:05 PM 2/24/2003, Rayn wrote:

>I'm waiting for the day when solid state drives are huge and cheap
>before I do anything like that.  With movable parts hard drives are
>still too unstable for me to devote myself to them completely.  Unless
>you have a raid array, putting everything on hard disk with no real way
>to be able to back it all up is really taking a chance.
>
>As for personal radio I've fallen in love with the Launch.com service
>offered by Yahoo.  They don't have everything available by the artists
>but the selection they have is amazing.  You configure your station how
>you want by rating songs, it will throw in random songs from similar
>artists you haven't configured yet etc and you slowly build youself a
>station that fits you and your tastes.  They also just added a moods
>feature that allows you to play music based on your moods as opposed to
>playing everything from your interests.  The free service has a 15 - 30
>second commecial about every 8 songs and it is really not annoying at
>all, and the pay service is pretty cheap if you want to get rid of
>commercials and take advantage of a few more features.
>
>Here's the link to my station that I have configured so you can take a
>look at what you can do with it.  I have very eclectic tastes that are
>definitely reflected here.
>http://launch.yahoo.com/lc/?rt=0&rp1=0&rp2=1208269951
>
>-Rayn
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: blindspot [mailto:blindspot@mac.com]
>Sent: Monday, February 24, 2003 11:23 AM
>To: boomboom@boomerangfidget.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] mp3 addiction (nrr)
>
>
>A friend of mine has a 40GB external hard drive and 15GB on an
>internal PowerBook drive full and will soon be in need of another.
>He's been collecting them for a while. Got lots off of Hotline back
>before Napster. Then got lots in the Napster Days. Then got lots
>during the excellent AudioGalaxy days. Now he uses LimeWire. he's on
>a Mac so it's a bit different than using PC methods.
>
>He also decided that having racks of CDs was waste of physical space
>in his immediate living environs, so he ripped them all and began
>selling them back to record stores. Often he'll take advantage of the
>70%  no questions asked return policy at Ameoba. He says it
>drastically reduces the amount of money he has to spend to pick up
>new music on CDs. He also likes to borrow CDs from friends and rip
>them.
>
>He says he really believes in what he calls the "digital
>entertainment box". He longs for the future he envisions when he will
>be able keep all his media (music, movies, books, magazines, games)
>all in one small box (a hard drive) and use various portable output
>devices (ipod, laptop, eBook, PDA,  etc.) to enjoy them. He says it
>reduces the physical clutter in his life and is also better for the
>environment. He's not attached to the physical material of media
>product. He says there is just too damn much of it to get sentimental
>about cover art, liner notes, and packaging. He just loves the music.
>
>I think he's basically trying to recreate what I call his "own
>personal radio". Since radio now sucks more than it ever has, he is
>trying to replace the magic that it might of once held for him. He
>says "There's just something though about having a little magic box
>that emanates forth such beautiful sounds."
>
>He likes it this way. Ain't technology great?
>
>
>

Funky House Room Hosted by House Nation

T H E F U N K I S T aka DJ FLAVE
(USCevents.com, and Zion's gate records - Seattle, WA)

After searching the globe we are excited to bring you one of the most
talented, cutting edge djs we have ever seen. The next level of djs is here!
Dj Flave not only scratches with his foot but also has an arsenal of never
before seen dj tricks to blow your mind. All the way from Seattle dont miss
his exclusive first ever Bay Area appearance. The best way to describe his
style is having the interactive energy of Donald Glaude, the technical
skills of dj Dan and a personality all his own.

Josh the Funky 1
(IHR/Mix Connection/Funktion/Fused  Chicago)

Hailing from Chicago, Josh, co produced Bad Boy Bills Bangn the Box Vol.4
 cd and has been know to rock crowds all over the world! Josh has also won
several scratching competitions and has produced for IHR and for his own
label Funktion. Come see why Josh is one of the most exciting djs in the
world and has sold thousands of his hit cd series Digital Funk.

Joey Mazzola vs Reckless Ryan
(Solmatic, joeymazzola.com) (recklessyan.com, 90.5 KSJS/BASSLINE FM)
Joey the producer of the hit record This is the Way we Rock on Solmatic
Records is the most sought after dj in the bay. Combining with Reckless Ryan
who has filled the dance floors at underground parties and major clubs from
SF, LA, AZ, NV, NY and beyond. We are proud to bring these two talented
artists for you to experience the ultimate funk!

Val Sparks vs Bazooka Joe
(valeriesparks.com)(djbazookajoe.com, Straight Hits)
By special request we are bringing you the first ever set with these two
local favorites!

(House Nation, SF)

Planet New Year, Cyberfest, Mango, and Banana.

2. Taught by the best DJ's around the country come see what talent Zelda
unleashes!

Southern Cali djs face off! This exclusive 2 hour battle set is guaranteed
to make history. Producers Dyloot and Theo are preparing a legendary set
that will be remembered for years to come!

(djdenise.com) (House Nation, Cool World)
Denise and St John have long been crowd favorites here in the Bay now for
years. With Denises increased travels, she is becoming a well recognized
and requested dj all along the west coast! Also, with St Johns radio show
House Nation and a number of top selling cd St John Do not miss some of the
Bays best and most popular talents!

to when you wanted your beats HARD! With his label Resistance Recordings
making waves internationally and top Hard House and Hardcore DJs playing his
material, Dj Tronic is on a rise to the top of the American Hard House and
Hardcore scene.

Friends,

A lot of you know our dear friend and
member of the Eyephunk family...

       KJ is facing deportation to Pakistan.

As he is Hindu (it is a Muslim country)
and he is gay (they do allow for stoning homosexuals to death)
he is sure to face extreme consequences if this happens.
He is seeking political asylum.

        This is not a joke.
        We are asking for your help!!


Information on how you can help is up at this address:

         http://www.eyephunk.com/kj/


Again, we are asking our community for help to support
our brother KJ who has touched so many people...
and has done so much for his greater American
community, not just San Francisco.

Will you please take a moment to write some words
to support his claim of political asylum?
It could save his life.

A short letter or long letter, any letter will do.
We are deeply distressed about this situation,
as you can imagine.

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Anna, Adam, Dave 'Dov', Stacey, Dave 'Vajra',
Kary, Liam, Ashley, Cyril and Surge

Source: An e-mail from a young gay man in Pakistan 1/02

To be gay in Pakistani and community is considered a gross abuse as well as
a mortal sin as terrible religion Islam holds extremely hostile policy
towards gays as according to so called Islamic scholars "if gays are caught
red handed they must be be headed, stoned to death or thrown from the
highest peak of lofty mountain to eradicate this inclination. (according to
panal code of Pakistan.)

In Pakistan, the Homosexual activity is illegal, punishable with life in
prison, and corporal punishment of 100 lashes, while Islamic law, which also
can be enforced legally, calls for up to 100 lashes or death by stoning. (a
report by an international human rights commission about hmosexuality in
Pakistan.)

quality..

that I don't use or even need to use since it's been outmoded. Here we go.

Absynth. Psp lexicon 84. Junglist. Scorpion (all vsti's)
Monitors - event project studio 6. Jbl game monitors w/subwoofer.
Compressor - 1066xl dbx. 166 dbx
Keyboard - nord lead 2
Effects - studio quad v2 (selling for 150$ OBO!)
Sampler - akai s5000
Record - tascam DA-40 dat. Sony dual tape. Sony mdr-? Minidisc. Apple Ipod!
Mixer - mackie 1404vlz
Turntables - 2xtechnic's w/blue ortofon

"Why of course the people don't want war. . . .

That is understood. But, after all, it is the leaders of the country who
determine the policy and it is always a simple matter to drag the people
along, whether it is a democracy, or a fascist dictatorship, or a
parliament, or a communist dictatorship. Voice or no voice, the people can
always be brought to the bidding of the leaders. That is easy. All you have
to do is tell them they are being attacked, and denounce the peacemakers for
lack of patriotism and exposing the country to danger. It works the same in
any country."

                 --Hermann Goering, during his Nuremberg war crimes trial


Moksha Tribe

market right now. Most made by 1-2 man teams.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] mp3 addiction (nrr)


I have about 40 gigs of music but I have lost the lust for MP3's.
I really miss reading liner notes. Holding a record jacket or cd case and
feeling the packaging. There is a vibe/connection to the music.
One big victim of Mp3 proliferation will be those authors of liner notes.
Though I expect that they can not make money while they make art somewhere
else.

That said, I wish some folk would move over to "Win MX" cause there isn't a
large enough selection of Underground music.(of all genres)

well...since everyone else is doing it...Here's my gear list:

I've toned it down a lot now that the computer can do many things better 
than some of the old outboard gear I used to have.

Computer:
Apple Mac Dual 1Ghz w/768Mb RAM 2X100Gb Drives

Audio Interface:
MOTU 828 Firewire

MIDI Interface:
MOTU MIDI Express USB (Finally had to get rid of the Opcode Studio 5 LX)

Software: I'm currently going back and forth between OS9 and OSX (until OSX 
is fully up to speed for audio)
OS9:
Cubase VST 5.1
Reason 2 (rewired into Cubase, mostly for the dope sampler)
Absynth
NI Pro52
Waldorf PPG Wave 2.v
ReCycle 2
Peak 3
TRacks/24
TC VST Plug-ins
Various other VST plug-ins
OSX:
Cubase SX
Reason 2.0 (Rewired into Cubase SX, mostly for the dope sampler)
Peak 3.x

Monitors:
Event Tria system

Keyboards:
Nord Lead 2
Kawai K5000s
Emu EMAX SE (Old school, baby!)

Mixer:
Yamaha 12/4

Outboard Gear:
Roland Space Echo RE201 (That was made in 1974!)
Alesis compressor (good only for using compression and gate as a mixer 
insert effect)
2 Patch bays

Turntables & DJ Mixer:
2x1200 mk2
Vestax 07Pro

Expect to hear some new tracks very soon.


Cheers,

** :CODE -> two rooms of live electronic music and DJs!
          || trance. techno. electro. jungle. drum+bass.
          || http://code.dnalounge.com
          || http://www.dnalounge.com/flyers/2003/02/13-code.html
          || displaying :CODE sequence for 02.27.03:

** Onstage bringing his original live techno to :CODE is Omniscient
   Records label owner Praxis. The style of music he makes varies
   immensely from hard, dark techno, to funky tech-house, to acid
   tech-trance, to hard breaks--but your one safe bet is that
   you'll be dancing and drawn in by Praxis' charismatic
   performance. You'll see nearly his full studio onstage, a
   virtual "command center" of equipment, all being triggered live
   and on the fly by a true musician.


IN THE MAIN ROOM:
---+-----------------------------------------------------------
   | Praxis -- live PA             [ Omniscient / BPM Culture ]
   | Amber                                [ :CODE / Sister SF ]

X-Sender: apollo@mail.speakeasy.org

Date: Wed, 26 Feb 2003 10:59:55 -0800

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_2429113==_.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Repeal Higher Education Act Drug Provision

--=====================_2429113==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

  ---- http://www.RaiseYourVoice.com ----


With the 108th Congress upon us and Reauthorization of the
Higher Education Act being worked on now, we at the Drug Reform
Coordination Network are writing to ask you to help turn up the
heat on the student-led campaign to repeal the Higher Education
Act's drug provision (http://www.RaiseYourVoice.com).


During the 2001-2002 school year, more than 47,700 students were
denied access to federal college aid because of drug
convictions, loans, grants, even work-study programs.  This
number doesn't account for people who didn't bother applying
because they assumed they would be ineligible.  The current
academic year, the third in which the drug provision is in force
and the second in which it is being fully enforced, is expected
to see just as many young people forced out of school or they or
their families plunged into financial hardship because of the
HEA drug provision.


In February of 2003, Rep. Barney Frank (D-MA) reintroduced his
legislation to repeal the drug provision in full.  Last year,
the bill had garnered 67 cosponsors, and 10 members of Congress
spoke at a press conference at the US Capitol organized by the
DRCNet-sponsored Coalition for Higher Education Act Reform.
Already, the new Frank bill, H.R. 685, has picked up 40
cosponsors, and Students for Sensible Drug Policy now stretches
across more than 200 campuses, with hundreds more in the works,
a formidable force turning up the heat on this issue.  Your help
is needed to meet and exceed the support the bill had last year
and to go on to get the drug provision repealed.  The most
likely opportunity for that is the Higher Education Act
reauthorization process.


Please visit http://www.RaiseYourVoice.com to write Congress,
learn about the issue and download our newly-updated activist
packet.  (Hit reload or refresh on your browser if you get a
"campaign expired" message.)  When you're done, please call your
Representative on the phone to make an even stronger impact --
you can use the Congressional switchboard at (202) 224-3121, or
visit http://www.house.gov to look up their direct numbers.


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

becomes transformed."

there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Sneak-a-Toke??

Notice that part of this press release, which came out two days ago,
refers to an operation that took place in January 2000. The DEA is trying
to inflate the numbers by adding numbers from an old bust to the new one,
basically.

Also, check out this piece in the New York Times that's obviously based on
the DEA press release:

http://www.nytimes.com/2003/02/24/politics/24CND-DRUG.html

It's even more inflammatory, using terms like "school highliters" which
weren't in the original press release. And they unquestioningly report
Ashcroft's propaganda:

> But Mr. Ashcroft, joined by the head of the D.E.A. and the White House
> drug czar, said the rising ease with which young people could get
> their hands on paraphernalia was a growing concern to him and others in
> the administration.

Where is the fact checking on that quote? How about some statistics that
would actually show that sales of paraphernalia were up? Bah.

Subject: [sfraves] PCDJ.com -- please cease and desist spamming people who subscribe

--------------060708080506080401060908
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I really don't appreciate continuing to receive spam from PCDJ. After
unsubscribing a few times, I just received yet another piece of spam
about an event in Florida (I live in SF, I have no interest in FLA).
I hit the unsubscribe button and it indicates I've already unsubscribed.
Nonetheless, I am still receiving spam from PCDJ.

Furthermore, I am also receiving significant spam from PCDJ "affiliates"
which doesn't seem to be stopping either. Your affiliate spam is complete
nonsense and has nothing to do with my interests. It's just generic spam.

If this doesn't stop, I will start putting out mass warnings against PCDJ
on many of the major rave lists and newsgroups, stating that you sell your
mailing list names to spammers. This is totally wrong.

At this point, I am so annoyed w/ PCDJ that I will never buy any products
from your company or your affiliates, and I will tell anybody I know
that your company is spam-scum.

By the way, I am a Native Instruments Traktor user currently, and
that product is far superior to anything you spam-happy clowns could
ever produce. In addition to great products, N.I. also has a sense of
ethics about the private information they gather from customers. The
mailings I get from them are pertinent and wanted because they're
strictly related to the products in which I've expressed interest.

PS: Deriving revenue from spam is not a business model. It's just cheezy.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Subject: Join me in a Virtual March on Washington


Please join me NOW in registering for a Virtual March on Washington
today, February 26th.  We are asking Congress to stop the Bush
administration's rush to war, and to Let the Inspections Work.
Time is running out.

With your help every Senate office will receive
a call EVERY MINUTE from a constituent, as they receive a
simultaneous crush of faxes and email.  In New York and Washington
D.C., "antiwar rooms" will highlight the progress of the day for
national media. Local media will visit the "antiwar room" online,
to monitor this constituent march throughout the day.

With your help, every Senate office switchboard will be lit up all
day with our antiwar messages. This will be a powerful reminder
of the breadth and depth of opposition to a war in Iraq.

Just go to:


    http://www.moveon.org/winwithoutwar/

Please join me and sign up now.  This has never been done
before.

From sfraves-return-99321-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Feb 26 23:47:00 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-99321-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 34572 invoked by uid 1103); 26 Feb 2003 23:47:00 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 34555 invoked from network); 26 Feb 2003 23:47:00 -0000
Mime-Version: 1.0
X-Sender: blindspot@mail.mac.com
Message-Id: <p04330104ba82ff099680@[172.16.2.25]>
Date: Wed, 26 Feb 2003 15:47:01 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: blindspot <blindspot@mac.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Paradoxical BSPs

Isn't it sort of paradoxical to what electronic dance music is when 
one bills the talent of an electronic dance music event as a "techno 
pioneer" or "originator of house".

It seems to me that electronic dance music has always been about 
what's happening with the sound RIGHT NOW or maybe even whats ABOUT 
TO HAPPEN or even what's happening TOMORROW.

The above phrases seem to me to harken to something old.

I know phrases like "pioneer" or "originator" are meant to connote a 
certain amount of genuine-ness about the person or music involved. 
Still, I expect that before these talents were pioneers or 
originators it was something else that made the kids flock to see and 
hear them, not any conferred status of "pioneer" or "originator".

It seems so normal to promote things like this that I'd be shocked if 
saw a BSP that told me I was gonna see or hear something I've never 
seen or heard before. In other words, how about a BSP that promotes 
something new instead of something old?

So jaded, I'm not jaded.

bs

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Operation Pipe Dreams Is a Nightmare

--=====================_1987823==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Operation Pipe Dreams Is a Nightmare

By Debra McCorkle, AlterNet
February 25, 2003

People selling drug paraphernalia are in essence no different than drug=20
dealers. They are as much a part of drug trafficking as silencers are a=20
part of criminal homicide.
=96 John Brown, acting DEA chief

I'd like to direct Mr. Brown to the Web site of revelationarms.com of=20
Aloha, Oregon. Not only will they sell me a gun silencer, there is an=20
entire page devoted to explicit directions on how to obtain the necessary=20
paperwork and background check in order to allow me to purchase a silencer=
=20
online. I have to be at least 21 and innocent of any felony crime. One=20
credit card payment and a little paperwork and I can blow someone's head=20
off with a minimum of personal hearing damage.

Of course John Brown, of the Drug Enforcement Agency, has little interest=20
in guns and murder outside of the world of drug dealing. In the last couple=
=20
of days, however, he has overseen the arrest of at least 55 people whose=20
only stated crime was the manufacture and selling of tobacco accessories.=20
His equation of bong-makers with drug traffickers is ludicrous at best, and=
=20
his apparent indifference to the legal sale of silencers across America=20
makes him a hypocrite caught in his own words.

This action, known as Operation Pipe Dreams, is part of a continuing effort=
=20
on the the part of Attorney General John Ashcroft to rid our land of the=20
ability to smoke weed with a little style. In the past 10 years the=20
pipemaking industry took an art class and began to integrate aesthetics=20
into the production line. Handblown glass pipes began as a one-of-a-kind=20
art form created usually by twentysomethings with talent and time on their=
=20
hands. Over the years pipes became amazingly elaborate, with high-end=20
waterpipes evolving into colorful gothic cathedrals. Simple $20=20
spoon-shaped pocket handpipes became the common smoking apparatus of=20
choice, replacing decades of utilitarian metal and acrylic.

However, the powers-that-be want a return to the paraphernalia stone age.=20
If the DEA has its way, that loathsome scum of an American subculture who=20
still dare to believe that smoking various herbal substances is their own=20
damned business will be forced back into stealing plumbing screens from=20
their faucets and emptying out plastic honey bears in order to fashion=20
crude waterpipes a la Brad Pitt in the movie "True Romance." Pepsi cans and=
=20
beer bottles will be pulled out of trashcans, aquarium tubing will be=20
purchased at Wal-Mart, and lamp parts from Home Depot will turn into pipe=20
bowls for the waterpipes that will be Rube Goldberged into existence.

Americans have been given the distinct impression that our federal budget=20
is strapped for cash and that we need all resources to ferret out the=20
terrorists in our midst. It seems a waste of resources to carry out=20
Operation Pipe Dreams in order to ensure that 55 pipesellers will no longer=
=20
be on the streets while terrorist cells await their orders in the heartland=
=20
of America. Doesn't Ashcroft have better things to do? What about those=20
darned silencers all over the internet?

In the meantime, lives are being ruined. Many if not most paraphernalia=20
dealers are under 40 years old and guiltier of being young and na=EFve than=
=20
of being dangerous. If forfeiture occurs there may not be enough money for=
=20
their families to hire top-notch lawyers. In a recent conviction Chris Hill=
=20
of Chills Pipes was sentenced to one year at the Eglin prison facility, and=
=20
Hill was one of the wealthier pipe manufacturers in the U.S. Pipe dealers=20
have not made their profits from stealing or acts of violence. It is an odd=
=20
choice on the part of the U.S. government to convict young entrepenuers and=
=20
house them in prisons at great taxpayer expense.

Over at impactguns.com there's a virtual cornucopia of submachine guns,=20
some with silencers, some without. There's an HK MP5 A3 machine gun=20
transferable 9mm in excellent condition on sale for $8,800. Oh darn, it's=20
got a "Sold" sign by the price. The top of the page states: "Machine guns=20
are a specialty here at Impact. They are very easy to purchase and are a=20
great investment."

If only our forefathers had the insight to put in an amendment for smoking=
=20
accessories right there with the right to bear arms. Maybe then John=20
Ashcroft and his DEA buddies could just sit around the fire with Tommy=20
Chong and the other paraphernalia company owners, and their only pipe=20
dreams would be world peace.


Debra McCorkle is a shopowner living in the mountains of North Carolina.

http://www.alternet.org/drugreporter/


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one=20
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But=20
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

At 03:47 PM 2/26/2003 -0800, blindspot wrote:
>Isn't it sort of paradoxical to what electronic dance music is when one 
>bills the talent of an electronic dance music event as a "techno pioneer" 
>or "originator of house".

That is a quasi-legal definition that everyone seemed to agree on in the 
house community years ago to end to shit about who "created" house 
music.  Jesse couldn't legitimately make that claim, of course, because 
this or any genre developed out of the work and creativity of many.  He 
stakes his claim, not at the creator, but as the "originator" because he 
published the first house release.

It's all crazy.  When I go back to writing House Music 101 I'll get into 
the details of all this.

Love,

Apollo


>It seems to me that electronic dance music has always been about what's 
>happening with the sound RIGHT NOW or maybe even whats ABOUT TO HAPPEN or 
>even what's happening TOMORROW.
>
>The above phrases seem to me to harken to something old.
>
>I know phrases like "pioneer" or "originator" are meant to connote a 
>certain amount of genuine-ness about the person or music involved. Still, 
>I expect that before these talents were pioneers or originators it was 
>something else that made the kids flock to see and hear them, not any 
>conferred status of "pioneer" or "originator".
>
>It seems so normal to promote things like this that I'd be shocked if saw 
>a BSP that told me I was gonna see or hear something I've never seen or 
>heard before. In other words, how about a BSP that promotes something new 
>instead of something old?
>
>So jaded, I'm not jaded.
>
>bs

get this, the tag line they use in that smarmy, know better than you, voice
says:

"Marijuania, it impairs judgement."

So far, so good.

of $20 million for just the airtime and not once did the subject of impaired
judgement, or say, it being a vehicle for date rate ever come up....

Want to do something about all this?

http://www.siliconsalon.com/420.htm

Enough is enough.

scientists of sound

/ / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / /


s e c r e t  _  g a r d e n
every friday night in monterey

a future blend of electronic and organic sounds
dub // downtempo // brokenbeat // nujazz // bossa nova //
deep jazzy house // 2*step // afro-tech // futurefunk //

tune into:
CHEMISTRY every other wednesday night
10pm to 12am on 90.9fm KHDC
with your hosts: kiyoshi one and sunshine

what i love about this ad is that it premiered during the "Super"Bowl.

get this, the tag line they use in that smarmy, know better than you, voice
says:

"Marijuania, it impairs judgement."

So far, so good.

Save for the fact that Budweiser ran **ELEVEN** beer ads at a minimum cost
of $20 million for just the airtime and not once did the subject of impaired
judgement, or say, it being a vehicle for date rate ever come up....

Want to do something about all this?

Circle April 20th on your calendar and pass on this link to a friend:

http://www.siliconsalon.com/420.htm

Enough is enough.

See you on the barricades.

nic

Ok, the ad that gets me is,



<Must be part to of the ad you mentioned>



You see a girl looking concerned, Her parents are standing there looking at
something, you see that they are looking at a pregnancy test; their little
girl is pregnant. Then the voice over, Marijuana can impair your judgment
(or something to that effect). First time I saw it I thought gosh, I didn't
know you could get pregnant from smoking some pot!

At 08:07 PM 2/26/2003 -0800, Sarilion wrote:
>Or the one where the brother visits the tree his sibling drove into while 
>high on pot?  Didn't say what else he was high on, or whether he was 
>drunk, or if there was inclement weather.  I went to Monte Vista, and 
>there was a guy in my class that drove into a tree and died.  He was 
>sober.  Nothing prevents stupidity except personal responsibility.
>
>
>sarilion

I was watching Mad TV last Saturday.  Rarely view commercial TV, but with 
my partner's illness we have been hanging around weekend nights watching 
movies and such.  (BTW, 24 Hour Party People is a must see).

Anyhow, you've all seen the "depression" commercials for some Prozac-like 
drug.  Cartoon faces.  Sad.  Expressing loss of interest in formerly 
attractive pursuits, etc.  Well, we see something very much like this on 
the screen.  Same sad faces.  Same symptoms of depression.  Then, the 
announcer says:  "Why not try Ecstasy?"  So the faces do E and they are all 
smiling.  Diagrams appear explaining the action of E on the mind.  The 
smiling faces bounce down past a "Rave" sign and they end up in a large 
venue with green glowsticks and Moby as the DJ.   As in the Prozac 
commercial there is an overview of bad side effects, and these included a 
compulsion to vote Green Party.

Right after this satirical thing, the anti-bud propaganda comes on:  the 
one with the 16-year old girl who got pregnant because she smoked pot.

And I thought to myself -- what a bizarre space we inhabit these 
days.  Took another toke and put "Reefer Madness" on the DVD player.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Sneak-a-Toke??


what i love about this ad is that it premiered during the "Super"Bowl.

get this, the tag line they use in that smarmy, know better than you, voice
says:

"Marijuania, it impairs judgement."

So far, so good.

Save for the fact that Budweiser ran **ELEVEN** beer ads at a minimum cost
of $20 million for just the airtime and not once did the subject of impaired
judgement, or say, it being a vehicle for date rate ever come up....

Want to do something about all this?

Circle April 20th on your calendar and pass on this link to a friend:

http://www.siliconsalon.com/420.htm

Enough is enough.

See you on the barricades.

nic

Subject: [sfraves] SFbay604 presents: Psy-Fi 604


We are happy to announce the release of Psy-Fi 604, SFbay604's first
compilation album.  This album contains unreleased tracks produced
exclusively by members of the SFbay604 bay area psy-trance mailing list.

Tracks on this album span many of the directions psy-trance has taken in
the last few years, from the traditional goa-inspired sound, to
techno-tinged, to the more minimal, to uplifting, to breaky, and to full-on
mind warping.

Arists include Temporary Humanity, wORMFOOD, Prabhamandala, Fractal Cowboys,
oCeLoT, Bufo, Ferrapsylix, Rinsl and Sanyama.

There are several way to obtain this CD.  We will be giving them out as
free gifts at the KJ release party this friday for those who contribute $20
for admission (while supplies last).  (This party is located in San Francisco)

You can order them online for $10+S/H at:
http://store.mixonic.com/sf604

This page has a link to high-quality .mp3 samples of all the tracks, and
features the stunning cover graphics work of Chris Olerich.

We may also be selling these at future events, including the Taco Portal
at the Boarder Cantina on upcoming thursday nights.

-Troy, and the entire Psy-Fi 604 production team.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

http://www.saturn5.com/tsheets/audio                 <- my .mp3 tracks

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Rounding Up the "Terrorists"

--=====================_4042683==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed




http://www.informationclearinghouse.info/article1684.htm
Santa Fe Police Arrest Attorney For Comments he Made In An Internet
Chat-Room


A St. John's College Library visit by a former public defender was abruptly
interrupted February 13 when city police officers arrested him about 9 p.m.
at the computer terminal he was using, handcuffed him, and brought him to
the Santa Fe, New Mexico, police station for questioning by Secret Service
agents from Albuquerque. Andrew J. O'Conner, 40, who was released about five
hours later, said in the February 16 Santa Fe New Mexican, "I'm going to sue
the Secret Service, Santa Fe Police, St. John's, and everybody involved in
this whole thing."


According to O'Connor, the agents accused him of making threatening remarks
about President George W. Bush in an Internet chat room. Admitting he talked
politics face-to-face in the library with a woman who was wearing a "No war
with Iraq" button, O'Connor recalled saying that Bush is "out of control,"
but that "I'm allowed to say all that. There is this thing called freedom of
speech." He also speculated that the FBI might have been observing him
because of his one-time involvement in a pro-Palestinian group in Boulder,
Colorado.


Earlier on the same day O'Connor was questioned, officials at St. John's-as
well as at the College of Santa Fe and Santa Fe Community College-issued
warnings to students and faculty that the FBI had been alerted to the
presence of "suspicious" people on campus within the past four weeks.


Concern about threats to individual privacy under the USA Patriot Act has
prompted New Mexico legislators in both houses to propose resolutions urging
state police not to help federal agents infringe on civil rights. The
resolutions also encourage libraries to post prominent signage warning
patrons that their library records are subject to federal scrutiny without
their permission or knowledge.


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one 
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But 
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

on 2/27/03 11:40 AM, Nathan Seven at scosol@yahoo.com wrote:

> Uhm-was anybody else just totally creeped out by Mr Rogers?

I found him to be a condescending bastard with an annoying twang, even as a
little kid. His public statement to kids on Gulf War One back when I was in
high school proved it to me. Guess I was a jaded jerk-off since childhood ;)
He helped foster my disdain for authority, so I suppose I should be thankful
for that.

Regardless, anyone dying of cancer is a sucky thing, IMO, but at least he
lived a long life and did a lot for kids who needed a push into imagining
things, which is always a plus in my book. I'm not gonna dance on the man's
grave.

I did think that the postman being named "Mr. McFeely" was creepy, though!

 - omid

Subject: [sfraves] Re: look out!  they're watching.. (SRR: Sneak-a-Toke??)

be careful where you point your browser...

-------------------

The feds are now starting to take over domain names of suspected law
breakers...such as mod chip sellers and sites that sell "tobacco"
pipes...and routing them directly to the DOJ website.

But that is not what is scary...this is:

The privacy policy on the Justice Department's site permits the DOJ to
hand personal information about visitors to the FBI or other law
enforcement agencies. It says, "We may take additional steps to identify
you based on this information, and we may share this information,
including your identity, with other government agencies."

so if you go to look at one of those sites that got busted, you will get
routed to the dept of justice and probably added to their list of "people
to watch."  sneaky bastards...

http://www.businessweek.com/technology/cnet/stories/986225.htm

Subject: RE: [sfraves] SRR: Sneak-a-Toke??

Not to mention we got the commercial where the kids are playing adults
in their dad's study while smokin' off a bong and he pulls the gun out
of the drawyer and it just happens to go off... I like how while he's
high, the gun isin't pointing anywhere really, just kinda wayward.. Now
if they were drunk with alcohol's agression factor, the commercial would
be much different.. He'd be pointing the gun at the kid with both of
them laughing most likely when it goes off.

Then you got the ones of the guys in the drive through that eventually
run over the kid on the bike because they ran out of money from buying
too much pot, wherein they go on to freak out and stomp on the gas
because their impaired judgement led them to believe that since they
couldn't pay they'd be in trouble...  Riiiiiiiiiigggghhhhhtttt.....
Everyone knows that most drivethroughs take credit cards/debit cards
now... Plus.. I don't think your avg. paranoid pot smoker would be
hotboxing their car while going through the drive through.  Except maybe
in the mission district.

Ahhh... Beautiful propaganda..  These commercials are like a sieve
filled with ice cubes.

be careful where you point your browser...

 

-------------------

 

The feds are now starting to take over domain names of suspected law

breakers...such as mod chip sellers and sites that sell "tobacco"

pipes...and routing them directly to the DOJ website.

 

But that is not what is scary...this is:

 

The privacy policy on the Justice Department's site permits the DOJ to

hand personal information about visitors to the FBI or other law

enforcement agencies. It says, "We may take additional steps to 

identify

you based on this information, and we may share this information,

including your identity, with other government agencies."

 

so if you go to look at one of those sites that got busted, you will 

get

routed to the dept of justice and probably added to their list of 

"people

to watch."  sneaky bastards...

from http://www.Merriam-Webster.com

terrorism
Pronunciation:	'ter-&r-"i-z&m
Function:	noun
Date:	1795
: the systematic use of terror especially as a means of coercion


terror
Pronunciation:	'ter-&r
Function:	noun
Etymology:	Middle English, from Middle French terreur, from 
Latin terror, from terrEre to frighten; akin to Greek trein to be 
afraid, flee, tremein to tremble -- more at TREMBLE
Date:	14th century
1 : a state of intense fear



So ask yourself WHO is using fear to coerce us? And HOW OFTEN and HOW 
SYSTEMATICALLY are they using it?


Now whose the REAL terrorist?

grandfathers

and

glass shatter.  He was just looking at the gun and stuff and it went off,
the bullet
went from where he was through the other wall opposite him, at our head
level and
2 feet in front of us.  Ahem.  Doesn't take aggression or any drug at all
for that
kinda thing to happen, and any drug being involved is going to up the ante
for
something bad to happen, intentional or not.

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 28 Feb 2003 03:41:48.0464 (UTC) FILETIME=[52973300:01C2DEDB]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Memoirs of a San franciscan vol. 3

   Today was absolutley beautiful!  I hope you can tell through the
intonation of this email note.
It was one of those days where the air touched your soul the way
you'd want it to every day.  Crisp, alive everso tender.
Since I moved to San Francisco, I have hurdled over the most
wonderful little obstacles that life could have given me from moving
into a new city filled with so much incertainty.  First there was
finding the right job.  It's easy to find work that pays the bills,
but finding one that satisfies someone on all the emotional levels
as well as one that will support your future growth and strength,
well, I  think I found it and I am very content.        Then I found
another, working at a very "she-she" nightclub called Ruby Skye.  (I
already got to ask a a guy who is in "6 feet Under" what his sign
was, he he he)
     There has been a big difference between the "type" of people
that I have waited on in Santa Cruz versus the "city folk" but the
one thing that hasn't changed one bit is that we are all here for
the same reason and that still makes me be able to relate to
everyone and have a wonderful time doing so.
    Today I awoke and turned on the news so I could hear  "the
communicators of sorrow."  We all know these folks as 'journalists.'
    Fred Rogers died today at the age of seventy-four.  Mr Rogers,
as we all know, helped us grow through his television show "Mr.
Roger's Neighborhood."  The things that I learned from this
gentleman have been those of compassion, respect, and imagination.
Who would have known that a person who you only watched every day of
your childhood could truly shape the way we see things such a long
time afterwards?  I also find it wonderful realizing how everyone
finally notices  how much a certain person meant to them once they
have passed on.
    At my restaurant today, right smack dab in the middle of the
financial district, surrounded my what seems to be hundreds of
skyscrapers owned by all the people neglecting you folks of a job, I
noticed a very common mood between everyone, a sort of meloncholy
existed everywhere.  One lady litterally had her head down a she
proceeded to order her chinese chicken salad.
  "Are you doing okay? I asked.
  "I've had better days," she said woefully.
   "I know, I heard"
  "heard what?,"  her eyes seemed excited to hear what I had to
say.
   "Mr. Rogers."
   "Whatabout Mr. Rogers?" she asked.
    Uh oh, She obviously hadn't heard the news and already having a
bad day based on whatever she may be going through, I didn't realize
that I may be the "journalist" in her day.  I told her.  She burried
her head in the salad.
    "Fuck," I thought, I always do shit like this, trying to help
people out and then it coming right back bigger that the biggest
foot could ever fit in my mouth.
    "Well at least he taught us something."  She said.
    Thank  god the woman had some sort of positivity vibrating in her head.
    "What do you think he taught us?" I asked.
    "He taught us everything but how to eat a chinese chicken salad
correctly."
   "oh,"  I never really thought about that...
     I thought about it and I thought about it and I thought about
it.  Basically I figured out that such simple things can come from
what seem to be such simple people.  Did Mr. Rogers surround himself
with drama, pain, and sorrow?  Nope, what about all of his friends
in that little world of his who still haven't come out of the closet
after all these years...They didn't have drama either, they were
always just mere friends in a simple little neighborhood.   I wonder
if they will all move to the Castro since Fred is now gone?
oh dear...
    oh dear...


Until next time folks, friends, and beautiful creatures all alike.
May the smallest of experiences throughout your day be your
brightest and may you treat all your good neighbors as Mr. Rogers did!!!!
Love and Blessings,
Danny Picard

P.S. if you never received any of the other vol's and would like them sent, 
email me.
blooshaman@hotmail.com
if you don't want to recieve any of these in the future, email me ...

"If it weren't for life I don't know what I'd be doing" -Bodhi

----- Original Message -----
From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, February 27, 2003 2:10 PM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Rounding Up the "Terrorists"





http://www.informationclearinghouse.info/article1684.htm
Santa Fe Police Arrest Attorney For Comments he Made In An Internet
Chat-Room


A St. John's College Library visit by a former public defender was abruptly
interrupted February 13 when city police officers arrested him about 9 p.m.
at the computer terminal he was using, handcuffed him, and brought him to
the Santa Fe, New Mexico, police station for questioning by Secret Service
agents from Albuquerque. Andrew J. O'Conner, 40, who was released about five
hours later, said in the February 16 Santa Fe New Mexican, "I'm going to sue
the Secret Service, Santa Fe Police, St. John's, and everybody involved in
this whole thing."


According to O'Connor, the agents accused him of making threatening remarks
about President George W. Bush in an Internet chat room. Admitting he talked
politics face-to-face in the library with a woman who was wearing a "No war
with Iraq" button, O'Connor recalled saying that Bush is "out of control,"
but that "I'm allowed to say all that. There is this thing called freedom of
speech." He also speculated that the FBI might have been observing him
because of his one-time involvement in a pro-Palestinian group in Boulder,
Colorado.


Earlier on the same day O'Connor was questioned, officials at St. John's-as
well as at the College of Santa Fe and Santa Fe Community College-issued
warnings to students and faculty that the FBI had been alerted to the
presence of "suspicious" people on campus within the past four weeks.


Concern about threats to individual privacy under the USA Patriot Act has
prompted New Mexico legislators in both houses to propose resolutions urging
state police not to help federal agents infringe on civil rights. The
resolutions also encourage libraries to post prominent signage warning
patrons that their library records are subject to federal scrutiny without
their permission or knowledge.


Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"Knowledge is the reward of action... For it is by doing things that one
becomes transformed."
-Heinrich Zimmer

"Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable.  But
there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops."
-H. L. Mencken

Subject: [sfraves] Jolly Green Jungle - Saturday Night (03-01-03)

Jolly Green Jungle - Featuring the tallest Drum and Bass DJ's in the bay
area.

Saturday March 1st, 2003

10 pm - 4am   $7 at the door

Only 10 minutes from the Bay Bridge in Oakland  

Info line: (415) 364-3095

 

And who's going to be playing you ask???

 

Controlled Substance 6'3" (Subtitles/Breakbeatscience/Thermal) - With
releases on TeeBee's Subtitles label, New York's Breakbeatscience and
Oakland's Thermal Controlled Substance has already established himself
as a top notch producer.  Now check out his talent on the decks as he
hauls the laptop and final scratch with him to bring you the most
upfront DNB around.

 

Freya 6'3" (Hemisphere) - She is responsible for the sexiest night of
dnb in San Francisco - Hemisphere.  Stick around till the end as she
closes out the night with some deep groovy beats to keep you dancing.

 

Genome 6'5" (Groundscore) - Resident DJ at San Francisco's famous weekly
event Eklektic.  Genome always comes armed with the hottest tunes
available.  Last time he played at this venue he tore the place apart.
Don't miss out.

 

Fife 6'6" (InnerspaceResearchGroup) - I'm not going to write stuff about
myself.  I'm tall and I play spacey sci-fi-esque drum and bass.  

 

Highside 6'7" (Hemisphere) - The nights tallest DJ.  Also a resident at
Hemisphere.  Highside is going to start off the night with a variety of
styles for everyone to enjoy.  Come early and check this guy out cause
he rocks.

 

So there you have it.  We could be the starting five for the bay area
DNB basketball team.  Unfortunately, I think most of us suck at
basketball.

 

And yes, we are all dorks.  Except Genome.he is cool.

 

And no, we are not 15 year old candy ravers.

 

Anyway, call on the day of the event for directions.  Hope to see you
all there.  Peace.

 

-Fife      


--Boundary_(ID_7GpB6Bjf/eOO+7OG16hJjg)--

>  
> 
> Genome 6'5" (Groundscore) - Resident DJ at San Francisco's famous weekly
> event Eklektic.  Genome always comes armed with the hottest tunes
> available.  Last time he played at this venue he tore the place apart.
> Don't miss out.
> 
>  
> 
> Fife 6'6" (InnerspaceResearchGroup) - I'm not going to write stuff about
> myself.  I'm tall and I play spacey sci-fi-esque drum and bass.  
> 
>  
> 
> Highside 6'7" (Hemisphere) - The nights tallest DJ.  Also a resident at
> Hemisphere.  Highside is going to start off the night with a variety of
> styles for everyone to enjoy.  Come early and check this guy out cause
> he rocks.
> 
>  
> 
> So there you have it.  We could be the starting five for the bay area
> DNB basketball team.  Unfortunately, I think most of us suck at
> basketball.
> 
>  
> 
> And yes, we are all dorks.  Except Genome.he is cool.
> 
>  
> 
> And no, we are not 15 year old candy ravers.
> 
>  
> 
> Anyway, call on the day of the event for directions.  Hope to see you
> all there.  Peace.
> 
>  
> 
> -Fife

-TOO FUNNY-

AUGUSTA, Ga. (AP) -- The controversy over Augusta National Golf Club's
all-male membership has attracted the attention of the Ku Klux Klan. 

A Klan group has asked for an application for a permit to demonstrate in
support of the club that hosts the Masters each April. 

The club has been under pressure from Martha Burk, chairwoman of the
National Council of Women's Organizations, to admit a female. Burk has said
she will seek a permit to demonstrate at the Masters against Augusta
National's membership practices. 

The Rev. Jesse Jackson's Rainbow/PUSH Coalition has requested an application
for a permit to demonstrate in support of Burk at the Masters in April.

Subject: [sfraves] [SRR] Eric P. is back...sort of

Hello sfravers!

It's been over a year since I've been to any events,
and even longer since dropping off the list, so I
thought I'd re-sub to see what's happening with the
scene these days, and with all the beautiful people
(remember, we are ALL beautiful people!) *S* I miss
the Bay Area underground scene like nobody's business,
and all the friends I've known while celebrating life
through dance!

If anyone around here remembers me, please give me a
shout! I spent most of last year in England, but
didn't get a chance to check out the scene there. I'm
very curious to know what the Bay Area rave scene is
like these days, especially the UG scene (which I
remember as being hella sweet!). So I'd appreciate if
people could give me the low-down on the throw-down ;)

Hope everyone's doing fantastically well, despite the
very shaky start this year as gotten off to...looking
forward to hearing from old friends, and maybe making
new ones, too!

Love, peace, and music,
Eric

http://www.geocities.com/thustar

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A new tune

On Fri, 28 Feb 2003 12:58:20 -0800, Jason <djjasonphilips@hotmail.com> wrote:

> I was working with one of my tunes last night and decided I needed some
> opinions to kind of see if people are feeling the mood and emotion I put
> into this tune. Go to this link
> <http://www.acidplanet.com/artist.asp?pid=247748&t=3657>  and give the
> track a listen and tell me what you think. And to dispel anything before
> it comes up the track was not created using Acid Pro I use Acidplanet to
> host mixes and such. Peace

Yeah right-I can totally tell you used Acid Pro to make it :p

Hmmm-I like the soft noises and lines and such-especially the one thats there from the beginning-
The drums while simplistic seem to fit the overall mood-
I don't really like the high stabs that come in at 0:49 at all.
It sounds too stark in contrast to the smoothness of everything else.
Maybe a fatter, warmer pad-think Vangelis.
And the notes used seem weird in that section as well.
And then-from there to the end seems to drag with not alot happening/changing.
The secondary bassline could be dropped out favoring the first at times etc etc-

JMO-I'm no expert :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] crash course in reality nrr

Geri Dahl wrote:
> i have no idea whatsoever if this will help...all i know is that i want the whining to stop in the world..if there were less whining, there'd be room for more beauty...also, just in case you haven't heard it from anyone else lately, of course, the answer is no 99.9 percent of the time...just check "no" in that little mental box, and your on your way...no, you are not the exception to the rule, for example...no, your version is not true...no, it is not okay...no, no, no, no. :) 


Girl, you bettah check yoself before you wreck yoself. Your message
embodies whining and negativity completely. "No" your message did not help. 
:-). If you want the whining to stop, then stop whining about things.

Also, if the answer is "no" 99.9% of the time, the typical human reaction
will be to increase the sample size over which you draw your percentages.
This further involutes the negativity until life appears to be little more
than a snake eating its own tail, ad infinitum, for all foreseeable futures.

If people would say "yes" more often, then there'd truly be more beauty
and truth. And maybe people would pester you less. Besides, who made you
the arbiter of what is or isn't beautiful? Beauty is an emergent property,
not an emergency.

:-)
